Preface 
_______ 
    This volume, as originally published, constituted the first revision and codification of the general ordinances of the City of Grandview, Missouri. It contained such of the ordinances of a general and permanent nature passed on or before February 15, 1968, as were found desirable for retention, except those expressly saved from repeal by the Adopting Ordinance. 
    The Code, as now supplemented, contains ordinances as indicated on the page of instructions for handling supplemental pages. 
    The ordinances were codified, edited and indexed by the Editorial Staff of Michie City Publications Company under the supervision of Chas. W. Sublett, Stephen C. Willard and John K. Haley. 
    The publishers wish to express their appreciation for the cooperation of all the city officials and employees during the preparation of this publication. Particular acknowledgment is due Mr. James C. Morris, Special Counsel, for his assistance during the progress of the work. The publishers also are grateful to Mrs. Ruth D. Kirkwood, City Clerk, for her assistance. 
    A feature to which the attention of the user is directed is the arrangement of the chapters in alphabetical order. Attention is also directed to the analysis preceding each chapter which, in many instances, will serve as an index within itself. The general index, carried at the end of the Code, has been carefully prepared and should serve as an accurate medium for locating the individual sections of law within the Code. In the footnotes appearing throughout the Code will be found references to the applicable and related provisions of the state law. These notes also contain cross references to other and related provisions in the City Code. By reference to the historical citations, appearing at the end of each section, the user will be able to ascertain the ordinance from which the present section has been derived. 
    It is a recognized fact that if any Code is to accomplish its intended purpose it must be kept up to date by means of an adequate supplemental service. Accordingly, the publishers point out the advisability and necessity of keeping this Code current. 
    The new City Code is presented to the officials and citizens of the City of Grandview, Missouri, in the belief that it will merit their approval. 
MICHIE CITY PUBLICATIONS COMPANY 
CHARLOTTESVILLE, VIRGINIA 
Adoption of Code

BILL NO. 1707 
ORDINANCE NO. 1584 
    An ordinance adopting a revision and codification of the ordinances of the City of Grandview, Missouri, entitled "The Code of the City of Grandview, Missouri," providing for the repeal of certain ordinances not included therein, with certain exceptions, and for other purposes hereinafter set out. 
    Be it ordained by the Board of Aldermen of the City of Grandview, Missouri, as follows: 
    Section 1. There is hereby adopted by the Board of Aldermen that certain Code entitled "The Code of the City of Grandview, Missouri," containing certain ordinances of a general and permanent nature as compiled, consolidated, codified and indexed in Chapters 1 to 30, both inclusive, of which Code not less than three copies have been and are now filed in the office of the City Clerk. 
    Section 2. The provisions of such Code shall be in force on and after January 13, 1970, and all ordinances of a general and permanent nature adopted on final reading and passage on or before February 15, 1968, and not contained in such Code are hereby repealed from and after January 13, 1970, except as hereinafter provided. 
    Section 3. The repeal provided for in the preceding section of this ordinance shall not affect any offense or act committed or done or any penalty or forfeiture incurred or any contract or right established or accruing before February 15, 1968; nor shall it affect any prosecution, suit or proceeding pending or any judgment rendered prior to February 15, 1968; nor shall such repeal affect any ordinance or resolution promising or guaranteeing the payment of money for the City or authorizing the issue of any bonds of the City or any evidence of the City's indebtedness or any contract or obligation assumed by the City; nor shall it affect the annual tax levy; nor shall it affect any right or franchise conferred by ordinance or resolution of the city on any person or corporation; nor shall it affect any ordinance adopted for purposes which have been consummated; nor shall it affect any ordinance which is temporary, although general in effect, or special, although permanent in effect; nor shall it affect any ordinance relating to the salaries of the City officers or employees; nor shall it affect any ordinance annexing territory to the City; nor shall it affect any ordinance naming, renaming, opening, accepting or vacating streets or alleys in the City; nor shall it affect any ordinance relating to zoning; nor shall it affect any ordinance adopted on final reading and passage after February 15, 1968; nor shall it affect any of the following ordinances or amendments thereto: 
    Ord. No. 147 (Naming, numbering certain streets) 
    Ord. No. 318 (Subdivision regulations) 
    Ord. No. 913 (Providing group life and hospitalization insurance) 
    Ord. No. 949 (Appointment of special counsel) 
    Ord. No. 1078 (Providing group life and hospitalization insurance) 
    Ord. No. 1220 (Providing group life and hospitalization insurance) 
    Ord. No. 1381 (Providing group life and hospitalization insurance) 
    Section 4. Whenever in the Code adopted by this ordinance or in any other ordinance or resolution of the City or in any rule, regulation or order promulgated by any officer or agency of the City under authority duly vested in him or if any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or an offense or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided therefor, the violation of any such provision of such Code or any other ordinance of the City or such rule, regulation or order shall be punished by a fine not exceeding one hundred dollars or imprisonment for a term not exceeding three months or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
    Except where otherwise provided, every day any violation of such Code or any other ordinance of the City or such rule, regulation or order shall continue shall constitute a separate offense. 
    Section 5. It is hereby declared to be the intention of the Board of Aldermen that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this ordinance and the Code hereby adopted are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this ordinance or the Code hereby adopted shall be declared unconstitutional or otherwise invalid by the valid judgment or decree of a court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality or invalidity shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Ordinance or the Code hereby adopted. 
    Passed this 12th day of January, 1970. 
    Approved this 12th day of January, 1970. 
/s/ ;hg;A. G. Holtan 
Mayor 
Attest: 
/s/ Ruth D. Kirkwood, City Clerk

ORDINANCE NO. I. 
    An Ordinance declaring the Incorporation of Grandview, Missouri, and defining the boundary lines of such incorporation. Be it ordained by the Board of Trustees of the Village of Grandview, Missouri, as follows: 
    Section 1. Declaring Incorporation. By virtue of an order of the County Court of the County of Jackson, State of Missouri, and under the provision Sec. 9430, Art. 6, Chap. 84, Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1909, dated February 6th, 1912, is hereby declared to be legally incorporated and shall be known as "The Village of Grandview." 
    Section 2. Defining Corporate Limits. By virtue of the order of the County Court of the County of Jackson and State of Missouri, dated February 6th, 1912, the Village of Grandview, Missouri, shall and does hereby cover all of that part of Jackson County within the following described limits, to-wit: 
    "Beginning at the Northwest Corner of Section Fourteen (14), Township Forty-seven (47), Range Thirty-three (33), thence South along the section line one and one-quarter (11/4) miles to the Southwest Corner of the Northwest Quarter of the Northwest Quarter (N.W.1/4 N.W.1/4) of Section Twenty-three (23), thence East One Quarter (1/4) miles to the Southeast Corner of the Northwest Quarter (1/4) of the Northwest Quarter (1/4) of Section Twenty-three (23); thence south One Eighth ( 1/8 ) mile; thence East One Quarter (1/4) mile; thence North Three Eighths ( 3/8 ) mile to the Northeast Corner of the Northwest Quarter (1/4) of Section Twenty-Three (23); thence East Three Hundred (300) feet; thence North One Quarter (1/4) mile; thence West Three Hundred (300) feet to the Northeast Corner of the Southeast Quarter of the Southwest Quarter (S.E.1/4 S.W.1/4) of Section Fourteen (14); thence North Three Quarters (3/4) mile to the Northeast Quarter of the Northeast Quarter of the Northwest Quarter (N.E.1/4 N.W.1/4) of Section Fourteen (14); thence West One Half (1/2) mile to the place of beginning." 
W. H. Leib, 
Clerk L. C. Hall, 
Chairman  
(Seal) 
Chapter 1 - GENERAL PROVISIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
State Law reference- Construction of statutes generally, see RSMo §§ 1.010-1.210. 

Sec. 1-1. - How Code designated and cited. 
    The ordinances embraced in this and the following chapters and sections shall constitute and be designated "The Code of the City of Grandview, Missouri," and may be so cited. 
Sec. 1-2. - Definitions and rules of construction. 
    In the construction of this Code and of all ordinances, the following definitions and rules of construction shall be observed, unless it shall be otherwise expressly provided in any section or ordinance, or unless inconsistent with the manifest intent of the board of aldermen, or unless the context clearly requires otherwise: 
    Board or Board of Aldermen. The words "board" or "board of aldermen" shall mean the board of aldermen of the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
    City. The words "the city" or "this city" shall mean the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
    City marshal and marshal. Where appearing in this Code and in ordinances of the city, the terms "city marshal" and "marshal" shall mean "chief of police" as provided by law and more particularly by section 79.050, RSMo, 1959, as amended in 1961. 
    Computation of time. The time within which an act is to be done shall be computed by excluding the first and including the last day; and if the last day be Sunday or a legal holiday, that shall be excluded, in which event the period runs until the end of the next day which is neither a Sunday nor a legal holiday. When the period of time is less than seven (7) days, intermediate Sundays and legal holidays shall be excluded in the computation. A half-holiday shall be considered as other days and not as a legal holiday. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.040. 
    County. The words "the county" or "this county" shall mean the County of Jackson, Missouri. 
    Gender. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the masculine, females as well as males, and associations and bodies corporate as well as individuals, shall be deemed to be included. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.030. 
    Joint authority. Words importing joint authority to three (3) or more persons shall be construed as authority to a majority of such persons. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.050. 
    Month. The word "month" shall mean a calendar month. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.020. 
    Number. When any subject matter, party or person is described or referred to by words importing the singular number, the plural and separate matters and persons and bodies corporate shall be deemed to be included. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.030. 
    Oath. The word "oath" shall be construed to include an affirmation in all cases in which, by law, an affirmation may be substituted for an oath, and in such cases the words "swear" and "sworn" shall be equivalent to the words "affirm" and "affirmed." 
    Owner. The word "owner," applied to a building or land, shall include any part owner, joint owner, tenant in common, joint tenant or tenant by the entirety, of the whole or a part of such building or land. 
    Person. The word "person" shall include a corporation, firm, partnership, association, organization and any other group acting as a unit as well as individuals. It shall also include an executor, administrator, trustee, receiver or other representative appointed according to law. Whenever the word "person" is used in any section of this Code prescribing a penalty or fine, as to partnerships or associations, the word shall include the partners or members thereof, and as to corporations, shall include the officers, agents or members thereof who are responsible for any violation of such section. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 556.050. 
    Preceding, following. The words "preceding" and "following," shall mean next before and next after, respectively. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.020. 
    Property. The word "property" shall include real property and tangible and intangible personal property. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.020. 
    Public way. The words "public way" shall include any street, alley, boulevard, parkway, highway, sidewalk or other public thoroughfare. 
    Real property. The terms "real property," "premises," "real estate" or "lands" shall be deemed to be coextensive with lands, tenements and hereditaments. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 1.020. 
    Sidewalk. The word "sidewalk" shall mean the portion of the street between the curb line and the adjacent property line, intended for the use of pedestrians. 
    Signature. Where the written signature of any person is required, the proper handwriting of such person or his mark shall be intended. 
    State. The words "the state" or "this state" shall mean the State of Missouri. 
    Street. The word "street" shall mean and include any public way, highway, street, avenue, boulevard, parkway, alley or other public thoroughfare, and each of such words shall include every other of them. 
    Tangible personal property. Tangible personal property shall include goods, chattels and all personal property except intangible personal property. 
    Tenant. The words "tenant" or "occupant," applied to a building or land, shall include any person who occupies the whole or a part of such building or land, whether alone or with others. 
    Writing. The words "writing" and "written" shall include printing, lithographing or other modes of representing words and letters. 
    Year. The word "year" shall mean a calendar year, unless otherwise expressed, and the word "year" shall be equivalent to the words "year of our Lord." 
(Ord. No. 1615, § 3) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, see RSMo § 1.020. 
Sec. 1-3. - Catchlines of sections. 
    The catchlines of the several sections of this Code printed in boldface type are intended as mere catchwords to indicate the contents of the section and shall not be deemed or taken to be titles of such sections, nor as any part of the section, nor, unless expressly so provided, shall they be so deemed when any of such sections, including the catchlines, are amended or reenacted. 
Sec. 1-4. - Provisions considered as continuations of existing ordinances. 
    The provisions appearing in this Code, so far as they are in substance the same as those of ordinances existing at the time of the effective date of this Code, shall be considered as continuation thereof and not as new enactments. 
Sec. 1-5. - Severability of parts of Code. 
    It is hereby declared to be the intention of the board of aldermen that the sections, paragraphs, sentences, clauses and phrases of this Code are severable, and if any phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section of this Code shall be declared unconstitutional by the valid judgment or decree of any court of competent jurisdiction, such unconstitutionality shall not affect any of the remaining phrases, clauses, sentences, paragraphs and sections of this Code, since the same would have been enacted by the board of aldermen without the incorporation in this Code of any such unconstitutional phrase, clause, sentence, paragraph or section. 
Sec. 1-6. - General penalty; continuing violations. 
    Whenever in this Code or in any other ordinance or resolution of the city, any act is prohibited or is made or declared to be unlawful or an offense, or the doing of any act is required or the failure to do any act is declared to be unlawful or a misdemeanor, where no specific penalty is provided for, the violation of any such provision of this Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the city shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment in the jail not exceeding three (3) months, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
    Every day any violation of this Code or any other ordinance or resolution of the city continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 1182, § 2; Ord. No. 2948, § 1, 10-13-81) 
Cross reference- Delinquency penalties for failure to pay tax, § 10-16; penalty conviction for driving under the influence of intoxicating liquor, § 14-36. As to municipal court generally, see Ch. 21. 
State Law reference- Maximum penalties the city may impose, RSMo § 79.470. 
Sec. 1-7. - Prisoners may be compelled to work off fines and costs. 
    Any person committed to jail for nonpayment of a fine or court costs or either, may be compelled to work to reduce the fine or cost at the rate of ten dollars ($10.00) per each day worked. 
(Ord. No. 1182, § 3; Ord. No. 3652, § 3, 9-8-87) 
Sec. 1-8. - Board of aldermen to arrange for imprisonment of prisoners. 
    The board of aldermen shall, at the expense of the city, make arrangements for the proper imprisonment of all prisoners. 
(R.O. 1929, Ch. 10, Art. 1, § 138) 
Sec. 1-9. - Commitment of prisoners to county common jail. 
    A defendant may be committed to the common jail of the county or such other facility of incarceration that is available to the city for the housing of prisoners by the municipal judge of the city by a warrant of commitment. Such city shall pay the board of such prisoner at the same rate as may be allowed by law to the sheriff or other custodian for the keeping of such prisoners in their custody. 
(R.O. 1929, Ch. 10, Art. 1, § 139; Ord. No. 3652, § 1, 9-8-87) 
Sec. 1-10. - Administrative search warrants. 
    The issuance of administrative search warrants relating to violations of Chapters 2A, 3, 4, 6, 9, 11, 12, 13, 13.1, 13A, 16, 19, 23, 25 and 31 of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview and relating to enforcement of those Chapters shall conform to and be governed by the following provisions: 
(a)  An administrative search warrant is a written order of the Municipal Court of the City of Grandview commanding the search of property to determine the existence of violations of Chapters 2A, 3, 4, 6, 9, 11, 12, 13, 13.1, 13A, 16, 19, 23, 25 and 31 of this Code and to permit abatement of nuisances and enforcement of violations of said code provisions. 
(b)  Any public official, code enforcement officer, special counsel, or the prosecuting attorney may make an application for the issuance of an administrative search warrant. The application may be made on a form prepared by the community development department and shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  State the time and date of the making of the application; 
(3)  Identify the property which is to be searched in sufficient detail and particularity that the code enforcement officer executing the warrant can readily ascertain it; 
(4)  Identify the city code violation in sufficient detail and particularity that the code enforcement officer executing the warrant can readily ascertain it; 
(5)  State facts sufficient to show reasonable suspicion for the issuance of the administrative search warrant; 
(6)  Be verified by the signed oath or affirmation of the applicant; 
(7)  Be filed in the municipal court. 
(c)  The application may be supplemented in writing as necessary to assist the municipal judge in determining whether there is reasonable suspicion for the issuance of an administrative search warrant and to fill out any deficiencies in the description of the property to be searched or in the code violation(s) on the property. Oral testimony shall not be considered. 
(d)  The municipal judge or acting municipal judge shall review the application and any written supplementation to determine whether sufficient facts have been stated to justify the issuance of an administrative search warrant. If it appears that there is reasonable suspicion to believe that a violation of Code Chapters 2A, 3, 4, 6, 9, 11, 12, 13, 13.1, 13A, 16, 19, 23, 25 and 31 exists on the property described, an original and two (2) copies of the administrative search warrant shall be issued. 
(e)  The application and any written supplementation and a copy of the warrant shall be retained in the records of the municipal court. 
(f)  The administrative search warrant shall: 
(1)  Be in writing; 
(2)  Be directed to a code enforcement officer of the City of Grandview; 
(3)  State the time and date the warrant is issued; 
(4)  Identify the property which is to be searched in sufficient detail and particularity such that the code enforcement officer executing the warrant can readily ascertain it; 
(5)  Identify the code violation in sufficient detail and particularity such that the code enforcement officer executing the warrant can readily ascertain it; 
(6)  Be signed by the municipal judge or acting municipal judge; 
(7)  Be executed by a code enforcement officer of the City of Grandview by conducting the search commanded and/or abating the nuisance or code violation; 
(8)  Be executed between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. except in the case of an emergency threatening immediate damage or harm to life or property. 
(9)  Be executed as soon as practicable and shall expire if it is not executed and returned within ten (10) days after the date of the making of the application; and 
(10)  After execution of the administrative search warrant, the warrant with a return thereon, signed by the code enforcement officer executing the warrant, shall be filed in municipal court. The return shall show the date and manner of execution, the name of the possessor and the name of the owner of the property, when they are not the same person, if known. 
(g)  An administrative search warrant shall be deemed invalid: 
(1)  If it was not issued and signed by the municipal judge or acting municipal judge, or 
(2)  If it was issued without a written application in compliance with this Code section having been filed and verified; or 
(3)  If it was issued without reasonable suspicion; or 
(4)  If it does not describe the property to be searched and/or the nuisance or code violation with sufficient certainty; or 
(5)  If it is not executed and returned within the time prescribed. 
(Ord. No. 5224, § 2, 10-26-99) 
Cross reference- Issuance and execution of warrants, § 21-13. 
Sec. 1-11. - Boundaries of city. 
    Following is a single metes and bounds description of the limits of the city. 
    Limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri as of January 1, 1995: 
    All or parts of Sections 10-15, inclusive, Sections 22 to 27 inclusive, and Sections 35 and 36, Township 47, Range 33 and all or parts of Sections 7,18, 19, 30 and 31, Township 47, Range 32 in Jackson County, Missouri, all more particularly described as follows: 
    Beginning at a point on the east-west center line of said Section 27, Township 47, Range 33, which is one hundred eighty (180) feet east of the west line thereof; thence north along a line one hundred eighty (180) feet east of and parallel with the west line of said Sections 27, 22, 15 and 10, Township 47, Range 33 to a point one hundred eighty (180) feet south of the east-west center line of said Section 10; thence east along a line one hundred eighty (180) feet south of and parallel with the east-west center line of said Section 10 to a point one hundred eighty (180) feet west of the east line thereof; thence north along a line one hundred eighty (180) feet west of and parallel with the east line of said Section 10 to a point one hundred eighty (180) feet north of the east-west center line thereof; thence east along a line one hundred eighty (180) feet north of and parallel with the east-west center line of said Sections 10, 11 and 12, Township 47, Range 33, to a point one hundred eighty (180) feet east of the west line of said Section 12; thence south along a line one hundred eighty (180) feet east of and parallel with the west line of said Section 12 to a point on the east-west center line thereof; thence east along the east-west center line of said Section 12 to the east line thereof and a point on the line between said Ranges 33 and 32; thence south along said range line 42.90 feet, more or less to a point on the east-west center line of said Section 7, Township 47, Range 32; thence east along the east-west center line of said Section 7 to the east line thereof; thence south along the east line of said Sections 7, 18, 19, 30, and 31. Township 47, Range 32, to the southeast corner of Section 31 and a point on the line between said Jackson County and Cass County, Missouri; thence west along said county line being also the south line of said Section 31, Township 47, Range 32 and along the south line of said Section 36, Township 47, Range 33 to the center of U.S. Highway No. 71, as now established, being the center of the medial strip between the east edge of the pavement for south bound traffic and the west edge of the pavement for north bound traffic, as said pavements existed on January 1, 1958; thence north along said center line, to the north line of said Section 35, Township 47, Range 33, thence northerly and northeasterly along the last described center line to the center of the pavement carrying both north bound and south bound traffic, as said pavement existed on January 1, 1958; thence north along the last described center line, to a point on the east-west center line of said Section 26, Township 47, Range 33; thence west along the east-west center line of said Section 26 and 27, Township 47, Range 33, to the point of beginning. 
(Ord. No. 55, Chapter 1, Article 1, 5-6-29; Ord. No. 4703, § § 1, 2, 2-14-95) 
Sec. 1-12. - City to be body corporate; name and general powers of city; continued existence of city. 
    The citizens of the city, a city of the fourth class, are hereby constituted a body corporate by the name of "City of Grandview" and by this name shall have perpetual succession, may sue and be sued, implead and be impleaded, defend and be defended in all courts of law and equity and in all actions whatever; may receive and hold property, both real and personal, within such city, and may purchase, receive and hold real estate within or without such city for the burial of the dead; and may purchase, hold, lease, sell or otherwise dispose of any property, real or personal, it now owns or may hereafter acquire; may receive bequests, gifts and donations of all kinds of property, and may have and hold one (1) common seal, and may break, change or alter the same at pleasure, and all courts of this state shall take judicial notice thereof. 
(Order, Jackson County Court, January 23, 1912; Order, Jackson County Court, February 6, 1912; Ord. No. 1; Ord. No. 50, Ord. No. 55, chapter 1, Article 2, Minutes, 1929 Meetings Board of Aldermen) 
Sec. 1-13. - Jurisdiction of city generally. 
    The city shall have and retain jurisdiction of all matters, affecting and appertaining to the city within the boundaries set forth in section 1-11, and the boundaries may be changed from time to time in the manner and form as is provided by law. 
(Ord. No. 55, § 2) 
Chapter 2 - ADMINISTRATION 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2-1. - Style of ordinances; procedure for enacting. 
    The style of the ordinances of the city shall be: "Be it ordained by the board of aldermen of the City of Grandview as follows:" No ordinance shall be passed except by bill, and no bill shall become an ordinance unless on its final passage a majority of the members elected to the board of aldermen shall vote for it, and the ayes and nays be entered on the journal. Every proposed ordinance shall be introduced to the board of aldermen in writing and shall be read by title or in full two (2) times prior to passage, both readings may occur at a single meeting of the board of aldermen. If the proposed ordinance is read by title only, copies of the proposed ordinance shall be made available for public inspection prior to the time the bill is under consideration by the board of aldermen. No bill shall become an ordinance until it shall have been signed by the mayor or person exercising the duties of the mayor's office, or shall have been passed over the mayor's veto as herein provided. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 15, art. 1, § 160; Ord. No. 3775, §§ 1, 2, 8-23-88) 
Sec. 2-2. - Fiscal year. 
    The fiscal year for the city is hereby declared to begin on October 1 and shall end on September 30 of each ensuing year, effective October 1, 1978. 
(Ord. No. 2534, § 3, 4-25-78) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2534, § 3, adopted April 25, 1978, did not expressly amend the Code; hence inclusion herein as § 2-2 is at the discretion of the editor. Former § 2-2 was repealed by Ord. No. 1776, § 4. 
Sec. 2-2.1. - Planning commission and board of adjustment fees. 
    Certain fees are hereby established for filing of applications to the planning commission and the board of adjustment. 
(a)  Planning commission. 
(1)  Applications for preliminary plats, ten dollars ($10.00) per acre or one hundred dollars ($100.00) whichever is more. 
(2)  Application for final plat, five dollars ($5.00) per acre or fifty dollars ($50.00) whichever is more. 
(3)  Application to rezone, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(b)  Board of adjustment. 
(1)  For all applications except those as stated in below, one hundred fifty dollars ($150.00). 
(2)  For all applications requiring review by the planning commission, seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(c)  Transcripts. Transcripts necessary to appeal from the board of adjustment to the circuit court shall be furnished by the appellant. These may be obtained upon payment of the current charge, from the reporting service employed by the board of adjustment to take testimony given at the public hearing. The board may waive the transcript costs where it is determined that the appellant is unable to pay for same. 
(Ord. No. 1645, § 1; Ord. No. 3179, § 1, 9-15-83; Ord. No. 5187, § 2, 7-13-99) 
Sec. 2-2.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5105, § 1, adopted Aug. 11, 1998, repealed Ord. No. 1521 from which former section 2-2.2 derived. Former section 2-2.2 pertained to the adoption of the 1968 issue of "General Provisions and Covenants" as prepared and published by the Kansas City Metropolitan Chapter of the American Public Works Association. 
Sec. 2-2.3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5809, § 1, adopted Aug. 24, 2004, repealed § 2-2.3, which pertained to certain meetings, records and votes closed to the public as well as reproduction fees and derived from Ord. No. 3360, §§ 1-5, adopted Sept. 22, 1987; and Ord. No. 5114, §§ 1-7, adopted Sept. 8, 1998. 
Sec. 2-2.4. - Disclosure of potential conflicts of interest and substantial interests for certain municipal officers. 
(1)  Declaration of policy. The proper operation of municipal government requires that public officials and employees be independent, impartial and responsible to the people; that government decisions and policy be made in the proper channels of the governmental structure; that public office not be used for personal gain; and that the public have confidence in the integrity of its government. In recognition of these goals, there is hereby established a procedure for disclosure by certain officials and employees of private financial or other interests in matters affecting the city. 
(2)  Conflicts of interest. The mayor or any member of the board of aldermen who has a substantial personal or private interest, as defined by state law, in any bill shall disclose on the records of the board of aldermen the nature of his interest and shall disqualify himself from voting on any matters relating to this interest. 
(3)  Disclosure reports. Each elected official, the city administrator, the finance director, and the purchasing manager shall disclose the following information by May 1 if any such transactions were engaged in during the previous calendar year. Candidates for elective office shall disclose such information if any such transactions were engaged in during the previous calendar year by the date defined in section 105.487(1) RSMo. 
(a)  For such person, and all persons within the first degree of consanguinity or affinity of such person, the date and the identities of the parties to each transaction with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that such person had with the political subdivision, other than compensation received as an employee or payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the political subdivision, and other than transfers for no consideration to the political subdivision; and 
(b)  The date and the identities of the parties to each transaction known to the person with a total value in excess of five hundred dollars ($500.00), if any, that any business entity in which such person had a substantial interest, had with the political subdivision, other than payment of any tax, fee or penalty due to the political subdivision or transactions involving payment for providing utility service to the political subdivision, and other than transfers for no consideration to the political subdivision. 
(c)  The city administrator, finance director, and purchasing manager also shall disclose by May 1 for the previous calendar year the following information: 
1.  The name and address of each of the employers of such person from whom income of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) or more was received during the year covered by the statement; 
2.  The name and address of each sole proprietorship that he owned; the name, address and the general nature of the business conducted of each general partnership and joint venture in which he was a partner or participant; the name and address of each partner or co-participant for each partnership or joint venture unless such names and addresses are filed by the partnership or joint venture with the secretary of state; the name, address and general nature of the business conducted of any closely held corporation or limited partnership in which the person owned ten percent or more of any class of the outstanding stock or limited partnership units; and the name of any publicly traded corporation or limited partnership that is listed on a regulated stock exchange or automated quotation system in which the person owned two percent or more of any class of outstanding stock, limited partnership units or other equity interests; 
3.  The name and address of each corporation for which such person served in the capacity of a director, officer or receiver. 
(4)  Filing of reports. The reports, on a form prescribed by the Missouri Ethics Commission, shall be filed with the city clerk and with the Missouri Ethics Commission. The reports shall be available for public inspection and copying during normal business hours in the office of the city clerk. 
(5)  When filed. The financial interest statements shall be filed at the following times, but no person is required to file more than one financial interest statement in any calendar year: 
(a)  Each person appointed to office shall file the statement within thirty (30) days of such appointment or employment; 
(b)  Every other person required to file a financial interest statement shall file the statement annually not later than May 1 and the statement shall cover the calendar year ending the immediately preceding December 31; provided that any member of the board of aldermen may supplement the financial interest statement to report additional interests acquired after December 31 of the covered year until the date of filing of the financial interest statement. 
(6)  Filing of ordinance. The city clerk shall send a certified copy of this ordinance to the Missouri Ethics Commission within ten (10) days of its adoption. 
(Ord. No. 4218, §§ 1-5, 9-10-91; Ord. No. 4504, § 1, 8-24-93; Ord. No. 4640, § 2, 8-23-94; Ord. No. 4776, § 2, 8-22-95; Ord. No. 5009, §§ 1, 2, 8-26-97; Ord. No. 5198, § 2, 8-10-99; Ord. No. 5667, § 1, 8-26-03; Ord. No. 5808, § 2, 8-24-04; Ord. No. 6034, § 1, 8-22-06) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4218, §§ 1-5, adopted Sept. 10, 1991, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as § 2-2.4 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Ord. No. 5415, § 1, adopted Aug. 28, 2001, readopted amended Ord. No. 4218. Ord. No. 4218, attached hereto as Exhibit "A", as amended by Ord. No. 5198, attached hereto as Exhibit "B", is hereby readopted as amended, a copy of which shall be filed with the Missouri Ethics Commission within ten (10) days of its adoption. Said Exhibit "A" and Exhibit "B" are not codified herein, but are on file and available for inspection at the office of the city clerk. 
ARTICLE II. - OFFICERS AND DEPARTMENTS GENERALLY[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Elections, Ch. 8. 

Sec. 2-3. - Appointment of certain officers. 
    The mayor, with the consent and approval of the majority of the members of the board of aldermen, shall have power to appoint a city treasurer, city attorney, city collector, and such other officers as he may be authorized by ordinance to appoint, and if deemed for the best interests of the city, the mayor and board of aldermen may, by ordinance, employ special counsel to represent the city, either in a case of a vacancy in the office of city attorney or to assist the city attorney, and pay reasonable compensation therefor. 
(Ord. No. 5370, § 1, 4-10-01) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 79.230. 
Sec. 2-4. - Qualifications to hold elective and appointive office generally. 
    All officers elected to or appointed to fill a vacancy in any elective office under the city government shall be voters under the laws and constitution of this state and the ordinances of the city and shall be residents of the city. Any person who files as a candidate for or seeks appointment to any elective municipal office shall be disqualified from participation in the election or appointment to the elective office if such person is delinquent in the payment of any state income taxes, personal property taxes, municipal taxes, or real estate property taxes on the place of residence, as stated in the declaration of candidacy. Persons appointed to non-elective offices of the city need not be city voters or residents unless another section or subsection of the Code of Laws provides otherwise, in which case such other section or subsection shall control. 
(Ord. No. 1776, § 2; Ord. No. 5227, § 1, 10-26-99; Ord. No. 6506, § 1, 11-8-11; Ord. No. 6758, § 1, 12-23-14) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 6758, adopted Dec. 23, 2014, changed the title of § 2-4 from "Qualifications of elected or appointed officers generally" to read as herein set out. 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 79.250. 
Sec. 2-5. - Elected officers to qualify. 
    Within fifteen (15) days after the results of any city election for city officers has been declared, such duly elected officers shall meet and qualify as provided for in this article. All officers, other than the mayor and aldermen, shall duly qualify unless further time be given by an order of record by such newly organized board of aldermen. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 4, § 18) 
Sec. 2-6. - Oath of office. 
    Every officer of the city and his assistants, including the mayor and members of the board of aldermen, before entering upon the discharge of the duties of their office shall take and subscribe to an oath before the city clerk, or some other officer, authorized by law to administer oaths and file the same with the city clerk. The oath shall be in substance as follows: That he possesses all the qualifications prescribed for the office to which he was elected or appointed, that he will support the constitution of the United States and the State of Missouri, and the provision of all the laws of this state affecting cities of the fourth class, this Code and other ordinances of this city and faithfully discharge all the duties pertaining to his office and faithfully demean himself in the office to which he has been elected or appointed. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 5, § 25) 
State Law reference- Oaths of office, RSMo § 79.260. 
Sec. 2-7. - Official bonds. 
(a)  The following named city officials shall each, before entering upon the duties of their respective offices, give a good and sufficient surety company bond to the city, duly approved by the city attorney, and conditioned upon the faithful performance and discharge of their respective duties, and for proper application and payment of all money or property coming into their hands by virtue of their offices in the following amounts: 
(1)  City treasurer ..... $25,000.00 
(2)  City tax collector ..... 25,000.00 
(b)  Nothing in this section shall preclude or prevent the city administration from requiring any officer of employee of the city to qualify and be bonded under a blanket surety and fidelity bond purchased by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1123, § 2) 
State Law reference- Bonds, RSMo § 79.260. 
Sec. 2-8. - Failure to qualify. 
    If any person elected or appointed to any city office, shall fail to take and subscribe and file the oath as required by this article or execute or file the bond required within the time and manner required, his office shall be deemed vacant. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 4, § 22) 
State Law reference- Similar laws, RSMo § 79.260. 
Sec. 2-9. - Suit for breach of bond. 
    For the breach of the condition of any bonds required in this article, a suit may be instituted in a court of competent jurisdiction by the city or by any persons injured by reason of such breach in the name of the city to the use of such person injured. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 5, § 27) 
State Law reference- Similar laws, RSMo § 79.260. 
Sec. 2-10. - Removal of officers-Procedure. 
    The mayor, with the consent of the majority of all members elected to the board of aldermen, can remove from office for good cause shown any elective or appointed officer of the city, such officer sought to be removed, being first given the opportunity, with witnesses, to be heard and to appear by counsel before the board of aldermen, sitting as a board of impeachment; such opportunity shall be evidenced by written notice of impeachment, personally served on the officer sought to be removed at least ten days before the date set for hearing, as may be directed by the board of aldermen. Such notice shall contain the date of the beginning of such hearing and shall state the cause or reason or charge upon which the impeachment is based. Any officer, including the mayor in like manner, can be removed from office by two-thirds vote of all members elected to the board of aldermen independent of the mayor's approval or recommendation. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 7, § 28) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo § 79.240. 
Sec. 2-11. - Same-Grounds. 
    The grounds for impeachment shall be misconduct in office, conviction of a felony or immoral or indecent conduct or for any other conduct which is unbecoming to a gentleman. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 7, § 29) 
Sec. 2-12. - Vacancies in certain offices; how filled. 
    If a vacancy occurs in any elective office, the mayor or the person exercising the duties of the mayor shall cause a special meeting of the board of aldermen to convene where a successor to the vacant office shall be selected. The successor shall serve until the next regular election. If a vacancy occurs in any office not elective which is appointed by the city administrator pursuant to authority granted by RSMo sections 77.042 and 77.046 and the Code of the City of Grandview, the city administrator shall appoint a replacement to fill such vacancy pursuant to the provisions of Article IV, section 2-23 of this chapter. If a vacancy occurs in any office not elective which is appointed by the board of aldermen, the mayor shall appoint a suitable person to discharge the duties of such office until the first regular meeting of the board of aldermen thereafter, at which time such vacancy shall be permanently filled. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 4, § 21; Ord. No. 3865, §§ 1, 2, 2-28-89) 
Sec. 2-13. - Duties of officers generally. 
    Each officer shall perform all duties required of his office by state law, this Code and other ordinances of the city and such other duties not in conflict therewith as may be required by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 5) 
Sec. 2-14. - Duties of department heads generally. 
    The duties and powers of the heads of departments shall be as follows: 
(a)  Responsibility to city administrator. Be immediately responsible to the city administrator for the effective administration of their respective departments and all activities assigned thereto. 
(b)  Inaugurate sound practices. Keep informed as to the latest practices in the particular field and shall inaugurate, with the approval of the city administrator, such new practices as appear to be of benefit to the service and to the public. 
(c)  Report to city administrator. Submit monthly and annual reports of the activities of his department to the city administrator. 
(d)  Maintain records. Establish and maintain a system of filing and indexing records and reports in sufficient detail to furnish all information necessary for proper control of departmental activities and to form a basis for the periodic reports to the city administrator. 
(e)  Authority over employees. Have power, when authorized by the city administrator, to appoint and remove, subject to personnel system regulations for personnel, all subordinates under him. 
(f)  Maintain equipment. Be responsible for the proper maintenance of all city property and equipment used in his department. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 5) 
Sec. 2-15. - Cooperation between departments. 
    Each department of the city shall furnish, upon the direction of the city administrator, any other department such service, labor and materials as may be requisitioned by the head of such department, and as its own facilities permit, through the same procedure and subject to the same audit and control as other expenditures are incurred. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 5) 
Sec. 2-16. - Daily deposits with city collector. 
    All units in the administrative service shall make a daily deposit with the city collector of any money received directly from the public. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 5) 
Sec. 2-16.1. - Authority of deputy city collector to sign certain documents or checks in absence of city collector. 
    The person appointed as deputy city collector is hereby authorized to sign any documents or checks required for the transfer of funds from the city collector's account to the city treasurer in the absence of the city collector. 
(Ord. No. 1712, § 1) 
Sec. 2-17. - Paying out city money generally. 
    All units in the administrative service shall pay out money belonging to the city only in the manner prescribed by this Code or other ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 5) 
ARTICLE III. - BOARD OF ALDERMEN 

Sec. 2-18. - Membership; meetings generally; election of president; quorum. 
    The board of aldermen shall consist of six (6) members, two (2) from each ward, elected as provided by law, and possessing all the qualifications as provided for herein. The board of aldermen shall meet regularly at the mayor's office or such place that shall be designated by the board of aldermen in regular session on the second and fourth Tuesdays in each month, at the hour of 7:00 p.m., unless the hours be changed by ordinance, but special meetings may be called by the mayor or by any two (2) members of the board of aldermen, but such call shall designate the time and place of such special meeting. At the time of the organization, the members of the board of aldermen shall elect one of their members as president of the board of aldermen, who shall preside over the board of aldermen meetings and perform all the duties of the mayor in the absence of the mayor. The majority of the board of aldermen elected shall constitute a quorum to do business, but a less number may adjourn from time to time; provided, that the board of aldermen may adjourn to any given date for such extra adjourned meeting. Neither the mayor nor members of the board of aldermen shall receive any additional compensation for adjourned or special meetings. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 3, art. 2, § 35; Ord. No. 785; Ord. No. 1898, § 1; Ord. No. 2289, § 1, 12-8-75; Ord. No. 6158, § 1, 12-11-07) 
State Law reference- As to acting president of board of aldermen, RSMo §§ 79.090, 79.100. 
Sec. 2-19. - Rescheduling of regular sessions of the board of aldermen. 
    The board of aldermen may reschedule a regular session in instances in which it is known in advance that a quorum will not be present, in which there is an apparent conflict with another meeting or event of significance to the community, or in which there is an emergency. The regular session shall be rescheduled to 7:30 p.m. on a day within seven (7) calendar days prior to or following the original date of the regular session. Rescheduling of a regular session shall require a motion by a board member approved by a majority vote, and be subject to the requirements as set forth in RSMo Supp. 1993, Conduct of Public Business, Chapter 610, Governmental Bodies and Records. In cases of emergency, the mayor may reschedule a regular session after polling the members of the board and providing reasonable notice of such rescheduling. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 3, art. 2, § 38; Ord. No. 4683, §§ 1, 2, 12-13-94) 
Sec. 2-20. - Powers and duties generally. 
    At all meetings of the board of aldermen the following officers are expected to be present: The mayor and six members of the board of aldermen. Only the board of aldermen and the mayor in case of a tie in the board of aldermen shall be entitled to a vote on a proposition. Neither shall any person be permitted to discuss any question before the board of aldermen without the consent of the majority of the members of the board of aldermen. The board of aldermen shall have the right to go into private conferences at any time, and to establish any rules of procedure before them that they shall deem fit and proper. The board of aldermen shall semiannually cause to be spread upon their records a full and detailed account and statement of the receipts and expenditures and the indebtedness of the city for the half year preceding. The board of aldermen shall cause a journal to be kept of their procedure, and a record of the names voting for or against any proposition before the board of aldermen. The board of aldermen shall further receive and approve or reject the annual statement of the city collector to be made at the April meeting of the board of aldermen and shall deliver the delinquent list of taxes to the city collector for suit against such delinquents or the property bound for the same, brought in the name of the state, at the relation and to the use of the city collector. The board of aldermen may on such report or on the monthly report of the city collector ascertain the worthless personal tax and cause the same to be stricken from the delinquent list and credit the same to the city collector as not collectible. The board of aldermen shall within a reasonable time, not exceeding thirty days after the ascertainment of the assessment of real estate and personal property in this city, fix the annual rate of levy thereon by ordinance and cause such levy to be made at the April meeting in each year. The board of aldermen shall make a full settlement with all city officers noting on their journal record their approval of the same. The board of aldermen, with the consent and the approval of the mayor, shall have power to pass such laws and ordinances from time to time as shall be deemed necessary and which shall not conflict with the laws of the state, and each succeeding ordinance or law appertaining to any one thing, shall operate as repeal of any preceding law or ordinance that may be enforced touching such thing at the time of its passage and adoption; provided, that if any ordinance or resolution be passed by the board of aldermen at a regular meeting or at an adjourned or special meeting, and shall be presented to the mayor and the mayor shall refuse to approve the same and return the ordinance together with his objections in writing, the question shall be brought before the board of aldermen again in the following manner: The following question shall be submitted to the board of aldermen, "Shall the bill be passed the objection of the mayor notwithstanding?" The vote shall then be taken and the ayes and nays shall be taken and recorded and if two-thirds of all the members of the board of aldermen shall vote in the affirmative, the city clerk shall certify the fact on the roll and the bill thus certified shall be deposited with the proper officer and shall become an ordinance in the same manner and with like effect as if it had received the approval of the mayor; provided, that should the mayor neglect or refuse to sign any ordinance and return the same with his objections in writing at the next regular meeting of the board of aldermen, the same shall become a law without his signature. The board of aldermen shall at any reasonable time, in a proper manner, construct sidewalks and other improvements in the city, paying for the same in the manner provided by ordinance requiring such improvements, and the board of aldermen shall at all times have control over such improvements. In the absence of the city clerk, the mayor, by and with the consent of the board of aldermen, may appoint a clerk protempore. The board of aldermen shall approve all official bonds, not otherwise provided for, and no officer of the city shall be accepted as security on such official bond. The board of aldermen shall order the issuance of all warrants on the treasury only after ascertaining that there are such funds in the treasury to meet such warrants. The board of aldermen shall by ordinance fix all licenses, penalties, provide for all levies and collection of taxes and perform all duties required of them by law and so fixing penalties for neglect or refusal to comply with any such ordinance; and further, when indebtedness is authorized by the qualified voters, the board of aldermen shall provide by levy such money for the payment of interest on the indebtedness and a sinking fund to retire the same. The board of aldermen shall further cause notices of elections to be given. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 3, art. 2, § 37) 
Sec. 2-20.1. - Striking uncollectible debts from city's accounts. 
    The city collector shall submit a report to the board of aldermen during its April meeting listing all debts due and owing the city from whatsoever source which the collector shall deem as being uncollectible. Thereafter, the board of aldermen may cause the same to be stricken from the city's accounts and credit the same to the city collector as not collectable. 
(Ord. No. 2891, § 1, 6-23-81) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2891, § 1, adopted June 23, 1981, not specifically amendatory of the Code, has been codified as § 2-20.1 pursuant to instructions from the city. 
Sec. 2-21. - Election of aldermen; qualifications. 
    One alderman shall be elected annually from each ward to hold office for a term of two (2) years; provided, that no person shall be elected a member that is not at least eighteen (18) years of age, a citizen of the United States, and an inhabitant and resident of the city for one year next preceding his election and is not a resident of the ward from which he is elected. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 3, art. 2, § 34; Ord. No. 6989, § 1, 4-25-17) 
State Law reference- Election and qualifications of aldermen, RSMo §§ 79.060, 79.070. 
ARTICLE IV. - CITY ADMINISTRATOR 

Sec. 2-22. - Appointment; qualifications. 
    The city administrator shall be appointed by ordinance and shall have the following qualifications: He shall be at least twenty-one (21) years of age, a graduate of an accredited university or college, majoring in public or municipal administration, or shall have the equivalent qualifications and experience in financial, administrative or public relations fields. He shall be a resident of the city while serving as administrator unless said residency requirement is waived by the board of aldermen in its discretion. He shall devote full time to the performance of the duties of his office. He shall receive a salary as set by ordinance and shall serve at the pleasure of the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 2; Ord. No. 1776, § 2; Ord. No. 7048, § 1, 1-9-18) 
Sec. 2-23. - Duties generally. 
    The city administrator shall be the chief administrative assistant to the mayor and who shall have the general superintending control of the administration and management of the government business, officers and employees, subject to the direction and supervision of the mayor, and his duties shall be as follows: 
(a)  Appoint, dismiss, etc., officers and employees. Appointment of competent, qualified officers and employees to the administrative service. He shall have the power to dismiss, suspend and discipline in accordance with the personnel system, all officers and employees in the administrative service under his control; provided, that the employment of all department heads shall be ratified by the board of aldermen. 
(b)  Appoint to acting capacity. Designate himself or some other officer or employee to perform the duties of any office or position in the administrative service under his control which is vacant or which lacks administration due to the absence or disability of the incumbent. 
(c)  Prepare annual report. Prepare and present to the board of aldermen an annual report of the city's affairs, including a summary of reports of department heads, and such other reports as the board of aldermen shall require. 
(d)  Prepare budget report. Assemble estimates of the financial needs and resources of the city for each ensuing year and prepare a program of activities within the financial power of the city, embodying in it a budget document with proper supporting schedules and analyses. 
(e)  Be subject to control and supervision. At all times all actions of the city administrator shall be subject to supervision and control and direction by the mayor and shall account to the mayor and board of aldermen for any actions taken when requested to do so. 
(f)  Aid in the preparation of the agenda of all regular and special sessions of the board of aldermen. He shall attend substantially all meetings of the board of aldermen and assemble detailed reports pertinent to the agenda with recommendations of various committees concerning the matter to be considered. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 3; Ord. No. 1776, § 2) 
Sec. 2-24. - Powers generally. 
(a)  The powers of the city administrator shall be as follows: 
(1)  Assign according to classification. To assign any employee of the city to any department or branch thereof requiring services. 
(2)  Prescribe rules. To prescribe such rules and regulations as are necessary or expedient for the conduct of administrative agencies subject to his authority. 
(3)  Investigate. Have the power, either by himself or by any officer or person designated for the purpose by him, to investigate and to examine or inquire into the affairs or operation of any department, division, bureau or office; and when so authorized by the board of aldermen, he shall have power to employ consultants and professional counsel to aid in such investigations, examinations or inquiries. 
(4)  Coordinate officials. To set aside any action taken by a department head and may supersede him in the functions of his office. 
(5)  Delegate duties. To direct any department to perform the work for any other department. 
(6)  Appoint administrative committees. To designate from the administrative service such committees and the officers thereof as he shall find necessary for the proper consideration of administrative problems. 
(7)  Appear before board of aldermen. To appear before and address the board of aldermen at any meeting. 
(b)  At no time shall the powers or duties of the city administrator supersede the action of the mayor or the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 3; Ord. No. 1776, § 2) 
Sec. 2-25. - Duty to promote, secure and preserve financial and property interests of city. 
    In all cases where the duty is not expressly charged to any other department or office, it shall be the duty of the city administrator to act to promote, secure and preserve the financial and property interests of the city. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 7) 
ARTICLE V. - CITY HEALTH OFFICER 

Sec. 2-26. - County health officer appointed city health officer; duties. 
    The county health officer is hereby appointed the city health officer and is authorized to perform all of the duties of health officers as such duties shall be prescribed by this Code or other ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 933, § 1) 
Sec. 2-27. - County health officer to serve at pleasure of board of aldermen; salary. 
    The county health officer shall serve as the city health officer at the pleasure of the board of aldermen and without salary. 
(Ord. No. 933, § 2) 
ARTICLE VI. - DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Cross reference- Finance and taxation generally, ch. 10. 

Sec. 2-28. - Duties of director of finance. 
    The duties of director of finance shall be as follows: 
(a)  Fiscal supervision over officers. Exercise general supervision over all officers of the city regarding the proper management of the fiscal concerns of their respective offices. 
(1)  Examine books. Examine the books of each department from time to time, and see that they are kept in proper form. 
(2)  Report delinquent payments and financial reports. See that officers receiving money pay the same into the city treasury, when required, and that all necessary financial reports are made by officers, and shall report all delinquents in such payments or reports to the city administrator and board of aldermen. 
(b)  Duty upon default of officer. Report the default of any officer of the city to the city administrator who shall direct the city attorney to take immediate legal measures for the recovery of the amount for which such officer may be in default. 
(c)  Responsibility for proceeds of bonds. Deposit the proceeds of all sales of bonds with the city treasurer immediately after he shall have received the same, and, until such deposit, he shall be responsible for the amount thereof. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 7; Ord. No. 1776, § 2) 
Sec. 2-29. - Department to be divided into divisions. 
    The department of finance shall be divided into divisions, as described by this article. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 7) 
Sec. 2-30. - Division of the treasury. 
    The division of the treasury shall be supervised by the city treasurer, who shall: 
(a)  Keep accounts of receipts and expenditures. Keep in proper books, a full and accurate account of all the money received and disbursed by him in behalf of the city, specifying the time of receipt and disbursement, from whom received and to whom disbursed, and on what account received and disbursed, and how paid. 
(b)  Cancel evidences of debt. Cancel all warrants and other evidences of debt against the city, whenever paid by him by writing or stamping across the face thereof the words, "Paid by the City Treasurer" with the date of payment written or stamped thereon. 
(c)  Receive and disburse money. Receive and have custody of all money paid to the city, and shall disburse city money upon the warrant of the board of aldermen or the authorization of the board of aldermen. 
(d)  Pay city employees. Pay city employees upon presentation of the properly certified payroll. 
(e)  Report monthly to board of aldermen. Make a detailed report to the board of aldermen, on the second Monday of each month, as to the business of his office during the month preceding, showing the balance on hand to the credit of the different funds at the time of his last report, the amounts received during the month, and on what account, together with such other items and facts as the board of aldermen may require. 
(f)  Endorse bills. When the board of aldermen refers a bill to him that contemplates the payment of money, he shall endorse such bill to the effect whether a sufficient sum stands to the credit of the city, unappropriated, in the fund covered by such ordinance, to meet the requirements of such bill. 
(g)  Keep custody of bonds, contracts, etc. Be charged with the custody of the official bonds of city employees, except his own, which shall be in the custody of the board of aldermen, and with the custody of all deeds, mortgages, contracts, judgments, notes, debts and choses in action. He shall keep and administer all securities, bonds or other forms of negotiable instruments owned by or belonging to the city. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 7; Ord. No. 1776, § 2) 
State Law reference- Duties of treasurer, RSMo § 79.300. 
Sec. 2-31. - Division of collection. 
    The division of collection shall be supervised by the city collector, who shall: 
(a)  Accept tax books: Accept tax books prepared by the city clerk and mail tax notices. 
(b)  Collect money and fees due the city: Demand and receive all money and fees owing to the city whenever any person is indebted to the city in any manner and the means of collection of such debt is not otherwise provided for by law. When any claim shall not be collectible by other methods, he shall report the same to the city attorney for prosecution. 
(c)  Daily settlement: Make a daily settlement of the amounts received and paid out during the day for which settlement is being made. 
(d)  Annual report: Make a detailed report to the board of aldermen stating the various money collected by him during the year, and the amount uncollected and the names of the persons from which he failed to collect and the causes therefor. 
(e)  Monthly reports: Make a monthly report to the board of aldermen of all taxes collected of the real and personal delinquent lists. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 7) 
Cross reference- Duty of city collector with respect to licenses, § 13-19. 
Sec. 2-32. - Division of accounts. 
    The division of accounts shall be headed by the city administrator, who shall: 
(a)  Audit accounts: Examine and audit the accounts of all officers and departments subject to the approval of the board of aldermen. 
(b)  Prescribe form: Prescribe the form of accounts and reports to be rendered to him. 
(c)  Certify contracts: Certify according to law all contracts, agreements or other obligations for the expenditure of public funds entered into by any official of the city government, and no such contract, agreement or other obligation shall be valid until so certified by him. 
(d)  Present budget report: Assemble estimates of the financial needs and resources of the city for each ensuing year, and shall prepare a program of activities within the financial power of the city, embodying in it a budget document with proper supporting schedules and analyses. The report shall be presented to the mayor and board of aldermen at least thirty (30) days prior to the close of each fiscal year. 
(e)  Prepare financial statements: Transmit to the board of aldermen at least monthly audited statements of cash on hand and of classified unencumbered appropriation balances for the city as a whole, and such other financial statements as the board of aldermen may from time to time require. He shall keep all departments, boards, commissions or institutions currently informed of its classified unencumbered appropriation balances. 
(f)  Keep accounts: Keep all general accounts of the city government and of the respective departments, offices, boards, commissions and institutions thereof. 
(g)  Supervise and approve purchases: Supervise and approve the purchase of all tools, equipment and supplies required by the city. In this connection he shall, aided by the city auditor, establish and maintain a system of purchase control designed to minimize the unnecessary expenditures of city funds and effect a savings through quantity and selective buying. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 7; Ord. No. 1776, § 2; Ord. No. 2534, §§ 1, 2, 4-25-78) 
Sec. 2-33. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 2-33 was repealed by Ord. No. 1776, § 1. 
Sec. 2-34. - Division of licenses. 
    The division of licenses shall be supervised by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 7) 
Cross reference- Licenses generally, Ch. 13. 
ARTICLE VII. - DEPARTMENT OF LAW 

Sec. 2-35. - Officers. 
    The department of law shall consist of the city attorney and any special counsel. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 6) 
State Law reference- Authorizing appointment of city attorney, RSMo § 79.230. 
Sec. 2-36. - Duties. 
    The city attorney or any special counsel, or both, shall enforce all laws and act to protect the interests of the city and shall: 
(a)  Prepare ordinances. Prepare or revise ordinances when so requested by the mayor, city administrator or the board of aldermen or any committee thereof. 
(b)  Give opinions. Advise and give his opinion upon any legal matter or question submitted to him by any elected official, the city administrator or by a department head. 
(c)  Attend board of aldermen meetings. Attend all regular board of aldermen meetings as directed by ordinance for the purpose of giving the mayor or the board of aldermen any legal advice requested by its members. 
(d)  Prepare legal instruments. Prepare for execution all contracts and instruments to which the city is a party, and shall approve as to form, all bonds required to be submitted to the city. 
(e)  Prosecute offenders and defend officials. Prepare when authorized by the board of aldermen, all charges and complaints against and shall appear in the appropriate court in the prosecution of, every person charged with the violation of this Code or other ordinance or of any regulations adopted under authority of state law or with the commission of a misdemeanor as declared by state law or by virtue of its authority. In any prosecution for violation of any regulation adopted by any board or commission created under authority of the state law, the city's special counsel shall act under the directions of such board or commission, subject to such paramount control as is given to the board of aldermen by state law. 
(f)  Settle claims. Have the power to adjust, settle, compromise or submit to arbitration, any action, causes of action, accounts, debts, claims, demands, disputes and matters of favor of or against the city or in which the city is concerned as debtor or creditor, now existing or which may hereafter arise, not involving or requiring payment to exceed an amount designated by the board of aldermen. 
(g)  Make reports. 
(1)  Immediate report of decision. Immediately report the outcome of any litigation in which the city has an interest to the city administrator, the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(2)  Annual report of pending litigation. Make an annual report to the mayor, city administrator and board of aldermen, as of January 1, of all pending litigation in which the city has an interest and the condition thereof. 
(h)  Control legal services incidental to board of aldermen action. Have charge of all legal services auxiliary to board of aldermen action in connection with the appropriating of property to public use and in the levying of assessments. 
(i)  Keep records. 
(1)  Suits. Keep a complete record of all suits in which the city had or has an interest, giving the names of the parties, the court where brought, the nature of the action, the disposition of the case or its condition if pending and the briefs of counsel. 
(2)  Opinions and titles. Keep a complete record of all written opinions furnished by him and of all certificates or abstracts of titles furnished by him to the city, or any department or official thereof. 
(j)  Deliver records to successor. Deliver all records, documents and property of every description in his possession of the city to his successor in office, who shall give him duplicate receipts therefor, one of which he shall file with the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 6; Ord. No. 1776, § 2) 
Cross reference- Duty of prosecuting attorney to prosecute municipal ordinance violations, § 21-12. 
ARTICLE VIII. - DEPARTMENT OF POLICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Police generally, ch. 20; duties of chief of police, § 20-8; police court, ch. 21. 

Sec. 2-37. - Establishment; duties; general supervision and control; appointment of chief of police. 
(a)  Establishment and duties. A department of the government of the city, to be known as the department of police, is hereby created. The primary mission of the department shall be: 
(1)  The suppression of crime. 
(2)  The protection of life and property from criminal depredation. 
(3)  The preservation of law and order. 
(4)  The enforcement of the criminal and traffic laws of the state and the criminal and traffic ordinances of the city. 
(5)  The detection and apprehension of criminal and traffic offenders. 
(6)  The recovery of stolen property. 
(7)  Such other duties and responsibilities as may be imposed by law. 
(b)  General supervision and control. The department shall be under the control and supervision of an executive officer to be known as the chief of police. He shall be responsible to the city administrator for the efficient operation of the department of police; and the position of chief of police is hereby included in the classified service and subject to the provisions of chapter 18. 
(c)  Appointment of chief of police. The city administrator shall appoint the chief of police of the police department as is provided for in section 2-23 of this Code, and such appointment shall be covered by chapter 18. 
(Ord. No. 1615, § 2) 
ARTICLE IX. - DEPARTMENT OF PUBLIC WORKS[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6049, approved Oct. 10, 2006, repealed section 10 of Ord. No. 974, approved May 26, 1965, from which §§ 2-38, 2-39, pertaining to the duties of the director of community development and divisions of department, derived. 

Secs. 2-38, 2-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - DEPARTMENT OF RECORDS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 2-40. - General duties of city clerk. 
    The department of records consists of a city clerk who shall: 
(a)  Clerk of board of aldermen. Serve as clerk of the board of aldermen and perform such other duties of a like nature as shall be required by that body. 
(b)  Keep records of board of aldermen. Be responsible for the recording, filing, indexing and safekeeping of all proceedings of the board of aldermen. 
(c)  Record ordinances. Record in full, uniformly and permanently, all ordinances and shall authenticate the same. 
(d)  Keep election records. Keep and maintain all election records and have custody of all property used in connection with elections. 
(e)  Notice of expiration of term. Notify the appointing authority of the impending expiration of the term of office of a member of any board or commission. Such notice shall be given at least thirty (30) days before such expiration. 
(f)  Keep official seal. Be the custodian of the official seal of the city. 
(g)  Tax books. The city clerk shall make out appropriate and accurate tax books and turn such tax books over to the city collector, charging him with the full amount of taxes to be levied and collected, and taking a receipt thereof. 
(h)  General accountant. The city clerk shall be the general accountant of the city. 
(i)  Issue permits and licenses. Issue all permits and licenses except those which are required, by ordinance, to be issued by a particular department or office. 
(Ord. No. 974, § 8; Ord. No. 1776, § 2) 
State Law reference- Duties of clerk, RSMo § 79.320. 
DIVISION 2. - RECORDS MANAGEMENT PROGRAM[5] 

Footnotes: 
--- (5) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 2312, adopted March 9, 1976, amended this Code by adding Div. 2, §§ 2-40.1-2.40.7, as herein set out. 

Sec. 2-40.1. - Short title; purpose. 
    This division shall be known and may be cited as the "Records Management Program of the City of Grandview." The declared purpose of this division is to provide for the proper and efficient management of the public records of the City of Grandview; and to herewith adopt the "State and Local Records Law," including the "Missouri Municipal Records Manual." 
(Ord. No. 2312, § 1) 
Sec. 2-40.2. - Definitions. 
    [For the purposes of this division, the following terms shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section:] 
(1)  City clerk means the city clerk of the City of Grandview, Missouri, or her duly designated representative. 
(2)  Records review board means the special counsel, director of finance, and city administrator for the City of Grandview, Missouri, or their duly designated representatives. 
(3)  Inactive records means those records no longer required in active office areas but which require further retention due to legal, operating or historical reasons. 
(4)  Maintenance of public records means the creation, maintenance, protection, use and disposition of all public records of the City of Grandview, Missouri, including the establishment and maintenance of a system of filing and indexing public records. 
(5)  Public record means all documents, books, papers, letters, photographs, tapes, maps, films, sound recordings or other materials, regardless of physical form or characteristics, made or received pursuant to law or ordinance or in connection with the transaction of official business by any officer or employee of the City of Grandview; however, "public record" shall not be construed to mean those public records which are deemed by law to be confidential or which are prohibited from being inspected by the public or which shall hereinafter be exempt from the provisions of this section or from the provisions of the "State and Local Records Law." Library and museum material made or acquired and preserved solely for reference or exhibition purposes, extra copies of documents preserved only for convenience of reference, and stocks of publications and of processed documents are not included within this definition, and are hereinafter designated as "nonrecord" materials. 
(Ord. No. 2312, § 1; Ord. No. 4611, § 1, 5-24-94)
