Sec. 2-40.3. - Ownership of public records. 
    All public records shall be the property of the city; and, in this regard, such records shall be delivered by outgoing officials and employees to their successors. 
(Ord. No. 2312, § 1) 
Sec. 2-40.4. - Duties of officers and employees. 
    It shall be the duty of each officer and employee of the city to protect, preserve, store, transfer, destroy or otherwise dispose of, use and manage public records only in accordance to applicable federal, state or local law, or such rules as may be promulgated or approved by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 2312, § 1) 
Sec. 2-40.5. - Duties of city clerk. 
    It shall be the responsibility, in cooperation with the records review board, of the city clerk to administer the records management program of the City of Grandview. In this regard the city clerk shall, among all other things that may be required for the proper and efficient management of the public records of the City: 
(a)  Develop and circulate such rules and regulations as may be necessary and proper to implement and maintain the records management program. 
(b)  Provide and maintain a city records center to house and preserve inactive records prior to disposition. 
(c)  Advise and assist city departments in the preparation of records inventory and destruction schedules for approval by the records review board, and for submittal to the state local records board. 
(d)  Approve destruction schedules before disposition of the public records. 
(e)  Advise and assist city departments in reviewing and selecting material to be transferred to the archives for preservation or microfilming. 
(f)  Provide microfilming services for public records pursuant to rules promulgated by the city clerk for the centralization of such services. 
(g)  Conduct, as the city clerk deems necessary, such surveys, studies and investigations as will assist in promoting a proper and efficient records management program for the city, including information retrieval systems. 
(Ord. No. 2312, § 1) 
Sec. 2-40.6. - Duties of records review board. 
    It shall be the responsibility of the members of the records review board to review and adopt retention and destruction schedules recommended by the affected department head on such records which are not enumerated in the "Missouri Municipal Records Manual" dated December 18, 1973 and all succeeding amendments thereto; and which recommendations shall then be transmitted to the state and local records board for their action. 
(Ord. No. 2312, § 1; Ord. No. 4611, § 2, 5-24-94) 
Sec. 2-40.7. - Duties of city departments. 
(1)  Departments shall create and maintain all records with adequate and proper documentation of the organization, together with the functions, policies, decisions, procedures and essential transactions of the department. 
(2)  Departments, with the advice of the city clerk, shall establish and maintain an active, continuing program for the economical and efficient management of the records of the department. Such program shall, among other things, provide for: 
(a)  Effective controls over the creation, maintenance and use of records in the conduct of current business. 
(b)  Cooperation with the city clerk in applying standards, procedures and techniques designed to improve the management of records. 
(c)  Promotion of the maintenance and security of records deemed appropriate for preservation. 
(d)  Segregation and disposal of records of temporary value in accordance with established retention schedules. 
(3)  Those public records which are not required in the current operation of the office where they are made or kept, and all public records which can properly be abolished or discontinued, shall be transferred to the city records center or archives so that the selected historical records of the city may be centralized, preserved and be made more widely available, insured permanent preservation or approved for destruction. 
(4)  Departments of the city shall designate a representative to coordinate the management of records in that department. The representative shall: 
(a)  Coordinate all records management activities and functions within the department and with the city clerk. 
(b)  With the advice and assistance of the city clerk, inventory or manage the inventory of all public records for disposition scheduling and transfer action in accordance with procedures prescribed by law or rule promulgated by the city clerk. 
(c)  Consult with any other personnel responsible for creation or maintenance of specific records within his department regarding records retention and transfer recommendation. 
(d)  Analyze records inventory data, examine and compare divisional or unit inventories for duplication of records, and recommend to the city records officer minimal retentions for all copies commensurate with legal, financial and administrative needs. 
(e)  Review established records retention schedules at least annually to insure that they are complete and current. 
(Ord. No. 2312, § 1) 
ARTICLE XI. - MAYOR 

Sec. 2-41. - Qualifications. 
    No person shall be elected mayor of the city who is not at least twenty-five (25) years of age, a citizen of the United States, a resident of the city at the time of and for at least one year next preceding his election and a qualified voter of the city. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 2, art. 3, § 6, ch. 3, art. 1, § 30) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo § 79.080. 
Sec. 2-42. - Duties generally. 
    The mayor shall exercise general supervision over all officers, property and affairs of the city and shall take care that all ordinances and laws relating to the city are enforced and complied with. The mayor shall preside over the board of aldermen at their meetings, but shall not vote on a question that comes before the board of aldermen, except in a case of a tie when he shall cast the deciding vote; the mayor shall not preside or vote in any case when he is personally an interested party. The mayor shall communicate to the board of aldermen such measures as may in his opinion tend to the improvement of the finances, the police, the health, the security, the ornamentation, the comfort and general prosperity of the city and the inhabitants thereof. When he deems it necessary or advisable, the mayor shall require any officer of the city to exhibit the city accounts, paper and records in charge of such officers, to him as mayor for inspection and examination and such mayor shall make report and recommendations relative thereto, to the board of aldermen annually. The mayor shall make a report in writing of the conditions of the city, matters relating to his office as mayor as well as those relating to other city officers to the board of aldermen, with his recommendations relative thereto. The mayor shall at all times be active and vigilant in looking after and caring for the welfare of the city in enforcing all laws relating to the city and deal promptly with all subordinate officers for failure to perform or neglect to perform or the violation of any duty. When necessary, the mayor may call every able-bodied male inhabitant of the city, between the ages of eighteen (18) and fifty (50) years to aid in the preservation of peace and enforcement of the law. The mayor shall have power to remit fines and forfeitures, to grant reprieves and pardons for offenses arising under this Code or other ordinances of the city, but not as to any costs of any officer. The mayor shall recommend to the board of aldermen for appointment, persons for appointive offices for the city. The mayor shall be, when acting as police judge, conservator of the peace and have exclusive original jurisdiction to hear and determine offenses against this Code or other ordinances of the city, keep a docket and record of proceedings of all matters pertaining to his office and deliver all such books, records and papers pertaining to his office to his successor in office. 
(R.O. 1929, ch. 3, art. 1, § 31) 
ARTICLE XII. - PLANNING COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-43. - Created; membership; term of office. 
    There is hereby created a planning commission consisting of seven (7) members who shall be appointed by the mayor and approved by the board of aldermen of the City of Grandview, and who shall serve without pay. There shall be two (2) representatives appointed from each of the three (3) wards within the city and one (1) representative appointed to serve at-large. Every member of the planning commission shall be a resident of the city, both at the time of appointment and throughout his or her term as a commissioner. The term of office for each member on the planning commission shall be for a period of four (4) years, except when appointed to fill a vacancy of an unexpired term. As terms of office expire, new members shall be appointed for terms of four (4) years each as per state statutes. 
    A planning commissioner's absence from one-third ( 1/3 ) of the planning commission meetings in any twelve-month period shall be deemed cause for removal from office pursuant to the provisions of Section 2-10 of the Code of Laws. 
    The planning commission created by this section shall be deemed to have been created under the terms and provisions of Chapter 89 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, 2010 (as amended), and their powers and duties shall be those vested in them by this section. 
(Ord. No. 1938, §§ 3, 5-7; Ord. No. 3677, § 1, 11-10-87; Ord. No. 6506, § 2, 11-8-11) 
Sec. 2-44. - Powers and duties. 
    The planning commission is granted all the powers and duties vested in it by law, and particularly by chapter 89, Revised Statutes of Missouri, 1986 (as amended). 
(Ord. No. 1938, § 3; Ord. No. 3677, § 2, 11-10-87) 
Sec. 2-45. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6066, adopted Jan. 23, 2007, repealed Ord. No. 1640, and any amendments thereto, from which § 2-45 derived. Said § 2-45 pertained to rules and procedures and had been amended by Ord. No. 3677, adopted Nov. 10, 1987; Ord. No. 4747, adopted May 23, 1995; and Ord. No. 4899, adopted Aug. 13, 1996. 
ARTICLE XIII. - CIVIL EMERGENCY 

Sec. 2-46. - Imposition of regulations; proclamation of emergency. 
    Whenever, in the judgment of the mayor, or in the event of his inability to act, the president of the board of aldermen or city administrator determines that an emergency exists as a result of mob action or other civil disobedience causing danger of injury to or damages to persons or property, he shall have power to impose by proclamation any or all of the following regulations necessary to preserve the peace and order of the city: 
(a)  To impose a curfew upon all or any portion of the city thereby requiring all persons in such designated curfew areas to forthwith remove themselves from the public streets, alleys, parks or other public places; provided, that physicians, nurses and ambulance operators performing medical services, utility personnel maintaining essential public services, firemen and city authorized or requested law enforcement officers and personnel may be exempted from such curfew. 
(b)  To order the closing of any business establishments anywhere within the city for the period of the emergency, such businesses to include, but not be limited to, those selling intoxicating liquors, cereal malt beverages, gasoline or firearms. 
(c)  To order the discontinuance of the sale of beer. 
(d)  To order the discontinuance of selling, distributing or giving away gasoline or other liquid flammable or combustible products in any container other than a gasoline tank properly affixed to a motor vehicle. 
(e)  To order the discontinuance of selling, distributing, dispensing or giving away any firearms or ammunition of any character whatsoever. 
(f)  To designate any public street, thoroughfare or vehicle parking areas closed to motor vehicles and pedestrian traffic. 
(g)  To call upon regular and auxiliary law enforcement agencies and organizations within or without the city to assist in preserving and keeping the peace within the city. 
(h)  To issue such other orders as are imminently necessary for the protection of life and property. 
    The proclamation of emergency provided herein shall become effective upon its issuance and dissemination to the public by appropriate news media. Any emergency proclaimed in accordance with the provisions of this section shall terminate after forty-eight (48) hours from the issuance thereof, or upon the issuance of a proclamation determining an emergency no longer exists, whichever occurs first; provided that such emergency may be extended for such additional periods of time as determined necessary by resolution of the governing body. 
(Ord. No. 1412, §§ 1-3) 
ARTICLE XIV. - TAX INCREMENT FINANCE COMMISSION 

Sec. 2-47. - Creation; membership; terms of office. 
    There is hereby created a Tax Increment Financing Commission consisting of eleven (11) members of which six (6) members shall be appointed by the Mayor with the consent of a majority of the Board of Aldermen. The six (6) municipal members shall serve without pay. The six (6) municipal members shall also be members of the Planning Commission. The term of office of each of the municipal members of the Tax Increment Financing Commission shall be for a period of four (4) years, except when appointed to fill a vacancy of an unexpired term. Of the members first appointed as municipal members, two (2) members shall be designated to serve for terms of two (2) years, two (2) members shall be designated to serve for a term of three (3) years, and two (2) members shall be designated to serve for a term of four (4) years from the date of such initial appointments. 
    With respect to the non-municipal members, two (2) members shall be appointed by the school boards whose districts are included within the redevelopment plan or redevelopment area, in any manner agreed upon by the affected districts. Two (2) members shall be appointed by the chief elected officer of Jackson County, with the consent of the majority of the governing body of Jackson County. One (1) member shall be appointed, in any manner agreed upon by the affected taxing districts, to represent all other districts levying ad valorem taxes within the area selected for a redevelopment project or the redevelopment area. At the option of the members appointed by the municipality the members who are appointed by the school boards and other taxing districts may serve on the commission for a term to coincide with the length of time a redevelopment project, redevelopment plan or designation of a redevelopment area is considered for approval by the commission, or for a definite term pursuant to this section. If the members representing school boards and other taxing districts are appointed for a term coinciding with the length of time a redevelopment project, plan or area is approved, such term shall terminate upon final approval of the project, plan or designation of the area by the governing body of the municipality. Thereafter, the commission shall consist of the six (6) members appointed by the City of Grandview, except that members representing school boards and other taxing districts shall be appointed as provided herein prior to any amendments to any redevelopment plans, redevelopment projects, or designation of a redevelopment area. 
(Ord. No. 4242, § 1, 10-2-91; Ord. No. 5048, § 1, 1-13-98) 
Sec. 2-48. - Powers and duties. 
    The Tax Increment Financing Commission is granted all the powers and duties vested in it by law, and particularly by Chapter 99, Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 4242, § 1, 10-2-91; Ord. No. 5048, § 1, 1-13-98) 
Sec. 2-49. - Rules and procedures. 
    The Rules and Procedures adopted by the Tax Increment Financing Commission on January 28, 1998, for conduct of meetings and for receipt of public input at public hearings, and as amended from time to time by the Commission, shall govern the procedures of the Tax Increment Financing Commission. Further, the Tax Increment Financing Commission shall follow all statutory requirements for the conduct of its powers and duties as vested by Chapter 99, Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 4242, § 1, 10-2-91; Ord. No. 5048, § 1, 1-13-98; Ord. No. 5056 § 1, 2-10-98) 
Sec. 2-49.1. - Application fees. 
    All applications and amended applications filed with the city seeking tax increment financing assistance shall be accompanied by an executed funding agreement, acceptable to the city, along with the deposit of funds required in said funding agreement and deemed adequate by the tax increment financing commission and the City of Grandview. 
(Ord. No. 5187, § 4, 7-13-99; Ord. No. 5660, § 1, 8-26-03) 
ARTICLE XV. - PARKS AND RECREATION COMMISSION[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5052, §§ 1, 2, adopted Jan. 27, 1998, repealed former Art. XV, §§ 2-50-2-70, in its entirety and enacted new provisions as herein set out. Former Art. XV pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 1971, § 5; Ord. No. 2723, § 1, 12-11-79; Ord. No. 3228, § 1, 3-27-84; Ord. No. 4371, § 2, 9-22-92)

Sec. 2-50. - Parks and recreation commission creation. 
    There is hereby created a parks and recreation commission, which shall be responsible for recommendations to the board of aldermen pertaining to the park and recreation needs of the city; programs to serve those needs; and fiscal policy relating to recreation needs and programs, including the establishment of fees and charges related thereto. 
(Ord. No. 5052, § 2, 1-27-98) 
Sec. 2-51. - Parks and recreation commission to serve as advisory body. 
    The Grandview Parks and Recreation Commission shall serve as an advisory body and shall act for and on behalf of the city on basic policies that will guide the department in the administration of the city's parks and recreation program. 
    Members shall not be personally or individually liable for, or accountable for, any acts performed in the direction or operation of the city's parks and recreation program. The commission shall have no supervisory authority over the city employees. 
(Ord. No. 5052, § 2, 1-27-98) 
Sec. 2-52. - Parks and recreation commission members; requirements, terms. 
(a)  Requirements. 
(1)  The Grandview Parks and Recreation Commission shall consist of nine (9) members, who shall serve without compensation. Each member shall be appointed by the mayor and confirmed by the board of aldermen. 
(2)  Members shall be residents of the city and exhibit an interest in the parks and recreation program as well as demonstrate an interest in providing a vital communication link between residents of the community and the elected and appointed officials. 
(b)  Terms. Terms of commissioners shall begin on May 1 of each year and continue until their successors are appointed. members may serve more than one (1) term with written notice of such intent submitted thirty (30) days prior to expiration of their respective term, and provided reappointment is made by the mayor with confirmation by the board of aldermen. 
(c)  Area of representation, length of term. 
(1)  Two (2) commissioners shall be appointed from each of the city's three (3) wards for five (5) year terms, or until their successors are appointed. 
(2)  One (1) commissioner shall be appointed from the board of aldermen for a five (5) year term, or until his or her successor is appointed. 
(3)  One (1) commissioner shall be appointed from Grandview Consolidated School District No. 4 for a five (5) year term, or until his or her successor is appointed. 
(4)  One (1) commissioner shall be appointed at-large for a five (5) year term, or until his or her successor is appointed. 
(Ord. No. 5052, § 2, 1-27-98) 
Sec. 2-53. - Removal of members; cause, vacancy. 
(a)  Removal, cause: 
(1)  The mayor, with the consent of the board of aldermen, may remove any member of the parks and recreation commission for misconduct or dereliction of duty. 
(2)  Any commissioner who shall have accrued three (3) absences within any twelve-month period shall receive written notification of such absences and a listing of the causes for removal. 
(3)  Any commissioner who shall have been absent from four (4) regular meetings in a twelve-month period shall be deemed to have resigned without notice. 
(4)  Representatives of the board of aldermen and Grandview Consolidated School District No. 4 shall be granted excused absences on those occasions on which they are attending official functions of their elected positions. 
(b)  Vacancies, how filled: Upon removal or resignation of a commissioner, the mayor, with the confirmation by the board of aldermen, shall appoint a new commissioner to complete the term of the vacated position. 
(Ord. No. 5052, § 2, 1-27-98) 
Sec. 2-54. - Officers; rules and records. 
    Within fifteen (15) days of their organizational meeting, members shall elect one (1) of their own to serve as president and elect such other officers as deemed necessary. The members shall establish such rules and adopt such bylaws and regulations as may be expedient, but not inconsistent with the ordinances of the city. A journal of all meetings of the commission shall be maintained, and approved copies thereof shall be forwarded to the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 5052, § 2, 1-27-98) 
Sec. 2-55. - Effect on other powers of city. 
    The provisions of this ordinance shall not in any way repeal, affect, or limit the powers heretofore or hereafter granted to the city under the provisions of any chapter or by law, to establish, maintain and operate parks and other recreational grounds and public recreation. 
(Ord. No. 5052, § 2, 1-27-98) 
Secs. 2-56-2-70. - Reserved.
