ARTICLE XVII. - GRANDVIEW ENHANCED ENTERPRISE ZONE BOARD 

Sec. 2-75. - Enhanced enterprise board established. 
    Pursuant to RSMo section 135.957, there is hereby established a seven-member enhanced enterprise zone board of the City of Grandview, Missouri, (the "EEZ board") to operate within the boundaries of the City of Grandview. The members of such EEZ board shall be the following, pursuant to RSMo section 135.957: One (1) member shall be appointed by the board or boards of education of school districts located within the enhanced enterprise zone; one (1) member shall be appointed by other affected taxing districts; and the remaining five (5) members shall be appointed by the mayor of the City of Grandview. The board of education member and the other affected taxing districts members shall each have initial terms of five (5) years. Of the five (5) members appointed by the mayor, two (2) shall have initial terms of four (4) years, two (2) shall have initial terms of three (3) years, and one (1) shall have an initial term of two (2) years. Thereafter, members shall serve terms of five (5) years. All vacancies shall be filled in the same manner as the original appointment. For inefficiency or neglect of duty or misconduct in office, a member of the EEZ board may be removed by the board of aldermen. The members of the EEZ board annually shall elect a chair from among the members. A majority of the members shall constitute a quorum of such EEZ board for the purpose of conducting business and exercising the powers of the EEZ board and for all other purposes. Action may be taken by the EEZ board upon a vote of a majority of the members present. The EEZ board shall adopt by-laws governing the conduct of its proceedings consistent with applicable statutes and with this article. 
(Ord. No. 6101, § 1(1), 5-22-07) 
Sec. 2-76. - Powers and duties of EEZ board. 
    The EEZ board is hereby authorized to exercise those obligations, duties, powers and functions authorized by RSMo sections 135.950 through 135.973, as the same may be amended or revised from time to time, to conduct the activities necessary to advise the board of aldermen on the designation of enhanced enterprise zones in the City of Grandview, to perform any other advisory duties with respect to such zones by the board of aldermen, to perform reviews and assessments of zone activities as such activities relate to the annual reports as set forth in RSMo section 135.960. 
(Ord. No. 6101, § 1(2), 5-22-07) 
Sec. 2-77. - Authority to act. 
    It is hereby recognized that the requirements of Missouri Statutes as pertain to the number, qualifications, terms and manner of appointment of persons to serve on the EEZ board may, from time to time, be revised. The mayor and such other persons as may be authorized to act with respect to appointments to the EEZ board under Missouri Statutes in the future are hereby authorized to act in accordance with Missouri Statutes, as from time to time revised, so that at all times hereinafter the EEZ board shall be and remain legally authorized to exercise the powers of an EEZ board under Missouri Statutes, without further action of this board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 6101, § 1(3), 5-22-07) 
Sec. 2-78. - Mayor authorized to appoint EEZ board members. 
    The mayor of the City of Grandview is hereby authorized to make the appointments referenced as mayoral appointments in section 2-75 above, within thirty (30) days following the effective date of this article. The board of education of Grandview Consolidated School District No. 4 is hereby authorized to make the appointment referenced as the board of education appointment in section 2-75 above. The other affected taxing districts are hereby authorized, collectively and as a group, to make the one appointment referenced as the other taxing districts appointment in section 2-75 above. 
(Ord. No. 6101, § 1(4), 5-22-07) 
Chapter 2A - ADULT-ORIENTED ENTERTAINMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4409, § 2, adopted Nov. 24, 1992 amended Ch. 2A to read as herein set out in §§ 2A-1-2A-3, 2A-21, 2A-22, 2A-31-2A-33. Prior to inclusion of said ordinance, Ch. 2A, §§ 2A-1, 2A-21-2A-24, 2A-31-2A-34 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3540, §§ 1-4, adopted Sept. 23, 1986; Ord. No. 3549, §§ 1-5, adopted Sept. 23, 1986. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 2A-1. - Definitions. 
    The following definitions shall govern the interpretation of this Chapter 2A: 
(a)  Adult. As used in this article, "adult" refers to persons who have attained the age of eighteen (18) years. 
(b)  Adult entertainment establishments. Any establishment, including but not limited to adult bookstores, adult video stores, adult motion picture theaters, and adult mini motion picture theaters, having any of the following: 
(1)  Forty (40) percent or more of its annual gross receipts derived from the offering of entertainment, stocks in trade of materials, scenes or other presentations characterized by emphasis on depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined; or 
(2)  Forty percent (40) or more of its inventory consisting of entertainment, stocks in trade of materials, scenes or other presentations characterized by emphasis on depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined; or 
(3)  Forty (40) percent or more of its total floor area allocated to entertainment, stocks in trade of materials, scenes or other presentations characterized by emphasis on depiction or description of "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined. 
(c)  Adult bookstore. Any establishment having any of the following: 
(1)  Forty (40) percent or more of its annual gross receipts derived from the sale, display or rental of material, books, magazines and other periodicals, videos and any other items which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined; or 
(2)  Forty (40) percent or more of its inventory consisting of books, magazines and other periodicals, videos and any other items which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined; or 
(3)  Forty (40) percent or more of its total floor area allocated to books, magazines and other periodicals, videos and any other items which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined. 
(d)  Adult motion picture theater. An enclosed building with a capacity of fifty (50) or more persons used for presenting or showing, for money consideration, movie or video films or pictures or other material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined, for observation by patrons therein. 
(e)  Adult mini motion picture theater. An enclosed building with a capacity for less than fifty (50) persons used for presenting or showing, for money consideration, movie or video films or pictures or other material distinguished or characterized by an emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined, for observation by patrons therein. 
(f)  Nudity. The showing of the human male or female genitals, pubic area, or buttocks, with less than a fully opaque covering, the showing of the female breast with less than a fully opaque covering of any part of the nipple, or the showing of the covered male genitals in a discernibly turgid state. 
(g)  Specified sexual activities. For the purpose of this article, "specified sexual activities" is defined as: 
(1)  Human genitals in a state of sexual stimulation or arousal; 
(2)  Acts of human masturbation, sexual intercourse or sodomy; or 
(3)  Fondling or other erotic touching of the human genitals, pubic region, buttock or the female breast. 
(h)  Specified anatomical area. For the purpose of this article, "specified anatomical areas" is defined as: 
(1)  Less than completely or opaquely covered: 
a.  Human genitals or pubic region; 
b.  Buttocks; or 
c.  Female breast area below a point immediately above the top of the areola. 
(2)  Human male genitals in a discernibly turgid state even if completely and opaquely covered. 
(i)  Adult video store. Any establishment having any of the following: 
(1)  Forty (40) percent or more of its annual gross receipts derived from the sale or rental of video tapes, films, compact discs, or laser discs which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined; or 
(2)  Forty (40) percent or more of its inventory consisting of video tapes, films, compact discs, or laser discs which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined; or 
(3)  Forty (40) percent or more of its total floor area allocated to video tapes, films, compact discs, or laser discs which are distinguished or characterized by their emphasis on matter depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as herein defined. 
(j)  Specified criminal acts. For the purpose of this article, "specified criminal acts" is defined as: 
(1)  Any felony within five years immediately preceding an application, or any felony occurring during the pendency of a permit or license issued under this chapter or 
(2)  Any misdemeanor criminal act within two (2) years immediately preceding an application, or any misdemeanor occurring during the pendency of a permit or license issued under this chapter, where such misdemeanor involved or involves sexual offenses, prostitution, promotion of prostitution, rape, indecent exposure, sexual abuse of a child, pornography and related offenses, as defined in the Missouri Criminal Code; or where such misdemeanor involved or involves controlled substances or illegal drugs or narcotics offenses as defined by the United States Code, Missouri or other state statute or city ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 5115, § 1(Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-2. - Regulations and requirements. 
(a)  Age restriction. Only adults as herein defined shall be permitted on the premises of any adult entertainment establishment as herein defined. 
(b)  Exterior display. No establishment, including but not limited to an adult entertainment establishment, shall be conducted in any manner that permits the observation of any material or persons depicting, describing or relating to "specified sexual activities" or "specified anatomical areas," as defined herein, from any exterior source by display, decoration, sign, show window or other openings. 
(c)  Live nudity prohibited. No person shall be permitted to appear live in any establishment, including an adult entertainment establishment, in a state of nudity as defined in this Chapter 2A. 
(d)  Erotic touching prohibited. No person in an adult entertainment establishment shall be permitted to place his or her hand or hands upon, touch with any part of his or her body, fondle in any manner, or massage, the breast, buttocks, genitals, or pubic region of any other person, whether or not such sexual or genital part of such other person is covered or clothed. 
(e)  Sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages prohibited. The sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages, as defined in Chapter 3, Article I, Section 3-1, of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview, on the premises of an adult entertainment establishment is prohibited 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 5115, § 1(Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-3. - Violations; penalties. 
    Any person who violates any provision of this Chapter 2A shall be guilty of a misdemeanor and shall, upon conviction, be subject to a fine of five hundred dollars ($500.00), or by imprisonment for a period of time not to exceed ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 4435, § 2, 2-9-93; Ord. No. 5115, § 1, 9-8-98) 
Secs. 2A-4-2A-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - ADULT PICTURE THEATERS 

Sec. 2A-21. - Regulations and requirements. 
(a)  Areas to be open to view. The aisles and hallways of any building used as an adult motion picture theater or an adult mini motion picture theater shall be constructed, located and maintained so that the whole length of any such aisle or hallway shall be open to view from the usual place occupied by the operator or cashier of such theater. 
(b)  Lighting required. The aisles or hallways of such theaters shall be so lighted at all times with illumination of adequate brightness so that the features of persons in such aisle or halls are clearly discernible from the position of the usual place occupied by the operator or cashier of such theater. 
(c)  Size and construction of viewing booths. Any cubicle, booth or room in an adult motion picture theater or adult mini motion picture theater used for the purpose of viewing of movie or video films or pictures of specified sexual activity or of specified anatomical areas shall be: 
(1)  Accessible at all times from the exterior and not able to be locked from the interior; 
(2)  Have at least one (1) door accessible from the principal hallway or aisle which door shall contain a window or opening of not less than eight (8) inches by eight (8) inches in size allowing clear two-way viewing into and out of such cubicle, room or booth, which such opening shall be not less than forty-eight (48) inches nor more than sixty-six (66) inches above the floor. 
(3)  So constructed that the interior of the doors and walls of such booths, cubicle or room shall be permanently made of or faced with metal, ceramic, or other materials so as to prevent the penetration or cutting through of any hole or opening between adjacent booths, cubicles, or rooms. 
(d)  Occupancy by more than one person prohibited. No cubicle, room or booth used for the purpose of private viewing of movie or video films or pictures of specified sexual activity or of specified anatomical areas shall be occupied at any time by more than one person. 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 5115, § 1(Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-22. - Duties of owners or operators. 
(a)  The owner or operator of any adult motion picture theater or adult mini motion picture theater shall cause to be posted in a conspicuous place at the entrance to each room, booth or cubicle in such theater a legible written notice of the provisions of this article prohibiting more than one person from occupying such room, booth or cubicle at the time and, in addition, stating that sexual activity, homosexual activity or any deviant sexual intercourse is prohibited in such theater. 
(b)  No owner or operator of any adult motion picture theater or adult mini motion picture theater, nor any person employed by such owner or operator in such theater, shall knowingly allow or permit any person to solicit for or engage in any overt sexual, homosexual or deviant sexual intercourse on the premises of such theater. 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 5115, § 1(Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Secs. 2A-23-2A-30. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - LOCATION AND DISTANCE REQUIREMENTS 

Sec. 2A-31. - Intent of article. 
    The special provisions of this article are intended to regulate the location of adult entertainment establishments as herein defined, by specifying districts in which such uses may be permitted and requirements for spatial separation of such uses. Nothing in this article shall be construed or interpreted to permit adult entertainment establishments in areas other than those set forth herein. 
    Adult entertainment establishments are hereby acknowledged to have special characteristics and impacts upon their surroundings, and upon the use and enjoyment of adjacent property. It is the intent of these regulations to provide for the confinement of adult entertainment establishments to those commercial and industrial areas in which these special impacts are judged to be least disruptive to the use and enjoyment of adjacent properties. These regulations are further intended to require that adult entertainment establishments shall not be permitted to locate in such concentrations that their operational features may establish the dominant character of any commercial or industrial areas. 
    These regulations are further intended to protect and balance lawful rights of expression with other lawful rights to the enjoyment and use of property, and are made with full consideration of the legal and constitutional issues heretofore adjudicated. 
    The provisions of this article shall govern the location and spatial separation of adult entertainment establishments in commercial districts and industrial districts, and no such regulated use, as defined, may be permitted except in conformance with these provisions. 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 5115, § 1(Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-32. - Location and spatial separation regulations. 
    Adult entertainment establishments, including but not limited to adult book stores, adult motion picture theaters, and adult mini motion picture theaters, as herein defined, are hereby declared to be regulated uses according to this article and their location and spatial separation shall be governed by rules as follows: 
(1)  Adult entertainment establishments may be located within a commercial zoning district or any industrial zoning district but not within one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet of any residential zoning district; 
(2)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be allowed to locate or expand within one thousand (1,000) feet of any other adult entertainment use or of any business licensed to sell or serve alcoholic beverages as defined in Chapter 3, Article I, of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview; 
(3)  No adult entertainment establishment shall be allowed to locate or expand within one thousand two hundred (1,200) feet of any school, religious institution or public park within the city; 
(4)  Any adult entertainment establishment which held a valid city occupational license on September 8, 1998, shall be exempt from the regulations imposed by this Article III. 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-33. - Measurement of distance. 
(a)  The distance between any two (2) adult entertainment establishments or between an adult entertainment establishment and a business selling or serving alcoholic beverages shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of each business. 
(b)  The distance between any adult entertainment establishment and any religious institution, school or public park or any property zoned for residential use shall be measured in a straight line, without regard to intervening structures, from the closest exterior structural wall of the adult entertainment establishment to the closest property line of the religious institution, school or public park or the property zoned for residential use. 
(Ord. No. 4409, § 2, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 5115, § (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Secs. 2A-34-2A-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - ADULT ENTERTAINMENT ESTABLISHMENT PERMIT AND EMPLOYEE LICENSE[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- The provisions of Art. IV, added by Ord. No. 5115, § 1, (Exh. A), adopted Sept. 8, 1998, have been renumbered by the editor to conform to the section numbering system used in this chapter. 

Sec. 2A-41. - Permit required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to operate, cause to be operated or maintain an adult entertainment establishment without a valid adult entertainment establishment permit issued by the city. A person commits a misdemeanor if he/she operates, causes to be operated or maintains an adult entertainment establishment without said permit or if said permit has been suspended or revoked. Said permit is required in addition to any other permits required by law. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any entertainer, server, employee, manager, operator or owner to knowingly perform any work, service or entertainment directly related to the operation of an adult entertainment establishment which does not hold a valid permit. 
(c)  The community development director or his/her designee shall be responsible for granting, denying, revoking, renewing, and suspending adult entertainment establishment permits for proposed or existing adult entertainment establishments. The community development director or his/her designee is also responsible for ascertaining whether a proposed adult entertainment establishment for which a permit is being applied complies with all locational requirements of this chapter and all applicable zoning laws and/or regulations now in effect or as amended or enacted subsequent to the effective date of this ordinance. The community development department shall also be responsible for inspecting a proposed permitted adult entertainment establishment in order to ascertain whether it is in compliance with applicable statutes and ordinances. 
(d)  The Grandview police department shall be responsible for providing information on whether an applicant has been convicted of a specified criminal act during the time period set forth. The Grandview Police Department may contact other law enforcement agencies as necessary to obtain relevant information in this regard. 
(e)  An application for a permit must be made on a form provided by the city. Any person desiring to operate an adult entertainment establishment shall file with the city clerk an original and two copies of a sworn permit application on the standard application form supplied by the city. The city clerk shall refer the filed application to the community development director for processing within three (3) days of filing. 
(f)  The completed application shall contain the following information and shall be accompanied by the following documents: 
(1)  If the applicant is: 
a.  An individual, the individual shall state his/her legal name, any aliases, and shall submit satisfactory proof that he/she is eighteen years of age; 
b.  A partnership, the partnership shall state its complete name, the names and current addresses of all partners, whether the partnership is general or limited, and shall provide a copy of the partnership agreement, if any; 
c.  A corporation or limited liability corporation, the corporation shall state its complete name, the date of its incorporation, evidence that the corporation is in good standing under the laws of Missouri, the names and capacity of all officers, directors and principal stockholders, the name of the registered corporate agent and the address of the registered office for service of process. 
(2)  Whether the applicant intends to operate the adult entertainment establishment under a name other than that of the applicant, and, if so the adult entertainment establishment's fictitious name. 
(3)  Whether the applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to this section has, within the two (2) or five (5) year period specified in section 2A-1(j) immediately preceding the date of the application, been convicted of a specified criminal act, and, if so, the specified criminal act involved, the date of conviction and the place of conviction. 
(4)  Whether the applicant or any other individual listed pursuant to this section holds any other permits and/or licenses under this article or other adult entertainment establishment ordinance from another city or county and, if so, the names and locations of such other businesses holding permits. 
(5)  Whether the applicant or any of the other individuals listed pursuant to this section and/or employees licensed under this article has had a previous permit under this article or other adult entertainment establishment ordinance from another city or county denied, suspended or revoked. The applicant shall include the name and location of the adult entertainment establishment for which the permit was denied, suspended or revoked, and the date of the denial, suspension or revocation. The applicant shall also include whether he/she or any other individuals listed pursuant to this section has been a partner in a partnership or an officer, director or principal stockholder of a corporation that holds a permit under this or similar article whose permit has previously been denied, suspended or revoked, including the name and location of the adult entertainment establishment for which the permit was denied, suspended or revoked as well as the date of denial, suspension or revocation. 
(6)  Whether the applicant operates an adult entertainment establishment in another city or county where a permit is not required, and, if so, the names and locations of such other businesses. 
(7)  The location of the proposed adult entertainment establishment, including a legal description of the property, street address, and telephone number(s), if any. 
(8)  The applicant's mailing address, residential address and current daytime telephone number. 
(9)  A photograph of the applicant(s) taken within six months of the application. 
(10)  The applicant's driver's license number, Social Security number, and his/her state or federally issued tax identification number. 
(11)  A sketch or diagram showing the configuration of the premises, including a statement of total floor space occupied by the business. The sketch or diagram need not be professionally prepared, but it must be drawn to a designated scale or drawn with marked dimensions of the interior of the premises to an accuracy of plus or minus six (6) inches. 
(12)  If a person who wishes to operate an adult entertainment establishment is an individual, he/she must sign the application for a permit as applicant. If a person who wishes to operate an adult entertainment establishment is other than an individual, each individual who has a ten (10) percent or greater interest in the business must sign the application for a permit as applicant. If a corporation is listed as owner of an adult entertainment establishment or as the entity which wishes to operate such a business, each individual having a ten (10) percent or greater interest in the corporation must sign the application for a permit as applicant. 
(13)  Any additional information required in the discretion of the community development director. 
(g)  Applicants for a permit under this section shall have a continuing duty to promptly supplement application information required by this section in the event that said information changes in any way from what is stated on the application. The failure to comply with said continuing duty within thirty (30) days from the date of such change, by supplementing the application on file with the city, shall be grounds for suspension of a permit. 
(h)  In the event that the community development director or his/her designee determines or learns at any time that the applicant has improperly completed the application for a proposed adult entertainment establishment, he/she shall promptly notify the applicant of such fact and allow the applicant ten (10) days to properly complete the application. The time period for granting or denying a permit shall be stayed during the period in which the applicant is allowed an opportunity to properly complete the application. 
(i)  The community development director may not issue a permit unless the applicant is qualified according to the provisions of this chapter and the premises have been inspected and found to be in compliance with health, fire and building codes and other applicable laws. 
(j)  The applicant shall be required to pay a non-refundable application fee of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) at the time of filing an application under this section. This fee is in addition to any other fees otherwise required by law. If the city issues a permit under this section, the one thousand dollar ($1,000.00) application fee shall also constitute the permit fee for the first year of operation. 
(k)  The fact that a person possesses other types of state or city permits and/or licenses does not exempt him/her from the requirement of obtaining an adult entertainment establishment permit where required by this article. 
(l)  By applying for a permit under this article the applicant shall be deemed to have consented to the provisions of this article and to the exercise by the community development director or his/her designee, the grandview police department, the grandview fire department and all other city agencies charged with enforcing the laws, ordinances and codes applicable in the city of their respective responsibilities under this chapter. 
(m)  The applicant shall provide the city with the names of any and all employees who are required to be licensed pursuant to section 2A-52 of this ordinance. This shall be a continuing requirement even after a permit is granted or renewed. 
(Ord. No. 5115, §1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-42. - Investigation. 
(a)  Upon receipt of an application properly filed with the city clerk and upon payment of the non-refundable application fee, the community development director shall immediately thereafter send photocopies of the application to the Grandview police department, Grandview fire department, and any other city agencies responsible for enforcement of health, fire and building codes and laws. Each department or agency shall promptly conduct an investigation of the applicant, application and the proposed adult entertainment establishment in accordance with its responsibilities under law and as set forth in this chapter. Said investigation shall be completed within twenty (20) days of receipt of the application by the community development department from the city clerk. At the conclusion of its investigation, each department or agency shall indicate on the photocopy of the application any code violations or pertinent facts which may result in denial of the application. The Grandview police department shall also be required to certify the criminal records request check mentioned at section 2A-41(d). 
(b)  The community development director shall disapprove an application if it finds that the proposed adult entertainment establishment will be in violation of any provision of any statute, code, ordinance, regulation or other law in effect in the city. 
(Ord. No. 5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-43. - Issuance of permit. 
(a)  The community development director or his/her designee shall grant or deny an application for a permit within thirty (30) days from the date of its proper filing. Upon the expiration of the thirtieth (30th) day, if the city has not acted on the application, the application shall be deemed granted and the applicant shall be permitted to begin operating the business for which the permit is sought. 
(b)  Grant of application for permit 
(1)  The community development director or his/her designee shall grant the permit unless one or more of the criteria set forth in subsection (c) below is present. 
(2)  The permit, if granted, shall state on its face the name of the person or persons to whom it is granted, the expiration date, and the address of the adult entertainment establishment. The permit shall also indicate that the adult entertainment establishment may be subject to prohibitions against Public Nudity and Indecency pursuant to the United States Supreme Court decision in Barnes v. Glen Theatre, Inc., 501 U.S. 560 (1991). The permit shall be posted in a conspicuous place at or near the entrance to the adult entertainment establishment so that it can be read easily at any time. 
(c)  Denial of application for permit 
(1)  The community development director or his/her designee, shall deny the application for any of the following reasons: 
a.  An applicant is under eighteen (18) years of age. 
b.  An applicant or an applicant's spouse is overdue on his/her payment to the city of taxes, fees, fines, or penalties assessed against him/her or imposed upon him/her. 
c.  An applicant's spouse or blood relative has either (1) been denied a permit by the City to operate an adult entertainment establishment within the preceding twelve (12) months; or (2) has had a permit to operate an adult entertainment establishment revoked within the preceding twelve (12) months. 
d.  An applicant has failed to provide information required by section 2A-41 or has falsely answered a question or request for information on the application form. 
e.  The premises to be used for the adult entertainment establishment have not been approved as being in compliance with health, fire and building codes by the department or agency responsible under law for investigating said compliance. 
f.  The application or permit fees required by this article have not been paid. 
g.  An applicant of the proposed business is in violation of, or is not in compliance with, any of the provisions of this chapter, including but not limited to the locational requirements for an adult entertainment establishment under Article III. 
h.  The granting of the application would violate a statute, ordinance, or court order. 
i.  The applicant has a permit under this article which has been suspended or revoked. 
j.  An applicant has been convicted of a specified criminal act, as defined in section 2A-1(j). 
1.  The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on disqualification of the applicant; 
2.  An applicant who has been convicted of a specified criminal act may qualify for an adult entertainment establishment permit only when the time period discussed in section 2A-1(j) has elapsed. 
k.  The applicant has an employee who does not have a valid license as required in section 2A-52 of this Ordinance. 
(2)  If the community development director or his/her designee denies the application, he/she shall notify the applicant of the denial and state the reasons(s) for the denial in writing. 
(3)  If a person applies for a permit for a particular location within a period of twelve (12) months from the date of denial of a previous application for a permit at the location, and there has not been an intervening change in the circumstances which could reasonably be expected to lead to a different decision regarding the former reasons for denial, the application shall be denied. 
(Ord. No.5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-44. - Inspection. 
(a)  An applicant or permittee shall allow representatives of the city, including but not limited to the community development department, the Grandview police department, the Grandview fire department or the county health department to inspect the premises of an adult entertainment establishment for the purpose of insuring compliance with the law, at any time such business is occupied or open for business. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful and a misdemeanor for a person who operates an adult entertainment establishment, regardless of whether or not a permit has been issued for said business under this article, or for his/her agent or employee to refuse to allow such lawful inspection of the premises at any time that it is occupied or open for business. 
(Ord. No.5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-45. - Annual renewal fee. 
    The annual fee for renewal of an adult entertainment establishment permit is five hundred dollars ($500.00). This fee is in addition to any other fees required by law and is non-refundable. 
(Ord. No.5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-46. - Expiration and renewal of permit. 
(a)  Each permit shall expire on the next June 30 following the date of issuance. Permits may be renewed by filing with the city clerk a renewal application provided by the city and by paying in full the renewal fee required by section 2A-45. The city clerk shall refer the application to the community development department for processing. Application for renewal shall be made at least thirty (30) days before the expiration date, and when made less than thirty (30) days before the expiration date, the expiration of the permit will not be affected. 
(b)  When the community development director or his/her designee denies renewal of the permit, the applicant shall not be issued a permit under this article until the community development director or his/her designee finds that the basis for denial of the renewal of the permit has been corrected. 
(Ord. No. 5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98; Ord. No. 5133, § 1, 10-27-98) 
Sec. 2A-47. - Suspension of permit. 
(a)  The community development director or his/her designee shall suspend a permit if he/she determines that a permittee, or an employee of a permittee, has: 
(1)  Violated or is not in compliance with any section of this chapter; or 
(2)  Been under the influence of alcoholic beverages or controlled substances while working in the adult entertainment establishment premises; or 
(3)  Refused to allow an inspection of the adult entertainment establishment premises as authorized by this Ordinance; or 
(4)  Knowingly violated or knowingly permitted a violation of any law by any person on the adult entertainment establishment premises; or 
(5)  Operated the adult entertainment establishment in violation of a building, fire, health, or zoning statute code, ordinance or regulation, whether federal, state or local, said determination being based on investigation by the division, department or agency charged with enforcing said rules or laws. In the event of such statute, code, ordinance or regulation violation, the city or its designee shall promptly notify the permittee of the violation and shall allow the permittee a seven (7) day period in which to correct the violation. If the permittee fails to correct the violation before the expiration of the seven (7) day period, the city or its designee shall forthwith suspend the permit and shall notify the permittee of the suspension. 
(6)  Engaged in permit transfer contrary to section 2A-50 of this article. In the event that the city or its designee, suspends a permit on the grounds that a permittee engaged in a permit transfer contrary to section 2A-50 of this ordinance, the community development director or his/her designee shall forthwith notify the permittee of the suspension. 
(7)  Knowingly employed a person who does not have a valid license as required in section 2A-52 of this Ordinance. 
(8)  Allowed the adult entertainment establishment to become a nuisance as defined by City ordinances. 
(b)  The suspension shall remain in effect until the violation of the statute, code, ordinance or regulation in question has been corrected, except that suspensions pursuant to subsections (2) and (4) of Section 2A-47(a) above shall be for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. 
(Ord. No.5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-48. - Revocation of permit. 
(a)  The community development director or his/her designee shall revoke a permit if an event causing suspension in section 2A-47 of this article occurs and the permit has already been suspended within the preceding twelve (12) months. 
(b)  The community development director or his/her designee, shall revoke a permit upon determining that: 
(1)  A permittee gave false or misleading information in the material submitted during the application process that tended to enhance the applicant's opportunity for obtaining a permit; or 
(2)  A permittee or an employee has knowingly allowed possession, use or sale of controlled substances in or on the premises; or 
(3)  A permittee or an employee has knowingly allowed prostitution on the premises; or 
(4)  A permittee or an employee knowingly operated the adult entertainment establishment during a period of time when the permittee's permit was suspended; or 
(5)  A permittee has been convicted of a specified criminal act for which the time period required in section 2A-1(j) of this chapter has not elapsed; or 
(6)  On two (2) or more occasions within a twelve (12) month period, a person or persons committed an offense, occurring in or on the permitted premises, constituting a specified criminal act for which a conviction has been obtained, and the person or persons were employees of the adult entertainment establishment at the time the offenses were committed. The fact that a conviction is being appealed shall have no effect on the revocation of the permit; or 
(7)  A permittee is convicted of tax violations for any taxes or fees related to an adult entertainment establishment; or 
(8)  A permittee or an employee has knowingly allowed any act of sexual intercourse, sodomy, oral copulation, masturbation, or any other specified sexual activities to occur in or on the permitted premises; or 
(9)  A permittee has been operating more than one sexually oriented business under a single roof. 
(c)  When the community development director or his/her designee revokes a permit, the revocation shall continue and the permittee shall not be issued an adult entertainment establishment permit until the community development director or his/her designee finds that the basis for revocation under this section has been corrected. The applicant shall not be granted a permit until at least ninety (90) days have elapsed since the date revocation became effective. 
(Ord. No. 5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-49. - Judicial review of permit denial, suspension or revocation. 
    After denial of an application, or denial of a renewal of an application, or suspension or revocation of a permit, the applicant or permittee may, within ten (10) days of the date of such denial, submit a written appeal to the board of aldermen, with right of hearing, by filing same with the city clerk for consideration at the next regular meeting of the board of aldermen. At a public hearing relating to suspension, revocation, or denial of a permit, the board of aldermen may, for good cause shown, continue the suspension or may revoke the permit. If the denial, suspension or revocation is affirmed upon review by the board of aldermen, the applicant may seek judicial review in the appropriate venue pursuant to RSMo. § 536.100. 
(Ord. No. 5115, §1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-50. - Transfer of permit. 
(a)  A permittee shall not operate an adult entertainment establishment under the authority of a permit at any place other than the address designated in the application for permit. 
(b)  A permittee shall not transfer his/her permit to another person. A person seeking an adult entertainment establishment permit for an existing business whose previous owner held a valid permit must comply with the requirements of section 2A-41. The applicant shall pay the permit application fee required by section 2A-41. 
(Ord. No. 5115, §1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-51. - Regulation of existing adult entertainment establishments. 
(a)  Any establishment operating as of the date of enactment of this article [Ord. No. 5115 enacted Sept. 8, 1998] which falls under the definition of adult entertainment establishment as that term is defined in section 2A-1(b) must comply with the permit procedure required by Section 2A-41 within thirty (30) days after the date of enactment of this article. 
(b)  Any establishment operating as of the date of enactment of this article whose application for an adult entertainment establishment permit is denied by the community development director for one of the reasons stated in section 2A-43 shall have two years from the date of the establishment's application for the permit to rectify the situation which caused the community development director to deny issuance of the permit. The establishment shall be allowed to operate under a provisional permit during the two (2) year period and must comply with all other requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Sec. 2A-52. - Adult entertainment establishment employee license. 
(a)  Each individual to be employed in an adult entertainment establishment shall be required to obtain an adult entertainment establishment employee license. Each applicant shall pay a license fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Said fee is to cover reasonable administrative costs of the licensing application process and is in addition to any other fees required by law. 
(b)  The community development director shall be responsible for granting, denying, revoking, renewing and suspending adult entertainment establishment employee licenses. 
(c)  Any applicant for an adult entertainment establishment employee license shall file with the city clerk an application on a form to be provided by the city. The applicant shall provide the following information: 
(1)  The applicant's name or any other names (including "stage" names) or aliases used by the individual; 
(2)  Age, date, and place of birth; 
(3)  Height, weight, hair and eye color; 
(4)  Present residence address and telephone number; 
(5)  Present business address and telephone number; 
(6)  State driver's license or identification number; 
(7)  Social Security number; 
(8)  Acceptable written proof that the individual is at least eighteen (18) years of age; 
(9)  Attached to the application form as provided above, a color photograph of the applicant clearly showing the applicant's face, and the applicant's fingerprints on a form provided by the Grandview police department. Any fees for the photographs and fingerprints shall be paid by the applicant; 
(10)  A statement detailing the license or permit history of the applicant for the five (5) years immediately preceding the date of the filing of the application. The statement shall include whether such applicant, in this or any other county, city, state, or country has ever had a license, permit, or authorization to do business denied, revoked, or suspended, or had any professional or vocational license or permit denied, revoked or suspended. In the event of any such denial, revocation, or suspension, the applicant shall state the date, the name of the issuing or denying jurisdiction, and describe in full the reasons for the denial, revocation, or suspension. A copy of any order of denial, revocation, or suspension shall be attached to the application; 
(11)  Whether the applicant has been convicted of a specified criminal act as defined in section 2A-1(j) of this chapter. This information shall include the date, place, nature of each conviction or plea of nolo contendere and identifying the convicting jurisdiction; and 
(12)  Any other information required in the discretion of the community development director. 
(d)  The city clerk shall refer the filed adult entertainment establishment employee license application to the Grandview police department for processing within three (3) days of filing. The city clerk shall also provide a copy of the application to the community development department. The Grandview police department shall conduct an investigation to verify the information contained on the application. The investigation shall be completed within ten (10) days from the date the completed application is filed, and a report shall be made to the community development director. Upon receiving the report, the community development director or his or her designee shall issue a license unless the report from the police department finds that one or more of the following findings is true: 
(1)  That the applicant has knowingly made any false, misleading, or fraudulent statement of a material fact in the application for a license, or in any report or record required to be filed with the sheriff's department or other department of the city; 
(2)  That the applicant is under eighteen (18) years of age; 
(3)  That the applicant has been convicted of a specified criminal act as defined in section 2A-1(j) of this chapter; 
(4)  That the adult entertainment establishment employee license is to be used for employment in a business prohibited by local or state law, statute, rule or regulation, or prohibited by particular provisions of this chapter; and 
(5)  That the applicant has had an adult entertainment establishment employee license revoked by the city within two (2) years of the date of the current application. 
(e)  Renewal of license: 
(1)  A license granted pursuant to this section shall be subject to annual renewal by the community development director or his or her designee upon the written application of the applicant filed with the city clerk and payment of the renewal fee. The city clerk shall refer the renewal application to the Grandview police department for processing within three (3) days of filing. The Grandview police department shall confirm to the community development director that the applicant has not been convicted of any specified criminal act as defined in section 2A-1(j) of this chapter or committed any act during the existence of the previous license period which would be grounds to deny the initial permit application. The community development director shall renew the adult entertainment establishment employee license after receiving the above confirmation from the Grandview police department. 
(2)  The renewal of the license shall be subject to payment of a fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). 
(f)  Suspension and/or revocation of license: An adult entertainment establishment employee license may be suspended or revoked pursuant to the procedures listed in sections 2A-47 and 2A-48. 
(Ord. No. 5115, § 1, (Exh. A), 9-8-98) 
Chapter 3 - ALCOHOLIC BEVERAGES 
ARTICLE I. - DEFINITIONS 

Sec. 3-1. - Enumeration. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following are defined as follows: 
    Adjacent property: Property immediately adjoining; except, that any intervening street, alley, highway or other public thoroughfare shall be disregarded. 
    Alcoholic beverages: Intoxicating liquor or malt liquor. 
    Amusement place: Any establishment whose business facility contains a square footage of at least six thousand (6,000) square feet, and where games of skill commonly known as billiards, volleyball, indoor golf, bowling or soccer are usually played, or has a dance floor of at least two thousand five hundred (2,500) square feet, or any outdoor golf course with a minimum of nine holes, and which has annual gross receipts of at least two hundred fifty thousand dollars ($250,000), of which at least forty-five per cent (45%) of such gross receipts is in nonalcoholic sales. 
State Law reference- Similar definition RSMo § 311.098.1 
    Church: Any building or structure regularly and primarily used as a place of worship by any organized religious society, organization or congregation, regardless of whether or not such building or structure was originally designed and constructed for such purpose. 
    Closed place: A place where all doors are locked and where no patrons are in the place or about the premises. 
    Coin-operated amusement device: Pinball machines, marble machines, music vending machines, pool tables or machines, coin-operated shuffleboards and any other devices operated by the insertion of a coin, disc or other insertion piece, whether or not also manipulated by the operator, and which operate for the amusement of the operator, whether or not by registering a score. It shall not include "slot machines," "claw machines" or machines prohibited by state law. It shall not include machines or devices used bona fide and solely for the vending of service, food, confections or merchandise. 
    C.O.L. licenses: A license for the consumption of alcoholic beverages in or upon premises which do not possess a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages and where food, beverages or entertainment are sold or provided for compensation as provided in section 311.480, Missouri Revised Statutes. 
    Dwelling: Any place that is used regularly or irregularly as a place of repose, sleep, rest or any place containing a bed, cot, divan, couch or any other article of furniture on which an adult person may recline. However, this shall not include any premises used as a hotel, motel or hotel room. 
    Event venue : Any establishment located within the Downtown Conservation District as established by Ordinance No. 6244 whose business facility is made available for rent to the public for social or commercial events at which food is served, such as weddings, banquets, business meetings and the like. 
    Fronts: As applied to the location of an alcoholic beverage establishment, shall refer to that street upon which the principal entrance of such alcoholic beverage establishment is located. 
    High density office building: An office building used exclusively for the administrative functions of business firms, professional groups or societies or any combination of such organization, under single ownership, and which shall be not less than four (4) stories high and shall have an occupancy of not less than four hundred (400) persons. 
    Intoxicating liquor or liquor: Alcohol for beverage purposes, alcoholic, spirituous, vinous, fermented, malt or other liquors or combination of liquors, a part of which is spirituous, vinous or fermented, and all preparations or mixtures for beverage purposes containing in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) per cent of alcohol by weight. 
    Licensee: The holder of all licenses issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Light wine: Any wine containing not in excess of fourteen (14) per cent of alcohol by weight exclusively from grapes, berries and other fruits and vegetables. 
    LLC: Limited liability company as defined in RSMo ch. 347. 
    Malt liquor: Any beer manufactured from pure hops or pure extract of hops, and pure barley malt or other wholesome grains or cereals and wholesome yeast and pure water, and free from all harmful substances, preservatives and adulterants, and having an alcoholic content in excess of three and two-tenths (3.2) per cent by weight, and not in excess of five (5) per cent by weight. 
    Managing officer: The person who is in active management and control, who may be designated by a corporation or LLC as the managing officer and who would be eligible as an individual to receive a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages, and who is a resident of the state for one (1) year. 
    Original package: One (1) container of not less than eight (8) ounces of any intoxicating liquor containing in excess of five (5) per cent alcohol by volume or three (3) or more standard containers of malt liquor. 
    Permittee: The holder of an employee's permit, issued under the provisions of this chapter. 
    Person: An individual, partnership, club or association, firm, corporation or LLC, unless the context requires a contrary interpretation. 
    Premises: The bounds of the enclosure where alcoholic beverages are sold or consumed. 
    Restaurant-bar: A restaurant-bar is any establishment having a restaurant or similar facility on the premises. 
    School: Any building which is regularly used as a public, private or parochial school, elementary school, high school, college, university, professional school, business or secretarial school. 
    Tax exempt organization: A charitable, fraternal, religious, service or veteran's organization which has obtained an exemption from the payment of federal income taxes as provided in Section 501(c)(3), 501(c)(4), 501(c)(5), 501(c)(8), 501(c)(10), 510(c)(19), or 501(d) of the United States Internal Revenue Code of 1986, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 1941, § 1; Ord. No. 3019, § 1, 4-13-82; Ord. No. 4950, § 1, 1-28-97; Ord. No. 5343, § 1, 12-26-00; Ord. No. 6332, § 1, 11-24-09; Ord. No. 6424, §§ 1, 2, 1-11-11; Ord. No. 6698, § 1, 8-12-14; Ord. No. 6870, § 1, 3-22-16; Ord. No. 7122, § 1, 12-11-18) 
Editor's note- Section 20 of Ord. No. 6332, adopted Nov. 24, 2009, states "This Ordinance shall apply to licenses and license renewals effective July 1, 2010. No new licenses for nonintoxicating beer shall be issued after the date of this Ordinance and any nonintoxicating beer licenses issued before the date of this Ordinance shall not be renewed for the license year beginning July 1, 2010." 
ARTICLE II. - DUTIES AND POWERS OF THE DEPARTMENT OF LIQUOR CONTROL[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 6499, adopted Oct. 11, 2011, changed the title of Art. II from "Duties and Powers of Director of Liquor Control and Board of Alderman" to "Duties and Powers of the Department of Liquor Control." 

Sec. 3-2. - Department of liquor control. 
(a)  There is hereby established a department within the city government to be known as the department of liquor control, which shall be administered by the city clerk. 
(b)  The department of liquor control shall consist of the city administrator, a director appointed by the city administrator from within the police department, and the city clerk. 
(c)  The department of liquor control shall have such duties, powers and authority as may be now or hereafter prescribed by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 1869, § 1; Ord. No. 6499, § 2, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-3. - Records, reports, forms. 
    It shall be the duty of the city clerk to keep a record of all licenses and permits issued to applicants, and of the suspension and revocation thereof. The city clerk shall make a full report to the city administrator at the end of each fiscal year. 
    The city clerk shall prescribe, with the approval of the city administrator, all forms of applications, licenses and permits in compliance with the provisions of this chapter and such other forms as are necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 1869, § 2; Ord. No. 6499, § 3, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-4. - Regulations. 
    The city administrator shall have the power to make such reasonable rules, regulations, orders and directions as may be necessary and feasible for the operation of the department of liquor control and as are not inconsistent with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 4, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-5. - Inspections; impoundment of objects. 
(a)  At the request of the city administrator or city clerk, the director of liquor control or any other member of the police department shall have the right, at any reasonable time, to inspect and the licensee shall allow inspection of any licensed premises and all portions of the buildings thereof, including all rooms, cellars, outbuildings, passageways, closets, vaults, yards, attics and all buildings used in connection with the operations carried on under such license and which are in his possession, or under his control, and all places where they keep or have liquor stored, and to seize any and all objects which may appear to be in violation of any provisions of this chapter and hold in custody such objects as evidence until any matter pertaining thereto is finally adjudicated. Upon such seizure, a receipt shall be given and upon demand, if not forfeited, objects shall be returned to their lawful owner after the matter is finally adjudicated unless the same are found to be contraband. If such objects are not claimed by their lawful owner within ninety (90) days after final adjudication, they shall be deemed forfeited. The board of aldermen shall conduct a hearing to determine whether objects seized are contraband. 
(b)  If such objects seized are found to be contraband, they shall remain in custody of the police department. All contraband and unclaimed objects shall be sold by the purchasing manager at public or private auction semiannually. All funds derived from such sales shall go to the city employee's welfare fund to be expended as directed by the board of aldermen. The purchasing manager shall have power to pay any fees required by the state or federal government as a result of such sale. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 5, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-6. - Examination of books, records, papers; hearings on complaints. 
    The city clerk shall have the right to examine books, records and papers of each licensee or applicant for a license or renewal thereof, and to report thereon to the board of aldermen. The board of aldermen shall have the power to hear and determine complaints against any licensee or applicant for a license. For such purposes, it shall have the power to issue subpoenas and all necessary processes to subpoena witnesses; to compel by subpoena duces tecum the production of books, records, papers and other evidence; to administer oaths and to take testimony; to make findings of fact thereon and to report to the state supervisor of liquor control the results thereof; and may recommend to such supervisor the suspension, revocation or cancellation of any license issued under the laws of the state. It shall have the power to suspend or revoke any license granted under the terms of this chapter, pursuant to the provisions hereof, for any violation hereof. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 6, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-7. - Suspension or revocation of license or permit. 
(a)  Scope of authority. Whenever it shall be shown or whenever the city clerk has knowledge that: 
(1)  A licensee or permittee under this chapter has not at all times maintained an orderly place; or 
(2)  Such licensee or any employee, agent or servant of such licensee has violated any of the provisions of this chapter; or 
(3)  The license or permit held by such person was obtained through materially false statements in the application for such license or permit, or renewal thereof; or 
(4)  The licensee or permittee failed to make a complete disclosure of all pertinent information in the application for such license or permit, renewal thereof; or 
(5)  The licensee, since the issuance of such license, has ceased to be the person actually engaged in the active control and management of the particular establishment for which the license was issued; or 
(6)  The licensed premises has been discontinued or abandoned and that after five (5) days' written notice, the licensee has failed to respond or satisfactorily explain; or 
(7)  Anything has occurred which would render the licensee or permittee or licensed premises ineligible or unsuitable for a license or permit under the provisions of this chapter; 
then the city clerk shall report same to the board of aldermen, and may, in his or her discretion, file a formal complaint thereon with the board of aldermen. The board of aldermen may suspend for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days, or revoke, the license or permit issued hereunder, or in the case of an original application for a license or permit, refuse to issue the license or permit. The failure of an employee to secure a proper permit, as required by this chapter, shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the retail license unless it can be shown by the retail licensee that he had no knowledge of such violation and did not contribute thereto. 
(b)  Hearing required. The board of aldermen, after not less than 15 days' notice, shall hold a hearing to ascertain all facts in the matter. Such notice shall be in writing and shall set out reasons for the hearing and conditions under which the hearing may be held, and shall be served upon the person to whom the license or permit is issued or by mailing such notice by certified or registered mail to the person to whom the license or permit is issued at his last known business or residence address. 
(c)  Hearing procedure. The applicant, licensee or permittee shall have full right to have counsel, to produce witnesses and cross-examine all witnesses who may appear against him. All proceedings in such hearings may be taken down stenographically, or recorded mechanically or electronically, or a combination thereof, and shall be transcribed whenever required by law. Subpoenas shall be issued by the city clerk for any witness whose presence is desired at any hearing or proceeding before the board of aldermen to suspend or revoke a license or permit, or to issue or refuse a license or permit or renewal thereof, and such subpoena may be served by the director of liquor control, or by any member of the police department, or any other qualified person. Such subpoenas shall be served and return thereon shall be made in the same manner as is provided by law in civil suits in the circuit court of this state. 
    Witnesses may also appear voluntarily at such hearings and testify. Before any witness shall testify in any such hearing or proceeding, he shall be sworn by the mayor to tell the truth and nothing but the truth. The board of aldermen shall make a finding and order on facts and law. No suspension or revocation shall become effective until 10 days after the finding and order have been made by the board of aldermen. 
(d)  Effect of revocation. Whenever any license or permit shall be revoked under the terms and provisions of this chapter, the licensee shall not thereafter be eligible for any license; provided, however, that in the case of the revocation of any employee's permit, the director shall have the discretion thereafter to issue any type permit. 
(e)  Administrative liability. No officer, agent or employee of the city shall render himself personally liable for any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this chapter. Any suit brought against any officer, agent or employee of the city as a result of any act required or permitted in the discharge of his duties under this chapter shall be defended by the city attorney or special counsel until the final determination of the proceedings therein. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 7, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-8. - Subpoenas. 
(a)  The failure or refusal of any person to obey all the terms and conditions of the subpoena issued by the city clerk is hereby declared to be a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof, such person shall be punished, as hereinafter provided. 
(b)  Upon information by the city attorney or special counsel that any person has failed or refused to obey all the terms and conditions of the subpoena or subpoena duces tecum issued by the city clerk, a warrant shall be issued for the arrest of the person complained against, which warrant shall be directed to the chief of police or the sheriff or any constable of the county, and shall be executed by him or any officer or member of the police force, or the director of liquor control. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-9. - Temporary closing of premises. 
    Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the director shall have the power to close for a period not to exceed 24 hours, any premises which may be in the immediate area of a mob, riot, strike or any type of violence, actual or probable; provided, however, that he may not close such place under such circumstances without advising, at the earliest possible moment, the city administrator or the mayor and board of aldermen; and provided further, that the director may not close such place for two or more consecutive 24 hour periods without approval of the city administrator, or the mayor, acting under his emergency police powers. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-10. - Violation of orders. 
    Any licensee who shall have had his license suspended by order of the board of aldermen shall not sell or give away any intoxicating liquor, nor shall he order or accept delivery of any intoxicating liquor during the period of time such order of suspension is in effect. Any licensee desiring to keep his premises open for the sale of food or merchandise during such period of suspension shall display the order of suspension issued by the board of aldermen in a conspicuous place on the premises so that all persons visiting the premises may readily see the same. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6332, § 2, 11-24-09) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
ARTICLE III. - LICENSES GENERALLY 

Sec. 3-11. - Required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, sell, solicit orders for the sale, or deliver, at wholesale or retail, alcoholic beverages, or allow the consumption of such beverages in or upon any premises where food, beverages or entertainment are sold or provided for compensation, within the limits of the city without first obtaining a license. 
    No licensee permitted under the provisions of this chapter shall operate in excess of any licenses granted. Whenever a manufacturer or wholesaler's place of business is wholly located outside the corporate limits of the city, no fee shall be charged for a license, but a license shall be issued as required by this chapter and such licensee shall be subject to all other regulations and restrictions as provided for in this chapter. 
    Notwithstanding any other law to the contrary, any caterer who possesses a valid state and valid local liquor license may deliver alcoholic beverages in the city, in the course of his or her catering business, and need not obtain a separate liquor license from the City of Grandview. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 5414, § 1, 8-28-01) 
Sec. 3-12. - License violations. 
(a)  False statements. It shall be unlawful for any person in obtaining or attempting to obtain a license, to make nay materially false statements in the application for such license. 
(b)  Incomplete information. It shall be unlawful for any person to fail to make a complete disclosure of all pertinent and material information required in the application for a license. 
(c)  Assignment, transfer prohibited. All licenses issued pursuant to the terms of this chapter are personal and it shall be unlawful for such licenses to be assigned or transferred. 
(d)  Illegally secured alcoholic beverages. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to allow on his licensed premises any alcoholic beverage which he has purchased or secured in violation of any city, state or federal ordinance or statute. 
(e)  Change in conditions. It shall be unlawful for a person to continue to hold an alcoholic beverage license when conditions have occurred which would render such licensee or the licensed premises ineligible or unsuitable for such license under the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
ARTICLE IV. - CLASSIFICATION OF LICENSES AND LICENSE FEES 

Sec. 3-13. - Terms; due dates; prorating of fees. 
(a)  All license fees for sales-by-drink licenses and C.O.L. licenses as provided for in this chapter shall be due and payable on or before the first day of July of each year, and shall be good for the year beginning July 1 and ending June 30. If such license is originally issued after July 1, the applicant shall pay one-twelfth of such fee for each month, or fraction thereof, remaining in the twelve-month period. 
(b)  All license fees for original package licenses and all license fees for manufacturing or sale at wholesale licenses shall be due and payable on or before the first day of July of each year and shall be good for the year beginning July 1st and ending June 30th. If such a license is originally issued after July 1st, the applicant shall pay one-twelfth of such fee for each month, or fraction thereof, remaining in the twelve-month period. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-14. - Classes of licenses. 
    The classes of licenses described in sections 3-15 through 3-33 are hereby created, for the manufacture and sale of intoxicating liquor, malt liquor, at wholesale and retail and C.O.L. licenses, for which the fees herein prescribed shall be charged. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6332, § 3, 11-24-09) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
Sec. 3-15. - Full sales-by-drink. 
    A license shall be issued to all applicants who have complied with this chapter, licensing such applicants to sell all kinds of alcoholic beverages at retail by the drink for consumption on the licensed premises upon payment to the city clerk for each such license the sum of four hundred fifty dollars ($450.00) per year. No waiver of any part of the license fee shall be granted to any applicant. Such license shall also include the privilege of selling alcoholic beverages in the original package on the licensed premises. Such licenses shall be divided into the following classifications, which fact shall be stated on the face of the license: 
(a)  Hotels, apartment hotels, motels, inns, lodges or similar places providing principally transient residential accommodations and having at least forty (40) rooms for overnight accommodation. 
(b)  Restaurant-bar. 
(c)  Tax exempt organizations. 
(d)  Amusement places. 
(e)  All other full sales-by-drink licenses. 
(f)  Event venues. 
(Ord. No. 1941, § 2; Ord No. 2011, § 1; Ord. No. 4950, § 2, 1-28-97; Ord. No. 5343, § 2, 12-26-00; Ord. No. 6870, § 2, 3-22-16; Ord. No. 7122, § 2, 12-11-18) 
Sec. 3-16. - Malt liquor and light wine sales-by-drink. 
    A license shall be issued to all applicants who have complied with this chapter, licensing such applicants to sell malt liquor and light wine at retail by-the-drink for consumption upon the licensed premises, upon payment to the city collector for each such license of fifty-two dollars and fifty cents ($52.50) per year. Such license shall also include the privilege of selling malt liquor and light wine in the original package on the licensed premises. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 3019, § 2, 4-13-82; Ord. No. 6332, § 4, 11-24-09) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
Sec. 3-16.1. - Temporary permit for intoxicating liquor. 
(a)  A temporary permit may be issued by the Board of Aldermen or its designee to any person holding a license for intoxicating liquor by-the-drink or malt liquor and light wine by-the-drink pursuant to RSMo §§ 311.200(4) or (5), to furnish provisions and service for use at a particular function, occasion, or event at a particular location in the City of Grandview other than the licensed premises, effective for a period not to exceed one hundred twenty (120) consecutive hours. Said permit shall authorize the service of intoxicating liquor by the drink at such function, occasion, or event during the hours at which alcoholic beverages may be lawfully sold or served upon premises licensed to sell alcoholic beverages for on-premises consumption in the city. For every permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this section, the permittee shall pay to the city collector the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) for each calendar day, or fraction thereof, for which the permit is issued. 
(b)  Applicants for a temporary permit whose licensed premises are located outside the city limits of the City of Grandview shall submit a copy of their valid State of Missouri liquor permit with their application. 
(c)  All provisions of chapter 3 of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview shall extend to the premises on which the function, occasion, or event for which the temporary permit was issued is held and shall be in force and enforceable during all the time that the permittee, its agents, servants, employees, or stock are on such premises. 
(Ord. No. 4491, § 1, 7-27-93; Ord. No. 5798, § 1, 8-10-04; Ord. No. 7075, § 1, 5-22-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7075, § 1, adopted May 22, 2018, changed the title of § 3-16.1 from "Temporary permit for malt liquor" to "Temporary permit for intoxicating liquor." 
Sec. 3-16.2. - Malt liquor sales-by-drink. 
    A license shall be issued to all applicants who have complied with this chapter, licensing such applicants to sell malt liquor at retail by-the-drink for consumption on the licensed premises, upon payment to the city collector for each such license the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per year. Any applicant licensed pursuant to this subsection may also sell malt liquor at retail on Sunday between the hours established in Section 3-68 for retail by-the-drink licenses. 
(Ord. No. 5750, § 2, 4-13-04; Ord. No. 6332, § 5, 11-24-09) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates.
