Sec. 3-17.1. - Limited permit to sell intoxicating liquor authorized. 
    Notwithstanding any other provisions of this Code, a permit for the sale of intoxicating liquor by the drink, for consumption on premises where sold, may be issued to any church, school, civic, service, fraternal, veteran, political or charitable club or organization for the sale of such intoxicating liquor by the drink at a picnic, bazaar, fair, or similar gathering. Such permit shall be issued only for the day or days named therein and it shall not authorize the sale of intoxicating liquor for more than seven (7) days by any such club or organization described above. For each such permit issued, the permittee or licensee shall pay to the city collector the sum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00). All other provisions of the permit shall be in compliance with RSMo § 311.482. 
(Ord. No. 2265, § 1, 9-8-75; Ord. No. 6169, § 1, 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6332, § 7, 11-24-09; Ord. No. 7075, § 2, 5-22-18) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7075, § 2, adopted May 22, 2018 changed the title of § 3-17.1 from "Limited permit to sell malt liquor authorized" to "Limited permit to sell intoxicating liquor authorized." 
 See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo § 312.135. 
Sec. 3-18. - C.O.L. consumption of alcoholic beverages. 
    A C.O.L. license shall allow the consumption of alcoholic beverages during the hours alcoholic beverages can be sold by full sales-by-drink licensees. 
(a)  For every C.O.L. license for clubs, organizations or associations which are private and nonprofit, where either food, beverage or entertainment is provided for compensation in the form of dues, fees or special assessments, the licensee shall pay the city collector ninety dollars ($90.00) per year. 
(b)  For every C.O.L. license for commercial establishments or establishments which are commercial in nature, where either food, beverage or entertainment is provided for compensation of any kind, the licensee shall pay the city collector ninety dollars ($90.00) per year. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-19. - Full original package sales. 
    A license shall be issued to all applicants who have complied with this chapter, licensing such applicants to sell at retail alcoholic beverages in the original package on the licensed premises, upon payment to the city collector for each such license of the sum of one hundred dollars ($100.00) per year. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 5746, § 1, 3-23-04) 
Sec. 3-19.1. - Special tasting permit for wine and malt beverages. 
    A special permit may be issued by the board of aldermen to any person licensed to sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail under section 3-19 of this chapter to conduct wine, malt beverage and distilled spirit tastings on the licensed premises. The fee for said license shall be an additional twenty-five dollars ($25.00) a year payable to the city at the same time and manner as other license fees. Nothing in this section shall be construed to permit the licensee to sell wine, malt beverages or distilled spirits for on-premises consumption. 
(Ord. No. 5321, § 1, 10-24-00; Ord. No. 6112, § 1, 7-10-07) 
Sec. 3-20. - Malt liquor original package sales. 
    A license shall be issued to all applicants who have complied with this chapter, licensing such applicants to sell at retail malt liquor in the original package on the licensed premises, upon payment to the city collector for each such license of the sum of seventy-five dollars ($75.00) per year. Any applicant licensed pursuant to this subsection may also sell malt liquor at retail on Sunday between the hours established in section 3-68 for original package Sunday sales licenses. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 5746, § 2, 3-23-04; Ord. No. 5750, § 1, 4-13-04; Ord. No. 6332, § 8, 11-24-09)

No. 5343, § 4, adopted Dec. 26, 2000; Ord. No. 5457, § 1, adopted Feb. 12, 2002; Ord. No. 5746, § 3, adopted Mar. 23, 2004; and Ord. No. 6879, § 1, adopted Mar. 22, 2016. 
Sec. 3-34. - Condition of license. 
    As a condition precedent to the issuance of a license under the provisions of this chapter, the applicant must also procure a permit and license from the State of Missouri, under the provisions of Chapters 311 and 312 of the Missouri Revised Statutes. 
(Ord. No. 1941, § 4) 
ARTICLE V. - QUALIFICATION OF LICENSEE 

Sec. 3-35. - Individuals. 
    No license provided for by this chapter shall be issued to or renewed for any individual except in conformity with the following: 
(a)  That such individual is to be in fact actively engaged in the actual control and management of the particular alcoholic beverages or C.O.L. establishment for which a license is sought. 
(b)  That such individual is twenty-one (21) years of age or over, a citizen of the United States, and a qualified legal voter and a taxpaying citizen of the State of Missouri, who is current in the payment of all taxes. 
(c)  That such person is of good moral character, has never been convicted of a felony, is qualified to hold an alcoholic beverage license in the state, and that such person has never been the holder of an alcoholic beverage license or permit which has been revoked by the city or the state except as stated in section 3-7(d). 
(d)  Full original package sales licenses shall not be issued to or renewed for any applicant who operates a gasoline service station selling gasoline or diesel fuel, motor vehicle repair garage, or motor propelled vehicle race track on the premises to be licensed, unless said applicant conforms to each of the following minimum requirements: 
(i)  The business shall contain no less than fourteen hundred (1,400) square feet of sales display area, exclusive of storage rooms and walk-in refrigeration coolers; and 
(ii)  The business shall keep and maintain a stock of no less than one thousand (1,000) distinguishable and separate products for sale, exclusive of liquor, beer, cigarettes and gasoline; and 
(iii)  The business shall have and keep a stock of goods having a value, according to invoices, of at least seven thousand five hundred dollars ($7,500.00) exclusive of liquor, beer, cigarettes and gasoline. 
(e)  For purposes of establishing these qualifications, the applicant shall provide documentation as may be required by the city clerk, including but not limited to, receipts for payment of taxes or evidence of exemption from the payment of taxes. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 2011, § 3; Ord. No. 2357, §§ 1, 2, 7-27-76; Ord. No. 2383, § 1, 10-12-76; Ord. No. 3355, § 1, 5-28-85; Ord. No. 6499, § 9, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-36. - Partnerships. 
    No license provided for in this chapter shall be issued to or renewed for any partnership unless all members of the partnership are persons who would be eligible for licenses as individuals under the provisions of this chapter, and no such license shall be issued to or renewed for any partnership, any partner of which has been the holder of a license or permit which has been revoked by the city or the state, except as stated in section 3-7(d). 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 10, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-37. - Corporations or LLCs. 
    No license provided for in this chapter shall be issued to or renewed for any corporation or LLC except in conformity with the following: 
(a)  That all officers and directors of such corporation or members of such LLC are persons of good moral character. 
(b)  That the managing officer of the corporation or LLC is a person who is eligible for a license as an individual under the provisions of this chapter, including but not limited to, section 3-35. 
(c)  That such corporation or LLC has not been the holder of a license or permit which has been revoked by the city or the state, except as stated in section 3-7(d). 
(d)  The corporation or LLC shall provide documentation as may be required by the city clerk to establish that the corporation or LLC is current in its payment of any taxes owed to the City of Grandview or for the benefit of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6424, § 3, 1-11-11; Ord. No. 6499, § 11, 10-11-11) 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 6424, adopted Jan. 11, 2011, changed the title of § 3-37 from "Corporations" to "Corporations or LLCs." 
ARTICLE VI. - EMPLOYEE'S PERMIT 

Sec. 3-38. - Requirement; exceptions. 
(a)  Requirement. Except as provided in subsections (c) and (f) of this section and section 3-38.1, all persons employed in the retail sale, dispensation, service or delivery of alcoholic beverages or on C.O.L. licensed premises must be twenty-one (21) years of age or older and must obtain a permit to do so from the director of liquor control; except that no permit shall be required of a person employed solely as a cashier on a by-the-drink premises where substantial quantities of food are sold. 
(b)  Obtaining permit. Each applicant must make written application and be fingerprinted by the director of liquor control and furnish the director of liquor control four (4) identifying photographs of him/herself. Upon application, each applicant shall pay the sum of ten dollars ($10.00) and provide the director with a letter of intent to hire from an authorized representative of the licensed business desiring to employ the applicant. If the applicant meets the applicable requirements of the city and the state, and if there are no outstanding arrest warrants for the applicant, then such applicant will be issued a permit good for one year from the date of application. Upon expiration of the permit, the applicant may obtain a new permit in the same manner as herein provided. The fee for an employee replacement work permit shall be five dollars ($5.00). 
(c)  Minor permits. Minors may be permitted to work on licensed premises as follows: 
(1)  Persons aged sixteen (16) and seventeen (17) may be permitted to work on premises where substantial quantities of food are sold so long as such persons do not sell or assist in the retail sale, dispensation, service or delivery of alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  Persons aged eighteen (18) through twenty (20) may be permitted to work as a waiter or waitress and accept payment for or serve intoxicating liquor on premises where substantial quantities of food are sold; provided that nothing in this subsection shall authorize persons under twenty-one (21) years of age to mix intoxicating beverages or serve intoxicating beverages across the bar. 
(3)  Persons aged eighteen (18) through twenty (20) may be permitted to work in businesses licensed to sell liquor in the original package where at least fifty (50) per cent of the gross sales made consists of goods, merchandise or commodities other than package liquor, including but not limited to grocery stores, drugstores and convenience stores, but only for the purpose of accepting payment for such package liquor and stocking, arranging displays, and sacking for carry out package liquor. Delivery of intoxicating liquor away from the licensed business premises cannot be performed by anyone under the age of twenty-one (21) years. 
(4)  Additional permitting requirements for minors. In addition to the application requirements set out in subsection (b), applicants aged sixteen (16) and seventeen (17) shall also furnish a written consent signed by a parent or legal guardian on a form furnished by the director. Such signature shall be notarized or such parent or legal guardian may appear in the office of the director and sign the consent in the presence of the director. The director or his designee shall then witness and acknowledge the signature of the parent or legal guardian. All such consents shall be accompanied by the minor's birth certificate and both such consent and a copy of the birth certificate shall remain on file and as a record of the director of liquor control. After the consent and birth certificate have been submitted, such person shall be issued a permit card. 
(d)  Form, content. All permit cards shall bear the name, physical description, thumbprint and photograph of the applicant and such other information that the liquor control director might lawfully require. Permit cards shall be serialized and laminated to prevent forgery, alteration and deterioration. 
(e)  Transfer prohibited. A permit card is personal to the holder thereof, and it shall be unlawful for the holder thereof to transfer such card to another person for any purpose made unlawful by the laws of the city, state or federal government. The permit card shall be kept available by the employer-licensee or the lawful holder thereof to be shown on demand to a police officer, liquor investigator or other person authorized by law to inspect same. In the case of permits issued to persons aged sixteen (16) and seventeen (17), possession of the permit card by the lawful owner shall be prima facie evidence that such person is of the age stated on such permit card and has the lawful consent of his parent or legal guardian to be employed on the licensed liquor premises. 
(f)  Package premises exception. No permit shall be required for any person to be employed in an establishment licensed under provisions of this chapter to sell liquor in the original package so long as such person does not, in any way, assist in the retail sale, dispensation, service or delivery of alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 3179, § 1, 9-15-83; Ord. No. 3473, § 1, 3-25-86; Ord. No. 6698, § 2, 8-12-14; Ord. No. 7136, § 1, 2-26-19) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6698, § 2, adopted Aug. 12, 2014, changed the title of § 3-38 from "Required" to read as set out herein. 
Sec. 3-38.1. - Limited license employee permit not required. 
    Other provisions of the Code of the City of Grandview, Missouri, notwithstanding, any licensee for a limited license or permit to sell intoxicating liquor by the drink may designate not to exceed twenty (20) persons, who shall be members of the organization to whom such limited permit or license is issued and who shall be at least twenty-one (21) years of age, to sell and dispense intoxicating liquor by the drink authorized by such organization's limited permit and license. No employee's permit shall be required for such designated members of the organization. 
(Ord. No. 7136, § 2, 2-26-19) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7136, § 2, adopted Feb. 26, 2019, amended § 3-38.1 in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former § 3-38.1 pertained to authorized for limited license or permit, no fee, and derived from Ord. No. 2265, § 2, adopted Sept. 18, 1975; Ord. No. 6169, § 2, adopted Feb. 12, 2008; Ord. No. 6223, § 1, adopted Sept. 2, 2008; and Ord. No. 6332, § 15, adopted Nov. 24, 2009. See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
Sec. 3-39. - Permit violations. 
(a)  No permit. It shall be unlawful for any retail licensee to have in his employ to sell or assist in the retail sale, dispensation, service or delivery of alcoholic beverages any person who does not have an employee's permit issued by the department of liquor control. 
(b)  False representation. It shall be unlawful for any person to use or possess any false or falsified employee's permit issued, or purporting on its face to have been issued, by the department of liquor control for the purpose of using such permit to obtain employment in, or to purchase alcoholic beverages from any premises granted a license under the provisions of this chapter, or to misrepresent to any licensee, his agent, servant or employee, or to the director of liquor control, his authorized agents or any member of the police department, such person's age to be twenty-one (21) years or older. 
(c)  Falsifying permit. It shall be unlawful for any person to manufacture, forge, reproduce in any way or to otherwise falsify an employee's permit issued, or purporting on its face to have been issued by the department of liquor control, or to give, lend, sell or otherwise provide to any person a false, falsified, manufactured, forged or reproduced employee's permit issued by the department of liquor control. 
(d)  Use of another's permit. It shall be unlawful for any lawful holder of an employee's permit issued by the department of liquor control to give, lend, sell or otherwise provide such permit to any other person, or for any person not the lawful holder of such permit to use the same for any purpose declared to be unlawful by the provisions of this article, or to give, lend, sell or otherwise provide such permit to any other person. 
(e)  Penalty. Any person found guilty of violating the provisions of this article shall be fined in a sum of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by a sentence of not less than three (3) months, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - APPLICATION FOR LICENSE 

Sec. 3-41. - Generally. 
(a)  Form and contents. Any person desiring to secure a license under the terms of this chapter shall make application therefor to the city clerk, in writing, and under oath. Each question in the application blank shall be considered material to the issuance of the license, and each question in such application must be answered in full by the applicant. Such applicant shall state: 
(1)  The name and residential address of the applicant or applicants and if the application is on behalf of a partnership, the names and residential addresses of all partners or any person who has a financial interest in such partnership. If the application is on behalf of a corporation, the date of incorporation, the state in which incorporated, the amount of paid-in capital, the amount of authorized capital, the names and residential addresses of the officers and directors and the names and addresses of all stockholders who hold ten (10) per cent or more of the capital stock shall be given. If the application is on behalf of an LLC, the date of organization, the state in which organized, and the names and residential addresses of all members who hold ten (10) per cent or more of the total membership interest in the LLC. 
(2)  The place of birth of the applicant or applicants and if the applicant is a naturalized citizen, the date and place of naturalization. 
(3)  The names and business addresses of the applicant's employers for a period of five (5) years prior to the application. 
(4)  Whether or not the applicant or applicants have been convicted of a felony. 
(5)  The location, place or premises for which a license is sought. 
(6)  Whether or not the proposed location, place or premises is within three hundred (300) feet of a school or church if application is for a bar classified in accordance with section 3-15(e) or within one hundred (100) feet of a school or church if application is for all other license classifications in section 3-15(a), (b), (c) and (d). 
(7)  The class of the license for which application is made. 
(8)  Whether or not any distiller, wholesaler, wine maker, brewer or supplier of coin-operated, commercial, manual or mechanical amusement devices or the employees, officers or agents thereof, have any financial interest in the retail business of the applicant for the sale of alcoholic beverages, or C.O.L. and whether or not the applicant, either directly or indirectly, will borrow or accept from any such persons equipment, money, credit or property of any kind except ordinary commercial credit for liquor sold. 
(9)  A complete description of the plans, specifications and fixtures in the applicant's proposed place of business, if the application is for a retail license; provided, however, that this shall apply only when application is for a new location or change in the plans for specifications within a previously established location. 
(10)  That the applicant will not violate any of the ordinances of the city, the laws of the state or of the United States, in the conduct of the business. 
(11)  A comprehensive and informative statement as the city clerk may deem necessary, to disclose the true ownership and management of the business and any further reasonable information required by the city clerk or the city administrator. 
(b)  Fingerprints and photographs. All applicants for licenses under this chapter shall be fingerprinted by the director of liquor control and shall furnish to the city clerk a recent photograph identification, passport size, together with the application. If the applicant is a partnership, all partners shall furnish recent photograph identifications and all partners shall be fingerprinted, as directed above. If the applicant is a corporation or LLC, the managing officer shall be fingerprinted and shall furnish the city clerk a recent photograph identification of himself or herself. The city clerk, in his or her discretion, may make similar requirements of the officers, directors, shareholders and/or members holding more than a ten (10) per cent interest in such corporation or LLC. 
(c)  Execution by applicant. Application for a license under this chapter shall be made by the individual who is to be, in fact, engaged in the control and management of the alcoholic beverage or C.O.L. establishment for which such license is sought. 
(d)  Supplemental reports. The licensee, upon request of the city clerk, shall file a supplemental report within fifteen (15) days, of any loan made to the licensee of money or credit relating directly to or indirectly to the licensed business. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6424, § 4, 1-11-11; Ord. No. 6499, § 12, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-42. - Investigation of applicants. 
(a)  Liquor control investigation. The city clerk shall cause an immediate investigation of to be made of the statements contained in each new application for an alcoholic beverage license as well as the character, background, associates, financial investments and indebtedness of the applicant. The suitability of the location and surrounding conditions of the proposed premises shall also be investigated. 
(b)  Police investigation. Upon receipt of an application, the city clerk shall immediately request that the Grandview Police Department perform a criminal history record investigation of the applicant pursuant to section 13-30 of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
(c)  Subsequent fire and building inspections. The city clerk may, at any reasonable time, request the directors of fire and community development departments, through their duly authorized agents and employees, to make investigations of licensed premises and the equipment and furnishings thereon to determine if the premises are in compliance with all the requirements of the ordinances under the jurisdiction of these departments. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6380, § 2, 6-22-10; Ord. No. 6499, § 13, 10-11-11; Ord. No. 7131, § 3, 1-22-19) 
ARTICLE VIII. - ISSUANCE OF LICENSE 

Sec. 3-43. - Authority of board of aldermen. 
    The board of aldermen is hereby authorized and empowered to issue new licenses, and to direct their issuance, provided by this chapter for the manufacture or sale of alcoholic beverages, at wholesale or retail and C.O.L. and may issue such licenses to applicants who have complied with the terms of this chapter and have paid the necessary license fees. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 14, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-44. - Purchasers of existing establishments. 
    A bona fide purchaser of an existing establishment who possesses all the individual qualifications required by this chapter may be issued a new license upon application approval by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 15, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-45. - Annexed businesses. 
    Any person doing business outside the city limits in an area which is annexed by the city, shall be eligible to apply, regardless of the limitations in section 3-46, within fifteen (15) days after annexation, for a city license within the classification to which he is entitled at the time of annexation. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-46. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7131, § 1, adopted Jan. 22, 2019, repealed § 3-46, which pertained to number of licenses, and derived from Ord. No. 2011, § 4; Ord. No. 2869, adopted Apr. 28, 1981; Ord. No. 3868, § 2, adopted Mar. 14, 1989; Ord. No. 4060, § 1, adopted June 12, 1990; Ord. No. 4879, §§ 1, 2, adopted May 28, 1996; Ord. No. 4951, § 1, adopted Jan. 28, 1997; Ord. No. 5343, § 3, adopted Dec. 26, 2000; Ord. No. 5343, § 3, adopted Dec. 26, 2000; Ord. No. 5731, § 1, adopted Feb. 10, 2004; Ord. No. 6332, § 16, adopted Nov. 24, 2009; Ord. No. 6499, § 16, adopted Oct. 11, 2011; and Ord. No. 7122, § 7, adopted Dec. 11, 2018. 
Sec. 3-47. - Priorities. 
(a)  Priority shall be given to new applicants on the basis of: 
(1)  Time the application is made. 
(2)  Qualifications of the applicant. 
(3)  Location and type of operation proposed. 
(b)  Such an application shall be filed with the city clerk and determination of time shall be based on the time of receipt by the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1941, § 5) 
Secs. 3-48-3-50. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - RENEWALS, TRANSFERS, LOST LICENSES AND CHANGES IN LICENSES 

Sec. 3-51. - Renewals. 
(a)  Sale-by-drink and C.O.L. licenses. Each person holding a license for the sale by the drink and persons holding C.O.L. licenses desiring such licenses renewed, shall file with the city clerk an application for license renewal on or before the first day of May of each calendar year. 
(b)  Package and wholesaler's licenses. Persons desiring renewal of licenses to sell alcoholic beverages in the original packages and licenses to manufacture or sell at wholesale alcoholic beverages, shall file such application on or before the first day of May of each calendar year. 
(c)  Proper parties to file. The application shall be filed by the actual owner, if a single ownership, or if a partnership, separate applications shall be filed by each member of the partnership. If a corporation, the person filing must be a stockholder in the corporation or managing officer for such filing. If an LLC, the person filing must be a member of the LLC or managing officer for such filing. 
(d)  Contents of application. The application shall be submitted with the license renewal fee and shall disclose in affidavit form the following information along with any other information the city clerk deems necessary: 
(1)  The name and address of the owner or owners at the date of filing. If a corporation, the names and residential addresses of the managing director or directors, all stockholders, if the total number of stockholders is less than fifteen (15), and the officers of the corporation, or if there are over fifteen (15) stockholders in the corporation, then applicant shall furnish the names and addresses of all stockholders who hold ten (10) per cent or more of the capital stock and the officers of the corporation. If an LLC, the names and residential addresses of all members who hold ten (10) per cent or more of the total membership interest in the LLC. 
(2)  The financial status of the firm, corporation or LLC, including all loans, notes, security agreements, financing statements, chattels, mortgages and any and all other outstanding obligations and the balance due thereon except current alcoholic beverage bills, or such other current bills for merchandise incidental to the operation of the establishment for which the license is sought. 
(3)  The bank or banks with which the firm, corporation or LLC is doing any business, and the signed consent by the licensee for the department of liquor control to examine any and all business bank accounts, records and other data pertaining to the licensed business. 
(4)  That the applicant shall list the names and addresses of any person or persons who have contributed any money, loaned any money to, or have any investments in the licensed business during the preceding year; applicant shall further state the amount or amounts received from such person or persons, the purpose for which the money was used and any outstanding obligations and the balance due thereon. 
(5)  That the applicant has not borrowed or accepted money and agrees not to borrow or accept money in the future from any wholesale supplier of alcoholic beverages or any supplier of coin-operated commercial manual or mechanical amusement devices or the employees, officers or agents thereof, or from any owner of coin-operated commercial manual or mechanical amusement devices on the licensed premises, or from any known felon. 
(6)  The names and addresses of any and all persons who may be engaged in, either directly or indirectly, any part of the management and control of the licensed business. 
(e)  Compliance with ordinances. It is the applicant's responsibility to cooperate fully with the department of liquor control in its investigation of the renewal application. 
(f)  Refusal to renew. If any affidavit contains information which does not justify such renewal, if there is other information that the applicant has not met all other requirements of this chapter, or if the applicant fails to cooperate with any investigation, the city clerk may refuse to renew such license. 
(g)  Notice of non-renewal. The city clerk shall give written notice of any non-renewal decision to the applicant on or before June 1, if the application was submitted on or before May 1, and if the applicant cooperated fully in the investigation. 
(h)  Appeal hearing. In the event of non-renewal, the applicant may request an appeal hearing before the board of aldermen. If written request for an appeal hearing is made to the city clerk on or before June 15, the hearing shall be conducted before July 1, at the next regular meeting of the board of aldermen. The applicant shall be given written notice of the time and place for the requested hearing. All hearings under this subsection shall be conducted using the process described in section 3-7(c) of this chapter 3. 
(i)  Effect of non-renewal. In the event the board of aldermen upholds the city clerk's non-renewal decision at the appeal hearing, or if the hearing is conducted after July 1, the applicant shall refrain from selling or manufacturing alcoholic beverages upon expiration of the existing license. In the event of expiration, the applicant may apply for a new license under the provisions of this chapter 3. 
(j)  Late fee. If any licensee files the application for license renewal after May 1, then such license application shall be submitted with a late fee of one hundred dollars ($100.00) between May 1 and May 30, and two hundred dollars ($200.00) between June 1 and June 30 to cover the processing of the late application. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 2865, § 1, 4-14-81; Ord. No. 5414, § 2, 8-28-01; Ord. No. 6424, § 5, 1-11-11; Ord. No. 6499, § 17, 10-11-11; Ord. No. 6698, § 3, 8-12-14; Ord. No. 7131, § 2, 1-22-19) 
Sec. 3-51.1. - Investigation of renewal applicants. 
    Applicants for renewal of licenses as provided in section 3-51 shall be subject to a name search investigation to be conducted by the city clerk. Failure of a license holder seeking renewal to cooperate in the investigation, including payment to the city clerk upon request of the city's cost incurred to conduct the name search investigation, shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and shall constitute grounds of denial of the renewal application. 
(Ord. No. 6332, § 19, 11-24-09; Ord. No. 6988, § 1, 4-25-17) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
Sec. 3-52. - Death of retail licensee. 
    In the event of the death of a retail licensee, any bona fide relative of such deceased licensee, who shall meet the individual requirements of this chapter, may be licensed to operate the business of the licensee for the remainder of the period for which a license fee has been paid, and it shall not be necessary for such relative to secure a new license until the expiration of the license issued to the deceased licensee. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-53. - Transfer of location. 
(a)  Application required. The board of aldermen must first approve a transfer of a license to a different location. The application for permission to transfer must be submitted to the city clerk in writing, together with twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to cover investigation costs, and shall set forth: 
(1)  The name and residential address of the licensee and current business address. 
(2)  The address and legal description of the premises to which transfer is sought, together with the name and address of the owner, a complete set of building plans, and a descriptive list of the fixtures in the proposed place of business. 
(3)  An affidavit by such licensee that he has not violated any of the provisions of this chapter or of the state liquor laws since the license was granted. 
(4)  Any additional information that the city clerk may require. 
(b)  Refusal of transfer. The board of aldermen shall refuse to approve any transfer of the business of a licensee when the licensed business is under citation by the city or the state liquor control department, and the matter has not been finally adjudicated. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 18, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-54. - Lost licenses. 
(a)  Whenever a license issued under this chapter is lost or destroyed, a duplicate in lieu thereof may be issued under this chapter by the city clerk. 
(b)  Application for a duplicate license must be by affidavit of the licensee and must set forth: 
(1)  Approximate date upon which license was lost or destroyed. 
(2)  The circumstances under which the license was lost or destroyed. 
(3)  A request that a duplicate license be issued. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 19, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-55. - Change in ownership or managing officer. 
(a)  Requirements. No person holding a license under this chapter to manufacture or sell alcoholic beverages or a C.O.L. license shall make any change in ownership of the business without first filing with the city clerk, in writing, notice of intention so to do, with an affidavit listing the names and addresses of creditors of the licensee who are wholesale suppliers of alcoholic beverages, and that all such creditors have been notified in writing, by registered mail, or that such creditors have been personally served with notice of any proposed change in ownership and the names of the prospective transferee or transferees; nor shall such person make any change in the management or control of such business without first notifying the city clerk, in writing, and by affidavit listing the names and residential addresses of any person or persons who may have any interest in such business or take part in the management and control thereof, whether directly or indirectly, and as a condition precedent for such transfer shall secure, in writing, from the board of aldermen permission to do so. 
    Whenever a corporation or LLC holding a liquor license under the provisions of this chapter makes application for a change of the managing officer, a charge of one hundred dollars ($100.00) shall be made for each such application for the purpose of defraying the costs of investigation of each prospective managing officer, said sum payable to the city collector. 
(b)  Time period for approval. The board of aldermen may have thirty (30) days from the filing of the notice and affidavit provided for in the preceding subsection before approving the transfer or purchase or a change of managing officer. Any such application not acted upon within a period of thirty (30) days from the date of filing may be considered disapproved and the applicant may make appeal in the manner provided in this chapter. 
(c)  Refusal to approve. The board of aldermen shall refuse to approve the application of the purchaser of the business or a change of managing officer, when the licensed business is under citation by the city or state liquor control department and the matter has not yet been finally adjudicated. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 2011, § 5; Ord. No. 3179, § 1, 9-15-83; Ord. No. 6424, § 6, 1-11-11; Ord. No. 6499, § 20, 10-11-11) 
Editor's note- Section 20 of Ord. No. 6499, adopted Oct. 11, 2011, changed the title of § 3-55 from "Change in ownership" to "Change in ownership or managing officer." 
Sec. 3-56. - Partner's withdrawal. 
    If one or more members of a partnership having a license for the sale of alcoholic beverages withdraws from the partnership, the board of aldermen, upon written application to the city clerk, accompanied by a bill of sale or affidavit of transfer, shall allow the remaining partner or partners originally licensed, to continue the operation under the original license for the remainder of the period for which the license fee has been paid and it shall not be necessary for the remaining partner or partners to secure a new license until the expiration of the license. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 21, 10-11-11) 
ARTICLE X. - LOCATION OF RETAIL AND C.O.L. PREMISES 

Sec. 3-57. - Requirements for alcoholic beverage licenses, distance. 
(a)  Compliance with ordinances. A license shall not be issued by the board of aldermen for a new location or for the expansion of existing premises until there has been shown compliance with the fire, health, building code and zoning ordinances of the city. 
(b)  Distance from churches or schools. No new full sales-by-drink license issued under subsection 3-15(e) of this chapter shall be issued for any premises when such premises is within three hundred (300) feet of any school, church or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship. No new alcoholic beverage license of any other type shall be issued for any premises when such premises is within one hundred (100) feet of any school, church or other building regularly used as a place of religious worship, unless the applicant shall first obtain the consent in writing of the board of aldermen. Such consent shall not be granted until at least ten (10) days' written notice has been provided to all owners of property within one hundred (100) feet of the proposed licensed premises. 
(c)  Measurement. All distances referred to in this section 3-57 shall be measured from the nearest point of the enclosing wall of the premises to the nearest point of the school or church building. 
(d)  Exceptions. Exceptions to the distance requirements set out in subsection (b) which shall not result in denial of a license are as follows: 
(1)  If the new alcoholic beverage license is sought for a premises which was the site of another alcoholic beverage license establishment of the same type which was in operation within thirty (30) days of the application for the new alcoholic beverage license. 
(2)  When a school, church or place of worship shall hereafter be established within the prohibited distance from any place of business licensed to sell intoxicating liquor. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 3076, § 1, 8-10-82; Ord. No. 3079, § 2, 8-24-82; Ord. No. 3868, § 1, 3-14-89; Ord. No. 4202, § 1, 7-17-91; Ord. No. 4409, § 3, 11-24-92; Ord. No. 4880, §§ 1, 2, 6-11-96; Ord. No. 4950, § 3, 1-28-97; Ord. No. 5343, § 4, 12-26-00; Ord. No. 5377, § 1, 5-8-01; Ord. No. 5690, § 1, 10-14-03; Ord. No. 6400, § 1, 9-14-10; Ord. No. 7122, § 8, 12-11-18) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 6400, adopted Sept. 14, 2010, changed the title of § 3-57 from "Requirements for sales-by-drink or C.O.L. licenses" to "Requirements for alcoholic beverage licenses, distance." 
Sec. 3-58. - Reserved. 
Sec. 3-59. - Retail package, wholesale and manufacturer's licenses. 
    A license shall not be issued for a new location or for the expansion of an existing premises until there has been shown compliance with the fire, health, building code and zoning ordinances of the city and compliance with the distance requirements from churches and schools as set out in section 3-57. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-60. - Form of consent. 
    The consent required under the terms of this article shall be in writing and shall contain a statement that the signers thereof are the persons required under the terms of this section. Such written consent shall be verified before a notary public. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-61. - Discretion as to issuance of licenses. 
    In passing upon any application for a license under this chapter, the board of aldermen shall have the authority to take into consideration the location of the proposed business and the density of alcoholic beverage licenses in the area for which a license is sought, and shall have authority to refuse or grant such license when in its judgment such issuance shall not be in the best interest of the locality involved. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-62. - Established premises. 
    Nothing contained in this article shall affect any alcoholic beverage establishment legally located before and continuously operated since the adoption of this article. 
ARTICLE XI. - RESTRICTIONS AS TO PREMISES 

Sec. 3-63. - Dwelling. 
    No license shall be issued for the sale of alcoholic beverages or C.O.L. in or upon any structure occupied in whole or in part as a dwelling unless such dwelling is equipped with a separate entrance and unless there is no means of entrance or exit from the licensed premises to any dwelling. This section shall not apply to back single rooms used by night watchmen as places of periodic rest. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-64. - Visibility. 
    Licensees shall not place or allow the placing of any object on or within the windows of premises covered by the license which shall substantially impede or obstruct vision from the exterior to the interior. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-65. - Exceptions. 
(a)  Hotels, motels and clubs. Nothing in this article shall be construed as to prevent any hotel or motel operator, or private club, from serving any alcoholic beverage to any guest, including registered guests, in or occupying any room of such hotel, motel or private club if such alcoholic beverage so served shall be kept in or served from a licensed location, place or premises in such establishments. 
(b)  Drugstores, pharmacies, etc. No alcoholic beverages sales-by-drink license and no C.O.L. license provided for in this chapter shall be issued if the structure for which such license is sought is occupied and operated as a drugstore, pharmacy, confectionery, soda fountain, soft drink, stationery or school supply store. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-66. - Single license. 
    No more than one retail license provided for by this chapter shall be issued for any single premises at any given time. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
ARTICLE XII. - CONDUCT OF BUSINESS 

Sec. 3-67. - Records; financial statements. 
(a)  Books and records. All persons holding an alcoholic beverage license under the provisions of this chapter shall keep complete and accurate records pertaining to their business. These records shall include a complete and accurate record of all purchases and sales of alcoholic beverages and gross sales of prepared meals and food made by them. These records must include the names and addresses of all persons from whom such alcoholic beverages are purchased, the dates, kinds and quantities of the purchases, and the dates and amounts of payments on account. 
    Such licensees shall also keep all files, books, records, papers, state, county or city licenses, federal tax stamps, and accounts and memoranda pertaining to the business conducted by them, on the licensed premises, and they shall also keep all records required by the city clerk, and upon request of the city clerk or his/her duly authorized agents and auditors, they shall, within forty-eight (48) hours allow an inspection and audit to be made by the city clerk or his/her agents, of such files, books, records, papers, state, county or city licenses, federal tax stamps and accounts and memoranda, and shall allow copies to be made and taken of them. All records required to be kept by law or by regulation of the city clerk must be kept and preserved for a period of two (2) years from the date such record was made. All licensees holding alcoholic beverage licenses under the provisions of this chapter, shall establish and maintain a uniform system of bookkeeping and accounts, according to generally accepted accounting practice. 
(b)  Distribution of earnings or assets. All alcoholic beverage licensees, upon request of the city clerk, shall file within thirty (30) days an affidavit showing the payment, or other distribution of all earnings or assets and the name and address of all persons to whom such distribution or payment was made. Information furnished pursuant to this provision shall be confidential; except, that it may be used for the purpose of administration and enforcement of liquor control laws and ordinances. 
(c)  Title to personality. All licensees shall be required at all times to establish and prove, to the city clerk or his/her authorized agents and members of the police department, title of ownership to all articles of personal property located in the licensed premises, except articles of equipment and fixtures used in the regular course of business. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 6499, § 22, 10-11-11) 
Sec. 3-67.5. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 7122, § 9, adopted Dec. 11, 2018, repealed § 3-67.5, which pertained to tax exempt organization Sunday sales only license, and derived from Ord. No. 3270, § 1, adopted Aug. 28, 1984. 
Sec. 3-68. - Retail licenses. 
(a)  Hours, days of sales. No licensee granted a license under the provisions of this chapter, nor any employee, agent or servant of such licensee, shall allow the consumption of or shall sell, give away or otherwise dispose of any alcoholic beverages or suffer the same to be done on or about the permitted premises: 
(1)  Between the hours of 1:30 a.m. and 6:00 a.m. Monday through Saturday. 
(2)  Between the hours of 1:30 a.m. Sunday and 6:00 a.m. Monday, except as hereinafter provided. 
(3)  Original package licensees who have been issued Sunday sales licenses, may remain open and sell intoxicating liquor in the original package at retail from 9:00 a.m. to 12:00 midnight on Sunday, in addition to the legal hours and days set out above. 
(4)  All classes of sales-by-drink and malt liquor sales-by-drink licensees who have been issued Sunday sales licenses, may remain open to sell intoxicating liquor for consumption only on the licensed premises from 12:00 noon to 12:00 midnight on Sunday, in addition to the legal hours and days set out above. 
(5)  Full sales by drink licensees without a Sunday sales license may remain open to sell intoxicating liquor for consumption only on the licensed premises from 12:00 noon to 12:00 midnight when January first, March seventeenth, July fourth, or December thirty-first falls on Sunday, and on the Sundays prior to Memorial Day and Labor Day and on the Sunday on which the national championship game of the national football league is played, commonly known as "Super Bowl Sunday." 
(b)  Sales to minors, intoxicated person. 
(1)  No such licensee, or employee, agent or servant of such licensee shall give away or otherwise dispose of, or suffer the same to be done, upon or about the premises for which such license has been issued, any alcoholic beverages to any person who is under the age of twenty-one (21) years or to a habitual drunkard, or to any person who is intoxicated or who is actually or apparently under the influence of alcoholic beverages. 
(2)  The operator's or chauffeur's license issued under the provisions of Missouri Revised Statutes, § 302.177, or an identification card as provided for under [Missouri Revised Statutes,] § 302.181 shall be presented by the holder thereof upon request of any agent of the department of liquor control or any licensee or the servant, agent or employee thereof for the purpose of aiding the licensee or the servant, agent or employee to determine whether or not the person is at least twenty-one (21) years of age when such person desires to purchase or consume alcoholic beverages procured from a licensee. Upon such presentation, the licensee or the servant, agent or employee thereof, shall compare the photograph and physical characteristics noted on the license with the physical characteristics of the person presenting the license. 
(3)  Upon proof by the licensee of full compliance with the provisions of this section, no penalty shall be imposed if the board of aldermen or the courts are satisfied that the licensee acted in good faith. 
(4)  Subparagraphs (2) and (3) hereof shall become effective on July 1, 1972. 
(c)  Reserved. 
(d)  Intoxicated persons on premises, prohibited. No retail licensee or employee, agent or servant of such licensee shall be, or allow any person who is intoxicated or under the influence of alcoholic beverages to remain on premises for which the license was issued. 
(e)  Serving or selling in vehicles, prohibited. No retail licensee, or employee, agent or servant of any such licensee, shall serve or sell any alcoholic beverages to any person who is in or about any motor car or other vehicle. 
(f)  Orders off-licensed premises, prohibited. No orders for the sale of alcoholic beverages at retail shall be taken at any place not licensed under this chapter for the sale of alcoholic beverages, even though such orders are filled and delivery thereon made at a place duly licensed hereunder. 
(g)  Unlicensed beverages on premises, prohibited. No person selling alcoholic beverages at retail shall allow on his premises any alcoholic beverages except that type in which he is licensed to deal. The presence of any unlicensed alcoholic beverages will be prima facie evidence of the illegal sale of the same, and shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of the license. 
(h)  Prohibited devices, games. No licensee shall allow upon the premises any pin game, pinball game, pinball machine or marble game, the operation, use or place of which is: 
(1)  Controlled by or contingent upon the payment of a fee therefore to any person; 
(2)  Capable of being played, used or operated a single time by the insertion in such machine or other receptacle connected thereto, of more than one (1) coin, disc, plate, plug, key or other token or insertion piece; nor shall any person allow upon a premises covered by such license, any gambling of any kind or character for money, trade checks, prizes, merchandise or any other consideration whatsoever. 
(i)  Condition of premises. All retail licensees shall at all times keep the premises covered by their license safe, clean and sanitary and in accordance with the applicable rules, regulations and ordinances under the jurisdiction of the health, fire and community development departments. 
(j)  Employment of felons. No license issued under this chapter shall be denied, suspended, revoked or otherwise affected based solely on the fact that an employee of the licensee has been convicted of a felony unrelated to the manufacture or sale of intoxicating liquor. Each employer shall report the identity of any employee convicted of a felony to the state division of liquor control pursuant to RSMo § 311.060, as well as the City of Grandview director of liquor control. 
(k)  Disorderliness, indecency, obscenity. No retail licensee under this chapter, or employee, agent or servant of such licensee shall allow in or upon the licensed premises any disturbances, disorderliness, lewdness, immoral activities, brawls, or any indecent, profane or obscene language, songs, entertainment, literature or advertising material, nor shall cause to have printed or distributed any lewd, immoral, indecent or obscene literature or advertising material; nor shall allow any bartender, barmaid, waitress, hostess or servant to appear on the licensed premises in a condition where either of the breasts, or the pelvic areas, or the buttocks, are not covered with opaque clothing; nor shall allow any employee or entertainer employed by such licensee or any patron to perform a dance of any kind whatever upon the bar or upon any other place used for serving food or beverages or in any place within the licensed premises open to public view from the sidewalk or street; nor shall allow either an exotic dance or striptease dance to be performed except as hereinafter provided: 
(1)  Such dance shall be performed on a raised dais or platform containing not less than one hundred (100) square feet of surface and at least eighteen (18) inches from the floor level where patrons may be seated or standing. 
(2)  Such dais must be at every point not less than six (6) feet from the nearest patron. 
(3)  Such dance shall not be performed in any place within the licensed premises which is open to public view from the sidewalk or street. 
(l)  Storing off-licensed premises. No licensee under this chapter shall store any alcoholic beverages off or outside of his licensed premises without first obtaining the written consent of the director of liquor control; provided, however, that a licensee may store alcoholic beverages in a bonded warehouse or central warehouse if he has first notified the director of liquor control in writing of his intention to do so. 
(m)  Nonlisted telephone. If a nonlisted or silent telephone or pay telephone is installed by any licensee on his licensed premises, this fact shall be stated to the director of liquor control within ten (10) days after installation, and the number of such telephones so used in the licensee's business shall be provided for the director of liquor control, and shall remain a part of the licensee's record. Failure to report the installation of such a telephone shall be grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license. 
(n)  Solicitation by females. No by-the-drink retail licensee, or his employee, agent or servant shall sell or give any alcoholic beverage, drink, merchandise or other thing of value in any quantity to any female who shall solicit another to buy any of the above items, nor shall he allow any such female person to solicit the purchase of such items by another on the premises of such licensee. 
(o)  Responsibility of licensee and employees. Licensees are at all times responsible for the conduct of their business and at all times responsible for any act or conduct of any employee on the premises which is in violation of this chapter or the regulations of the department of liquor control. 
It shall be the duty and responsibility of the licensee and the person in charge of the licensed premises at all times to supervise the operation and conduct of business in a diligent manner and to make reasonably certain that this chapter or regulations of the department of liquor control are not violated. 
It shall also be the duty and responsibility of the licensee's agents, servants and employees to report to the licensee or person in charge of the licensed premises any violation of this chapter or regulations of the department of liquor control. 
(p)  Insufficient checks. All retail licensees who purchase alcoholic beverage supplies and pay for the same with first party checks that are returned insufficient funds, without funds, or no accounts, shall be subject to immediate suspension within the discretion of the board of aldermen. 
(q)  Delinquent accounts. All retail licensees who remain delinquent in payment of accounts for more than sixty (60) days shall be subject to suspension, and licensees who remain delinquent for more than ninety (90) days shall be suspended or revoked within the discretion of the board of aldermen. 
(r)  Limits of license. No license issued under the terms of this chapter shall extend beyond the actual premises for which the license is issued. 
(s)  Display of license required. Before commencing or doing any business for the time for which a city license has been granted, such license shall be posted, and kept displayed at all times during the term of the license in a conspicuous place on the premises so that all persons visiting the premises may readily see the same. 
No licensee shall post such license or allow such license to be posted upon premises other than the premises licensed, or upon premises where traffic in alcoholic beverages is being carried on by any person other than the licensee, or knowingly deface, destroy or alter any such license in any respect. 
All such licensees shall also keep prominently displayed on their licensed premises at all times while their city license is in effect all federal tax stamps or state licenses issued to them or to any other person designating them or the licensed premises as a person or place authorized by the federal government or state to deal in alcoholic beverages or C.O.L. 
(t)  Prohibited interests. No license for the sale of alcoholic beverages at retail or a C.O.L. license shall be issued to any person, firm, or corporation in which any distiller, wholesaler, wine maker, brewer or supplier of coin-operated commercial, manual or mechanical amusement devices, or the employees, officers or agents thereof, has any financial interest or has furnished, directly or indirectly, equipment, money, credit or property of any kind except ordinary commercial credit for alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A; Ord. No. 1941, § 6; Ord. No. 2011, § 6; Ord. No. 2846, § 1, 1-13-81; Ord. No. 2868, § 1, 4-28-81; Ord. No. 3177, § 1, 8-23-83; Ord. No. 3270, § 2, 8-28-84; Ord. No. 3747, § 1, 5-24-88; Ord. No. 4009, § 1, 1-23-90; Ord. No. 4038, § 1, 4-10-90; Ord. No. 5317, § 1, 10-10-00; Ord. No. 5746, § 4, 3-23-04; Ord. No. 6043, § 1, 9-12-06; Ord. No. 6332, § 17, 11-24-09; Ord. No. 6428, § 1, 2-8-11; Ord. No. 6499, § 23, 10-11-11; Ord. No. 6698, §§ 4, 5, 8-12-14; Ord. No. 7122, § 10, 12-11-18) 
Editor's note- See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
Sec. 3-69. - Retail by-the-drink and C.O.L. licenses. 
(a)  Closed place. The premises of any such licensee shall be and remain a "closed place," as defined, at the times and upon the days during which the sale or consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited by this chapter; provided, that where such licenses are held by clubs, motels and hotels, this prohibition shall only apply to the premises where alcoholic beverages are dispensed or consumed; and provided further, that where such licenses are held by restaurants where substantial quantities of food are served, then the licensee shall keep securely locked during the hours and upon the days specified, all refrigerators, cabinets, cases and boxes and taps from which alcoholic beverages are dispensed. Securely locked shall mean locked in such a manner that alcoholic beverages cannot be removed without unlocking a lock. Any unlocked container or any open case of alcoholic beverages in such place of business shall be deemed an illegal sale of the same and grounds for suspension or revocation of the license. 
(b)  Inducement to drink. It shall be unlawful for any employee, agent or servant of such licensee to give away any alcoholic beverage either in drinks or otherwise, either with or without food, or to charge any less price for such drinks when served with food than when served without food. 
    It shall be likewise unlawful for any person holding such a license or any employee, agent or servant to give away any food with any drink sold, or to offer any food free as an inducement to customers to purchase alcoholic beverages or to operate or maintain what is commonly called a "free lunch counter," or any other promotional scheme as an inducement to drink. 
(c)  Prohibited acts on sales-by-drink-premises. It shall be unlawful for any person holding a sales-by-drink license or any agent, servant or employee of such licensee to allow alcoholic beverages to be brought into or upon the licensed premises by patrons or customers. No such licensee or his employee, agent or servant shall knowingly sell, give away or serve upon the premises described in the license, any glass, ice, water, soda water, phosphates or any other kind of liquid to be used for the purpose of mixing intoxicating drinks and commonly referred to as "set ups"; nor shall any such licensee or his agent, servant or employee suffer any person, while in or upon the premises covered by such license, to pour into, mix with or add intoxicating liquor to water, soda water, ginger ale, seltzer, malt, phosphates or any other kind of liquid or other liquor; provided, however, that nothing herein contained shall be construed to prohibit any of the above acts in any private guest room or private dining room of any duly licensed hotel, motel or private club. No licensee, or employee, agent or servant of any licensee shall knowingly allow any person, while in or upon the premises covered by such license, to drink or consume out of any bottle any alcoholic beverage containing in excess of five (5) per cent alcoholic content by volume. 
(d)  Alcoholic beverages brought on premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to take alcoholic beverages into or upon any premises covered by a sales-by-drink license for the purpose of consuming such alcoholic beverages in any form on such premises. 
(e)  Minor entering premises, prohibited. It shall be unlawful for any licensee holding a sales-by-drink license or a C.O.L. license or his employee, agent or servant to either directly or indirectly suffer or allow a person under the age of twenty-one years to enter the premises or to linger or loiter in or about such premises, without lawful business or in violation of this chapter. 
(f)  Dispensing to employees. No by-the-drink retail licensee, or his employee, agent or servant shall give or sell to any employee of the establishment operated by such licensee, any alcoholic beverage, nonalcoholic beverage, drink, merchandise or other thing of value, nor shall he allow any patron of the licensed premises to give, purchase or drink with any employee any alcoholic beverage, nonalcoholic beverage, drink, merchandise or other thing of value, nor allow any employee to sit with at any bar or table or dance with any patron. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A.) 
Sec. 3-70. - Full original package sales licenses. 
(a)  Consumption on premises. It shall be unlawful for such licensee or any employee, agent or servant of such licensee to allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverages in or upon the licensed premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages on such premises. 
(b)  Other than original package. It shall be unlawful for such licensee or any employee, agent or servant of such licensee to sell, dispense or give away alcoholic beverages except in the original package. 
(c)  Alcoholic beverages, locked up when. All such licensees whose place of business remains open on the days and at the hours when the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited by law, shall at all times upon such days and at such hours, keep all alcoholic beverages securely under lock and key in such a manner that such alcoholic beverages cannot be removed without unlocking a lock. Any unlocked alcoholic beverages in such places of business shall be deemed an illegal sale of same and grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A.) 
Sec. 3-71. - Malt liquor original package sales license. 
(a)  Consumption on premises. It shall be unlawful for any agent, servant or employee of such licensee, or for such licensee, to allow the consumption of any alcoholic beverages in or upon the licensed premises. It shall be unlawful for any person to consume alcoholic beverages on such premises. 
(b)  Unlicensed beverages on premises. It shall be unlawful for such licensee, or any agent, servant or employee of such licensee to have in or upon the licensed premises any intoxicating liquor other than malt liquor. 
(c)  Malt liquor to be locked up when. All such licensees whose places of business remain open on the days and at the hours when the sale and consumption of alcoholic beverages is prohibited by law, shall keep all malt liquor securely under lock and key in such a manner that such alcoholic beverages cannot be removed without unlocking a lock. Any unlocked alcoholic beverages in such places of business shall be deemed an illegal sale of the same and grounds for the suspension or revocation of the license. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A.; Ord. No. 6332, § 18, 11-24-09) 
Editor's note- Section 18 of Ord. No. 6332, adopted Nov. 24, 2009, changed the title of § 3-71 from "Malt liquor and nonintoxicating beer original package sales licenses" to "Malt liquor original package sales license." 
 See editor's note to § 3-1, regarding effective dates. 
Sec. 3-72. - All wholesale licensees. 
(a)  Credit to retailers. No such licensee shall extend commercial credit to any retailer beyond the limitations provided in the state statutes or by regulations pursuant thereto. 
(b)  Report of delinquency. No such licensee shall fail to report to the director of liquor control later than the third and eighteenth day of each calendar month, any and all retail accounts which have become delinquent on or before the first and fifteenth day of any calendar month as provided under the state statutes or by regulations pursuant thereto. 
(c)  Sales to delinquents, prohibited. No such licensee shall sell, give away or otherwise dispose of or suffer the same to be done, any alcoholic beverages to any retail licensee who is delinquent in payment to any wholesalers. 
(d)  Availability of information. All information obtained by the director of liquor control under the provisions of this section shall be available at all reasonable times to any person having a wholesale license under the terms of this chapter, or his duly authorized agent. 
(e)  Status of retailer's accounts. It shall be the duty of all such licensees to inquire of the director of liquor control not later than the fifth and twentieth day of each calendar month, to determine whether any retail licensee to whom delivery is about to be made is delinquent in payment to any other wholesaler. 
(f)  Preparation of delinquency list. In order to comply with the above provision, the wholesale licensee may arrange through the department of liquor control to report the name of the delinquent retail licensee (if corporation, corporate name; if individual or partnership, individual names) to the department of liquor control, and then cause to be circulated among the wholesale licensees only, the names of the delinquent retail licensees as long as they remain delinquent. This list may be compiled and circulated by a data processing company upon procuring the information from the department of liquor control or the wholesale licensee. Removal of the names of delinquent retail licensees from such a list shall be based on information furnished by the wholesale licensee or the department of liquor control. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
ARTICLE XIII. - MINORS[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Purchase or possession of intoxicating liquor by persons under twenty-one (21) RSMo, § 311.325; purchase and possession of nonintoxicating beer by persons under twenty-one (21), RSMo, § 312.407. 

Sec. 3-73. - Purchase or possession of alcoholic beverages prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to purchase alcoholic beverages. No such person shall have in his possession, either on his person or in a vehicle in which he is riding or sitting, any alcoholic beverages, except when such minor shall be accompanied by parent or lawful guardian. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-74. - Entrance on licensed retail premises. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to enter, or be on the premises of any licensee holding any sales-by-drink license or C.O.L. license under this chapter, without lawful business or in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Sec. 3-75. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6698, § 6, adopted Aug. 12, 2014, repealed § 3-75, which pertained to employment of minors and derived from Ord. No. 1847, § A; and Ord. No. 3179, § 1, adopted Sept. 15, 1983. 
Sec. 3-76. - Misrepresenting age by minor. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years to misrepresent his age or make false statements willfully about his age to anyone for the purpose of purchasing or in any way obtaining alcoholic beverages. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
State Law reference- Misrepresentation of age by minor to obtain liquor, beer, RSMo §§ 311.320, 312.405. 
Sec. 3-77. - Acquisition of alcoholic beverages for minors. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to obtain, convey, make available or deposit alcoholic beverages in any place where such person knows, or by the exercise of reasonable care should know, that a person or persons under the age of twenty-one (21) years are likely to come into possession of the same. It shall be unlawful for any person to purchase or in any way obtain alcoholic beverages for any person under the age of twenty-one (21) years. Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction thereof, shall be punished by a fine of nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term of not more than three (3) months, or both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
ARTICLE XIV. - VIOLATIONS OF CHAPTER 

Sec. 3-78. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. The municipal court shall have the power to hear and determine alleged violations of the provisions of this chapter. Upon the conviction of anyone hereunder, all such guilty persons shall be punished by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment for a term not to exceed three (3) months or by both such fine and imprisonment where no other penalty is specifically provided for in this chapter. 
(b)  Each day that a violation of this chapter continues shall be deemed a separate offense and shall be proceeded against, as in the first instance. In addition, any violation of any provision of this chapter shall be grounds for suspension or revocation of any license or permit after a hearing before the board of aldermen as provided for in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 1847, § A) 
Chapter 3A - AMUSEMENT DEVICES AND VENDING MACHINES 

Sec. 3A-1. - Registration. 
(a)  Definitions. For the purpose of this section, the terms defined in this section shall have the following meanings: 
(1)  Vending machine: The term "vending machine" shall include such devices operated by the insertion of a coin, disk or other insertion piece, whether or not manipulated by the operator, which provide foods, confections or merchandise to the operator. 
(2)  Coin-operated amusement device: The term "coin-operated amusement device" shall include pinball machines, video game machines, marble machines, miniature pool machines and other devices operated by the insertion of a coin, disk or other insertion piece, whether or not also manipulated by the operator, and which are operated for the amusement or entertainment of the operator or participants thereon regardless of whether a score is registered. It shall not include "slot machines", "claw machines" or any other machine or device prohibited by state law. 
(3)  Distributor: The term "distributor" shall include any owner of a vending machine or coin-operated amusement device who sells, leases, rents or otherwise distributes any such vending machine or coin-operated amusement device to exhibitors for operation within the City of Grandview. 
(4)  Exhibitor: The term "exhibitor" shall include any person who exhibits or maintains for operation one or more vending machines or coin-operated amusement devices within the City of Grandview, whether owned by the exhibitor, a distributor or any other person. 
(b)  Required. It shall be unlawful for any distributor, exhibitor or other person to engage in the business of selling, leasing, renting, operating or exhibiting a vending machine or coin-operated amusement device (when such device is located in a place of amusement, entertainment or recreation) within the City of Grandview without first registering each such machine or device with the Clerk of the City of Grandview and complying with all requirements of this section. 
(c)  Application for registration; issuance of certificate. The owner, distributor or exhibitor of each vending machine or coin-operated amusement device which is required to be registered pursuant to the terms of this section shall, within ten (10) days of the delivery or installation of such machine or device in the City of Grandview, complete an application for registration of each such machine or device. Such application for registration shall be made to the office of the Clerk of the City of Grandview and shall require, at a minimum, the following information: 
(1)  The name of the manufacturer of the machine or device, the model number or description and the serial or other identifying number for each machine or device. 
(2)  The name, address and telephone number of the owner of each vending machine or coin-operated amusement device. 
(3)  The owner's Missouri retail sales tax number or other identifying information as may be required. 
(4)  The name, address and telephone number of the premises where each such vending machine or coin-operated amusement device is located within the City of Grandview. 
(5)  The Missouri retail sales tax number or other identifying information as may be required of the operator of the business or premises where the vending machine or coin-operated amusement device is located within the City of Grandview. 
Upon the submission of the completed application for registration to the Clerk of the City of Grandview, the clerk shall issue to the applicant a registration certificate for each such vending machine or coin-operated amusement device. 
(d)  Display of registration certificate. Each vending machine or coin-operated amusement device which has been duly registered shall affix the registration certificate to the vending machine or coin-operated amusement device so that said certificate shall be visible at all times. 
(e)  Transfer of license. Upon notification to the Clerk of the City of Grandview of the intention of a distributor, exhibitor or other person to replace a registered vending machine or coin-operated amusement device with a similar machine or device and upon providing the information required in paragraph (c) above, the registration certificate may be transferred to the substituted machine or device. In the event a registered vending machine or coin-operated amusement device is removed from the City of Grandview and is not replaced with a similar machine or device, the distributor, exhibitor or such other person shall return the registration certificate for that machine or device to the Clerk of the City of Grandview and the registration certificate shall be declared null and void. 
(f)  Inspection. It shall be the duty of the city inspector to inspect business premises and other locations in the City of Grandview from time to time to ensure compliance with this section. 
(g)  Penalty for violation. Any distributor, exhibitor or other person found guilty of a violation of the provisions of this section shall be punished by a fine not to exceed five hundred dollars ($500.00) per offense. Each day that a violation occurs shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. No. 3036, § 1, 5-25-82) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3036, adopted May 25, 1982, did not specifically amend this Code; hence inclusion of § 1 as 3A-1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 4 - ANIMALS AND FOWL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 4-1. - Intent of chapter. 
    The intent of this chapter is to require dog and cat owners to comply with the law, not merely to operate an impoundment program. The enforcement of this chapter shall therefore place primary emphasis upon apprehending and initiating prosecution of violators of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-2. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this chapter, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Adequate care: Normal and prudent attention to the needs of an animal, including that care which is normally necessary to maintain good health in a specific species of animal. 
    Adequate food: Wholesome foodstuffs suitable for the species provided at suitable intervals in a sanitary manner in quantities sufficient to maintain good health in an animal considering its age and condition. 
    Adequate health care: The provision to each healthy animal of all immunizations and preventative care required to maintain good health; space adequate to allow the animal rest and exercise sufficient to maintain good health, and the provision to each sick, diseased, or injured animal of necessary veterinary care or humane death. 
    Adequate shelter: A structurally sound, properly ventilated, sanitary and weatherproof shelter suitable for the species, condition and age of the animal which provides access to shade from direct sunlight and regress from exposure to inclement weather conditions. The condition of the shelter should be such as to not exacerbate existing weather conditions, e.g., a metal dog house in the hot sun. 
    Adequate water: A continual access to or access at suitable intervals to a supply of clean, fresh, potable water provided in a sanitary manner suitable for the species, condition and age of the animal in sufficient amounts to maintain good health in the animal. Such water will be provided in a secure manner so that the container cannot be overturned. 
    Cat: A cat of either sex if over the age of four (4) months. The burden is on the person owning and keeping or harboring such animal to establish the animal's age. In the absence of reliable proof of age, the age shall be determined through use of the best evidence readily available at the discretion of the director of community development, humane office, or police officer charged with enforcing this chapter. 
    Commercial animal establishment: Any pet shop, grooming shop, auction, riding school, stable, kennel, guard dog service, dog trainer, business keeping animals in stock for retail or wholesale trade, or any establishment performing one or more of the principal activities of the aforementioned establishments. 
    Cruelty to animals: Including but not limited to the intentional killing, maiming, torturing, mutilating, beating, neglect, overworking of any animal, abandoning, inhumane trapping, poisoning, or allowing animal to go without veterinary care when ill or diseased. 
    Dangerous animal: 
(1)  Any animal that has inflicted a severe or fatal injury on a human being, without provocation, on public or private property. Severe injury means any physical injury resulting directly from an animal's bite that results in broken bones, lacerations requiring stitches or in-patient hospitalization. A victim who receives severe injuries must provide the animal control officer with a signed physician's statement documenting injury and treatment qualifying such as a severe injury or sign an authorization for release of such statement; 
(2)  Any animal that has killed a domestic animal, dog, or cat without provocation, while off the owner's property; or
