(3)  Any animal that is owned, possessed or harbored primarily or in part for the purpose of animal fighting or any animal trained for animal fighting; or 
(4)  Any animal that has bitten a human being without provocation on public or private property other than the property of the owner; or 
(5)  Any animal that, when running at large and unprovoked, chases or approaches a person upon the streets, sidewalks, or any public grounds or private property other than the property of the owner, in a menacing fashion or apparent attitude of attack, regardless of whether or not a person is injured by such an animal; or 
(6)  Any animal with a known propensity, tendency or disposition to attack unprovoked, to cause injury, or to otherwise threaten the safety of human beings, domestic animals, dogs or cats. 
    Dog: A dog of either sex if over the age of four (4) months. The burden is on the person owning and keeping or harboring such animal to establish the animal's age. In the absence of reliable proof of age, the age shall be determined through use of the best evidence readily available at the discretion of the director of community development, humane office, or police officer charged with enforcing this chapter. 
    Domestic animals: Domestic animals, excluding dogs and cats, deemed allowable to be owned, kept or harbored upon any premises or property within the city shall include small warm-blooded animals commonly kept as house pets such as: Rats, mice, gerbils, rabbits, ducks, guinea pigs, hamsters, birds, and other small fowl and small cold-blooded animals commonly kept as house pets such as fish and nonpoisonous lizards and snakes. Nonpoisonous snakes shall be kept in locked, escape-proof cages and shall not be permitted to escape while being handled by owner, keeper or handler. 
    Exotic animals : Any animal, excluding dogs, cats, and domesticated animals defined herein. Exotic animals include, but shall not be limited to, the following: wolves and wolf hybrids, raccoons, ferrets, foxes, skunks, animals of the ape species, leopards, lions, tigers, bobcats, panthers, bears, goats, sheep, swine, miniature pigs, cattle, horses, donkeys, mules, venomous or poisonous animals, alligators, and crocodiles. This shall preclude the keeping of livestock such as horses in areas owned for agricultural use. 
    Fowl: Any and all fowl, poultry and birds, domesticated and wild, male and female, single and plural, except a bird or birds kept caged within a house. 
    Humane officer: Animal control officer, police officer, or other employees of the city designated by the board of aldermen; an agent of a kennel, pound, shelter or licensed veterinary hospital designated by the board of aldermen. 
    Kennel: The keeping of more than four (4) dogs or four (4) cats, or two (2) dogs and two (2) cats each of which is over the age of four (4) months. 
    Neutered dog or cat: A dog or cat certified by a licensed veterinarian to have been neutered. 
    Owner: Any person owning, keeping or harboring an animal or who shall allow any animal to habitually remain or to be lodged or fed within his house, store, yard, enclosure, or place. 
    Public nuisance: Any animal (or group of animals which contains any animal) which: 
(1)  Molests or intimidates any passerby or pedestrian or chases passing vehicles including bicycles. 
(2)  Attacks any other animal. 
(3)  Is in heat and not properly confined as provided in section 4-27. 
(4)  Is at large in violation of section 4-19. 
(5)  Damages public or private property. 
(6)  Barks, whines, or howls in an excessive fashion which is hereby defined as continuous or untimely so as to disturb the sleep of an individual who is a neighbor (a neighbor for this purpose is hereby defined as an individual residing in a residence structure which is within one hundred (100) yards of the property on which the animal is kept or harbored) and who does in writing state that he will so testify if called upon to testify about such a matter under oath. 
(7)  Causes injury to people. 
(8)  Threatens or causes a condition such as an insanitary condition in enclosure or surrounding where an animal is kept or harbored which endangers public health. 
(9)  Impedes refuse collection by ripping any bag or tipping any container of such. 
(10)  Causes excessive odor. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 4486, § 1, 7-13-93; Ord. No. 5424, § 1, 9-25-01; Ord. No. 5526, § 1, 9-24-02; Ord. No. 5981, § 1, 12-13-05; Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, §§ 1, 2, 3-10-15) 
Sec. 4-3. - Inhumane treatment, abuse, and neglect of animals prohibited. 
(a)  No owner or keeper of an animal shall fail to provide the animal with adequate care, adequate food, adequate water, adequate health care, and adequate shelter. Such shelter should be clean, dry, shaded, and compatible with the condition, age, and species. An animal must also have the opportunity for adequate daily exercise as determined by the humane officer. This requires that an owner must offer some freedom from continuous chaining, stabling, and tethering. Any restraint placed on an animal must be such that it prevents the animal from being tangled or injured by the restraint. Grooming of animals is also required so that they are free from dangerous matting which can affect their health. The area where animals are kept must also be kept free from unsanitary conditions, vermin-harboring debris, junk, or any other dangerous protuberances which can provide an opportunity for injury or a danger to the animal's health. Any owner, keeper or harborer of an animal in this city by the act of owning, keeping or harboring such animal does thereby authorize the humane officer to enter the yard where such animal is kept, if the humane officer reasonably believes that the animal is kept in an unlawful, negligent, cruel, abusive or inhumane manner, and to examine such animal and to seize and impound such animal when, in said examiner's opinion, it is being kept in an unlawful, negligent, cruel, abusive or inhumane manner. If a humane officer cannot view and observe the animal in plain sight, the owner, keeper, or harborer, upon request, must exhibit for inspection any and all animals which are not in plain sight but are on or inside the premises. 
(b)  No person shall beat, cruelly ill treat, torment, overload, overwork, or otherwise abuse an animal, or cause, instigate or permit any dogfight, cockfight, or other combat between animals or between animals and humans and any animal so used shall be seized, impounded and promptly and humanely destroyed. In addition, no person shall place or attempt to place an animal in an enclosure or in any other place for the purpose of fighting or combat. Nor shall any person attend such unlawful exhibition or be umpire, judge or spectator at such. 
(c)  The operator of a motor vehicle which strikes any animal shall report the accident as soon as possible to the humane officer. 
(d)  No person shall offer to give or give a live animal as a prize or as a business inducement or any other form of gratuity. 
(e)  Fowl younger than eight (8) weeks of age may not be sold or offered for sale in quantity of less than twenty-five (25) birds to an individual purchaser. Vendors of such fowl shall provide and operate brooders or other heating devices as may be necessary to maintain the fowl in good health, and shall keep adequate food and water available for the fowl. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-4. - Permitting fowl to run at large prohibited; enclosure required. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning, controlling, harboring, possessing or having the management or care, in whole or in part, of any fowl, to permit such fowl to run at large. In areas of the City of Grandview zoned as R-1A, R-1 and R-1M (Single Family Residential Districts), only female chickens shall be allowed and must be kept in compliance with the Zoning Ordinance of the City of Grandview pertaining to accessory uses. In those areas of the City of Grandview zoned as AG (Agricultural District), there shall be no limit on the number or type of fowl allowed to be housed on each tract of land therein. All fowl kept in areas zoned AG shall be kept in an enclosure approved by the community development department prior to the commencement of construction, and such enclosure shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times. Such structure shall be inspected by the community development department on a regular basis to ensure that the structure is maintained according to the provisions in Chapter 6 of the Code of Laws. In areas of the city zoned AG, the minimum distance between the structure housing the fowl and the nearest dwelling unit or place of business, except the house of the person keeping the fowl, shall be one hundred fifty (150) feet. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5526, § 1, 9-24-02; Ord. No. 6164, § 1, 1-22-08; Ord. No. 6527, § 4, 3-27-12) 
Sec. 4-5. - Permitting livestock or exotic animals to run at large prohibited. 
    No person shall allow any hogs, horses, mules, asses, cattle, goats, sheep, or other livestock or exotic animals to run unrestrained in the city outside the premises of the owner of the same. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 4486, § 2, 7-13-93) 
Sec. 4-6. - Trapping. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to set or use traps which do not painlessly capture the animal or use any trap commonly referred to as "steel-jawed traps" or "leghold traps" for purposes of trapping any animal within corporate limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-7. - Poisoning. 
    No person shall willfully administer any poison to any domesticated animal or shall willfully expose any poisonous substance where the same may be likely to be eaten by any domesticated animal. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-8. - Dead animals. 
(a)  Responsibility. The owner or keeper shall be responsible for the removal of small dead animals found within the city located on private property except as otherwise provided in this section. In this section, "dead animal" shall mean one not killed for food or no longer fit for food. 
(b)  Removal of large dead animals. All large dead animals shall be removed by the owner or proprietor of the premises within twelve (12) hours after the death of such animal. If not so removed, such animal shall be removed by the City of Grandview at actual cost to the property owner or proprietor. 
(c)  Access. On occupied property, the owner or the tenant thereof shall provide easy access to the subject animal for purposes of its removal. 
(d)  Notice. No person owning or having in his possession the carcass of any animal not to be used for food shall permit the same to remain in or upon any street, sidewalk, park, public ground, private lot, or other place unless placed for pick up after having given notice to the city. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-9. - Abandonment. 
    It shall be unlawful for any owner or keeper to abandon any animal. For the purpose of this section, to abandon means for the owner or keeper to leave an animal without demonstrated or apparent intent to recover or to resume custody; to leave an animal for more than twelve (12) hours without providing for adequate food and shelter for the duration of the absence; or, to turn out or release an animal for the purpose of causing it to be impounded. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-10. - Rescue of animals from vehicles. 
    Whenever any animal is found confined in a motor vehicle in a public place under weather conditions that endanger its life as determined by the humane officer, the humane officer is hereby authorized, with assistance from the police which is hereby authorized, to enter such vehicle and rescue such animal and thereafter impound it in accordance with section 4-21. A prominent written notice shall be left on or in the vehicle advising that the animal has been removed under the authority of this section and impounded in accordance with section 4-9, 4-21, or 4-22. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-10.1. - Miniature pigs. 
    No more than one (1) miniature pig, as defined and regulated herein, may be kept in a residential dwelling unit provided that males over the age of four (4) weeks and females over the age of one hundred twenty (120) days are neutered and adult pigs do not exceed ninety-five (95) pounds in weight. All such animals must be of proven pure-bred lineage, and the owner must be able to produce litter papers to verify pedigree. In addition, pigs over the age of one hundred twenty (120) days must be registered and licensed as required of dogs and cats in section 4-11. Articles II and III applicable to dogs and cats shall also apply to domesticated miniature pigs. If a miniature pig has been deemed dangerous by the humane officer, the regulations for dangerous animals contained in Article IV shall be followed. 
(Ord. No. 4486, § 3, 7-13-93) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4486, § 3, adopted July 13, 1993, amended the Code by adding provisions designated as § 4-10A. In order to facilitate ease of usage of the Code, said provisions have been renumbered as § 4-10.1 at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 4-10.2. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, repealed § 4-10.2 which pertained to pit bull dogs, and derived from Ord. No. 5926, § 3, adopted July 26, 2005; and Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh A), adopted Feb. 12, 2008. 
ARTICLE II. - RESERVED[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5600, § 1, adopted Feb. 11, 2003, repealed ch. 4, art. II, §§ 4-11-4-18, in its entirety. Former art. II pertained to Licensing and registration of dogs and cats and derived from Ord. No. 4107, § 2, adopted Oct. 23, 1990 and Ord. No. 5424, § 4, adopted Sept. 25, 2001. 

Secs 4-11-4-18. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - DOGS AND CATS 

Sec. 4-19. - Permitting dog to run at large prohibited; when deemed running at large; allowable distance to walkways, sidewalks, or streets for staking of dogs. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person owning, controlling, harboring, possessing or having the management or care, in whole or in part, of any dog, to permit such dog to run at large. For the purpose of this article, every dog when on any street, alley or any other public place in the city or when on private property within the city, which is either not attached to a leash, the other end of which is securely held, or which is not so confined as to prevent its straying from the premises, or not securely confined in a cage or motor vehicle shall be deemed running at large. Dogs attached to leashes, ropes or chains which are staked into the ground in yards without the confinement behind a fence shall not be staked in a manner that permits the dog, regardless of the length of such leash, rope or chain, to come within ten (10) feet of all walkways, sidewalks or streets in order to allow the safe unhindered passage of persons utilizing said walkways, sidewalks or streets. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-20. - Cats not under control prohibited; when deemed not under control. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own, control, harbor, possess, manage or care for or have the management or care, in whole or part of any cat which is not under control. For the purpose of this article, cats which cause injury to persons or damage to property shall be deemed not under control. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-21. - Impoundment-When authorized; place of impoundment. 
    Dogs and cats not displaying a rabies vaccination tag in accordance with section 4-36, or found running at large or not under control, or abandoned, or not properly cared for as defined in section 4-3, shall be seized and impounded in a humane manner by the humane officer or any police officer. Impoundment may be in any registered kennel, pound, animal shelter or licensed veterinary designated by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5600, § 2, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 4-21.1. - Impoundment-Costs. 
    The owner, keeper or custodian of any animal impounded pursuant to the provisions of this Chapter 4 shall be liable for the reasonable expense incurred by the city for the care and maintenance of said animal, including impoundment fees, and the city shall be permitted to collect such expense from such owner, keeper or custodian as any other debt owed to the city. Upon conviction in municipal court on charges against such owner, keeper or custodian for an offense resulting in impoundment of said animal, the municipal judge shall, as part of the costs of such prosecution, render judgment against the defendant for the amount of such expense as may be documented by the City, which shall be collected as other fines and costs. 
(Ord. No. 5841, § 1, 12-14-04) 
Sec. 4-22. - Impoundment-Notice. 
    If a dog or cat wears a rabies vaccination tag or if the owner can by any other reasonable means be identified and located, the owner shall be notified within twenty-four (24) hours that the dog or cat has been impounded and the City of Grandview shall see that the dog or cat is held for a period of up to ten (10) business days to allow the owner to reclaim said animal. 
    In the event that the owner of any dog or cat is unknown, written notice shall be posted for five (5) consecutive days at a conspicuous place in the Municipal Services Building and such notice shall describe the dog or cat and the place and time of taking. The notice shall state that, if the animal is not redeemed, it will be subject to destruction or made available for adoption on or after the sixth business day after posting of the notice. The owner of any impounded animal has the right to redeem the animal after payment of the impoundment fees. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5021, § 1, 10-28-97; Ord. No. 5600, § 3, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 4-23. - Impoundment and destruction or adoption of unredeemed dogs and cats. 
    If a dog or cat is not redeemed by the owner as provided for in section 4-22, the dog or cat may be made available for adoption or be disposed of by a painless method approved by the Humane Society of the United States. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5021, § 1, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 4-23.1. - Humane destruction of seriously injured or sick animals authorized. 
    When an animal is impounded and is so sick or injured that, in the judgement of the humane officer or a licensed veterinarian, humane compassion requires that the suffering be promptly ended, in such instance the minimum impoundment period of five (5) days shall not apply and the animal will be humanely destroyed to prevent needless suffering. 
(Ord. No. 4786, § 1, 9-26-95) 
Sec. 4-24. - Same-Charges payable before redeeming; procedure. 
    An owner redeeming a dog, cat or other animal from impoundment shall pay to the city collector, before release, a sixty-dollar ($60.00) administrative fee plus any amounts billed to the city by the private contractor boarding the animal. In the event an impounded animal is required to be vaccinated for rabies in accordance with section 4-36, but has not been so vaccinated, the owner shall be required to sign a written acknowledgment of receipt of the animal and a written promise to have the animal vaccinated and duly licensed with the city within seven (7) days. If a registered veterinarian determines it would be temporarily dangerous to the health of the animal to vaccinate it during this seven (7) day period, the owner will be given an extension of up to thirty (30) days after the animal's release from impoundment in which to obtain the vaccination. In any event, the rabies vaccination tag required by section 4-36 shall be withheld pending final vaccination. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 4520, § 1, 10-12-93; Ord. No. 5055, § 1, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 5187, § 10, 7-13-99; Ord. No. 5600, § 4, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 4-24.1. - Impoundment of neglected or abused animals pending court hearing. 
    An animal impounded under the following circumstances shall not be subject to redemption by the owner or keeper except as provided in this section 4-24.1: 
(1)  The animal has been impounded pursuant to section 4-3 of this chapter; 
(2)  The owner or keeper of said animal has been issued a general ordinance summons for a violation of section 4-3 and a court date has been set; and 
(3)  A licensed veterinarian has certified that the impounded animal was subject to neglect or cruel, abusive or inhumane treatment. 
    Under such circumstances, and assuming the animal is not otherwise subject to humane destruction, the impounded animal shall remain impounded until the court date and the owner or keeper shall remain responsible for the administrative fees and boarding costs. The case shall be set for hearing on the earliest possible date. If the municipal judge finds the owner or keeper to be guilty of violating section 4-3 and is satisfied that the animal would in the future be subject to continued neglect or cruel, abusive or inhumane treatment by such owner or keeper, then such animal shall not be returned to or allowed to remain with such person, but its disposition shall be determined by the municipal judge. In addition to determining the appropriate disposition of the animal, the municipal judge in his discretion may condition return of the animal to the owner or keeper on payment by said person to the city of all administrative fees, boarding fees, and veterinary costs, or may forgive all or a portion of such fees and costs, as warranted by the circumstances. 
(Ord. No. 5515, § 1, 8-13-02) 
Sec. 4-25. - Domestic animals causing injuries when running at large; animals putting persons in fear; animals interfering with utility or postal service employees. 
(a)  Any person owning, controlling, harboring, possessing, or having the management or care, in whole or in part, or any domestic animal running at large, in violation of this chapter, which causes injury to any human being or other domestic animal, shall be guilty of a violation in accordance with section 4-43 of this chapter. 
(b)  No person shall own, control, harbor, possess or have the management or care of any domestic animal that is not securely confined, which by attempting to bite, jump upon, charge toward, or otherwise threaten any other person shall cause such other person to have a reasonable fear of immediate serious physical injury. Any person cited pursuant to this subsection may state as a defense, subject to proof, that the threatening behavior of the animal was instigated or provoked by the complainant or that the fear expressed by the complainant was not a reasonable fear of immediate serious physical injury. The court shall give any such defense or defenses such weight as the court in its judicial discretion finds to be appropriate in the circumstances of the case. Complaints under this subsection may be lodged only by a humane officer or by any person who feels threatened by the behavior of such animal. Said person shall describe in writing to the humane officer and the court the threatening behavior of the animal and agree to appear in municipal court and/or agree to appear pursuant to section 40-30.8 in the case of an appeal to the humane officer's designation of the animal being deemed a dangerous animal under Article IV of this chapter. 
(c)  No person shall own, control, harbor, possess or have the management or care of any domestic animal in such a manner as to hinder, obstruct or interfere with access to an outside utility meter, utility pole or mailbox by any authorized employee of a utility or of the postal service. Any domestic animal so owned, controlled, harbored, or possessed as to hinder, obstruct or interfere with access to an outside utility meter, utility pole or mailbox may be removed by a humane officer and impounded pursuant of sections 4-21 through 4-24 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No 4519, § 1, 10-12-93) 
Sec. 4-26. - Noisy animals and destruction of property. 
    No person shall own or keep any animal which by making excessive noise disturbs a neighborhood. The phrase "excessive noise" shall mean and include any noise produced by an animal which is so loud and continuous or untimely as to disturb the sleep or peace of a neighbor. The term "neighbor" shall mean an individual residing in a residence structure which is within one hundred (100) yards of the property on which the animal is kept or harbored and who does in writing state that he will testify under oath to said animal making excessive noise. It shall also be unlawful for a person keeping any animal to carelessly, willfully or maliciously permit such animal to destroy or damage property including but not limited to bruising, tearing up or injuring any lawn, flower bed, plant, tree, shrub or garden, or to defecate thereon. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-27. - Confinement of female dogs or cats in heat. 
    The owner shall confine any female dog or cat in heat within a building, in such a manner that the dog or cat shall not be accessible to other dogs or cats except for planned breeding. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-28. - Enumeration of animals. 
    The board of aldermen may require an annual enumeration of all dogs and cats owned within the city. The enumeration shall count for the number and ownership of all dogs and cats owned in the city. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-28.1. - Prohibition against harboring excess animals. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to own and keep or harbor upon his premises, more than four (4) dogs or cats or any combination thereof, regardless of the age of such animals, unless such person first complies with the provisions of section 4-38 of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 5424, § 3, 9-25-01) 
ARTICLE IV. - DANGEROUS ANIMALS 

Sec. 4-29. - Dangerous, exotic and prohibited animals. 
    The owning, keeping or harboring of dangerous animals within the city is hereby prohibited except as provided for within sections 4-30 through 4-30.14. The animal control officer shall have the authority to declare a dog dangerous based upon the definition of such animal as defined in article I, section 4.2. 
    Within any residential area (for the purposes of this section here defined as any area not zoned for commercial, agricultural, or industrial purposes), the owning, keeping, or harboring of any poisonous animal, or any warm-blooded carnivorous or omnivorous animal, (including but not limited to wolves and wolf hybrids, raccoons, skunks, foxes, leopards, panthers, tigers and lions, but excluding fowl, dogs, house cats, and small rodents of varieties used for laboratory purposes) or exotic animals, excepting miniature pigs, as defined in section 4-2 is hereby prohibited. Nonpoisonous snakes shall be kept in escape proof cages except when being handled. No snake shall be permitted by the owner, keeper, or handler to escape from a cage or while being handled. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 4486, § 4, 7-13-93; Ord. No. 5926, § 4, 7-26-05; Ord. No. 5981, § 4, 12-13-05; Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, § 4, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Section 4 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-30 as § 4-29. 
Sec. 4-30. - Permit required. 
    No person owning, harboring, or having charge, custody, control or possession of any animal deemed dangerous shall allow such animal to remain within the city unless and until a permit to do so has been obtained and complies with all terms and conditions of such permit; and, in addition thereto, such animal shall at all times be so confined, controlled and restrained in such manner so the life, limb or property of any person lawfully entering such premises shall not be endangered. 
    Failure to obtain a permit within ten (10) days from receiving the initial written notification from the city concerning the dangerous animal designation shall be adequate grounds for said officer to impound said animal until a permit is obtained. If no permit is obtained within ten (10) days of the date of impoundment, said animal will be subject to summary destruction in a humane manner. 
    If, however, the owner or keeper of the animal chooses not to purchase and acquire the required dangerous animal permit from the city, they shall be required to remove the animal from the city and provide proof of the relocate of the animal to the animal control officer responsible for the case. In this case, the owner has ten (10) days from receiving the initial written notification from the city concerning the dangerous animal designation to complete the relocation process and provide written proof to the city. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 6775, § 5, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Section 5 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-30.1 as § 4-30. 
Sec. 4-30.1. - Issuance of permit. 
    Except as hereinafter provided, no person shall have, keep, maintain, or have in said person's possession or under said person's control within the city any dangerous animal without first applying to and receiving a permit from the community development department; provided, no permit shall be granted except with such conditions attached as shall, in the opinion of the animal control officer or director of community development, reasonably ensure the public health, safety and general welfare. In any event, no permit shall be granted for any animal at any particular location except upon an explicit finding by the animal control officer or director of community development that the issuance thereof will not be contrary to the public health, safety and general welfare. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 6775, § 6, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Section 6 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-30.2 as § 4-30.1. 
Sec. 4-30.2. - Application and fees for initial permit and annual renewal permit. 
    An application for any permit required shall be made to the community development department in writing and upon a form furnished by the department. Said application shall be verified by the person who desires to have, keep, maintain or have in said person's possession or under said person's control in the city, the animal for which a permit is required and shall set forth the following: 
(a)  Name, address and telephone number of the applicant. 
(b)  The applicant's interest in such animal. 
(c)  The proposed location, and the name, address, and telephone number of the owner of such location, and of the lessee, if any. 
(d)  The number and general description of all animals including two (2) color photographs of each animal for which the permit is sought. 
(e)  The housing arrangements for all such animals with particular details as to safety or structure, locks, fencing, etc. 
(f)  Safety precautions proposed to be taken. 
(g)  Noises or odors anticipated in the keeping of such animals. 
(h)  Prior history of incidents involving the public health or safety involving any of said animals and the specific details surrounding the incident(s) causing the animal to be deemed dangerous. 
(i)  Proof of insurance to cover those who may be injured or killed by said animal. 
(j)  A statement, signed by the applicant, indemnifying the city and its agents and employees for any and all injuries that may result from said animal. 
(k)  Any additional information required by the animal control officer at the time of filing such application or thereafter. 
    The annual fee for a permit application shall be one hundred ninety dollars ($190.00) for one (1) dangerous animal. No more than one (1) dangerous animal shall be permitted per household. Said fee shall be payable to the city collector at the time of filing the permit application. The permit shall be valid for one (1) year renewable on June 30 each year and applications for renewal of any permit shall be made not less than forty-five (45) days prior to the expiration thereof and shall be accompanied by a non-refundable fee of fifty dollars ($50.00). Applications for renewals received late shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable fee of seventy-five dollars ($75.00). 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5926, § 5, 7-26-05; Ord. No. 6775, § 7, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Section 7 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-30.3 as § 4-30.2. 
Sec. 4-30.3. - Confinement of dangerous animals. 
(a)  No person shall own, harbor, maintain, or allow to be in or upon any premises occupied by him or under his charge or control any animal which has been deemed to be a dangerous animal as defined in section 4-2 without such animal being securely confined indoors or confined in a securely enclosed and locked pen or structure. The pen or confinement structure shall not be closer to the adjacent property line than six (6) feet. Such pen or structure must have secure sides, a secure top, and a bottom with a concrete or asphalt surface which is imbedded no less than two (2) feet into the ground and secured to the sides and must measure not less than six (6) feet by eight (8) feet in area and five (5) feet in height. 
(b)  No person owning, harboring, maintaining or having the care of a dangerous animal (as defined in section 4-2) shall permit said animal to go outside its kennel, cage or secure structure unless such animal is securely leashed and muzzled by a muzzling device sufficient to prevent the animal from biting persons or other animals. The leash of such animal shall be held securely at all times by the owner or keeper, shall not be anchored to any inanimate object (such as trees, posts or buildings), and shall not be longer than four (4) feet. 
(c)  If a dangerous animal is confined indoors, the room in which it is confined shall have secure solid doors and closed windows which will adequately prevent its escape. Rooms with open or screened windows, screened doors, porches and patios are not considered secure enough to prevent the animal from escaping confinement. No dangerous animal shall be kept on a porch, patio or in any part of a house or structure that would allow the animal to exit such building on its own volition. 
(d)  It shall further be the duty of the owner of such animal to post a notice on the premises, conspicuously visible to the public in reading in letters of not less than two (2) inches high, "Bad Dog" or "Bad Cat," or "Beware of Dog," or otherwise identifying the dangerous animal. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5632, §§ 1, 2, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 5981, §§ 2, 3, 12-13-05; Ord. No. 6775, § 8, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Section 8 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-29 as § 4-30.3. 
Sec. 4-30.4. - Inspections for renewal. 
    Prior to the annual renewal of any permit issued hereunder and at least once not more than six (6) months after the issuance of any such permit or after its renewal, the animal control officer shall inspect the premises subject to such permit to determine whether the person to whom it has been issued is continuing to comply with all of the conditions specified in this chapter. If the animal control officer determines during any such inspection that any of the conditions therein specified are being violated, the animal control officer shall recommend denial of a renewal of any such permit, or shall recommend revocation of such permit in the event that such violation is not corrected within the period of time as directed. 
    For those animals which have been deemed dangerous according to the definition contained in section 4-2, there shall be an opportunity for the animal to have their dangerous designation removed during the annual renewal inspection. 
    During the renewal inspection period, the dangerous animal designation can be removed by the director of community development if there is evidence present that the subject animal has not had any further complaints, reports or violations registered against it regarding the occurrence of dangerous behavior since the beginning of that permit year. When the determination for the removal of the dangerous animal designation is made, the city shall notify the owner, keeper or harborer of said action in writing, informing them of the decision. 
    If, after the dangerous animal permit and requirements have been lifted, and the animal reverts back into exhibiting dangerous behavior as defined in section 4-2 of this chapter, the city has the right to again label the animal as dangerous and require the owner, keeper or harborer to file a new application for a dangerous animal permit with the department of community development, pay the required fee amount, and sign the necessary documents acknowledging the owner's responsibilities for keeping dangerous animals within the city. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, § 9, 3-10-15) 
Sec. 4-30.5. - Revocation of permit. 
    The animal control officer may, for good cause, revoke any permit or modify any terms or provisions thereof and may, in the event it is reasonably necessary to protect against an immediate threat or danger to the public health or safety, suspend any permit or portion thereof without hearing, for a period not to exceed thirty (30) days. Failure to comply with any of the provisions of this chapter shall be sufficient grounds for revocation. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 6775, § 10, 3-10-15) 
Sec. 4-30.6. - Exemptions. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the transportation of such animals through this city when such transporter has taken adequate safeguards to protect the public and has notified the local law enforcement agency of the proposed route of transportation and the time thereof. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-30.7. - Commercial establishments. 
    Commercial establishments possessing such animals for the purpose of sale or display may replace the same with others of the same kind, but the number of each shall not be in excess of the number thereof allowed by the terms of such permit. Such establishments, at the discretion of the animal control officer, may be granted a permit for such numbers of each kind of animal as do not exceed the maximum number such establishment estimates will be maintained by it in this city at any one (1) time during the period of the permit. Such permit shall require the immediate notification of the animal control officer upon the acquisition of any animal having a prior history of any incident involving the public health or safety, or resulting in any bodily injury or property damage. 
    Upon the sale of any dangerous animal, said commercial establishment shall immediately send notification of said sale along with the name and address of the buyer, the method of transporting the animal, the path of travel of such transportation, and the destination to the animal control officer. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 6775, § 11, 3-10-15) 
Sec. 4-30.8. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), adopted February 12, 2008, renumbered the provisions of former § 4-30.8 as § 4-30.15. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 4-30.9. - Tattooing or identification devices. 
    The owner of any animal deemed to be dangerous pursuant to this article IV shall arrange to have a licensed veterinarian humanely place a permanent tattoo, microchip or other identifying device as pre-approved by the humane officer upon the animal's body at the owner's expense. This action may only occur after the appeal provisions of section 4-30.8 have been exhausted. The owner shall also cause the dangerous animal to wear a bright orange collar at all times for quick identification. 
(Ord. No. 4626, § 1, 7-26-94; Ord. No. 5632, § 4, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 6171, §§ 1, 2(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, § 12, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), adopted February 12, 2008, repealed former § 4-30.9, which pertained to identification photographs. Section 2 of said ordinance renumbered § 4-30.9A as § 4-30.9. See also the Code Comparative Table. 
Sec. 4-30.10. - Reporting requirements. 
    All owners, keepers or harborers of dangerous animals, within ten (10) days of the incident, shall report the following information in writing to the animal control officer as required hereinafter: 
(a)  The removal from the city or death of a dangerous animal. If removed, the address to which the animal has been removed; 
(b)  The new address of the owner of the dangerous animal should the owner move within the corporate city limits. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5632, § 5, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 6775, § 13, 3-10-15) 
Sec. 4-30.11. - Failure to comply. 
    It shall be unlawful for the owner, keeper or harborer of a permitted dangerous animal to fail to comply with the requirements and conditions set forth in this chapter. Failure to comply will result in the immediate revocation of the dangerous animal permit providing for the keeping of such animal. The notice of revocation shall be provided to the owner in writing. 
    Any owner of a permitted dangerous animal found to be the subject of violation of this chapter shall be given the opportunity to appeal the permit revocation and be heard through the administrative hearing process pursuant to the provisions of section 4-30.14. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5981, § 6, 12-13-05; Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, § 16, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Sections 14 and 15 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, repealed former §§ 4-30.11 and 4-30.11A which pertained to animals born of dangerous animals, and dangerous animals spayed or neutered, and derived from Ord. No. 4107, § 2, adopted Oct. 23, 1990; Ord. No. 5632, § 6, adopted June 10, 2003; and Ord. No. 5926, § 6, adopted July 26, 2005. Section 16 of said ordinance renumbered former § 4-30.12 as § 4-30.11. 
Sec. 4-30.12. - Liability insurance required for permitted dangerous animals. 
    All owners, keepers or harborers of permitted dangerous animals must provide proof to the community development department of public liability insurance in a single incident amount of one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for bodily injury to or death of any person or persons or for damage to property owned by any persons which may result from the ownership, keeping or maintenance of such animal. This policy shall contain a provision requiring the city to be named as an additional insured for the sole purpose of the city to be notified by the insurance company of any cancellation, termination or expiration of the policy. This policy shall be presented to the community development department at the initial permit application as well as at future permit renewal times. 
    In the event said liability insurance is cancelled, lapses, or for any other reason becomes nonenforceable, said owner, keeper, or harborer shall be in violation of the provisions of the chapter and subject to the penalties provided herein. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, § 17, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Section 17 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-30.13 as § 4-30.12. 
Sec. 4-30.13. - Notice of keeping dangerous animals in violation; seizure and impounding of same. 
    Upon written notice of a person owning, keeping or harboring a dangerous animal in a violation of this chapter, the animal control officer shall investigate the matter and determine if violation has occurred. The animal control officer shall put in writing findings of fact and, if a violation has occurred, shall send written notice to the violator to remove the animal from the city or properly apply for a permit as provided herein within ten (10) days. If the dangerous animal previously has caused injury or death or has escaped or is running at large, the animal control officer shall immediately seize and impound said animal, or tranquilize or kill said animal if seizure and impoundment are not possible without risk of serious physical harm or death to any person. If person owning, keeping or harboring animal does not comply within the ten-day period, the animal control officer shall seize and impound the animal as provided herein and may arrange to have the animal destroyed in a humane manner after notice to the owner and after giving the owner the opportunity to be heard pursuant to the provisions of section 4-30.8. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5981, § 7, 12-13-05; Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, § 18, 3-10-15) 
Editor's note- Section 18 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-30.14 as § 4-30.13. 
Sec. 4-30.14. - Appeals; fees; administrative hearing; subpoena power; violations and penalties. 
    Any person aggrieved by or dissatisfied with any decision, ruling, action, or finding of the City of Grandview and/or its animal control officer pursuant to the provisions of this article IV may, within ten (10) days thereafter, request in writing a hearing on said decision, ruling, action or finding to the director of community development. The request for a hearing under this subsection shall not stay any action taken pursuant to this chapter except a decision of the animal control officer to destroy the dangerous animal. The hearing provided for shall be conducted by the department of community development. The sole issue for determination shall be whether decisions, rulings, actions, or findings of the animal control officer are supported by substantial evidence, and not arbitrary or capricious in nature. If, after a hearing, the director of community development upholds the animal control officer's decision to destroy the dangerous animal, the humane destruction of said animal may proceed unless a court of competent jurisdiction enjoins such destruction within ten (10) days. 
    The owner or keeper of an animal deemed dangerous pursuant to section 4-30.2 of this chapter, after exhausting the appeal provisions of this section 4-30.14, shall cause the spaying or neutering of said animal within ten (10) days after service of the written decision denying said appeal and shall immediately thereafter provide written proof of such procedure signed by a licensed veterinarian performing such procedure. 
    Any person violating or permitting the violation of any provision of sections 4-29 or 4-30 of this chapter shall, upon conviction be fined a sum not less than two hundred dollars ($200.00) and not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00). In addition to the fine imposed, the court may sentence the defendant to imprisonment in the city jail for a period not to exceed ninety (90) days. In addition, the court shall order the registration of and permit for the subject dangerous animals revoked and the animal removed from the city. Should the defendant refuse to remove dangerous animal from the city, the municipal court judge may find the defendant owner in contempt and order the immediate confiscation and impoundment of the animal. In addition to a conviction for the violation of any provision of sections 4-29 or 4-30, the municipal judge may order the destruction of said animal in a humane manner by the animal control officer, and for that purpose, the officer may enter upon any private premises to carry out such order. Each day that a violation of this chapter continues it shall be deemed a separate offense. In addition to the foregoing penalties, any person who violates this chapter shall pay all expenses, including shelter, food, handling, veterinary care, and testimony necessitated by the enforcement of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5632, § 3, 6-10-03; Ord. No. 5981, § 5, 12-13-05; Ord. No. 6171, § 1(Exh. A), 2-12-08; Ord. No. 6775, § 19, 3-10-15; Ord. No. 6848, § 1, 12-8-15) 
Editor's note- Section 19 of Ord. No. 6775, adopted March 10, 2015, renumbered and amended former § 4-30.15 as § 4-30.14. 
ARTICLE V. - ANIMAL BITE PROCEDURES 

Sec. 4-31. - When animal is deemed to have been exposed to rabies. 
    An animal has been exposed to rabies within the meaning of this article if it has been bitten by any other animal known or reasonably suspected to be infected with rabies. Any individual or business having in his or its charge any animal which has been substantially exposed to rabies, upon failure to have it impounded or appropriately disposed of as determined by a veterinarian, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-32. - Confinement of animals after having bitten someone. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for the owner or any person to harbor any animal that has bitten any person or has so injured any person as to cause an abrasion to the skin, to sell or give away such animal or to permit or allow such animal to be taken from the owner's premises, except under the care of a licensed veterinarian, humane officer or police officer. 
(b)  It shall be the duty of any person injured through having been bitten or clawed by a dog or cat or any animal to report same as soon as possible directly to the humane officer or the police department. 
(c)  It shall be the duty of the owner or keeper of such dog, cat or any animal upon receiving notice that the animal has bitten someone, to immediately inform the humane officer or the police department and, if the animal does not have a current rabies vaccination, to confine such animal in a licensed veterinary hospital within a five (5) mile radius of the corporate limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri, or in the bite observation room of the city pound for not less than ten (10) days nor more than twelve (12) days from the date of the bite, or to use one (1) of the alternatives for confinement, if applicable, found in section 4-33. The humane officer shall maintain animal bite reports for a period of not less than two (2) years after the court date or if no court date is involved, then not less than two (2) years after the date the bite occurrence is reported. If any such dog or cat or other animal is dangerous, fierce or vicious, and cannot safely be taken into custody and impounded, such dog or cat or other animal may be rendered harmless by using a tranquilizer weapon, such weapon to be used only by the humane officer or police officer. 
(d)  It shall be the duty of the veterinarian or city-authorized impounding agent, with whom the impounded animal is placed, to notify the humane officer, in writing, that such animal has been confined and will remain so for ten (10) to twelve (12) days. After the period of confinement ends, the veterinarian or city-authorized impounding agent shall inform the humane officer, in writing, as to the health of the animal pertaining to the diagnosis of rabies. 
(e)  Should any animal so held for observation be found to be suffering from rabies or be of such nature to endanger the public generally, the humane officer shall cause such animal, after examination by a licensed veterinarian, to be destroyed in a humane manner. The humane officer and any police officer may, for the purpose of this section, enter upon any private premises. If such animal is not afflicted, it may be returned to its owner as hereinafter provided. In the event such animal is confined under the provisions of this section, the owner thereof shall be liable for any fees and costs which accrued because of the detention of such animal. 
(f)  Before any such dog or cat or other animal shall be released, the person to whom it is released shall have a licensed veterinarian administer a rabies inoculation unless such dog or cat or other animal has a current rabies inoculation. 
(g)  If such confined animal develops symptoms of rabies, it shall be allowed to die a natural death or, if the animal shall die while in confinement for any reason, the head of such animal shall be removed by a veterinarian or other qualified person and submitted to any qualified official laboratory for examination, which expense shall be paid by the owner or keeper of the dog, cat, or other animal. 
(h)  It shall be the duty of the humane officer to promptly notify the victim's family both verbally and in writing of the location where the animal is confined, the date of confinement, whether rabies was present, and the date the animal was released from confinement. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5055, §§ 2, 3, 2-10-98) 
Sec. 4-33. - Alternatives for confined animal. 
    In the event the investigating humane officer determines that the animal which injured the person did so while confined on a chain or leash on property under control of the animal's owner or within a fence or building enclosing property under control of the animal's owner, and the person injured was upon the owner's property when injured, or in the event the investigating humane officer determines that the animal has bitten or injured its owner or a member of the owner's family as to cause an abrasion to the skin, and if the animal which caused the injury has an affective rabies inoculation and displays a rabies vaccination tag as required under section 4-36 of the City Code at the time of the injury, then the animal need not be impounded in accordance with section 4-32 of the City Code. However, in such cases, the following alternative procedure shall be followed: 
(1)  If the injured person, his/her parent or guardian desires that the animal be impounded and agrees in writing to pay for its board during the period of impoundment, it shall be so impounded for the period specified in section 4-32, notwithstanding any other provisions of this chapter. 
(2)  If the injured party, or his/her parent or guardian is unwilling to agree in writing to pay for the animal's board during the period of impoundment, the animal shall be permitted to remain on the property of its owner or keeper, provided such person signs a written agreement to keep the animal confined to the property for the period specified in section 4-32 and further agrees to allow the animal to be examined periodically to determine its physical condition during the confinement period. Such home confinement shall require that the animal be confined inside the home except for twenty (20) minute exercise periods each day in which case the animal must be tethered. If the owner or keeper is unwilling to sign such an agreement, the animal shall be immediately impounded in accordance with section 4-32. 
(3)  In cases where a dog, cat or other animal has bitten or so injured his owner or member of the owner's family so as to cause an abrasion of the skin, the dog or other animal may be held on the premises of the owner for the lawful observation period. 
(4)  When such dog or cat or other animal has been held by the individual, it will be the duty of the owner or keeper to cause delivery of the dog or cat or other animal to be made to a veterinarian within the corporate limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri, for rabies inoculation. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5055, § 4, 2-10-98; Ord. No. 5600, § 5, 2-11-03) 
Sec. 4-33.1. - Early destruction of animals where ownership released to the city. 
    In the event the owner of the animal which caused injury to any person by biting desires to execute a written release of ownership of said animal to the city in lieu of complying with the confinement provisions of section 4-32 and/or 4-33 of this Article V, said animal may be immediately destroyed in a humane manner and the head of said animal delivered to the State Department of Health for pathological examination. Before the city can accept ownership of said animal for purposes of this section, the owner or the bite victim, or the bite victim's parent(s) or guardian(s), must promise in writing, on a form approved by the director of community development, to pay for all costs associated with the impoundment, boarding, destruction and testing of said animal. 
(Ord. No. 5293, § 1, 8-22-00) 
Sec. 4-34. - Killing or removal from city of animal exposed to rabies prohibited; exception. 
    No person shall kill an animal exposed to rabies, nor remove such an animal from the city without permission from the humane officer or a police officer, except when it is necessary to kill such animal to prevent it from escaping or from biting any other animal or person. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-35. - Surrender of body of animal. 
    The body of any animal dead of rabies or having been exposed to rabies prior to death shall be surrendered to the humane officer or police officer by the owner upon demand from the humane officer or a police officer. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-36. - Inoculation against rabies required; rabies vaccination tags required. 
(a)  No person shall own, keep, harbor or maintain any dog or cat, six (6) months of age or older, within the city which has not been vaccinated with anti-rabies vaccine by a registered veterinarian. A rabies tag issued by the licensed veterinarian administering the anti-rabies vaccine shall constitute proof of the vaccination. 
(b)  The owner of any dog or cat, six (6) months of age or older, kept, harbored, or maintained within the city, shall cause a current rabies vaccination tag issued by a licensed veterinarian to be fixed to the collar or harness of such dog or cat at all times and in such a manner that the rabies vaccination tag can be easily seen. 
(c)  If a rabies vaccination tag required by this section 4-36 is lost or stolen, it shall be the duty of the animal's owner to obtain a replacement tag from a licensed veterinarian. 
(d)  Veterinarians conducting business in the city shall be required to provide rabies vaccination tags to owners of dogs and cats vaccinated by such veterinarian. Such rabies tags shall identify the veterinarian and shall display a unique number identifying the vaccinated animal. The licensed veterinarian covered by this section 4-36 shall maintain complete records of vaccinations administered for a period of three (3) years, including the identity of the animal and the animal's owner. Such records shall be opened to the director of community development, animal control officer, or their designees upon reasonable notice. 
(e)  When rabies or other communicable diseases are known to exist in the community, or in neighboring communities, the mayor, director of community development, or their designees may declare a quarantine of all dogs, cats, other domestic animals, and any other warm-blooded animals. The owners of quarantined animals shall be responsible for confinement of such animals. If any owner does not comply with these provisions, the mayor may deputize persons as needed to ascertain ownership of an unconfined animal and to issue warrants of arrest against a violating owner. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5600, § 6, 2-11-03) 
ARTICLE VI. - COMMERCIAL ANIMAL ESTABLISHMENTS 

Sec. 4-37. - Commercial animal establishment standards. 
(a)  Any person operating a commercial animal establishment shall keep and maintain the animals, and all structures, pens, or yards, tanks, ponds, or other holding areas in which the animals are kept, in such a manner as to prevent a nuisance or health hazard to humans and to avoid injury and illness to these animals. All holding areas must be properly sanitized so as to keep the animals enclosed therein free of diseases. All such animals shall be provided with a constant supply of wholesome food and water or in lieu of this, the proprietor shall prominently and publicly post and shall follow a schedule for adequate feeding and watering. A schedule shall also be posted for cleaning and maintaining cages and other holding areas at the facility. Any animal that is infected or diseased with an infectious agent shall be immediately isolated in such a manner as to prevent spread of disease to any other healthy animals, and it shall be treated immediately to prevent further condition deterioration or euthanized, and if the owner or keeper fails or refuses to provide for such, the humane officer may remove each such animal for disposition as provided by this chapter. 
(b)  All commercial animal establishments which are proposed to be operated and located within the city, must obtain an occupational license from the Finance Department. Such license shall be renewable each year on June 30. Prior to renewal, the humane officer shall inspect the establishment annually prior to renewal of the license. The license will be considered delinquent if not renewed by June 30 of the following year. Such license shall not be issued to an applicant unless the humane officer finds the applicant qualified and able to operate the proposed business in a safe and humane manner. Such license shall not be renewed unless the humane officer finds that the license holder has operated his or her business in a safe and humane manner in the previous permit period. Said permit shall be a prerequisite to obtaining an occupational license to operate the business in question on the specific premises licensed. An application form for such a license will be made available by the Finance Department to any applicant and will provide information concerning the owner and applicant, the type of business proposed, all previous businesses of this or similar nature operated, background qualifying applicant to operate the proposed business in a safe and humane manner, and any other information required for the humane officer to make an objective judgment as to whether or not the applicant is qualified to operate the proposed business in a safe and humane manner. During the permit process, the applicant must also provide proof that his or her proposed or existing establishment meets zoning, building code, and fire code requirements. The applicant shall also furnish to the humane officer a written program of veterinary care outlining inoculation, worming and other necessary care, treatment or euthanasia to prevent the exchange, barter, sale, rental or hire of such animals which are diseased or unfit. The adequacy of such a program will be a prerequisite for obtaining said license. Prior to authorizing a new license or renewing an existing license, the humane officer will inspect the proposed or existing business premise as to its suitability for its intended use. Such inspection will include but not be limited to holding areas, primary enclosures, waste disposal methods, food and bedding, vermin control, heating and ventilation, and isolation facilities. All such facilities where animals are kept are subject to comply with the needs of animals as outlined in section 4-3 of this chapter. It shall be grounds for permit revocation or denial, for an owner proprietor, manager, or employee to refuse or deny access to any humane officer for the purposes of inspection or complaint investigation with reference to granting, renewing, suspending or revoking a commercial animal establishment permit. The humane officer shall make any denial, suspension or revocation of a permit in writing to the applicant or license holder stating the reasons for such action. The applicant or license holder shall have ten (10) days after receipt of such denial, suspension or revocation in which he may appeal from such to the Director of Community Development Department, and said director or director's assistant, if designated, shall conduct a hearing and make findings in such fashion that the result of such hearing may be appealed on the record to the Municipal Court. Appeal by a license holder shall stay suspension or revocation of the permit pending final disposition of the appeal. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-38. - Kennels; standards of operation, inspection and inspection fee. 
(a)  Kennels. Any person who shall own and keep or harbor upon his premises more than four (4) dogs or cats or any combination thereof where such animals are four (4) months of age or older, shall be deemed the operator of a kennel. For purposes of this section and for purposes of counting the number of animals owned and kept or harbored by any person, dogs and cats four (4) months of age and under shall be counted as though they are older than four (4) months where such animals were born to a mother not properly licensed to such person at the time of birth. It shall be unlawful to operate a kennel within the corporate limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri, which violates the zoning ordinance or the standards of operation established in this section. 
(b)  Standards of operation. Kennel premises shall be maintained in a clean and sanitary condition at all times and sanitary methods shall be used to obliterate or prevent any offensive odors. 
(c)  Inspection. The humane officer shall have the right to make an unannounced inspection of such kennels at all reasonable hours. The humane officer shall inspect each registered kennel operating within the corporate limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri, at least once each calendar year to ensure compliance with the standards of operation. 
(d)  Registration. Any person who is deemed to be the operator of a kennel within the corporate limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri, shall register said kennel on a form provided by the office of Community Development. 
(e)  Inspection fee. At the time of initial registration of each kennel and annually thereafter, the operator of a kennel shall pay an inspection fee of ten dollars ($10.00). 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5424, § 2, 9-25-01) 
ARTICLE VII. - ENFORCEMENT AND PENALTIES 

Sec. 4-39. - Enforcement of chapter. 
    The enforcement of the terms and provisions of this chapter are made the duty of the Director of Community Development, or anyone having the authority of humane officer or city police officer. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-40. - Right of pursuit of humane officer; right of entry of humane officer, etc.; interference with humane officer, etc., prohibited. 
    The humane officer or any police officer is authorized to enter upon any enclosed grounds adjacent to private dwellings or other structures within the corporate limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri, for the sole purpose of pursuit, apprehension and removal of the dog(s), and/or cat(s), in violation of sections 4-19, or 4-20, or other animals where a violation of sections 4-3, 4-9, 4-10, 4-25, 4-27, 4-29, or 4-30 of the Grandview City Code has occurred. Interference with the authorized actions of the humane officer or police officer in carrying out their duties is prohibited and subject to penalties contained in section 4-42. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-41. - Hospitals, clinics, etc., exempt from provisions of chapter; exceptions. 
    Hospitals, clinics and other facilities operated by veterinarians for the treatment of animals are exempt from all provisions of this chapter except sections 4-36 and 4-40. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Sec. 4-42. - Violations of sections 4-10.2, 4-19, 4-20 or 4-36. 
    Any persons violating sections 4-10.2, 4-19, 4-20, or 4-36 of Chapter 4 of the Code of the City of Grandview shall, upon conviction and after the court, subsequent to such conviction, has examined any prior conviction record to determine if the person has previously been convicted of the same offense within the previous three (3) years, be sentenced by the court according to the following schedule of fines with reference to initial or subsequent violation of the particular section within the said three (3) year period. 
(1)  First violation ..... $ 40.00 
(2)  Second violation ..... 80.00 
(3)  Third violation ..... 140.00 
(4)  Fourth violation ..... 280.00 
(5)  Fifth violation ..... 500.00 
On the sixth or any subsequent offense the judge shall have the option to order the destruction of the animal by the humane officer. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90; Ord. No. 5600, § 7, 2-11-03; Ord. No. 5926, § 7, 7-26-05) 
Sec. 4-42.1. - Penalties for violation of section 4-3. 
    The inhumane treatment, abuse, and animal neglect is a Class C misdemeanor. Any person violating section 4-3 of Chapter 4 of the City of Grandview Code of Laws entitled "inhumane treatment, abuse, and neglect of animals prohibited", shall upon first conviction, be fined not less than two hundred fifty dollars ($250.00), nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or be imprisoned for not less than three (3) days nor more than ninety (90) days or be both so fined and imprisoned. Each days violation of, or failure, or refusal or neglect to comply with section 4-3 of this chapter shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
    The second and all subsequent convictions shall be a Class B misdemeanor punishable by imprisonment or a fine not to exceed one thousand dollars ($1,000.00), or both. All fines and penalties for a first conviction of animal neglect may be waived by the court provided that the person found guilty of animal neglect shows that adequate permanent remedies for the neglect have been made. Costs incurred for care and maintenance of neglect in animals may not be waived. 
(Ord. No. 4786, § 2, 9-26-95; Ord. No. 5021, § 51, 10-28-97) 
Sec. 4-43. - General penalties for violations. 
(a)  Any person who fails to do anything required by this chapter or who does anything prohibited by this chapter is guilty of a violation thereof. Any person convicted of the violation of any provision of this chapter where a specific penalty is not otherwise prescribed shall be fined not less than fifty dollars ($50.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or imprisoned for not less than three (3) days nor more than ninety (90) days or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(b)  Each day's violation of, or failure, or refusal or neglect to comply with any provision of this chapter shall constitute a separate and distinct offense. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
ARTICLE VIII. - SEVERABILITY 

Sec. 4-44. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, subdivision, paragraph, sentence, clause, or phrase in this chapter, sections 4-1 through 4-44, inclusive, or any part thereof, is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid or ineffective by any court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity of effectiveness of the remaining portions of this chapter or any part thereof. 
(Ord. No. 4107, § 2, 10-23-90) 
Chapter 5 - BARBERSHOPS 

Sec. 5-1. - "Barbershop" defined. 
    The term "barbershop" is hereby defined to be any place where any person engages in the vocation of shaving the beard and cutting and dressing the hair of the general public, predominantly male, for hire. 
(Ord. No. 368, § 4) 
Sec. 5-2. - Hours of operation. 
    No barbershop within the city shall open before 7:00 a.m. any day of the week and shall not remain open after 6:00 p.m. including Saturdays and the day before the following holidays: New Year's Day, Decoration Day, July 4th, Labor Day, Veterans' Day, Thanksgiving Day, Christmas Day and Sunday. 
(Ord. No. 368, § 1) 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate closing hours of barbershops, RSMo § 71.750. 
Sec. 5-3. - Admission after closing hours prohibited. 
    No customer shall be admitted to such barbershop after the hours of closing mentioned in this chapter, provided that work may be performed and services rendered to such customer who enters such barbershop before such closing hour and there remains until served. 
(Ord. No. 368, § 2) 
Sec. 5-4. - Compliance with chapter. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person, or his agent, servants, operators or employees, to keep open or cause or permit to be kept open any barbershop for the purpose of barber service, except as provided herein; and it shall be unlawful for such barber service to be performed or rendered to any customer on any holiday mentioned herein; and it shall be unlawful for any such barbershop service to be performed or rendered to any customer on Sunday or during the hours between the closing and opening time enumerated herein. 
(Ord. No. 368, § 3) 
Chapter 6 - BUILDINGS[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 6-1. - Fire limits. 
    The following shall be and are hereby declared to be the fire limits: All property, lots, lands or area presently located in a district zoned or hereinafter zoned for local business, general business, light industrial or heavy industrial under the zoning regulations and amendments of the city. 
(Ord. No. 132, § 101; Ord. No. 148; Ord. No. 644) 
ARTICLE II. - BUILDING CODE 

Sec. 6-2. - Building construction codes adopted; amended. 
(a)  Building construction codes and adoption of codes. The Board of Alderman of the City of Grandview adopts the building construction codes listed below, which shall be on file with the city clerk. Throughout this article and other articles, chapters and sections within the Grandview Code of Laws, reference to the Grandview Building Construction Code shall mean and consist of the following, including the amendments set out in subsections (c) through (h) of this section: 
(1)  2012 International Building Code, including Appendices B, C, E, F, G, I and J, and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(2)  2012 International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings, including Appendices A, B, C, D, E, F, G, H, J, K, M, N, O, P and Q, and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(3)  2012 International Plumbing Code, including Appendices B, D, E and F, and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(4)  2012 International Mechanical Code, including Appendix A, and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(5)  2012 International Fuel Gas Code, including Appendices A, B, C and D, and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(6)  2012 International Energy Conservation Code and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(7)  2012 International Existing Building Code, including Appendices A, B and C, and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(8)  2012 International Swimming Pool and Spa Code and all supplements published by the International Code Council. 
(9)  2011 National Electric Code, including Appendix H, and all supplements published by the National Fire Protection Association. 
(b)  Conflicts. When there is a conflict between these regulations and other provisions of the Grandview Code of Laws, the Code of Laws shall govern. 
(c)  2012 International Building Code amendments. Section 903.2.8 of [the] 2012 International Building Code is amended to read as follows: 
Section 903.2.8. Automatic Sprinkler Systems. An automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3 shall be provided throughout all buildings with a Group R fire area, except for single-family (or one-family) dwellings or residences or multi-family dwellings of four or fewer units. A builder of one- or two-family dwellings or townhouses shall offer to any purchaser, on or before the date of entering into a purchase contract, the option to install or equip such dwellings or residences with a fire sprinkler system at the purchaser's cost. The requirement that the builder offer to purchaser the option of installing a sprinkler system at the purchaser's cost shall expire on December 31, 2019. Effective January 1, 2020, automatic sprinkler systems shall be required in all multi-family dwellings of two or more units, except automatic sprinkler systems shall not be required for additions or alterations to existing multi-family dwellings that are not already provided with an automatic residential sprinkler system. At no time are automatic residential fire sprinkler systems required to be installed in single-family (or one-family) dwellings. 
1.  Pursuant to Section 67.281.2, RSMo, the adoption herein of the 2012 International Residential Code for One- and Two-Family Dwellings without mandated automatic fire sprinkler systems in Section R313 requires retention of the language in Section R317 of the 2006 International Residential Code for two-family dwellings (R317.1) and townhouses (R317.2). See Section R302 of the 2012 International Residential Code. 
2.  Two-family dwellings. Dwelling units in two-family dwellings shall be separated from each other by wall and/or floor assemblies having not less than a 1 hour fire resistance rating when tested in accordance with ASTME 119. Fire-resistance-rated floor-ceiling and wall assemblies shall extend to and be tight against the exterior wall, and wall assemblies shall extend to the underside of the roof sheathing. 
Exceptions: 
a.  A fire-resistance rating of 1/2 hour shall be permitted in buildings equipped throughout with an automatic sprinkler system installed in accordance with NFPA 13. 
b.  Wall assemblies need not extend through attic spaces when the ceiling is protected by not less than 5/8 ? inch (15.9 mm) Type X gypsum board and an attic draft stop constructed as specified in Section R502.12.1 is provided above and along the wall assembly separating the dwellings. The structural framing supporting the ceiling shall also be protected by not less than 1/2 inch (12.7 mm) gypsum board or equivalent. 
3.  Townhouses. Each townhouse shall be considered a separate building and shall be separated by fire-resistance rated wall assemblies meeting the requirements of Section R302 for exterior walls. Exception: A common 2-hour fire-resistance rated wall is permitted for townhouses if such walls do not contain plumbing or mechanical equipment, ducts or vents in the cavity of the common wall. Electrical installations shall be installed in accordance with Chapters 33 through 42. Penetrations of electrical outlet boxes shall be in accordance with Section R317.3. 
(d)  2012 International Residential Code amendments. The indicated sections of the 2012 International Residential Code are amended or added to read as follows: 
(1)  R105.2 Work exempt from permit. Permits shall not be required for the following. Exemption from permit requirements of this code shall not be deemed to grant authorization for any work to be done in any manner in violation of the provisions of this code or any other laws or ordinances of this jurisdiction . 
Building: 
1.  One-story detached accessory structures used as tool and storage sheds, playhouses and similar uses, provided the floor area does not exceed 30 square feet. 
2.  Retaining walls that are not over 4 feet (1,219 mm) in height measured from the bottom of the footing to the top of the wall, unless supporting a surcharge. 
3.  Water tanks supported directly on grade if the capacity is not greater than 5,000 gallons (18,925 L) and the ratio of height to diameter or width does not exceed 2 to 1. 
4.  Sidewalks and driveways not located within the city or state right-of-way. 
5.  Painting, papering, tiling, carpeting, cabinets, counter tops, and similar finish work. 
6.  Swings and other playground equipment. 
7.  Window awnings supported by an exterior wall which do not project more than 54 inches (1,372 mm) from the exterior wall and do not require additional support.
