47, Range 33, thence south along the east line of said Section 26, to the point of beginning, being the southeast corner of the northeast one-quarter of Section 26, Township 47, Range 33. 
(c)  Ward No. 3. All or parts of Sections 19, 30, and 31, Township 47, Range 32, and Sections 24, 25, and 36, Township 47, Range 33 in the City of Grandview, Jackson County, Missouri, more particularly described as follows: Beginning the northeast corner of Section 19, Township 47, Range 32, thence west along the north line of said Section 19, to the northeast corner of Section 24, Township 47, Range 33, thence west along the north line of said Section 24 1450 ft to the centerline of Winchester Avenue, thence south along the centerline of Winchester Avenue to the centerline of 134th Terrace, thence west along the centerline of 134th Terrace to the centerline of Bennington Avenue, thence southerly along said centerline of Bennington Avenue to the centerline of 140th Place, thence westerly along said centerline to the centerline of 140th Street, thence westerly along the centerline of 140th Street to the west line of Section 25, Township 47, Range 33 south along the west line of said Section 25 to the northwest corner of Section 36, Township 47, Range 33, thence continuing south along the west line of said Section 36 to the southwest corner of said Section 36, thence east along the south line of said Section 36 to the southwest corner of Section 31, Township 47, Range 32, thence east along the south line of said Section 31 to the southeast corner of said Section 31, thence north along the east line of said Section 31, to the southeast corner of Section 30, Township 47, Range 32, thence north along the east line of said Section 30, to the southeast corner of Section 19, Township 47, Range 32, thence north along the east line of said Section 19 to the point of beginning, said point being the northeast corner of Section 19, Township 47, Range 32. 
(Ord. No. 309; Ord. No. 386; Ord. No. 725; Ord. No. 924; Ord. No. 1585; Ord. No. 1792; Ord. No. 2132; Ord. No. 3113, § 2, 11-9-82; Ord. No. 4245, § 1, 10-2-91; Ord. No. 5418, § 1, 9-12-01; Ord. No. 6486, § 1, 9-13-11) 
Sec. 8-2. - Schedule of elections. 
    The mayor and municipal judge shall be elected on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April every second year. An alderman from each ward shall be elected annually on the first Tuesday after the first Monday in April to serve a two-year term. 
(R.O. 1929, Chap. 2, Art. 1, § 3; Ord. No. 118, 3-21-47; Ord. No. 1615 § 5, 4-13-70; Ord. No. 3344 § 1, 5-14-85; Ord. No. 5024, § 1, 10-28-97; Ord. No. 5370, § 2, 4-10-01) 
Sec. 8-3. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5024, § 2, adopted Oct. 28, 1997, repealed former section 8-3 in its entirety which pertained to the method of making election returns and derived from the Revised Ordinances of 1929, Ch. 2, Art. 4, § 13. 
Sec. 8-4. - City clerk to be in charge of elections; duties of police during elections; to be conducted by county board of election commissioners. 
    The city clerk shall be in charge of all elections held in the city. The police of the city shall make their services available to the city clerk and to the judges of election, and generally see that good order is maintained at the polling places; provided, that the city's population having exceeded ten thousand (10,000) as shown by the United States Census of 1960, the election shall be conducted by the county board of election commissioners in accordance with the election laws of the state. 
(Ord. No. 926, § 1; Ord. No. 3344, § 2, 5-14-85) 
Sec. 8-4.1. - Notice of filing for election to be published. 
    The City of Grandview, when calling an election shall, before the sixteenth Tuesday prior to any election at which offices are to be filled, notify the general public of the opening filing date, the office or offices to be filled, the proper place for filing and the closing filing date of the election. Such notification may be accomplished by legal notice published in at least one (1) newspaper of general circulation in the city. 
(Ord. No. 3803, § 1, 10-25-88; Ord. No. 3969, § 1, 10-10-89; Ord. No. 4893, § 4, 7-23-96; Ord. No. 5671, § 2, 9-10-03) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3803, § 1, adopted October 25, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as 8-4.1 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 8-5. - Qualification of voters. 
    All persons over the age of eighteen (18) years who are citizens of the United States and who have resided in the City of Grandview and in the ward in which such citizen proposes to become registered for voting for at least thirty (30) days, shall be entitled to register and vote at all elections for city officials and pertaining to all matters which may be submitted by the board of aldermen to the qualified voters of the city, provided that any such person is not otherwise disqualified under the laws of the United States or of the State of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 1798, Art. 1; Ord. No. 2448, § 2, 6-14-77) 
Sec. 8-6. - Declarations of candidacy. 
(a)  Except as provided in subsection (b) of this section 8-6, all persons aspiring to the election of City of Grandview elective offices shall file their declarations of candidacy in person between the hours of 8:00 a.m. and 5:00 p.m. commencing the sixteenth Tuesday and closing at 5:00 p.m. the eleventh Tuesday prior to the election with the city clerk of the City of Grandview, Missouri, in the city clerk's office in the municipal offices, 1200 Main Street, Grandview Missouri. The office of the city clerk shall not be open on those days designated holidays by the city, nor from 12:00 p.m. to 1:00 p.m. Monday through Friday nor on Saturdays or Sundays. 
(b)  A candidate may file a declaration of candidacy by certified mail if he or she is: 
(1)  Unable to appear in person because of physical disability, and the declaration is accompanied by a sworn statement of a licensed physician so stating; or 
(2)  A member of the Armed Forces of the United States on active duty, and the declaration is accompanied by a sworn statement of the candidate's commanding officer so stating. 
    To be effective, a declaration of candidacy submitted by certified mail as permitted by this subsection (b) must be received by the city clerk on or before the close of filing for in-person filings. 
(Ord. No. 3344, § 3, 5-14-85; Ord. No. 3442, § 1, 12-7-85; Ord. No. 3803, § 2, 10-25-88; Ord. No. 3969, § 2, 10-10-89; Ord. No. 4893, § 1, 7-23-96; Ord. No. 5671, § 1, 9-10-03; Ord. No. 6860, § 1, 2-23-16) 
Sec. 8-7. - Withdrawal of candidacy. 
    Persons who, after filing their names as candidates, wish to withdraw as a candidate, must file their notice of withdrawal with the city clerk in the city clerk's office no later than 5:00 p.m. the eleventh Tuesday prior to the election. 
(Ord. No. 3344, § 4, 5-14-85; Ord. No. 3803, § 3, 10-25-88; Ord. No. 4893, § 2, 7-23-96) 
Sec. 8-8. - Filing fee. 
    The filing fee for all elective municipal offices shall be ten dollars ($10.00). All filing fees shall be paid to the city clerk at the time filing of declaration of candidacy. In case of withdrawal of a candidate, there shall be no refund of filing fee. 
(Ord. No. 3344, § 5, 5-14-85) 
Sec. 8-9. - Notification of election commission. 
    The city clerk shall certify such information as may be necessary to the Jackson County board of election commissioners no later than the tenth Tuesday prior to the election, and they shall conduct the election in accordance with the statutes of the State of Missouri relating to fourth class cities. 
(Ord. No. 3344, § 6, 5-14-85; Ord. No. 4893, § 3, 7-23-96) 
Sec. 8-10. - Filing campaign finance disclosure reports. 
(a)  If a successful candidate, or the treasurer of his candidate committee fails to file the disclosure reports which are required by this chapter, the candidate shall not take office until such reports are filed. 
(b)  In addition to any other penalties provided by law, no person may file for any office in a subsequent election until he or the treasurer of his existing candidate committee has filed all required campaign disclosure reports for all prior elections. 
(Ord. No. 3803, § 4, 10-25-88) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3803, § 4, adopted October 25, 1988, did not specifically amend the Code; therefore, inclusion as § 8-10 was at the discretion of the editor. 
Chapter 9A - FAIR HOUSING 

Sec. 9A-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, the following terms, phrases, words, and their derivations shall have the meaning given herein unless the context otherwise indicates. 
    Financial institution: The term shall mean any person regularly engaged in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans on housing accommodations or real property. 
    Housing accommodation: The term shall mean: 
(1)  Any building or portion thereof, whether such building or portion is constructed or is to be constructed, which is used or intended for use as the residence or sleeping place of one or more persons. 
(2)  The term "housing accommodation" shall not mean or include: 
a.  The rental of a dwelling, or a portion thereof, containing accommodation for no more than two (2) families, one of which is occupied by the owner or his family at the time of rental. 
b.  The rental of less than four (4) rooms in a one-family dwelling to another person or persons by the owner or occupant of such accommodation in which he or members of his family reside. 
    Owner: The word "owner" shall mean and include the owners, lessee, sublessee, assignee, manager, agent, or other person, firm, or corporation, having the right to sell, rent, or lease any housing accommodation or real property within the corporate limits of the city. 
    Person: Shall include one or more individuals, partnerships, associations, organizations, corporations, legal representatives, trustees, trustees in bankruptcy, or receivers. 
    Real estate broker: The term shall mean any person who, for a fee or other valuable consideration, sells, purchases, exchanges, rents, negotiates, offers, or attempts to negotiate the sale, purchase, exchange, or rental of housing accommodations or real property of another person. 
    Real estate salesman or agent: The term shall mean any person employed by a real estate broker to perform, or to assist in the performance of, any or all of the functions of a real estate broker. 
    Real property: The term shall include all real estate, leaseholds, and any vacant land offered for sale or rent. 
    Unlawful discriminatory housing practice: Shall mean any discrimination or segregation or separation against any person or group of persons because of race, sex, national origin or ancestry, religion and handicap, families with children, and shall include only those types of unlawful practices and acts as set forth in section 9A-2 of the chapter. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 9-13-88; Ord. No. 3940, § 1, 8-8-89) 
Sec. 9A-2. - Unlawful discriminatory housing practices. 
    It shall be an unlawful discriminatory housing practice: 
(a)  For the owner, real estate broker, real estate salesmen, or employees or agent thereof: 
(1)  To refuse to sell, rent, assign, lease, or sublease, or offer for sale, rental, lease, assignment, or sublease, or to refuse to negotiate for the sale, rental, lease, assignment, or sublease of any real property or portion thereof which is in fact listed or available for sale, rent, lease, or sublease, to any person who has shown the financial ability to satisfy the terms and conditions of the sale, rental, assignment, lease or sublease of said property or to otherwise deny or withhold any household accommodations or real property or any part or portion thereof to or from any person because of the race, color, sex, religion, national origin, handicap, ancestry, or families with children of such person; or 
(2)  To discriminate against any person because of race, color, sex, religion, national origin, handicap or ancestry, or families with children in the terms, conditions, or privileges of the sale, lease, rental, assignment, or sublease of any housing accommodations or real property or part or portions thereof or in the furnishing of facilities or services in connection therewith; or 
(3)  To print, publish, circulate, issue, display, post, or mail or cause to be printed, published, circulated, issued, displayed, posted, or mailed, any statement, advertisement, publication, or sign or use any form of application for the purchase, rental, lease, assignment, or sublease of any housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification, or discrimination as to race, color, sex, religion, national origin, handicap, families with children, or ancestry or any intent to make any such limitation, specification, or discrimination. 
(b)  For any persons or financial institution or loan institution to which application is made for financial assistance for the purchase, acquisition, or construction of any housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof, or any agent or employee thereof: 
(1)  To discriminate against any person because of the race, color, sex, religion, national origin, handicap, families with children, or ancestry of such person or of prospective occupants or tenants of such housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof in the granting, withholding, extending, modifying, or renewing, or in fixing of the rates, terms, conditions, or provisions of any such financial assistance, or in the extension of services in connection therewith; or 
(2)  To use any form of application for such financial assistance or to make any record or inquiry in connection with applications for such financial assistance or to make any record or inquiry in connection with applications for such financial assistance which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification, or discrimination, as to race, sex, color, religion, national origin, handicap, families with children, or ancestry, or any intent to make any such limitation, specification, or discrimination. 
(c)  For any person, owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman, or agent thereof: 
(1)  To discriminate against any person because of their race, color, sex, religion, national origin, handicap, families with children, or ancestry of such person or of prospective occupants or tenants of such housing accommodations or real property or part or portion thereof in the granting, withholding, extending, modifying, or renewing, or in the fixing of the rates, terms, conditions, or provisions of any such financial assistance, or in the extension of services in connection therewith; or 
(2)  To use any form of application for such financial assistance or make any record or inquiry in connection with applications for such financial assistance which expresses, directly or indirectly, any limitation, specification, or discrimination, as to race, sex, color, religion, national origin, handicap, families with children, or ancestry, or any intent to make any such limitation, specification, or discrimination. 
(d)  For any person, owner, real estate broker, real estate salesman, or agent thereof: 
(1)  To discriminate or to engage in economic or other reprisals against another person because such person complies with the provision of this chapter or has opposed any practice forbidden under this chapter, or has filed a complaint, testified, or assisted in any proceedings under this chapter; or 
(2)  To aid, abet, incite, compel, coerce, cooperate, or participate in the doing of any act declared to be a discriminatory practice under the provisions of this chapter, or to obstruct or prevent compliance with the provisions of this chapter or to attempt directly or indirectly to commit any act declared by this chapter to be a discriminatory practice; or 
(3)  To induce or attempt to induce the sale or listing for sale of any dwelling unit, commercial unit, or real property or any part or portion thereof by representing that a change has occurred or will or may occur with respect to the racial, religious, or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood, or area in which the property is located or to induce or attempt to induce such sale by representing that the presence or anticipated presence of persons of any particular race, religion, sex, national origin, color, handicap, families with children, or national ancestry in the area will or may result in: 
a.  The lowering of property values; 
b.  The change in the racial, religious, or ethnic composition of the block, neighborhood, or area in which the property is located; 
c.  An increase in criminal or antisocial behavior in the area; 
d.  A decline in the quality of the schools serving the area. 
(4)  To design and construct any new multi-family dwelling with four (4) or more dwelling units not meeting all adaptability and accessibility requirements of state and federal law. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 9-13-88; Ord. No. 3940, § 2, 8-8-89; Ord. No. 4123, § 1, 12-11-90) 
Sec. 9A-3. - Exemptions. 
    Nothing in this chapter shall prohibit a religious organization, association, or society, or any nonprofit institution or organization organized, supervised or controlled by or in conjunction with a religious organization, association, or society, from limiting the sale, rentals, or occupancy of dwellings which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose to persons of the same religion, or from giving preference to such persons. Nor shall anything in this chapter prohibit a private club not in fact open to the public, which as an incident to its primary purpose or purposes provides lodging which it owns or operates for other than a commercial purpose, from limiting the rental or occupancy of such lodging to its members or from giving preference to its members. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 9A-4. - Administration of chapter. 
(a)  Any person claiming to be aggrieved of an unlawful discriminatory housing practice, hereinafter referred to as "complainant," may on his own behalf, or by his attorney, make, sign, and file with the city clerk a complaint in writing, under oath, which shall state the name and address of the person alleged to have committed an unlawful discriminatory housing practice. The city clerk will then refer the complaint to the board of aldermen. Said complaint shall set forth the particulars thereof and contain such other information as may be required by the city clerk of the City of Grandview. 
(b)  Alternatively, the board of aldermen may issue, in like manner, a verified complaint of an alleged unlawful discriminatory housing practice. 
(c)  Any complaint filed under this chapter must be filed within thirty (30) days after the date of the alleged incident. 
(d)  In the event of a complaint being filed pursuant to this section, a true copy of such complaint shall forthwith be transmitted by certified United States mail, postage prepaid, addressed to the person complained against. 
(e)  Every complaint of a violation of this chapter shall be referred to the city clerk of the City of Grandview; and the board of aldermen shall forthwith notify the person against whom the complaint is made. The identity of the aggrieved person shall be made known to the person against whom the complaint is made at that time. If the board of aldermen, after investigation, finds there is no merit to this complaint, the same shall be dismissed. If the board of aldermen finds that there is merit to the complaint, in its opinion, then and in that event, it will endeavor to eliminate the alleged discriminatory practice by conference and conciliation. 
(f)  If the board of aldermen, within thirty (30) days from the receipt of such complaint, is unable to eliminate the alleged discriminatory practice by a conference or conferences and conciliation, then and in that event, the city clerk of the City of Grandview shall return the complaint to the city attorney for handling; and, after the final determination of whether or not to prosecute on said complaint, the city attorney may commence a proceeding in the municipal court for the prosecution of said complaint as permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 9A-5. - Penalties. 
(a)  Any person violating any of the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof may be fined in an amount not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00), or be imprisoned not to exceed thirty (30) days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(b)  Any person making false, malicious, or unfounded accusations against any person under oath and under the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof may be fined in an amount not to exceed one hundred dollars ($100.00) or be imprisoned not to exceed thirty (30) days, or be both so fined and imprisoned. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 9-13-88) 
Sec. 9A-6. - Severability. 
    If any section, subsection, sentence, clause, or phrase of this chapter is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portion of this chapter which will remain in full force and effect. 
(Ord. No. 3776, § 1, 9-13-88) 
Chapter 10 - FINANCE AND TAXATION[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Department of finance, § 2-28 et seq.; alcoholic beverage licenses, Ch. 3; licenses generally, Ch. 13; city motor vehicle licenses, § 14-161 et seq.; personnel retirement system, deduction of contributions from wages, § 18-74; sewer use charges, § 25-45 et seq. 
State Law reference- Special assessments, RSMo Ch. 88; financial administration and indebtedness, RSMo Ch. 95; imposition of tax on business limited, RSMo § 71610; taxation in fourth-class cities, RSMo § 94.190 et seq.; city sales tax, RSMo § 94.500 et seq.; collection of delinquent city taxes, RSMo § 140.670 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 10-1. - Cancelled checks to be kept five years; destruction of cancelled checks. 
    The city treasurer is authorized and directed to keep in a safe place all cancelled checks for a period of five (5) years from date of issue and thereafter to destroy such cancelled checks by burning, shredding or such other method of destruction which may be deemed appropriate and to make a report thereof to the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 951, § 1; Ord. No. 2910, § 1, 7-28-81) 
Sec. 10-2. - Redeemed bond coupons to be kept five years; destruction of redeemed bond coupons. 
    The city treasurer is authorized and directed to keep in a safe place redeemed coupons from the city's bonds for a period of five (5) years after their redemption and thereafter to destroy such redeemed coupons by burning, shredding or such other method of destruction which may be deemed appropriate and to make a report thereof to the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 950, § 1; Ord. No. 2910, § 2, 7-28-81) 
Sec. 10-2.1. - Schedule of licenses, fees and charges for services and activities. 
    Those fees and charges set out in Exhibit A to Ordinance 3179, approved by the board of aldermen on September 15, 1983, shall remain in effect unless reestablished or increased by the subsequent adoption of ordinances, resolutions or authorized administrative actions regarding said fees and charges. The city clerk is directed to compile a comprehensive schedule of licenses, fees and charges and to update said schedule whenever existing fees and charges are increased or new fees and charges are adopted. 
(Ord. No. 3179, § 1, 9-15-83; Ord. No. 6756, § 1, 12-23-14) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ord. No. 6756, adopted Dec. 23, 2014, changed the title of § 10-2.1 from "Schedule of licenses, fees and charges for certain services and activities adopted" to read as herein set out. 
ARTICLE II. - COLLECTION OF TAXES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
State Law reference- Payment and collection of current taxes, RSMo, § 139.010 et seq.; collection of delinquent taxes generally, RSMo, § 140.010 et seq. 
Cross reference- Division of collection in the department of finance, § 2-31. 

Sec. 10-3. - Date property liable for taxation. 
    As provided by Revised Statutes of Missouri, section 137.075, every person owning or holding real property or tangible personal property in the city on January 1 of each year, including all such property purchased on that day, shall be liable for taxes thereon during the same calendar year. 
(Ord. No. 562, § 1) 
Sec. 10-4. - Tax books; taxes, duties, etc., charged to city collector. 
    The city clerk shall make out appropriate and accurate tax books, and shall therein set out in suitable columns, opposite the name of each person and the item of taxable property, the amount of taxes, whether general or special, due thereon, and shall charge the city collector with the full amount of taxes levied and to be collected. The city clerk shall also charge the city collector with all licenses and other duties of all kinds to be collected. 
(Ord. No. 562, § 3) 
Sec. 10-5. - When taxes become delinquent; real property taxes constitute lien; when suits may be instituted. 
    On January 1 of each year all unpaid city taxes shall become delinquent, and the taxes upon real property are hereby made a lien thereon. Suits upon all unpaid city taxes may be instituted by the city collector on or after February 1 following, and within five (5) years from such day. 
(Ord. No. 562, § 2) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo § 94.300. 
Sec. 10-6. - Delinquent tax lists-To be made by city collector. 
    The board of aldermen shall require the city collector, at the first meeting of the board of aldermen in April of each year, or as soon thereafter as may be practical, to make out, under oath, lists of delinquent taxes remaining due and uncollected for each year, to be known as "the land and lot delinquent list" and the "personal delinquent list." 
(Ord. No. 562, § 4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo, § 94.320. 
Sec. 10-7. - Same-Examination and approval by board of aldermen. 
    The board of aldermen, at the meeting at which the delinquent lists are returned or as soon as may be practical thereafter, shall examine the lists carefully, and if it appears that all property and taxes contained in the lists are properly returned as delinquent, the board of aldermen shall approve the lists, enter a record thereof in the journal and credit the amount thereof to the account of the city collector. 
(Ord. No. 562, § 5) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo § 94.320. 
Sec. 10-8. - Back tax book-Preparation; contents generally. 
    After the delinquent tax list has been returned by the city collector, as provided by statute and by this chapter, the city clerk shall make a back tax book as follows: 
(a)  All tracts of land or city lots on which back taxes are due shall be listed in numerical order with the legal description thereof. 
(b)  The name of the owner, if known, and if unknown the name of the person to whom such land was last assessed, shall be set forth opposite each tract of land or city lot. 
(c)  In appropriate columns shall be entered the year for which such land is delinquent, the amount of original tax due each fund, the interest due on such tax at the time of making the back tax book, the city clerk's fees then due and the aggregate amount of taxes, interest and city clerk's fees charged against such land for all years delinquent. 
(Ord. No. 311, § 1) 
State Law reference- Similar state law, RSMo § 140.060. 
Sec. 10-9. - Same-To be made in alphabetical order. 
    The back tax book shall be made out, in alphabetical order, in the name of the owner, if known, and if not known, then in the name of the person to whom such land was last assessed. 
(Ord. No. 311, § 1) 
Sec. 10-10. - Collection generally. 
    The board of aldermen shall return the delinquent lists to the city collector, charging him therewith, and he shall proceed to collect the same in the same manner as provided by law for state and county taxes, including the seizure and sale of goods, and chattels, both before and after such taxes shall become delinquent; provided, that all suits for the collection of city taxes shall be brought in the name of the state, at the relation and to the use of the city collector. 
(Ord. No. 562, § 6) 
Sec. 10-11. - Applicability of state land for tax collection law. 
    After January 19, 1965, the city shall be subject to the provisions of the Land Tax Collection Law of the state as set out in chapter 141, Revised Statutes of Missouri, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 1) 
Sec. 10-12. - Preparation and delivery of annual list of real estate tax bills delinquent four or more years to county collector. 
    The city collector is empowered and directed to prepare and deliver annually to the collector for the county, a list of all delinquent real estate tax bills on which city taxes have been delinquent and unpaid for four or more years. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 2) 
Sec. 10-13. - Payment of fees for delivered tax bills. 
    The city collector and other proper officials are authorized and directed to pay the requisite fee of one dollar fifty cents to the county collector for each delinquent tax bill so delivered. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 3) 
Sec. 10-14. - Delivery of tax bills to county collector on property being sold for taxes. 
    The city collector is authorized and directed to check with the county collector from time to time to determine the property in the city which is being sold for taxes and to prepare and deliver delinquent real estate tax bills for the city on all such property, even though the delinquency with the city is less than four years. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 4) 
Sec. 10-15. - Exclusive collection powers in county collector. 
    The city collector is authorized and directed to give to the county collector exclusive collection power on all tax bills delivered to the county for collection. 
(Ord. No. 927, § 5) 
Sec. 10-16. - Delinquency penalties. 
(a)  Real and personal property tax: In addition to the amount of real and personal property tax delinquent, and fees and costs as provided by statute, a penalty shall be charged as follows: 
(1)  For all real and personal property taxes, fees and costs delinquent prior to January 1, 1983, one percent of the unpaid tax per month shall be charged, not to exceed ten (10) percent per year, to January 1, 1983. 
(2)  For all real and personal property taxes, fees and costs delinquent prior to January 1, 1983, two (2) percent of the unpaid tax per month shall be charged, not to exceed eighteen (18) percent per year, after January 1, 1983. 
(3)  For all real and personal property taxes, fees and costs first becoming delinquent on or after January 1, 1983, two (2) percent of the unpaid tax per month shall be charged, not to exceed eighteen (18) percent per year. 
In addition, a collector's commission of two (2) percent of the amount of the delinquent tax and any interest due on the account shall also be charged. 
(b)  Merchants' and manufacturers' inventory tax: In addition to the amount of merchants' and manufacturers' inventory tax delinquent, and fees and costs as provided by statute, a penalty of one percent of the amount of the delinquent tax per month shall be charged, not to exceed ten (10) percent per year. In addition, interest at a rate of ten (10) percent per annum shall be assessed on any amount of delinquent tax and penalty. Additionally, after calculation of interest and penalty as provided for by this section, a collector's commission of two (2) percent of the total amount of the delinquent tax, penalty and interest shall be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 562, § 7; Ord. No. 2825, § 1, 10-28-80; Ord. No. 3044, § 1, 6-8-82; Ord. No. 3118, § 1, 12-28-82) 
ARTICLE III. - PURCHASING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2761, § 1, adopted March 26, 1980, repealed Ord. No. 1021, which provided for purchasing by the city; §§ 2-4 and 6-21 of said ordinance were formerly codified herein as Art. III of Ch. 10, §§ 10-17-10-39. 
In lieu of said former provisions, and at his discretion, the editor has included §§ 3-9 of Ord. No. 2761 as a new Art. III of Ch. 10, §§ 10-17-10-23. 

Sec. 10-17. - Definitions. 
    As used in this article: 
    Supplies shall be deemed to mean supplies, materials, equipment, contractual services and any and all articles or things, except as in this article otherwise provided. 
    Purchase shall include the rental or leasing of any equipment, articles or things. 
(Ord. No. 2761, § 3, 3-26-80) 
Sec. 10-18. - Rules and regulations applicable; publication in purchasing manual. 
    The city administrator is hereby authorized and directed to establish and promulgate rules and regulations which will govern the conduct of city purchasing. Such rules and regulations shall be published and designated as the "Purchasing Manual for the City of Grandview." Said manual shall be subject to initial approval, by resolution, of the board of aldermen. Thereafter, the city administrator may, from time to time, suggest changes and amendments to such purchasing manual, which changes or amendments shall be first approved by resolution of the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 2761, § 8, 3-26-80) 
Sec. 10-19. - City purchasing agent-Designation. 
    The city purchasing agent shall be designated by the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 2761, § 4, 3-26-80) 
Sec. 10-20. - Same-Powers and duties generally. 
    The city purchasing agent shall perform all duties with respect to the purchase of supplies as required by this article or other ordinances and shall have the powers and duties as set forth in the city purchasing manual. 
(Ord. No. 2761, § 5, 3-26-80) 
Sec. 10-21. - Purchasing manual adopted. 
    The revised purchasing manual for the city is hereby adopted and is on file and available for inspection in the office of the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 4717, §§ 1, 2, 3-28-95) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4717, § 1, adopted March 28, 1995, repealed former § 10-21 and added a new § 10-21. Former § 10-21 pertained to purchasing methods and derived from Ord. No. 2761, adopted March 26, 1980, and Ord. No. 3474, adopted March 26, 1986. 
Sec. 10-22. - Conformity with budget appropriations. 
(a)  Required. All purchases of supplies under section 10-21 shall be made in accordance with annual budget appropriations. 
(b)  City treasurer to certify existence of funds to pay for certain orders. The city purchasing agent shall not issue any order for delivery on a contract or open-market purchase in excess of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) until the city treasurer has certified that there exists an unencumbered appropriation balance, in excess of all unpaid obligations, sufficient to defray the cost of the contract or purchase. 
(Ord. No. 2761, §§ 6, 9(d), 3-26-80) 
Sec. 10-23. - Conflict of interest. 
(a)  Definitions. The terms used in this section are defined as follows: 
(1)  Official or employee. Any person elected or appointed to, or employed or retained by, any public body of the City of Grandview, whether paid or unpaid and whether part-time or full-time. 
(2)  Public body. Any agency, board, body, commission, committee, department or office of the city. 
(3)  Financial interest. Any interest of an official or employee in another person or entity if: (i) The interest is ownership of ten (10) percent or more of the voting stock, shares or equity of the entity or ownership of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) of the equity or market value of the entity; or (ii) funds received by the official or employee from the other person or entity either during the previous twelve (12) months or the previous calendar year equal or exceeds five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) in salary, bonuses, commissions or professional fees or twenty thousand dollars ($20,000.00) in payment for goods, products or nonprofessional services, or ten (10) percent of the official or employee's gross income during that period, whichever is less; or (iii) the official or employee serves as a corporate officer or member of the board of directors or other governing board of the for-profit entity, other than a corporate entity owned or created by the board of aldermen; or (iv) the official or employee is a creditor, debtor, or guarantor of the other person or entity in an amount of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more. 
"Financial interest" includes any interest in real property which is an equitable or legal ownership with a market value of five thousand dollars ($5,000.00) or more. 
(4)  Personal interest. Any interest arising from blood or marriage relationships or from close business or political association whether or not any financial interest is involved. 
(b)  Conflict of interest. Any official or employee who, either on his own behalf or on the behalf of any other person, knows or has reason to know of any financial or personal interest in any business or transaction with any public body shall make full public disclosure of the nature and extent of such financial or personal interest. The disclosure shall be made in writing to the city clerk at the time the conflict occurs and during the month of January every year thereafter while such affected financial or personal interest continues. The information on the disclosure, except for any valuation attributed to the reported interest, shall be made available by the city clerk to any citizen of this state for inspection, provided, however, the valuation shall be confidential. 
(c)  Disqualification. Whenever the performance of official duties shall require any official or employee to deliberate and vote on any matter involving a financial or personal interest, said official or employee shall publicly disclose the nature and extent of such interest on the record of the public body involved, and such official or employee shall disqualify himself from participating in the deliberation as well as in the voting. 
(d)  Bidding. No contract or purchase involving services or property in a value in excess of one thousand dollars ($1,000.00) shall be made with or from any person or business entity in which any official or employee of the city has a financial or personal interest unless the contract or purchase is made after public notice and competitive bidding. 
Secs. 10-24-10-39. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - CIGARETTE TAX[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 4793, §§ 1, 2, adopted Oct. 10, 1995, amended Art. IV of Ch. 10 by repealing former sections 10-40-10-51 of this article and enacting new provisions as herein set out. Former sections 10-40-10-51 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 3309, § 2(subparts 1-12), adopted Jan. 22, 1985. 

Sec. 10-40. - Definitions. 
    When used in this article, the following words shall have the meanings herein indicated: 
    Cigarettes: Any roll for smoking made wholly or in part of tobacco irrespective of size or shape and whether or not such tobacco is flavored, adulterated or mixed with any other ingredient, the wrapper or cover of which is made of paper or any other substance or material except tobacco. 
    Cigarette occupation license tax: The cigarette occupation license tax is the tax imposed by the city under this article upon the business of and for the privilege of selling cigarettes in the City of Grandview. 
    Cigarette sales license: That license required by this article to be obtained for the privilege of selling cigarettes in the City of Grandview. 
    Finance director: The term "finance director" shall mean the person appointed to the position of finance director of the City of Grandview and his designated representatives. 
    Manufacturer of cigarettes: Any person or business engaged in the business of manufacturing cigarettes for distribution, delivery, give away, or conveyance by any means, to wholesale, wholesale/retail, and/or retail cigarette dealers. 
    Missouri retail sales/use tax license: That license issued by the Missouri Department of Revenue to all manufacturers, wholesalers, and retail cigarette dealers for the purpose of sales/use tax collections and reporting. 
    Package: A quantity of cigarettes wrapped and sealed in paper, tin foil or otherwise by the manufacturer of cigarettes prior to being placed in cartons for shipment from the manufacturer. 
    Police chief: The term "police chief" shall mean the person appointed to the position of police chief of the City of Grandview and his designated representatives. 
    Retail cigarette dealer: Any person or business engaged in the selling or disposing of cigarettes, by personal handling, vending machine, or any other means, to the ultimate consumer. 
    Sale: Any transfer of title or possession, or both, exchange or barter, conditional or otherwise, in any manner or by any means whatsoever for a consideration, or any agreement therefor. 
    Vending machine: A mechanical device used for the sale and dispensing of cigarettes and automatically operated by the purchaser through the deposit of coins, slugs or tokens. 
    Wholesale cigarette dealer: Any person or business engaged in selling, distributing, delivering, giving away, or conveying by any means, cigarettes to retail dealers or other persons for the purpose of resale only. 
    Wholesale/retail cigarette dealer: Any person or business qualifying as both a wholesale dealer, and a retail dealer as those terms are defined in this section. 
(Ord. No. 4793, § 2, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 4921, § 3(1), 11-12-96) 
Sec. 10-41. - Dealer's and manufacturers' licenses. 
(a)  Cigarette sales license. 
(1)  Every manufacturer of cigarettes shall obtain a cigarette sales license for each such place of business from which they operate within the City of Grandview. 
(2)  Every wholesale cigarette dealer shall obtain a cigarette sales license for each place of business from which they operate within the city. Every wholesale cigarette dealer located outside the City of Grandview who is engaged in the selling of cigarettes or offering, delivering, displaying, or conveying by any means, the same for resale by retail cigarette dealers in the City of Grandview shall obtain a cigarette sales license for the privilege of selling cigarettes within the city. 
(3)  Every wholesale/retail cigarette dealer shall obtain a cigarette sales license for each place of business from which they operate within the city. Every wholesale/retail cigarette dealer located outside the City of Grandview who is engaged in the selling of cigarettes or offering, delivering, displaying, or conveying by any means, the same for resale to retail cigarette dealers or sale to ultimate consumers within the city shall obtain a cigarette sales license for the privilege of selling cigarettes in the city. 
(4)  Every retail cigarette dealer shall obtain a cigarette sales license for each place of business from which they operate within the city. A separate license must be obtained for each such place of business selling or offering cigarettes for sale. 
(5)  For purposes of this section, each vending machine shall be considered a separate place of business requiring a separate license. 
(6)  At the same time applications for cigarette sales licenses are completed, the applicant shall pay to the finance director a cigarette sales license fee of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for each such license. 
(b)  Application; issuance. Every application for a cigarette sales license shall be made upon a form prescribed, prepared and furnished by the finance director and the city clerk and shall set forth such information as they shall require. Upon approval of the application by the city clerk, the city shall grant and issue to the applicant a cigarette sales license as herein provided. 
(c)  Restrictions. 
(1)  Excluding manufacturers, no cigarette sales license shall be issued until a current Missouri retail sales/use tax license has been obtained from the Missouri Department of Revenue as required, and said license number submitted to the city. 
(2)  No cigarette sales license shall be issued until any and all fees and taxes due the city are paid in full. 
(3)  Cigarette sales licenses shall not be assignable and shall be valid only for the persons and locations identified in the license as issued. 
(4)  Cigarette sales licenses shall at all times be conspicuously displayed at the location for which it is issued. 
(5)  Each vending machine requiring a cigarette sales license shall conspicuously display its license at all times. 
(6)  All cigarette sales licenses shall expire on June 30 of each year, unless sooner suspended, surrendered or revoked for cause as provided herein. 
(d)  Duplicates. Whenever any cigarette sales license issued pursuant to this article is defaced, lost or destroyed, the city clerk shall issue a duplicate license upon the payment of a fee of fifty cents ($0.50). 
(Ord. No. 4793, § 2, 10-10-95) 
Sec. 10-42. - Cigarette occupation license tax. 
    In addition to the cigarette sales license fee, every wholesale cigarette dealer, or wholesale/retail cigarette dealer, or their servant, employee, authorized representative or agent, shall pay to the city a cigarette occupation license tax at the rate of two dollars and fifty cents ($2.50) per thousand for all cigarettes sold, offered for sale, delivered, displayed for sale, or otherwise disposed of, or conveyed by any means, and for all cigarettes in his possession. 
(Ord. No. 4793, § 2, 10-10-95) 
Sec. 10-43. - Payment of tax. 
    The cigarette occupation license tax shall be paid to the finance director. It shall be the duty of every wholesale or wholesale/retail cigarette dealer or other person or their servant, employee, authorized representative, or agent to remit the monthly cigarette tax reporting form and full payment by the 15th day of each following month. The cancelled check, accompanied by the monthly cigarette tax reporting form, shall be proof of payment. 
(Ord. No. 4921, § 3(2), 11-11-96) 
Editor's note- Section 1 of 4921, adopted November 12, 1996, repealed 10-43 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to tax paid by purchase of stamps, affixing by wholesale, or wholesale/retail cigarette dealer, and derived from § 2 of 4793, adopted October 10, 1995. Section 3(2) of said ordinance did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § 3(2) of said ordinance as § 10-43 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 10-44. - Rules and regulations; reporting. 
    For the purpose of enabling the finance director to enforce the terms of this ordinance, the following provisions are enacted: 
(a)  Each retail, wholesale, or wholesale/retail cigarette dealer or other person or their servant, employee, authorized representative or agent shall procure and retain invoices showing the amount and value of the shipment of cigarettes received, the date thereof, and the name of the shipper, and shall retain this invoice for a period of three (3) years subject to the use and inspection of the finance director and police chief. 
(b)  All retail, wholesale, or wholesale/retail cigarette dealers or other persons or their servants, employees, authorized representatives, or agents shall maintain and keep for a period of three (3) years such other records of cigarettes received, sold, or delivered within the city as may be required by the finance director. 
(c)  Any cigarette tax reporting information received by the city from the State of Missouri shall be held in confidence by the finance director and used solely for verifying cigarette tax payments. 
(Ord. No. 4921, § 3(3), 11-12-96) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4921, adopted November 12, 1996, repealed § 10-44 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to sale at retail without tax stamps prohibited; counterfeiting altering of stamps prohibited; tampering with meter machines prohibited, and derived from § 2 of Ord. No. 4793, adopted October 10, 1995. Section 3(3) of said ordinance did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § 3(3) as § 10-44 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 10-45. - Sale or dispensing of cigarettes without payment of cigarette occupation license taxes or from unlicensed premises. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any wholesale, wholesale/retail, or retail cigarette dealer, or other person, or their servant, employee, authorized representative or agent, to sell or dispense, by any means for any purpose any cigarettes in the city upon which the cigarette occupational license tax has not been paid. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any wholesale, wholesale/retail, or retail cigarette dealer, or other person, or their servant, employee, authorized representative or agent, to sell or dispense cigarettes, by any means for any purpose, in the City of Grandview from any place of business or location for which a cigarette sales license has not been obtained or to an ultimate consumer until such license has been obtained. 
(Ord. No. 4793, § 2, 10-10-95; 49; Ord. No. 4921, § 3(4), 11-12-96) 
Sec. 10-46. - Duty of retailer to post notices prohibiting sales to persons under twenty-one years of age. 
    Every wholesale, wholesale/retail, retail cigarette dealer, or other person, or their servant, employee, authorized representative or agent selling cigarettes at retail in the city shall keep posted in his place of business, in a conspicuous place readily visible and readable from the area in which cigarette sales are made, a notice to the public that ordinances of the city prohibit the sale of cigarettes to persons under the age of twenty-one (21); provided, that every such dealer making sales of cigarettes through vending machines shall keep such notice prominently posted on the face of each such vending machine. 
(Ord. No. 4793, § 2, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 6887, § 2, 5-24-16) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6887, § 2, adopted May 24, 2016, changed the title of § 10-46 from "Duty of retailer to post notices prohibiting sales to minors" to read as herein set out. 
Cross reference- Sale of tobacco products to persons under the age of twenty-one, § 17-48. 
Sec. 10-47. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4921, adopted November 12, 1996, repealed § 10-47 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to possession, receipt of cigarettes without stamps, and derived from § 2 of Ord. No. 4793, adopted October 10, 1995. 
Sec. 10-48. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4921, adopted November 12, 1996, repealed § 10-48 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to furnishing of records and reports and derived from § 2 of Ord. No. 4793, adopted October 10, 1995. 
Sec. 10-49. - Penalties for false statements. 
    Any wholesale, wholesale/retail, or retail cigarette dealers or other person, or their servant, employee, authorized representative or agent, found making false statements in any report required to be made by this article, the effect of which would be to reduce the amount of cigarette occupation license tax due, shall pay to the finance director, upon demand therefor, the additional amount of cigarette occupational license tax found to be due, plus a penalty of twenty-five (25) percent of such additional amount, with interest on the additional cigarette occupation license tax of one percent for each month after the date on which the demand for additional amounts was made. 
(Ord. No. 4793, § 2, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 4921, § 3(5), 11-12-96) 
Sec. 10-50. - Verification of tax. 
(a)  Inspections authorized. The finance director or police chief, or their designated representatives, are hereby authorized to examine books, records, invoices, papers, stocks of cigarettes in and upon any premises in the city where same are placed, stored, warehoused or sold, and equipment of any such wholesale, wholesale/retail, or retail cigarette dealer, or place of storage, pertaining to the sale, storage or delivery by any means of conveyance, of cigarettes in the city. To verify the accuracy of the cigarette occupation license tax imposed and assessed by this article, each such person is hereby directed and required to give the finance director or police chief the means, facilities and opportunity for such examination as herein provided for and required. 
(b)  Inspection of vehicles. The finance director or police chief, or their designated representatives, shall have the authority to enter upon trucks or any other means of conveyance, known to be engaged in the business of delivering cigarettes in the city for resale at retail or for individual consumption, for the purpose of examining the contents of such trucks or other vehicles in search of evidence of violation of the provisions of this article. 
(c)  Segregation of deliveries. Any person making delivery by any means of conveyance, of cigarettes in the city consigned to more than one customer shall segregate the deliveries sufficient to disclose the names and addresses of wholesale/retail, or retail cigarette dealers or individual consumers for whom each delivery is intended. 
(Ord. No. 4793, § 2, 10-10-95; Ord. No. 4921, § 3(6), 11-12-96) 
Sec. 10-51. - Refunds. 
    The finance director is hereby authorized to adopt, prescribe, and promulgate rules and regulations including a monthly cigarette tax reporting form with regard to the presentation and proof of claim for refunds and credits as he may deem advisable. 
(Ord. No. 4921, § 3(7), 11-12-96) 
Editor's note- Section 2 of Ord. No. 4921, adopted November 12, 1996, repealed § 10-51 in its entirety. Formerly, said section pertained to refunds for stamps purchased and derived from § 2 of Ord. No. 4793, adopted October 10, 1995. Section 3(7) of said ordinance did not specifically amend this Code; hence, inclusion of § 3(7) as § 10-51 herein was at the editor's discretion. 
Sec. 10-52. - Seizure and sale of cigarettes. 
(a)  Seizure. Whenever the finance director or police chief, or their authorized designated representatives, shall discover any cigarettes subject to the cigarette occupation license tax on which said tax has not been paid, such person shall be authorized and empowered forthwith to seize and take possession of such cigarettes together with any vending machines or other automatic mechanical device for selling and dispensing cigarettes or receptacles in which they are held for sale and the same shall thereupon be deemed to be forfeited to the city. 
(b)  Sale. The purchasing agent of the city may, within a reasonable time after seizure of such cigarettes, by public notice at least five (5) days before the date of sale, sell such forfeited vending machines or devices and such cigarettes at a place designated by him, and from the proceeds of such sale shall collect the tax due thereon together with a penalty of fifty (50) percent thereof and the costs incurred in such proceedings. 
(c)  Authority of purchasing agent. The purchasing manager of the city shall pay the balance of any sales proceeds to the person in whose possession such forfeited cigarettes or vending machines were found; provided, that such seizure and sale shall not be deemed to relieve any person from any fine or imprisonment provided for the violation of any provision of this article. 
(Ord. No. 3309, § 2, 1-22-85; Ord. No. 4921, § 3(8), 11-12-96) 
Sec. 10-53. - Authority of city administrator to promulgate rules and regulations. 
    The city administrator is hereby authorized and empowered to prescribe, adopt, promulgate and enforce rules and regulations including but not limited to: 
(a)  Cancellation. The method and means to be used in the cancellation of stamps and meter impressions, if any. 
(b)  Denomination; sale. The denomination and sale of stamps and meter impressions. 
(c)  Meter machines. The methods and means of using meter machines in printing on containers of cigarettes evidence of payment of the cigarette occupation license tax. 
(d)  Delegation of powers. The delegation of powers to the finance director or police chief. 
(Ord. No. 3309, § 2, 1-22-85) 
Sec. 10-54. - Penalties for violation. 
(a)  Every person convicted of violating this article shall be punished by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(b)  Upon conviction for violation of any provision of this article, the finance director may revoke or suspend the cigarette sales license of any person. Upon such action by the finance director, the holder of said cigarette sales license may within ten (10) days of such action, appeal said suspension and revocation to the board of aldermen. The board of aldermen shall, after providing the person the opportunity to be heard, affirm or reverse the action of the finance director in revoking or suspending said license. Upon a decision affirming the suspension or revocation, the holder of said license shall surrender to the finance director all licenses, cards or other evidence of the issuance of each such license. 
(Ord. No. 3309, § 2, 1-22-85; Ord. No. 4921, § 3,(9), 11-12-96) 
Secs. 10-55-10-57. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE V. - SALES TAX 

Sec. 10-58. - Levied; amount; authority of city pursuant to state law. 
    Pursuant to the authority granted by and subject to the provisions of House Committee Substitute for House Bill No. 243, passed by the 75th General Assembly of the state, a tax for general revenue purposes is hereby imposed upon all sellers for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided in sections 144.010 to 144.510 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, and the rules and regulations of the director of revenue issued pursuant thereto. The rate of the tax shall be one percent on the receipts from the sale at retail of all tangible personal property or taxable services at retail within the city, if such property and services are subject to taxation of the state under the provisions of sections 144.010 to 144.510 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. The tax shall become effective as provided in subsection 4 of section 2 of House Committee Substitute for House Bill No. 243 and shall be collected as provided in such House Committee Substitute for House Bill No. 243. 
    The city shall have and exercise all such powers as are granted to it under and by the provisions of House Committee 
Substitute for House Bill No. 243 including the powers to proceed to impose and collect a city sales tax in conformity therewith, and in conformity with the provisions of sections 144.010 to 144.510 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 1657, §§ 1, 5) 
Sec. 10-59. - Additional sales tax for transportation purposes; fund established. 
(a)  Sales tax for transportation purposes imposed. Pursuant to the authority granted by the State of Missouri, a sales tax for transportation purposes under the provisions of RSMo Sections 94.700 to 94.755 (1994), as amended, is hereby imposed upon all persons in the City of Grandview, who are engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property and taxable services subject to a sales tax under the provisions of RSMo Sections 144.010 to 144.510 (1994), as a tax for the privilege of engaging in such business, at the rate of one-half of one percent on the receipts from the sale at retail of all such tangible personal property or taxable services within the City of Grandview, Missouri. Said tax shall become effective, shall be imposed, and shall be collected in the manner and the extent provided in RSMo Sections 144.010 to 144.510 (1994), the rules and regulations of the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri issued pursuant thereto, and the provisions of all other applicable laws of the State of Missouri. 
(b)  Amount of tax to be reported and returned established. The amount of tax to be reported and returned to the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri by all persons subject to the tax shall be computed on the basis of the combined rate of tax imposed by RSMo Sections 144.010 to 144.510 (1994), the tax imposed by ordinance as authorized by RSMo Sections 94.700 to 94.755 (1994), as amended. 
(c)  Effective date and expiration date of sales tax. The transportation sales tax shall become effective July 1, 2001, and the said sales tax shall expire on June 30, 2011, as approved by a majority of the qualified voters at the August 8, 2000, special election. 
(d)  Transportation sales tax fund established. The city administrator and finance director are hereby authorized to establish the transportation sales tax fund to serve as a fund for the collection and disbursement of revenues received from the one-half cent sales tax for transportation purposes. The establishment of the fund shall be effective July 1, 1986. 
(Ord. No. 3477, §§ 1, 2, 4, 4-8-86; Ord. No. 3480, § 1, 4-22-86; Ord. No. 4162, §§ 1, 2, 4, 4-9-91; Ord. No. 5296, § § 1, 2, 4) 
Sec. 10-60. - Sales tax for capital improvement purposes. 
(a)  Sales tax for capital improvement purposes imposed. Pursuant to the authority granted by the State of Missouri, a sales tax for capital improvement purposes under the provisions of RSMo Section 94.577 (1994), as amended, is hereby imposed on all retail sales in the City of Grandview which are subject to taxation under the provisions of RSMo Sections 144.010 to 144.525 (1994), at the rate of one-half of one (0.5) percent. Said tax shall become effective, shall be imposed, and shall be collected in the manner and the extent provided in RSMo Sections 144.010 to 144.525 (1994), the rules and regulations of the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri issued pursuant thereto, and the provisions of all other applicable laws of the State of Missouri. 
(b)  Amount of tax to be reported and returned established. The amount of tax to be reported and returned to the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri by all persons subject to the tax shall be computed on the basis of the combined rate of tax imposed by RSMo Sections 144.010 to 144.510 (1994), the tax imposed by ordinance as authorized by RSMo Section 94.577 (1994), as amended. 
(c)  City clerk to mail ordinance. No later than August 21, 1998, the city clerk shall forward to the Director of Revenue by United States registered or certified mail, a certified copy of this ordinance and the ordinance of the board of aldermen making the declaration of the capital improvements sales tax election results, all of which shall be accompanied by a map of the City of Grandview clearly showing the boundaries thereof. 
(d)  Effective date and expiration date of sales tax. Pursuant to RSMo Section 32.087, the capital improvements sales tax shall become effective on the first day of the second calendar quarter after the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri receives notice of the adoption of the sales tax, which said effective date shall be January 1, 1999, and the said sales tax shall expire on September 30, 2008. 
(e)  Effective date of section. That this section shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval [Aug. 11, 1998]. 
(Ord. No. 5109, §§ 1-5, 8-11-98) 
Sec. 10-61. - Capital improvements sales tax imposed on domestic utility sales. 
(a)  Pursuant to authority granted by the State of Missouri, the capital improvements sales tax of one-half of one (0.5) percent previously imposed pursuant to Ordinance No. 5109 [section 10-60], is hereby also imposed on all domestic utilities sales covered by RSMo Section 144.032, including all sales of metered water services, electricity, electrical current and natural, artificial or propane gas, wood, coal, or home heating oil for domestic use only. Such tax shall be administered by the Department of Revenue and assessed by utility retailers in the same manner as other city sales taxes. 
(b)  This section shall be in full force and effect from and after its passage and approval [November 10, 1998]. 
(Ord. No. 5139, §§ 1, 3, 11-10-98) 
Sec. 10-62. - City sales tax for local parks. 
(a)  A city sales tax for local parks at the rate of one-half of one percent (1/2 of 1%) on the receipts from all retail sales within Grandview, Missouri, is hereby imposed upon all sellers within the city for the privilege of engaging in the business of selling tangible personal property or rendering taxable services at retail to the extent and in the manner provided by Sections 144.010 to 144.525, inclusive, RSMo, and the rules and regulations of the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri issued pursuant thereto. Such tax shall not be effective until the terms and provisions of this Ordinance [No. 5400] have been complied with. 
(b)  Such sales tax shall be submitted to the voters of Grandview, Missouri, at an election to be held in Grandview on Tuesday, November 6, 2001. The form of notice of special election containing the question of approval of the sales tax, a copy of which is attached hereto and made a part hereof, is hereby approved. The city clerk is hereby authorized and directed to notify the Jackson County Board of Election Commissioners of the passage of this Ordinance [No. 5400] no later than 5:00 P.M. on Tuesday, August 28, 2001, and to include in said notification all of the terms and provisions required by Chapter 115, RSMo. 
(c)  If such sales tax is approved by a majority of the votes cast by the qualified voters voting thereon at said election, the city clerk shall as soon as possible after the election date (but in any event no later than ten (10) days after the election date) forward to the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri by United States registered mail or certified mail (1) a certified copy of this Ordinance [No. 5400], including the notice of special election attached hereto, and (2) a copy of the abstract of votes cast on the question at said election. The city sales tax for local parks hereby imposed shall then become effective on April 1, 2002, and shall be levied and collected in the manner provided by the Act, by Sections 32.085 and 32.087, RSMo, as amended, and by all other applicable laws, and shall be used for the purposes hereinabove authorized. 
(d)  The city expects to make capital expenditures (the "Expenditures") in connection with park improvements (the "Project") on and after the date hereof, and intends to reimburse itself for the Expenditures with the proceeds of a lease-purchase agreement or other obligations to be issued by the city (the "Obligation"). The maximum principal amount of the Obligation expected to be issued for the Project is ten million dollars ($10,000,000.00). 
(e)  Election results. That it is hereby found and determined that the vote at the special election held in the City of Grandview, Missouri, on November 6, 2001, at which there was submitted the question of imposing a special local parks sales tax as described below, resulted as follows: 
Shall the City of Grandview, Missouri, impose a sales tax of one-half of one percent (1/2 of 1%) on the receipts from all retail sales of property or services within the City which are subject to taxation by the State of Missouri under the provisions of Sections 144.010 to 144.525, RSMo, for the purpose of providing funding for local parks for the City of Grandview? 
Yes  1,397 
No  686 
(f)  Voter determination. It is found, declared and determined that a majority of the qualified voters voting at said election on the question voted in favor of said question, and that the board of aldermen is therefore vested with full power and authority to impose the local parks sales tax as authorized by RSMO Section 644.032(1) and Ordinance No. 5400. 
(g)  Conformance to law. It is further found, declared and determined that notice of said election was duly given and published in the manner provided by law, and that said election was held and conducted in all respects in conformity with the Constitution and laws of the State of Missouri covering elections in cities of the Fourth Class, and in accordance with ordinances duly adopted by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 5400, § 1-4, 7-24-01; Ord. No. 5441, § 1-3, 11-13-01) 
Secs. 10-63-10-70. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VI. - TRANSIENT GUEST TAX 

Sec. 10-71. - Definitions. 
    These terms when used in this article shall have the following meanings: 
    Daily rental receipts: All receipts from the rental of sleeping accommodations by hotels or motels, whether paid in cash, credits or property, and without any deduction or exemption. 
    Hotel and motel: Any structure or building, under one (1) management or ownership, which contains rooms furnished for the accommodation or lodging of guests, with or without meals being provided, and kept, used, maintained, advertised, or held out to the public as a place where sleeping accommodations are sought for pay or compensation to transient guests or permanent guests and having more than three (3) bedrooms furnished for the accommodation of such guests. This definition is intended to include tourist courts, bed and breakfast establishments and similar facilities, but not hospitals, nursing homes or convalescent centers. 
    Person: For purposes of this article, the definition of "person" in section 1-2 of this Code shall apply. 
    Transient guests: A person or persons who occupy a room or rooms in a hotel or motel for thirty-one (31) days or less in any calendar quarter. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-72. - Levy of tax. 
    There is hereby levied upon every person engaged in the business of operating and carrying on the business of the operation of a hotel or motel, a transient guest tax in an amount equal to five (5) per cent of daily rental receipts derived from transient guests for sleeping accommodations. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-73. - Payment of tax. 
    The transient guest tax due under this article shall be paid to the department of finance monthly. The tax due for daily rental receipts collected during each month shall be due and payable on or before the last day of the following month. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-74. - Reports required. 
    Every person engaged in the business of operating a hotel or motel shall file monthly reports with the finance director on forms prescribed by the director or the director's designee, giving such information as may be necessary to determine the amounts to which the transient guest tax shall apply for the monthly period. The monthly reports shall be submitted with the monthly payments. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-75. - Examination of books, records. 
    The finance director or the director's designee shall have the right at all reasonable times during business hours to make such examination and inspection of the books and records of the hotel or motel as may be necessary to determine the correctness of the reports required by this article and it shall be the duty of hotel or motel owner or operator to cooperate in such examination. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-76. - Bond requirement. 
    Renewal of any city occupation license or liquor license by any person who has been delinquent in remitting the transient guest tax for or during three (3) or more months during the year preceding renewal shall be conditioned upon the posting of a bond to secure payment of said taxes during the year of renewal. The amount of the bond shall be equal to the amount of transient guest tax payments owed by such person during the year preceding renewal. The bond shall be subject to the approval of city special counsel. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-77. - Penalties for non-payment. 
    For each month, or part thereof, any transient guest tax provided for under this article remains unpaid after the same shall be due and payable, there shall be added to such tax as a penalty five (5) per cent of the amount of such tax for the first month or part thereof the same is unpaid, and for each and every month thereafter five (5) per cent of the amount of such tax shall be added until the same is fully paid. In no case shall the total penalty exceed twenty-five (25) percent of the tax. If the tax as provided in this article is not paid by the fifth day after said tax is due, the finance director or the director's designee may initiate suspension or revocation of the city occupation license and/or liquor license of the person liable for such tax in accordance with the procedures provided by ordinance for the suspension or revocation of said licenses. In addition to the penalties provided herein, any person subject to the provisions of this article who fails to file a statement or pay the tax or files a false or a fraudulent statement required by this article or within the time required by this article shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine not exceeding five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by imprisonment not exceeding ninety (90) days, or by both such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-78. - Administration fee. 
    The city shall be entitled to an administration fee to be charged against transient guest tax collections which shall reflect the cost to administer the levying and collecting of the transient guest tax. The administration fee shall be five (5) per cent of the amount of transient guest tax collected during the month in which the fee is charged. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12) 
Sec. 10-79. - Confidentiality of records. 
    To the extent allowed by law, the reports generated pursuant to section 10-74 and records or information generated by inspection and/or examination pursuant to section 10-75 and any other information or record that would disclose facts or figures about an identifiable hotel or motel which would or could provide information concerning the identified hotel or motel's receipts or occupancy shall not be divulged or be made public, and all such records shall be closed. 
(Ord. No. 6503, § 1, 10-25-11, eff. 1-1-12)
