Sec. 11-11. - Use of firemen and equipment outside of city. 
    All fire-fighting equipment owned by the city and all firemen, including volunteer and paid firemen, may, under certain rules and regulations as may be determined and set forth by the fire chief and approved by the board of aldermen, leave the city to fight fires and assist in cases of emergencies; provided that at no time shall all the fire equipment or all the firemen leave the city at one time, and at all times there shall remain in the city at least one (1) fire truck in good operating condition with sufficient firemen to operate such fire truck. 
(Ord. No. 643, § 1) 
Section 11-12. - International Fire Code adopted and amendment. 
(a)  Fire Code adopted. The board of alderman of the city adopts the 2012 International Fire Code, including all appendices and all supplements published by the International Code Council, which shall be on file with the city clerk. Throughout this article and other articles, chapters and sections within the Grandview Code of Laws, reference to the Grandview Fire Code shall mean and consist of the 2012 International Fire Code and appendices as amended by subsection (b) of this section. 
    These regulations are adopted as the regulations governing fire prevention practices and procedures within the city. The code shall be collectively known as the Grandview Fire Code and, together with other building codes, shall be deemed the accepted practice for construction and equipping of buildings and for fire prevention and life safety in connection with hazardous materials management, operational processes and structural situations. It shall be unlawful to maintain any condition or take any action in violation of the Grandview Fire Code. 
(b)  2012 International Fire Code amendments. The following sections of the 2012 International Fire Code are amended to read as follows: 
(1)  104.1.1 Contractor Licensing. To ensure that contractors and their employees are trained, experienced and knowledgeable in performing any work related to fire and life safety protection systems with the installation, altering, maintaining, servicing, testing, repairs, inspection and removal in City of Grandview, Missouri, contractors shall hold one or more valid contractor licenses from Johnson County Kansas or from City of Kansas City, Missouri and one or more valid Occupational/Craftsman licenses from City of Grandview Finance Department. 
License's Electrical contractor Class III may install, alter, repair, or remove communication, fire alarm, burglar alarm, and remote control equipment, as well as low-voltage power, signal, sound, recording, and similar equipment. 
Fire protection contractor Class I may install, alter, modernize, maintain, service, repair, test, and inspect automatic sprinkler systems and standpipe systems for any and all types of occupancies, inclusive of all related underground fire lines and fire services and inclusive of, but not limited to, all appurtenances such as fire pumps; water storage tanks; fire control systems; automatic and manual water-spray and deluge systems; special extinguishing systems using carbon dioxide, foam, dry chemicals or inert gas; and other such systems used for the control or extinguishment of fire. Backflow prevention devices are permitted to be installed, but they must be tested in accordance with Jackson County Water District #1 and State of Missouri regulations. 
Fire protection contractor Class II may install, maintain, test, or repair only dry, wet, or combination standpipe systems and install fire hydrant lines. 
Fire protection contractor Class III may install, maintain, test, or repair only special systems using carbon dioxide, foam, dry chemicals, or inert gas for the control or extinguishment of fire. 
Copy of licenses must be provided annually to the City of Grandview Fire Marshal's Office or when submitting application for plan review and/or installation permit. 
If work is being conducted by a contractor or employee not listed on the contractor's license or without a valid license, a stop order will be issued immediately in accordance with the International Fire Code Section 111 "Stop Work Order" along with a violation fine imposed not to exceed $250.00. 
(2)  104.10.2 Reimbursement of Services. The City of Grandview Fire Department will bill the property/building owner's insurance company up to $500.00 for reimbursement of services provided for the extinguishment, overhaul and investigation into the origin and cause of the fire. 
No occupant and/or property owner would be billed for reimbursement where no insurance policy coverage is provided on the property where a fire has taken place. 
(3)  108.1 Board of appeals established. The Construction Code Board of Appeals, the members of which are appointed by the Board of Aldermen and shall hold office at its pleasure, shall hear and decide appeals of orders, decisions or determinations made by the fire code official relative to the application and interpretation of this code. All references to the Fire Code Board of Appeals in this code shall mean the Construction Code Board of Appeals. The fire code official shall be an ex officio member of said board but shall have no vote on any matter before the board. The board shall adopt rules of procedure for conducting its business, and shall render all decisions and findings in writing to the appellant with a duplicate copy to the fire code official. 
(4)  109.4 Violation penalties. Persons who shall violate a provision of this code or shall fail to comply with any of the requirements thereof, or who shall erect, install, alter, repair or do work in violation of the approved construction documents or directive of the fire code official, or of a permit or certificate used under provisions of this code, shall be guilty of a misdemeanor, punishable by a fine according to the following schedule: 
Not more than $50.00 for the 1st violation, not more than $200.00 for the 2nd violation, not more than $300.00 for the 3rd violation, not more than $400.00 for the 4th violation, and not more than $500.00 for the 5th and subsequent violations; or by imprisonment not exceeding 90-days; or both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that a violation continues after due notice has been served shall be deemed a separate offense. In determining the applicable minimum fine, an offense shall be considered a recurring offense only if the defendant has previously pleaded, or been found guilty of, violating the same minimum standards at the same location. 
(5)  503.3.1 Curbs. All curbs and curb ends shall be painted red with four inch (4") white lettering stating "FIRE LANE-NO PARKING". Wording may not be spaced more than fifteen feet (15') apart. Where no curb exists or a rolled curb is installed, a 6-inch (6") wide painted red stripe applied to the concrete or asphalt with four inch (4") white lettering stating "FIRE LANE-NO PARKING." 
(6)  503.3.2 Signs. In areas where fire lanes are required, but no continuous curb is available, one of the following methods shall be used to indicate the fire lane. 
Option 1 : A sign twelve inches (12") wide and eighteen inches (18") in height shall be mounted on a metal post set in concrete a minimum of depth of eighteen inches (18") set back one foot (1') in from the edge of the roadway with the bottom of the sign being seven feet (7') from finished grade. Signs shall face oncoming traffic. Spacing of signs shall not exceed fifty feet (50') between signs. Signs shall be reflective material with a white color background with symbols, letters and border in red color. "FIRE LANE-NO PARKING". 
Option 2 : A sign twelve inches (12") wide and eighteen inches (18") in height shall be mounted on the side of a structure or other permanent fixture approved by the Fire Code Official. The bottom of the sign being seven feet (7') from finished grade. Spacing of signs shall not exceed fifty feet (50') between signs. Signs shall be reflective material with a white color background with symbols, letters and border in red color. "FIRE LANE-NO PARKING". 
(7)  503.3.3 Enforcement. It will be the responsibility of the City Grandview Police Department to enforce this section as they apply to both public and private properties. The City of Grandview Police Department is hereby authorized to ticket, tow or cause to be towed any vehicle that has been parked or placed upon the public or private street in violation of the parking laws of the City of Grandview. 
(8)  507.5.1.2 Fire Hydrant for fire suppression sprinkler systems. Buildings equipped with a fire suppression sprinkler system installed in accordance with Section 903.3 shall have a fire hydrant within 200 feet of the fire department connections. 
(9)  507.5.1.3 Fire Hydrant within Commercial and Industrial areas. All new fire hydrants and replacement of any existing fire hydrants within any commercial or industrial area shall be a Class-A type fire hydrant with a four inch (4") Storz steamer discharge connection on the front and 2-2 1/2 inch national thread discharge connections on either side. The specifications are on file with the Jackson County Public Water Supply District #1. 
(10)  507.5.4.1 Obstructing a Fire Hydrant. No person shall park a motor vehicle or place any other object within fifteen feet of either side of a fire hydrant used or to be used for fire protection when such hydrant is located on private or public property, except that sign or fence posts, shrubbery and protective bollards shall not be within three feet of any such hydrant. 
(11)  507.5.4.2 Enforcement. It will be the responsibility of the City of Grandview Police Department to enforce this section as they apply to both public and private properties. The City of Grandview Police Department is hereby authorized to ticket, tow or cause to be towed any vehicle that has been parked or placed obstructing the fire hydrant in violation of the parking laws of the City of Grandview. 
(12)  9 03.3.7 Fire Department Connections. The location of Fire Department Connections shall be approved by the Grandview Fire Department. The connection shall be a four-inch (4") Storz coupling connector. 
(13)  507.5.4.3 Fire Hydrant Color Schedule. To distinguish public fire hydrants from private fire hydrants, public fire hydrants shall be the color of YELLOW and private fire hydrants shall be the color of RED. 
(14)  903.4.2 Alarms. Approved audible alarms shall be connected to every automatic sprinkler system. Such sprinkler water-flow devices shall be activated by water flow equivalent to the flow of a single sprinkler of the small orifice size installed in the system. Visual and audible alarm devices shall be provided on the exterior of the building in an approved location. Where a fire alarm system is installed, actuation of the automatic sprinkler system shall actuate the building fire alarm system. 
(15)  907.2.11.5 Maintaining Smoke Alarm(s) within Rental and/or Leased Dwelling Units. It shall be the responsibility of the owner or the designee landlord of every rental or leased dwelling unit, apartment or room (occupied or vacant) to maintain an operable smoke alarm where sleeping rooms are located. 
It shall be the responsibility of the owner or the designee landlord to supply and install smoke alarms in accordance to the International Fire Code. The owner shall be responsible to test and maintain smoke alarms in common interior stairways, interior hallways and corridors and common rooms within multi-family structures. 
The owner shall install new batteries and test the operating condition of each smoke alarm before the new tenant takes possession of the dwelling unit. 
It shall be the responsibility of the tenant to test the smoke alarm(s) within their dwelling unit. The tenant shall notify the owner or designee landlord of any deficiencies with the operation of the smoke alarm(s). 
The tenant shall be responsible for the replacement of the required battery in each smoke alarm located in the dwelling unit at least annually, unless the battery is supplied or replaced by the owner or designee landlord. 
The owner or designee landlord is responsible to replace smoke alarms if they are ten years (10) of age or older. 
The owner or designee landlord should maintain a written log for each smoke alarm tested and when batteries were changed. 
(16)  907.2.11.6 Smoke Alarm(s) and Carbon Monoxide Detector within Residential Dwellings. Before any one or two family dwelling is sold in the City of Grandview and subject to change in occupancy for residential purposes, the owner (seller) shall ensure that existing smoke alarm(s) within the dwelling are in proper working condition. The owner (seller) shall replace any smoke alarm that is ten years (10) of age or older and replace any smoke alarm that is not in proper working condition. If the dwelling does not have a carbon monoxide detector, one shall be installed. 
The owner (seller) shall disclose at the time of the final sale (closing) that smoke alarm(s) and carbon monoxide detector have been installed and are in proper working order. 
Failure to provide smoke alarm(s) and carbon monoxide detector a violation penalty in accordance with section 109.4 shall be imposed against the seller. 
(17)  Sections 5706.3 through 5706.3.7 of the 2012 International Fire Code and Tables 22.4.1.1 through 22.4.1.6 of the National Fire Protection Association (NFPA) Standard 30 Flammables and Combustible Liquids Code, 2012 edition, are hereby amended to read in conformity with the setback requirements set out in Section 11-110(a) of the Code of Law of the City of Grandview. 
(Ord. No. 2044; Ord. No. 2724, §§ 1, 2, 12-11-79; Ord. No. 2876, § 1, 5-12-81; Ord. No. 3051, §§ 1-3, 6-22-82; Ord. No. 3116, § 1, 12-14-82; Ord. No. 3598, § 1, 3-4-87; Ord. No. 3820, § 1, 12-13-88; Ord. No. 4263, § 1, 12-10-91; Ord. No. 4393, §§ 1-4, 10-27-92; Ord. No. 4763, §§ 1, 2, 7-25-95; Ord. No. 5038, § 1, 11-25-97; Ord. No. 5176, §§ 1-3, 6-8-99; Ord. No. 5835, § 3, 11-23-04; Ord. No. 6373, § 2, 5-25-10; Ord. No. 6666, §§ 2, 9, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 6768, § 1, 2-24-15; Ord. No. 6853, § 1, 2-9-16; Ord. No. 7060, § 1, 3-27-18)

ARTICLE II. - PERMITS, PLAN REVIEWS, INSPECTIONS AND TESTING[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- Section 3 of Ord. No. 2367, adopted Aug. 24, 1976, repealed former Art. II, §§ 11-13, 11-14 and 11-16-11-18, pertaining to the fire department generally. Said former sections were derived from Ord. No. 720, §§ 1, 2, 4 and 5; Ord. No. 1022, § 1; Ord. No. 1296, § 1; and Ord. No. 2282, §§ 1 and 2, enacted Nov. 10, 1975.  Subsequently, section 1 of Ord. No. 6668, adopted March 25, 2014, enacted new provisions as herein set out. 

Sec. 11-13. - Permits and fees. 
    The fire prevention bureau of the city fire department shall coordinate the issuance, inspection and enforcement of the following required permits within the city in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code. A schedule of fees for permits shall be maintained by the fire marshal. 
(1)  Blasting permit. To perform blasting within the City of Grandview, a permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code - Chapter 56 Explosives and Fireworks - Section 5601.2 Permit Required. The application for a permit must be accompanied by the site plan, completed copy of Missouri Notification of Blasting Operations form, copy of State of Missouri Licensing for Blasting and copy of certificate of insurance for the contractor conducting the blasting. Site inspection will be conducted before a permit is issued and during times of operations to ensure compliance with blasting operations. Prior to any blasting, the permit holder must notify the fire department dispatcher at 816-316-4980. 
Blasting licenses are issued by the state division of fire safety at the following link: firesafe@dfs.dps.mo.gov. 
Permits will be issued for a maximum of forty-five (45) days. Renewal of the permit is required. 
The fee for a blasting permit for storage of explosives permit is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
The fee for a blasting permit for site work is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(2)  Recreational Fire, Open Burning and Bonfire Permits. Within the City of Grandview, no person may cause or allow open burning without a permit. A permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code-Chapter General Requirements-Section 307.2 Permit Required. Open burning must comply with the State of Missouri Department of Natural Resources Open Burning Regulations. 
(a)  Recreational fires which include cooking, warming fires, smudge pots and similar types may be exempted from a permit. This would be determined with the information provided to the fire prevention bureau at the time the application is submitted. A recreational fire with a fire greater than three (3) feet in diameter and by two (2) feet in height would require a permit. 
(b)  A bonfire shall be no more than five-foot by five-foot by five-foot in dimension, and shall not burn longer than four (4) hours. The placement of the bonfire shall not be closer than fifty (50) feet away from combustible structures. Fuel for a bonfire shall consist only of seasoned dry firewood and shall be ignited by igniting paper and/or twigs. The size and duration of the bonfire may be increased only upon approval by the fire prevention bureau. 
(c)  Open burning of hedge rows, cleared land and the use of an air curtain for burning of clean wood and under brush with approval from the State of Missouri Department of Natural Resources, shall require a permit to be issued. 
Any open burning shall be prohibited when atmospheric conditions or local circumstances make such fires hazardous. 
A site diagram may be required to be submitted with the application. The site will be inspected by the fire prevention bureau before a permit is issued. 
No combustible or flammable liquids are permitted to be used to start the fire and no materials except clean wood can be used and burned. A portable fire extinguisher with minimum 4A rating shall be located within fifty (50) feet of the permitted fire. (The 4A rated fire extinguisher is rated to extinguish fires involving paper, wood, cardboard, grass, etc. This extinguisher can be a water or a powder type extinguisher.) 
Prior to lighting a recreational and/or bonfire, the permit holder must notify Grandview Police dispatcher at 816-316-4980. 
Permit issued for a maximum of thirty (30) days. Renewal of the permit is required. 
The fee for a recreational fire, open burning or bonfire permit is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(3)  Fireworks 1.3G and pyrotechnic permit. The sale, storage or use of fireworks is not permitted within the City of Grandview. Those persons or organizations wishing to produce an organized outdoor public fireworks display may do so under restrictions, and only after obtaining a permit issued by the fire prevention bureau in accordance with 2012 International Fire Code Chapter 56-Explosives and Fireworks-Section 5608.2 Permit Required. The application for a permit must be accompanied by the site plan, copy of Missouri State license for each operator and/or pyrotechnic and copy of certificate of insurance. 
Note: All permits issued will have one (1) rain date included. 
There will be a site inspection before a permit is issued by the fire prevention bureau. Prior to the display of the fireworks, an inspection will be conducted by the fire prevention bureau. 
Permit issued is date specific with a rain date included. 
The fee for a fireworks permit (ground display, aerial display, proximate audience display and/or other displays) is listed in the schedule f fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(4)  Fireworks 1.4G Consumer permit. The storage, handling, distribution and sale of any quantity of fireworks or pyrotechnic special effects in accordance with 2012 International Fire Code Chapter 56 - Explosives and Fireworks - Section 5601.1.3(4). Small fireworks devices containing restricted amounts of pyrotechnic composition designed primarily to produce visible or audible effects by combustion. There will be a site inspection conducted annually by the fire prevention bureau before the permit is issued. The sale of 1.4G Consumer Fireworks shall be in accordance with Article III of this Chapter. 
Permits can be issued for a maximum of three hundred sixty-five (365) days. 
The fee for fireworks 1.4G permit is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(5)  Tent/canopy permit. Within the City of Grandview, all temporary tents, canopies, membrane structures or other such structures erected having an area in excess of four hundred (400) square feet must have a permit. A permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code - Chapter 31 - Section 3103.4 Permit Required. Additional provisions of Chapter 31 will be required as determined by the fire prevention division. 
Before a permit is granted, the owner or agent shall file with the fire prevention bureau a certificate executed by an approved testing laboratory certifying that the tents and membrane structures and their appurtenances; sidewalls, drops and tarpaulins; floor coverings, bunting and combustible decorative materials and effects, including sawdust when used on floors or passageways, are composed of material meeting the flame propagation performance criteria of NFPA 701 or shall be treated with a flame retardant in an approved manner and meet the flame propagation performance criteria of NFPA 701, and that such flame propagation performance criteria are effective for the period specified by the permit. 
No permit is required for the following exceptions: 
1.  Tents used exclusively for recreational camping purposes. 
2.  Tents open on all sides, which comply with all of the following: 
2.1.  Individual tents having a maximum size of seven hundred (700) square feet (65 m 2). 
2.2.  The aggregate area of multiple tents placed side by side without a fire break clearance of not less than twelve (12) feet (3,658 mm) shall not exceed seven hundred (700) square feet (65 m 2) total. 
2.3.  A minimum clearance of twelve (12) feet (3,658 mm) to structures and other tents shall be provided. 
Permits are issued for maximum of thirty days (30) days. 
The fee for a tent/canopy permit is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(6)  HOT work permit. Within the City of Grandview, welding, cutting, open torches and other hot work operations and equipment involved with construction, demolition and applied roofing must have a permit. A permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code - Chapter 33 Fire Safety During Construction and Demolition and Chapter 35 Welding and Other Hot Work. 
Each site will be inspected by the fire prevention bureau before work can begin. 
As part of the HOT work permit, the work site will implement the following: 
A pre-hot-work check shall be conducted prior to work to ensure that all equipment is safe and hazards are recognized and protected. A report of the check shall be kept at the work site during the work and available upon request. The pre-hot-work check shall determine all of the following: 
1.  Hot work equipment to be used shall be in satisfactory operating condition and in good repair. 
2.  Hot work site is clear of combustibles or combustibles are protected. 
3.  Exposed construction is of noncombustible materials or, if combustible, then protected. 
4.  Openings are protected. 
5.  Work areas are kept clean. 
6.  No exposed combustibles are located on the opposite side of partitions, walls, ceilings or floors. 
7.  Fire watches, where required, are assigned. 
8.  Approved actions have been taken to prevent accidental activation of suppression and detection equipment in accordance with Section 3504. 
9.  Fire extinguishers and fire hoses (where provided) are operable and available. 
Permits can be issued for maximum of thirty (30) days. 
The fee for a HOT work permit is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(7)  Oil and gas well drilling/operation permit . Within the City of Grandview, a permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code-Chapter 57 Flammable and Combustible Liquids-Section 5706.3 Well Drilling and Operation. 
The permit application must be accompanied with a copy of a State of Missouri DNR issued permit-10CSR 50-2.030; City of Grandview Conditional Use Permit-Ordinance 5631 Chapter 31-25(E); oil/gas well site plan including location of tank battery; inventory of all hazardous materials including quantities; and emergency plan including egress routes and fire protection. 
Each site will be inspected by the fire prevention bureau before work can begin and periodically during the permit period. 
The permit is to ensure proper storage of flammable and combustible products; location of storage tanks; erection and maintaining of containment embankments and dikes; that sources of ignition are removed; proper setbacks from public access, property lines and buildings; fire protection and site emergency plan and access is maintained. 
Permits can be issued for a maximum of three hundred sixty-five (365) days. 
The fee for an oil/gas well permit (site inspection, drilling (each well) and/or operation (each well)) is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(8)  Above-ground and under-ground storage tank removal permit . Within the City of Grandview, the removal of above-ground and under-ground flammable and combustible liquid storage tanks requires a permit. A permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code - Chapter 57 Flammable and Combustible Liquids, section 5704.2.14 Removal and Disposal of Tanks. In conjunction with the tank removal, a HOT work permit maybe required if any welding, cutting, open torches and other HOT work operations would take place in the removal of the storage tank. 
Permits can be issued for a maximum of thirty (30) days. 
The fee for a storage tank removal permit (above ground or underground) is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(9)  Structure demolition permit . Within the City of Grandview, the demolition of any structure requires a permit. A permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code-Chapter 33-Fire Safety During Construction and Demolition and 2009 National Fire Protection Association Standard 241-Chapter 10-Safeguarding Demolition Operations. Inspection of the work site to ensure all utilities have been disconnected, provide access for fire department apparatus, secure the scene preventing access from unauthorized people and fire protection before approval would be granted for demolition to begin. In conjunction with the demolition, a HOT work permit may be required if any welding, cutting, open torches and other HOT work operations would take place during the demolition. 
Permits can be issued for a maximum of forty-five (45) days. 
The fee for a structure demolition permit is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(10)  Places of assembly exterior event permit . Within the City of Grandview, any event that would have two hundred fifty (250) or more persons attending requires a permit. A permit must be issued by the fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department in accordance with the 2012 International Fire Code-Chapter 1 Scope and Administration-Section 105-Permits when there is an event to be held at an exterior location that normally is not a place of assembly for the gathering of persons attending a concert, stage show, carnival, fair, etc. where persons are restricted by a controlled entrance and fencing or some other type of boundary. Prior to the event, there will be an inspection of the assembly area to ensure aisle widths and egress paths to EXIT's are maintained. When chairs and tables are used, ensure proper aisle width is maintained to the egress path. When a temporary stage is assembled, inspection is required of the electrical wiring, fabric flame resistance and sturdiness of the stage and overhead lighting fixtures. Portable fire extinguishers are to be located throughout the assembly area and emergency generator to provide lighting for egress when one thousand (1,000) or more persons attend the event. In conjunction with the places of assembly permit, a tent/temporary membrane permit and/or fireworks and pyrotechnic permit may be required. 
Crowd management and fire watch personnel would be required if one thousand (1,000) or more persons attend the event. There will be a crown manager for every two hundred fifty (250) persons. 
Permit is date specific with a rain date included. 
The fee for a place of assembly-exterior event permit is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(Ord. No. 6668, § 1, 3-25-14; Ord. No. 6853, § 2, 2-9-16; Ord. No. 7060, § 2, 3-27-18) 
Editor's note- The schedule of fees referenced has not been set out but shall be maintained by the fire marshal and made available for public inspection at all times. 
Sec. 11-14. - Plan reviews, inspections, tests and fees. 
    The fire prevention bureau of the Grandview Fire Department conducts plan reviews, site inspections and acceptance testing on fire protection systems. With the adoption of the 2012 International Fire Code by the City of Grandview, the following details these plan reviews, acceptance testing, installation permits and fees. 
(1)  Plan review for fire alarm and detection systems. The fire alarm plan review fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. Manufacturer specification sheet(s) on each device being installed must be submitted along with the drawing. Fee listed in the schedule of fees. 
Each revised plan review will generate a fee as listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal in addition to the original fees as outlined above. 
(2)  Installation permit for fire alarm and detection systems. It will be issued for the installation of the fire alarm system as approved in the submitted drawing(s). The permit includes rough-in inspections, witness acceptance testing and final inspection. Fee listed in the schedule of fees. 
Each additional acceptance test required, whether due to previous tests being unsuccessful or responsible parties failing to participate, will generate an additional permit fee as listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
The replacement of any damaged component such as the FACP, dialer or any addition of devices to the existing fire alarm system would require a permit. The permit includes rough-in inspection, witness re-acceptance testing and final inspection. The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(3)  Plan review of sprinkler suppression systems. The fee for a fire sprinkler plan review is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a profession engineer. Manufacturer specification sheet on each device being installed must be submitted along with the drawing. Each revised plan review will generate a fee as listed in the schedule of fees in addition to the original fee as outlined above. 
(4)  Installation permit for fire sprinkler suppression systems. A permit will be issued for the installation of the fire sprinkler suppression system as approved in the submitted drawing(s). An additional fee would be added for fire sprinkler heads being installed exceeding one hundred (100) heads as listed in the schedule of fees. The permit includes rough-in inspections, witness hydrostatic acceptance testing and final inspection. The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
Each additional inspection/hydrostatic test required, whether due to previous installation/tests unsuccessful or responsible parties failing to participate will generate an additional permit fee as listed in the schedule of fees. 
The replacement of any damaged component such as the backflow preventer, sprinkler riser piping, clapper valve or any addition of piping and sprinkler heads to the existing fire sprinkler suppression system would require a permit. The permit includes rough-in inspection, witness re-acceptance testing and final inspection. The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(5)  Plan review of fire extinguishing systems for commercial cooking. Fire extinguishing systems for commercial cooking plan review fee as listed in the schedule of fees. Fire extinguishing systems for commercial cooking are FM-300 dry and wet systems. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. Manufacturer specification sheet on each device being installed must be submitted along with the drawing. The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
Each revised plan review will generate a fee as listed in the schedule of fees in addition to the original fees as outlined above. 
(6)  Installation permit for fire extinguishing systems for commercial cooking. A permit will be issued for the installation of the fire extinguishing system for commercial cooking as approved in the submitted drawing(s). The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees. The permit includes rough-in inspections, witness acceptance testing and final inspection. 
Each additional acceptance test required, whether due to previous tests being unsuccessful or responsible parties failing to participate, will generate an additional permit fee as listed in the schedule of fees. 
(7)  Plan review underground fire main and sprinkler riser. Underground fire main and sprinkler riser plan review fee as listed in the schedule of fees. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. The drawing shall show the size and type of piping, location and size of all thrust blocks, thrust block details, detail of the spigot piece or in-building riser turn, type of stone or sand used, depth of bury and type of fittings/joints, methods of connection and rod size. 
Each additional revised plan review will generate a fee as listed in the schedule of fees in addition to the original fee as outline above. 
(8)  Installation permit for underground fire main and sprinkler riser. A permit will be issued for the installation of the underground fire main and sprinkler riser as approved in the submitted drawing(s). The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees. The permit includes visual of all underground piping, joints and thrust blocks which must be uncovered and exposed. All ductile iron pipe, retaining rods, and other non-plastic components shall be externally coated for corrosion and poly wrapped. Visual inspection prior to the hydrostatic test, witness the two hundred (200) psi two-hour hydrostatic test of the underground fire main from the gate valve to the top of the spigot. Flushing of the underground piping after the completion of the hydrostatic test and prior to stacking of the riser and the final inspection. 
(9)  Plan review specialized fire extinguishing systems. Specialized fire extinguishing system plan review fee as listed in the schedule of fees. Specialized fire extinguisher systems are FM-200 clean agent systems, carbon dioxide systems and dry chemical systems. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. Manufacturer specification sheet on each device being installed must be submitted along with the drawing. 
Each additional revised plan review will generate a fee as listed in the schedule of fees in addition to the original fee as outline above. 
(10)  Installation permit for specialized fire extinguishing systems. A permit will be issued for the installation of the specialize fire extinguishing system as approved in the submitted drawing(s). The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. The permit includes rough-in inspections, witness hydrostatic acceptance testing and final inspection. 
(11)  Plan review of drawings for all structures new or being remodeled, with the exception of one and two family structures. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. The plan review will cover the location of EXIT doors, egress travel distance, portable fire extinguishers, EXIT signs, emergency lighting, fire separation, etc. with the exception of a fire protection system which would be reviewed separately. The plan review fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(12)  Plan review above-ground fuel storage tank. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that has been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. The plan review will cover the site plan indicating the location of the above-ground tank, the tank capacity, distance from the property line, distance from the public way and distance from any building, tank construction type and secondary containment. The drawing will indicate tank vent(s) location, location of fuel dispenser(s), remote emergency shut-off, vehicle impact protection, required signage and location of the portable fire extinguisher. Provide copy with submittal of the specification sheets on the storage tank(s), dispensing hose, nozzles and dispensing pumps. 
The above-ground fuel storage tank shall be installed in accordance with 2012 International Fire Code sections 2304, 2305 and 2306, the International Building, Fuel Gas and Mechanical Codes, NFPA 30A and NFPA 70. 
The plan review fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(13)  Installation permit for above-ground fuel storage tank. A permit will be issued for the installation of the above-ground fuel storage tank as approved in the submitted drawing(s). The permit includes visual Inspection of the tank placement and pipe connections along with proper tank vents. Connection to the fuel dispensing pumps, proper signage on dispensing units, hoses, nozzles, remote emergency disconnect switch and location of the portable fire extinguisher. Witness acceptance testing of the fuel dispensing pump(s) emergency disconnect switch. 
The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(14)  Plan review for under-ground fuel storage tank. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. The plan review will cover the site plan indicating the location of the under-ground tank(s), the tank capacity, and distance from the property line, distance from the public-way and distance from any building, tank construction type, secondary containment and hold down devices. The drawing will indicate location of the under-ground piping, tank vents, location of fuel dispenser(s), the construction of the dispensing island, vehicle protection, emergency shear valves, remote emergency disconnect switch and proper signage. Provide copy with submittal of the specification sheets on the storage tank(s), dispensing hose, nozzles and dispensing pumps. Provide copy of Approval from the State of Missouri Department of Natural Resources. The below-ground fuel storage tank shall be installed in accordance with 2012 International Fire Code sections 2304, 2305 and 2306, the International Building, Fuel Gas and Mechanical Codes, NFPA 30A and NFPA 70. 
The plan review fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(15)  Installation permit for under-ground fuel storage tank. A permit will be issued for the installation of the above-ground fuel storage tank as approved in the submitted drawing(s). The permit includes visual Inspection of the tank placement, tank hold-down devices and pipe connections along with proper tank vents. Under-ground tanks will be pressure tested. Connection to the fuel dispensing pumps, proper signage on dispensing units, hoses, nozzles, remote emergency disconnect switch and location of the portable fire extinguisher. Witness acceptance testing of the emergency shear valve at each fuel dispensing pump(s) and the operation of the emergency disconnect switch. 
The permit fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal. 
(16)  Investigation fees. Where work for which a permit is required by this code is started prior to obtaining such permit, the fee specified in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal shall be doubled, but the payment of such double fees shall not relieve any persons from fully complying with the requirements of this code in the execution of the work nor from any other penalties. 
(17)  Outside plan reviews. When it is determined by the fire marshal that a fire detection, and/or fire suppression system requires a plan review by an independent licensed professional, a base fee equal to the cost of the independent professional's services plus fifteen (15) per cent will be charged. Said fees must be paid in full prior to the issuance of any review comments and/or approval. 
(18)  Plan review for fire pump. This fee includes the initial plan review of the submitted drawings that have been sealed and stamped by a professional engineer. The plan review will cover the pad site location and/or pump house, rated capacity, location of pump test outlets (header), water supply piping, fire department connection, fuel type and storage, transfer switch and fire pump and engine specifications. The fire pump shall be installed in accordance with 2012 International Fire Code section 913, the International Building Code, NFPA 20 and NFPA 110. The plan review fee is listed in the schedule of fees maintained by the fire marshal.

Sec. 11-15. - Fire investigation and incident reports. 
    Within the City of Grandview when a request is made for a copy of an investigation and incident reports, the following will apply: 
Requests for copies of fire investigation and incident reports are made by the property owner, insurance companies, private investigators and attorneys. No fire investigation report would be released until complete, especially if criminal investigation is ongoing. 
The cost for each fire investigation report would be one dollar ($1.00) per page, minimum ten dollars ($10.00). 
The individual or company requesting a fire investigation or incident report and will submit a request form. Before any copies are released a check payable to the City of Grandview would be submitted. 
Insurance companies must first submit an "immunity letter" in accordance with RMSo § 320.081-320.087 before investigation reports will be released. 
(Ord. No. 6668, § 1, 3-25-14)

ARTICLE III. - FIREWORKS 

Sec. 11-19. - Display or sale within the city limits prohibited; exception. 
    The display, offer for sale, and retail sale, of fireworks within the city limits of Grandview is prohibited, except as provided in this Article III and in Chapter 56 of the 2012 International Fire Code. It shall be unlawful for any person to offer for sale, expose for sale, or sell fireworks except that bona fide jobbers or wholesalers may possess, store and sell lawful fireworks, provided that the possession, storage, and sale comply with all requirements of law, including the Missouri Revised Statutes, as amended, and local codes. 
    Note- Sections 5601.1.3 and 5601.7 listed in Chapter 56 of the International Fire Code, 2012 edition, provide as follows: 
5601.1.3 Fireworks. The possession, manufacture, storage, sale, handling and use of fireworks are prohibited. 
Exceptions: 
1.  Storage and handling of fireworks as allowed in Section 5604. 
2.  Manufacture, assembly and testing of fireworks as allowed in Section 5605. 
3.  The use of fireworks for fireworks displays as allowed in Section 5608. 
4.  The possession, storage, sale, handling and use of specific types of Division 1.4G fireworks where allowed by applicable laws, ordinances and regulations, provided such fireworks comply with CPSC 16 CFR Parts 1500 and 1507, and DOTn 49 CFR Parts 100-185, for consumer fireworks. 
5.  A Fireworks and Pyrotechnic Permit issued by the City of Grandview Fire Prevention Bureau. 
5601.7 Seizure. The fire code official is authorized to remove or cause to be removed or disposed of in an approved manner, at the expense of the owner, explosives, explosive materials or fireworks offered or exposed for sale, stored, possessed or used in violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 4463, § 1, 4-27-93; Ord. No. 6768, § 2, 2-24-15; Ord. No. 7060, § 4, 3-27-18) 
Sec. 11-20. - Jobber and wholesaler defined. 
    A "jobber or wholesaler" within the meaning of this section shall be a person, business, company or corporation that sells fireworks in unbroken pieces or parcels to a purchaser for the following purposes and under the following guidelines only: 
(1)  To a purchaser to whom the sale is exempt under the sales tax laws of the State of Missouri, Chapter 144 Revised Missouri Statutes, as amended, and who buy for the purposes of resale; or 
(2)  To a person, business, company, corporation or organization who purchases fireworks for the purpose of a lawful display as defined in and meeting the requirements of Chapter 56, Sections 5601 and 5608 of the 2012 International Fire Code. 
(3)  To a person, business, company, corporation or organization who purchases fireworks for a lawful supervised display by such person, business, company, corporation, or organization outside the limits of the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
    Before any jobber or wholesaler shall make any such sale of fireworks within the City of Grandview, such jobber or wholesaler, in writing, shall advise any purchaser of the ordinances of the City of Grandview prohibiting the retail sale of fireworks or the unlicensed display or use of fireworks within the City of Grandview and, in addition, shall obtain from such purchaser a statement signed by such purchaser setting forth the purchaser's name, address, telephone number, the organization, business, company or corporation for whom such fireworks are purchased, the Missouri State Tax Identification Number, the date, and location of the intended display thereof. Such statements from the purchaser shall be retained by said jobber or wholesaler and such statements and all other documents or records pertaining to the sale of fireworks shall be made available to the city administrator of the City of Grandview, Missouri, or to such person designated by him upon demand. 
(Ord. No. 4463, § 1, 4-27-93; Ord. No. 6668, § 2, 3-25-14) 
Secs. 11-21-11-40. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - HAZARDOUS MATERIALS EMERGENCY RESPONSE COST RECOVERY[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2995, § 1, adopted Jan. 26, 1982, repealed former §§ 11-41-11-95, which had been included as Arts. IV-VII, pertained to flammable liquids, dry cleaning and dyeing establishments, liquefied petroleum gases, and nitrocellulose motion picture film, and were derived from Ord. No. 132, §§ 504, 701-711, 801-814, 901-919, 1001-1007; and Ord. No. 1886, § 1.  Subsequently, section 3 of Ord. No. 6668, adopted March 25, 2014, enacted new provisions as Art. IV, §§ 11-41-11-45. 

Sec. 11-41. - Missouri statute. 
    Missouri state law (RSMo § 260.546) states, in the event that a hazardous substance release occurs for which a political subdivision or volunteer fire protection association as defined in RSMo § 320.300, provides emergency services, the person having control over hazardous substances shall be liable for such reasonable cleanup costs incurred by the political subdivision or volunteer fire protection association. Such liability includes the cost of materials, supplies and contractual services actually used to secure an emergency situation. 
    The liability may also include the cost for contractual services that are not routinely provided by the department or political subdivision or volunteer fire protection association. Such liability shall not include the cost of normal services that otherwise would have been provided. ;p0p; To assist local hazardous substance emergency responding agencies recover cleanup costs in accordance with RSMo §§ 260.500 through 260.550, sometimes referred to as the "Spill Bill." Under RSMo §§ 260.500 through 260.550 in the State of Missouri, the City of Grandview Fire Department can submit an itemized bill to the responsible party to recover cost associated with a hazardous materials incident. The billing procedure and approved state costs are attached. 
(Ord. No. 6668, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 11-42. - Recommended procedure for billing. 
    The following steps should be followed when trying to recover costs incurred while handling a hazardous substance release. Remember that the billing is to recover actual costs while trying to clean-up/mitigate the release of the hazardous substance. Its purpose is not to acquire new equipment that may be used by the agency for future responses or replace exhausted equipment. An attached price guide has been provided by a committee comprised of division of fire safety, department of natural resources, and local response agencies across Missouri. 
Step 1. Ensure that the release has been reported to the department of natural resources twenty-four-hour spill line at 573-634-2436. This will help document the release and can assist with consistency in response details. 
Step 2. Keep good documentation of the activities at the site and who performed various duties (using ICS forms and submitting them will help document the response). Include photos of any damaged equipment. If any gear needed to be cleaned or replaced submit documentation (including photos) of the cleaning and pricing. 
Step 3. An itemized, dated, detailed bill (see attached example invoice) should be sent via certified mail, with a return receipt requested, to the person having control of the hazardous substance (owner, responsible party, etc.). If equipment was destroyed and compensation is being sought, explain how and why it was lost, including information as to how the replacement cost was determined. This bill should include copies of all bills for any assistance that was required from other departments as defined in the statute. It should be noted that the person having control of the hazardous substance can contest the billing if done in accordance with the law. 
Step 4. If payment is not received within thirty (30) days, resubmit the detailed billing via certified mail, with a return receipt requested, along with a copy of the Chapter [RSMo §§] 260.500-260.550 (or at least [RSMo] § 260.546). It is important to outline the part of the law that states, "Full payment shall be made within thirty (30) days of receipt of the cost statement." Also, it would be advisable to note to them that "John Doe" signed for the initial statement, which was sent earlier. 
Step 5. If the second step is unsuccessful at recovering costs incurred, your agency will need to seek legal counsel (city attorney, county prosecutor, etc.) to assist with the cost recovery. 
Step 6. Send one (1) invoice for all agencies involved. This invoice should be sent by the lead agency responsible for the incident with jurisdictional authority. 
(1)  Emergency response spiller cost recovery fees: 
Engines:

This contact also has rates for heavy equipment. 
(Ord. No. 6668, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 11-43. - Appeal of emergency expenses. 
    If the person having control over the hazardous substance elects to contest the payment of such costs, such person shall file an appeal with the director of the Missouri Department of Natural Resources within thirty (30) days of receipt of the cost statement. If billing is contested, it is important that the agency trying to collect incurred costs has submitted an itemized, detailed bill. 
    This itemized detailed bill and proper supporting documentation (narrative incident summary, final reports, invoices, receipts, etc.) will help the director in resolving the appeal in a timely manner. Per [RSMo] § 260.546 "The burden of proof shall be on the political subdivision or volunteer fire protection district to document and justify such costs allowed under section 11-42 of this article. 
    Questions about cost recovery may be directed to the department's environmental services program at 573-526-3315. 
(Ord. No. 6668, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 11-44. - Local government reimbursement. 
    The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has a program designed to reimburse local governments that have been affected by costs beyond those routinely incurred when dealing with a hazardous substance release. The local governments reimbursement program (LGR) is found under federal regulations at 40 CFR Part 310, which defines a hazardous substance in section 101 (14) of the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act of 1980 (CERCLA). Only emergencies involving CERCLA compounds will be eligible for compensation using the LGR program. This does not include petroleum, crude oil or any fraction thereof. 
    The LGR program will reimburse local governments for expenses incurred in carrying out temporary emergency measures. These measures must be necessary to prevent or mitigate injury to human health or the environment associated with the release of any hazardous substance, pollutant or contaminant. The financial relief is limited to twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) per single response. To obtain more information about the LGR program or to receive an application, call 800-431-9209 or 
www.epa.gov/ceppo/web/content/lgr/. 
(Ord. No. 6668, § 3, 3-25-14) 
Sec. 11-45. - Oil Pollution Act. 
    The EPA has a program designed to reimburse cost associated with petroleum releases that enter or threaten to enter U.S. waters. The Oil Pollution Act improved the nation's ability to prevent and provide money and resources necessary to respond to oil spills. To obtain more information about the Oil Pollution Act fund, contact EPA Region 7 at 913-551-7000. 
    Nothing in this document may be used to implement any enforcement action or levy any penalty unless promulgated by rule under chapter 536 of the 2012 International Fire Code or authorized by statute. 
(Ord. No. 6668, § 3, 3-25-14)
