    Bank means any banking corporation, credit union or savings and loan licensed by the state or the United States of America and for the purposes of this section includes the following establishments as defined at section 31-3 of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview (Zoning Ordinance): check cashing establishment, pawn shop, consumer credit loan business, title loan business, and Section 500 Company. 
    Intimidate means to engage in conduct which would make a reasonable person fearful or feel compelled. 
    Public area means an area to which the public or a substantial group of persons has access, and includes but is not limited to alleys, bridges, buildings, driveways, parking lots, parks, playgrounds, plazas, sidewalks and streets open to the general public, and the doorways and entrances to buildings and dwellings, and the grounds enclosing them. 
    Solicit or solicitation means to request an immediate donation of money or other thing of value from another person, regardless of the solicitor's purpose or intended use of the money or other thing of value, offering for sale, or advertising any product, property or service of any kind. The solicitation may be, without limitation, by spoken, written or printed word or by other means of communication. 
(c)  Prohibited acts. It shall be unlawful for any person to solicit money or other things of value or to solicit the sale of goods or services: 
(1)  In an aggressive manner in a public area. 
(2)  In an aggressive manner from person in vehicles. 
(3)  On any public transportation. 
(4)  Within fifteen (15) feet of any entrance or exit of any or within fifteen (15) feet of any automated teller machine during the hours of operation of such bank or automated teller machine without the consent of the owner or other person legally in possession of such facilities; provided, however, that when an automated teller machine is located within an automated teller machine facility, such distance shall be measured from the entrance or exit of the automated teller machine facility. 
(5)  On private property if the owner, tenant or lawful occupant has asked the person not to solicit on the property or has posted a sign clearly indicating that solicitations are not welcome on the property. 
(d)  Miscellaneous 
(1)  This section is not intended to prohibit any demand for payment for services rendered or goods delivered. 
(2)  Transient merchants or itinerant vendors shall obtain a solicitor's permit as required by Chapter 30 of the Code of Laws. 
(3)  Solicitation from persons in vehicles shall only be allowed after issuance of a solicitation permit authorized by section 14-126 of the Code of Laws. 
(Ord. No. 6189, § 3, 4-22-08) 
Chapter 17A - PARKS AND PARKWAYS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Parks and recreation commission, § 2-50 et seq. 

Sec. 17A-1. - Protection of persons and of lawns, grassplots, etc. 
(a)  No person shall conduct himself in such a manner in or upon any public park, parkway or park road under the control of the city, which would endanger any other persons or which would destroy, injure or damage any lawns, grassplots, flowers, trees or other park properties. 
(b)  The lawns or grassplots of public parks or parkways shall not be used by any person or vehicle as thoroughfares in crossing from one roadway or street to another roadway or street, and all motorized vehicles, including motorcars, trucks, buses, motorbikes, motorcycles, motorscooters, minibikes, go-carts or any other mechanically propelled vehicles are confined to roadways, parking areas or other areas designated for special activities. 
(c)  This section shall not be construed to interfere with the use of public parks or parkways as pleasure grounds by the people for the purposes of recreation under such reasonable rules and regulations as may from time to time be prescribed by the Grandview Parks and Recreation Director. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 1; Ord. No. 5621, § 1, 5-13-03) 
Sec. 17A-2. - Protection of park properties and facilities. 
    No person shall destroy, deface, injure, remove or relocate any park properties or facilities, including restrooms, comfort stations, tables, benches, grills, ovens, shelter houses, play equipment, signs, fences or any other man-made or natural features of any public park or parkway, excepting city or county employees, or their contractors, in pursuit of their normal duties. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 2) 
Sec. 17A-3. - Injuring or destroying gates, fences, etc. 
    No person shall tear down, remove, loosen, cut or otherwise injure or destroy, or cause to be torn down, removed, loosened, cut or otherwise injured or destroyed, any gate, plank, post, picket or fence enclosing or within any public park or parkway. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 3) 
Sec. 17A-4. - Cutting, etc., trees, flowers, etc.; breaking or carrying away rocks, stones, etc. 
    No person shall cut, pick, damage or injure any trees, flowers, shrubs or any other flora on land or in water within any public park in the city, nor shall any rocks, stones or other native materials be broken off, or carried away at any time. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 4) 
Sec. 17A-5. - Unleashed dogs, cats, etc., prohibited; horseback riding. 
    No unleashed dog or cat or other domesticated animal shall be permitted within any public park at any time. Horseback riding is prohibited upon any lawns, playfields or playing areas of any public park. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 5) 
Sec. 17A-6. - Possession of firearms prohibited; exception. 
(a)  The possession of firearms on the lakes, streams or in the parks shall not be permitted at any time. The possession of a firearm shall be considered prima facie evidence of violating this chapter. 
(b)  This section shall not be construed as to prohibit the carrying of a firearm by a peace officer or other persons otherwise authorized to carry a firearm. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 6) 
Sec. 17A-7. - Hunting wildlife. 
    No person shall hunt, pursue, catch, kill, trap or take any wildlife in any manner or in any quantity or at any time or place, except as permitted by the rules and regulations of the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 7) 
Sec. 17A-8. - Discharging fireworks and firecrackers prohibited. 
    Discharge or displays of fireworks and firecrackers within any public park or parkway is prohibited at all times. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 8) 
Sec. 17A-9. - Solicitation and sale of articles. 
    The solicitation of any business or service is prohibited without proper approval. No person is permitted to offer or advertise merchandise or other goods for sale or hire, to expose any article or thing for sale, or to maintain any concession or use any park facilities, or building, trails, roads or other park properties under the control of the city, for commercial purposes, unless authorized by the parks and recreation director, or his/her designated representative, and a valid occupational license has been obtained from the city in accordance with Chapter 13 of the Grandview Municipal Code. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 9; Ord. No. 5621, § 1, 5-13-03) 
Sec. 17A-10. - Refuse, trash, etc., disposal; contaminating lakes and streams prohibited. 
    No refuse, trash, tin cans or waste papers of any kind shall be placed in the waters, lakes or streams or on the land of any park, but shall be placed in containers provided for that purpose. Contaminating or polluting of any lake or stream is prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 10) 
Sec. 17A-11. - Fires generally. 
    Fires shall be built only in the ovens, grills, stones, or fire rings provided and must be extinguished before leaving the area. Fires may be prohibited entirely by the posting of special signs, or upon notification by a member of the city's parks and recreation department, police department or fire department. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 11; Ord. No. 5621, § 1, 5-13-03) 
Sec. 17A-11.1. - Closing hours for parks generally. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to be on or in the premises, boundaries or facilities of any park or park facility between the hours of 10:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. from April 1 to October 31, and between 8:00 p.m. and 6:00 a.m. from November 1 to March 31 unless participating in a scheduled, supervised program of the city's parks and recreation department or has written permission from the director of parks and recreation. Every person convicted for a violation of this section shall be punished by a fine of not more than one hundred dollars ($100.00), or by imprisonment of not more than ninety (90) days, or both by such fine and imprisonment. 
(Ord. No. 2680, § 2, 7-24-79; Ord. No. 6696, § 1, 8-12-14) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2680, § 2, adopted July 24, 1979, did not expressly amend this Code; hence, codification as § 17A-11.1 is at the discretion of the editor. 
Sec. 17A-12. - Overnight camping-Where permitted; permit required. 
    Overnight camping is permitted only in the areas designated and only upon receipt of a valid permit issued by the parks and recreation director or his/her designated representative. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 12; Ord. No. 5621, § 1, 5-13-03) 
Sec. 17A-13. - Same-Campground regulations enumerated. 
    [The following regulations apply to use of campground areas:] 
(1)  Quiet must be observed from 10:00 p.m. to 6:00 a.m. 
(2)  All garbage must be wrapped and placed in containers. 
(3)  Fires are permitted only in facilities provided. 
(4)  Dogs, cats and other pets must be under control or on a leash. 
(5)  Tables and benches are not to be moved from the site. 
(6)  All vehicles must remain on the roadways or parking areas. 
(7)  The natural terrain, plants and animals shall not be disturbed in any way. 
(8)  The cleaning of fish, washing of dishes or clothes at water hydrants is prohibited. 
(9)  No wastewater may be dumped on campgrounds. 
(10)  Camps must not be left unattended for more than twenty-four (24) hours. 
(11)  Campsites must be cleaned daily. 
(12)  Trenching of tents is prohibited. 
(13)  Camping is limited to five (5) nights. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 13) 
Sec. 17A-14. - Disorderly, etc., persons. 
    Persons who render themselves obnoxious by disorderly conduct, bad behavior, or indecent exposure shall be subject to penalties prescribed by law, and in addition thereto, or in lieu thereof, may be summarily removed from the area by the parks and recreation director or his designee or any peace officer. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 14; Ord. No. 5621, § 1, 5-13-03) 
Sec. 17A-15. - Intoxicating beverages. 
    Possession and consumption of intoxicating beverages within public parks is prohibited unless an authorized permit is obtained from the parks and recreation director or his/her designated representative for special uses as outlined in the operational manual for the Grandview Community Center and on multipurpose room patios of the community center. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 15; Ord. No. 5621, § 1, 5-13-03) 
Sec. 17A-16. - Speed limit; weight limit of trucks. 
    The speed limit shall be not in excess of fifteen (15) miles per hour for any vehicle and all vehicles are confined to roadways or parking areas provided. Trucks over one and one-half (11/2) tons shall be prohibited. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 16) 
Sec. 17A-17. - Applicability of other regulations. 
    In addition, the following chapters of this Code are applicable and enforceable within any public park or parkway under the control of the city, as if fully set out herein: 
(a)  Chapter 14-Motor Vehicles and Traffic. 
(b)  Chapter 15-Noise. 
(c)  Chapter 17-Offenses-Miscellaneous. 
(Ord. No. 1883, § 17) 
Chapter 18 - PERSONNEL 
ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 18-1. - Purpose of article. 
    It is the purpose of the rules contained in this article to establish normal procedures, which will serve as a guide to administrative action, concerning various personnel activities and transactions. These rules are intended to indicate the customary and most reasonable methods whereby the aims of the merit system can be carried out. 
(Ord. No. 1332, § 1) 
Sec. 18-2. - Applicability of article. 
    All officers and employees in the service of the city shall be included within the classified service, except the following: 
(a)  Elective officers; 
(b)  Members of appointive boards, commissions and committees; 
(c)  Persons engaged under contract to supply expert professional or technical services for a definite period of time; 
(d)  Volunteer personnel; 
(e)  City administrator and city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 1332, § 1) 
Sec. 18-3. - Administration of article. 
    The rules established by this article shall be administered by the personnel officer, under the direction of the city administrator, and in conformity with these rules and regulations. The city administrator may be the personnel officer. 
(Ord. No. 1332, § 1) 
Sec. 18-4. - City administrator authorized to establish rules and regulations. 
    The city administrator is hereby authorized and directed to establish and promulgate rules and regulations for employees and paid personnel of the city based upon principles of merit, as hereinafter set forth. Such rules and regulations shall be published and designated as the "Personnel Manual" for the City of Grandview. Such rules and regulations shall be subject to approval, by resolution, of the board of aldermen. The city administrator may, from time to time, suggest changes and amendments to such personnel manual, which such changes or amendments shall be first approved by the board of aldermen. A copy of such personnel manual, and changes and amendments thereto, shall be furnished by the city administrator to each department head, and to such other employees as the city administrator may designate. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 1, 8-24-76) 
Editor's note- Sections 1 and 2 of Ord. No. 2367, enacted Aug. 24, 1976, have been included herein as new §§ 18-4 and 18-5 pursuant to instructions from the city. Section 3 of said Ord. No. 2367 repealed former §§ 18-4-18-66, pertaining to personnel rules and regulations and derived from the following ordinances: Ord. No. 902, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1332, §§ 2-13; Ord. No. 1491; Ord. No. 1742, § 1; Ord. No. 1851, §§ 1-4; Ord. No. 1907, § 2; Ord. No. 2003, 1; Ord. No. 2040, § 1; and Ord. No. 2343, § 1, 6-24-76. 
Sec. 18-5. - Merit principles. 
    Such personnel manual shall pertain to such matters of personnel administration as the city administrator shall determine to be necessary for the efficient and equitable administration of the personnel system of the city, and shall be based on the following principles of merit: 
(1)  Recruitment, selection and advancement of employees shall be on the basis of their relative ability, knowledge, and skills, including open consideration of qualified applicants for initial appointment; 
(2)  Equitable and adequate compensation shall be provided all personnel; 
(3)  Training shall be provided all employees, as needed, to assure high-quality performance; 
(4)  Employees shall be retained on the basis of the adequacy of their performance, correcting inadequate performance, and separating employees whose inadequate performance cannot be corrected; 
(5)  Fair treatment of applicants and employees in all aspects of personnel administration shall be without regard to political affiliation, race, color, national origin, sex, age, handicap or religious creed, and with proper regard for their privacy and constitutional rights as citizens; and 
(6)  Employees shall be protected against coercion for partisan and nonpartisan political purposes and shall be prohibited from using their official authority for the purpose of interfering with or affecting the result of an election or a nomination for office. 
(Ord. No. 2367, § 2, 8-24-76; Ord. No. 3278, § 1, 10-9-84) 
Note- See editor's note following § 18-4. 
Secs. 18-6-18-66. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - SOCIAL SECURITY 

Sec. 18-67. - Extended to certain employees and officers. 
    It is hereby declared to be the policy and purpose of the city to extend to all eligible employees and officials of the city who are not excluded by law or by this article, and whether employed in connection with a governmental or proprietary function of the city, the benefits of the system of federal old-age and survivors insurance as authorized by the Social Security Act Amendments of 1950 and section 105.300 et seq. of the Revised Statutes of Missouri and amendments thereof, as the same may be in effect on and after February 6, 1956. 
(Ord. No. 233, § 1) 
Sec. 18-68. - Persons authorized to execute and implement plan. 
    The mayor and city clerk are authorized and directed, on behalf of the city, to prepare, execute and submit to the division of budget and comptroller of the state, as state agency of the state, a plan and agreement for extending social security benefits to eligible employees and officials of the city, in the form prepared by the state agency and approved and adopted by the board of aldermen, which plan and agreement are to become effective upon approval thereof by the state agency, and are further authorized and directed to execute agreements and modifications and amendments thereof with the state agency, providing for the extension of such benefits to the employees and officials as set forth in the plan and agreement, as provided for in section 18-67. The plan and agreement shall provide that the extension of benefits is to be effective on January 1, 1956. 
(Ord. No. 233, § 1) 
Sec. 18-69. - Deductions from wages. 
    Commencing on the first day of the month following the date of the approval of the plan and agreement of the city by the state agency there shall be deducted from the wages of all employees and officials of the city, to whom the benefits of the system of Federal Old Age and Survivors Insurance are extended, by virtue of the plan and agreement provided for in this article, the amount of each of such employees' and officials' contributions, as determined by the applicable state and federal laws and by the plan and agreement, the aggregate amount of such deduction shall be paid into the contributions fund created by section 105.300 et seq. of the Revised Statutes of Missouri; provided, that from the first payment of wages made to each of such employees and officials after the benefits of the system have been extended to such employees and officials, there shall be deducted a sum equal to the amount which would have been due and payable from each of such employees and officials had the extension of benefits been provided and effective on January 1, 1956. 
(Ord. No. 233, § 1) 
Sec. 18-70. - Administration of plan. 
    The city, from and after the approval of the plan and agreement of the city by the state agency, shall fully comply with, and shall keep such records, make such reports and provide such methods of administration of the plan and agreement as may be required by all applicable state and federal laws, rules and regulations, now and hereafter in effect with respect to the extension of the benefits of the Federal Old Age and Survivors Insurance System to the employees and officials of the city. For the purpose of administering the plan and agreement, the city treasurer shall be the official who shall make all required reports, keep all records and be responsible for the administration of the plan and agreement on behalf of the city, and any and all notices and communications from the state agency to the city with respect to the plan and agreement shall be addressed to "City Treasurer, City Hall, Grandview, Missouri." 
(Ord. No. 233, § 1) 
Sec. 18-71. - Contributions by city. 
    Commencing on the first day of the month following the date of the approval of the plan and agreement of the city by the state agency, there is hereby authorized to be appropriated from the general fund of the city, the sum of money necessary to pay the contributions of the city which shall be due and payable by virtue of the extension of the benefits of the Federal Old Age and Survivors Insurance System to the eligible employees and officials of the city. The sum of money shall be paid into the contributions fund created by section 105.300 et seq. of the Revised Statutes of Missouri; provided, that in making the first payment to the contributions fund, after the benefits of the system have been extended to such employees and officials, the first payment shall include a sum equal to the amount which would have been due and payable had the extension of benefits been provided and effective on January 1, 1956. The fund from which the appropriation is made shall, at all times, be sufficient to pay the contributions of the city, by this section, directed to be paid to the contributions fund. 
(Ord. No. 233, § 1) 
ARTICLE III. - RETIREMENT SYSTEM 

Sec. 18-72. - City elects to be covered by state retirement system. 
    The city, a political subdivision as defined in Sections 70.600 through 70.760 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, hereby elects to have covered by the Missouri local government employees retirement system all its eligible employees in the following classes: 
    Present and future general employees. 
    Present and future firemen. 
    Present and future policemen. 
(Ord. No. 1710, § 1) 
Sec. 18-73. - One hundred percent prior employment to be creditable. 
    The city hereby elects that one hundred (100) percent of prior employment shall be considered for prior service credit in computing benefits and contributions to the system. 
(Ord. No. 1710, § 2) 
Sec. 18-74. - City clerk authorized to deduct contributions from wages. 
    The director of finance is hereby authorized and directed to deduct from the wages and salaries of each employee member the member contributions required by Section 70.705 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri, and to promptly remit the deductions to the retirement system, together with the employer contributions required by Section 70.730 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri. 
(Ord. No. 1710) 
Chapter 20 - POLICE[1]

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 20-1. - Appointment of policemen. 
    The police of the city may be appointed by the board of aldermen in such numbers, for such time and in such manner as it may prescribe. 
State Law reference- RSMo, § 85.620. 
Sec. 20-2. - Powers of policemen generally. 
    The city policemen shall have power to serve and execute all warrants, subpoenas, writs or other process, and to make arrests in the same manner as the city marshal. 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo, § 85.620. 
Sec. 20-3. - Compensation and uniforms for school crossing patrol women. 
    The rate of pay of women employed by the city to serve as school crossing patrol women shall be five dollars ($5.00) per day effective at the beginning of the 1964-65 school term. 
    The city shall furnish to each patrol woman at the city's expense two (2) pairs of slacks and two (2) white shirts. 
(Ord. No. 895, §§ 1, 2) 
Cross reference- Uniform allowances for policemen, § 18-18.

Editor's note- Ord. No. 2299, adopted Jan. 13, 1976, repealed former Art. II, §§ 20-4-20-7, relative to establishment of a board of police commissioners, membership and duties. Said former sections were derived from Ord. No. 719, § 6; Ord. No. 1093; and Ord. No. 1298, § 2. It should be noted that § 20-15 contains provisions relative to certain hearings to be held before the board of police commissioners, which said Ord. No. 2299 has abolished. 

Secs. 20-4-20-7. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - CHIEF OF POLICE[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Cross reference- Supervision and control of police department, appointment, § 2-37. 

Sec. 20-8. - Powers and duties generally. 
(a)  The chief of police shall appoint such number of ranking officers, patrolmen and other employees deemed necessary to efficiently perform the duties and responsibilities of the department and in conformance with budget allocations as adopted by the board of aldermen. 
(b)  The chief of police shall organize the department in such manner as to efficiently and properly conduct the duties and responsibilities of the department as prescribed by law. 
(c)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to, and shall prescribe and enforce such directives as may be necessary to carry out the provisions of this chapter and any other laws the enforcement and administration of which are vested in this department. 
(d)  The chief of police is hereby authorized to, and shall establish such regulations and procedures for promotion within the department consistent with the merit system of the city. During the first year of appointment to a particular higher rank, the chief of police may reduce any officer to his previous rank for unsatisfactory performance or conduct unbecoming to an officer. After the year, no officer will be reduced in rank except as provided for by the merit system. 
(e)  The chief of police shall have the power to recommend pay increases or decreases in conformance with the merit system. 
(f)  The chief of police shall have the authority to suspend a member of the department for any period of time in conformance with the merit system. 
(g)  The chief of police and all appointed officers are hereby empowered to arrest, under the authority of Chapter 85 of the Revised Statutes of Missouri or any amendments thereto, for any violation of any criminal law of this state or of any provisions of this Code and ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 1615, § 4) 
State Law reference- Similar provisions, RSMo § 85.610. 
Secs. 20-9, 20-10. - Repealed by Ordinance No. 1615. 
ARTICLE IV. - RESERVE UNIT 

Sec. 20-11. - Established; membership. 
    The city marshal is authorized and directed to establish a police reserve unit to be made up of citizens of the city. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 1) 
Sec. 20-12. - Recruit school for reserve police officers. 
    The city marshal is authorized and directed to establish and conduct a recruit school for all reserve police officers. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 2) 
Sec. 20-13. - Application for appointment; procedure for qualifying for appointment. 
    Applicants for appointment to the police reserve unit shall make application to the city marshal. In order to become a reserve, the applicant shall: 
(a)  Meet the height and weight standards set out in Chapter 18. 
(b)  Pass a physical examination to determine color blindness, condition of eyesight and general health. This examination shall be paid for by the city from police department funds. 
(c)  Pass a written examination prepared and conducted by the police department. 
(d)  Appear before the board of police commissioners for oral examination and screening. 
(e)  Receive appointment by a favorable vote of the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 2) 
Editor's note- Personnel rules and regulations formerly set out in full in Chapter 18 of this Code may be found in the document entitled "Personnel Manual," which document is adopted by reference pursuant to § 18-4 of this Code. 
The board of police commissioners has been abolished pursuant to Ord. No. 2299, adopted Jan. 13, 1976; the user's attention is directed to the editor's footnote to Art. II of this chapter. 
Sec. 20-14. - Reserve officer to complete recruit school; purchase of uniform and side arm. 
    Each newly appointed reserve police officer shall complete satisfactorily the recruit school and thereupon, before his final acceptance as a reserve by the city marshal, shall purchase one complete police uniform, including side arm. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 4) 
Sec. 20-15. - Control of reserve police officers; hours of duty of reserve officer; procedure upon lodging complaint against reserve officer. 
    All reserve police officers shall be under the direct control of the city marshal and commanding officers of the police department. They may be called to duty by any regular officer when needed for emergency work. Each reserve shall devote at least sixteen (16) hours per month to police duty, eight (8) hours being scheduled by the police department and eight (8) hours voluntary. In case a formal written complaint is lodged against any reserve officer, the proceedings shall be the same as under Chapter 18, with the hearing before the board of police commissioners and final action thereon by the mayor and board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 5) 
Editor's note- Personnel rules and regulations formerly set out in full in Chapter 18 of this Code may be found in the document entitled "Personnel Manual," which document is adopted by reference pursuant to § 18-4 of this Code. 
The board of police commissioners has been abolished pursuant to Ord. No. 2299, adopted Jan. 13, 1976; the user's attention is directed to the editor's footnote to Art. II of this chapter. 
Sec. 20-16. - Compensation for reserve officers. 
    Reserve police officers shall receive no remuneration for their services unless such be specially authorized and the money appropriated therefor by the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 972, § 6) 
ARTICLE V. - PRIVATE SECURITY 

Sec. 20-17. - Definitions. 
    For purposes of this article, the following words and terms shall have the meanings given when used in this article, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning. 
    Peace officer means a person whose primary occupation is a police officer commissioned or authorized by the United States Government, the State of Missouri or any governmental subdivision thereof to generally enforce the criminal statutes or ordinances of such governmental units. 
    Private security officer means an individual in uniform or in plain clothes, who has the duty of maintaining law and order and discouraging crime and disorderly conduct, performing the duty for fee or wages, at any bank, store, restaurant, public entertainment, or other business or event. 
    Private security operator means a person, firm, or corporation which furnishes or agrees to furnish for hire, a private security officer to protect persons or property of another. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-18. - Private security operator's permit required. 
    A person, firm, or corporation shall not engage in the business of a private security operator in the city without first obtaining a private security operator's permit from the police department and paying the annual permit fee hereinafter provided for. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-19. - Application for private security operator's permit. 
(a)  Application for a private security operator's permit shall be filed with the police department. The person, agent or owner shall provide information that is relevant to the consideration of the application as required by the police department. 
(b)  The police department shall complete a criminal history check and background investigation on each applicant for a private security operator's permit. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-20. - Permit issuance/refusal. 
    The chief of police shall grant or deny the applicant permission to engage in business as a private security operator. The permit shall be issued if investigation has determined that the applicant, agent, or owner has not been convicted of a felony or an offense involving violence, theft, fraud, or unlawfully carrying a concealed weapon. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-21. - Terms and conditions of permit. 
    Any permit granted by the chief of police as provided in this article, shall be issued upon the following terms and conditions: 
(1)  The chief of police shall regulate the style and color of uniform, if any, to be used by said security operator. The uniform color and shoulder patches shall not resemble a uniform of the Grandview Police Department. 
(2)  Any permit issued pursuant to this article may at any time be revoked by the chief of police for cause shown, notice to the holder thereof and an opportunity to be heard shall be given. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-22. - Private security operator's fee. 
    Every person, firm, or corporation as herein provided conducting or operating any security service shall pay a fee to the police department of fifty dollars ($50.00) per annum, payable yearly. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-23. - Private security officer's permit required. 
    No person shall serve as a private security officer anywhere within the city without first obtaining a permit from the police department; except, that a peace officer as defined in this article is not required to obtain a permit. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-24. - Application for private security officer's permit. 
(a)  Application for a private security officer's permit shall be made to the police department. The application shall include all relevant information necessary for consideration of the application as required by the police department. 
(b)  A criminal history check on each applicant shall be completed by the police department. 
(c)  The applicant will list his/her private security operator employer on the application. 
(d)  Private security officer applicants who are to work armed with a firearm, shall show proof of qualification. It shall be the applicant's responsibility to receive certification with a duty firearm. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-25. - Private security officer's fee. 
    At the time the application is filed for a private security officer's permit, the applicant shall pay a nonrefundable investigation fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-26. - Qualifications, issuance. 
    No private security officer permit shall be issued to any person convicted of a felony, or a crime involving violence, theft, fraud or unlawfully carrying a weapon. No permit shall be issued to any person who does not meet the requirements of this chapter, or who has not reached the age of twenty-one (21). 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-27. - Term, renewals. 
    Private security officer permits shall be valid for the calendar year. A permit may be renewed each calendar year for a fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-28. - Suspension and revocation of permit. 
    The chief of police may suspend or revoke any private security officer's permit in accordance with this article. 
(1)  A permit shall be suspended or revoked for serious or repeated violations by the security officer of any Federal or State law or city ordinance, and for any serious or repeated violation of the civil rights of any person. 
(2)  It shall be unlawful for any private security officer to wear a uniform of the same color or having uniform patches that resemble the Grandview police uniform. 
(3)  A permit may be suspended for up to fourteen (14) days without a previous hearing, but the chief of police shall, if the person requests a hearing, schedule a hearing as soon as practicable. No permit shall be revoked permanently until a hearing is held by the chief of police upon notice to the private security officer. No formalities shall be required at such hearing. The decision made by the chief of police is final. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Sec. 20-29. - Penalty. 
    Any person, firm, or corporation violating any provision of this article shall be fined not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, and a separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day on which the violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 4634, § 1, 8-9-94) 
Chapter 21 - MUNICIPAL COURT[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2609, § 1, adopted Dec. 12, 1978, repealed former Ch. 21, which provided for a police court and was derived from R. O. 1929, ch. 3, art. 3, §§ 39, 42-45, 48, and ch. 4, art. 1, §§ 69, 70; Ord. No. 60; Ord. No. 625, §§ 2, 3; Ord. No. 1125, §§ 1, 2; Ord. No. 1370, § 1; Ord. No. 2304, § 1; Ord. No. 2531, § 1, adopted April 11, 1978; and Ord. No. 2587, §§ 2, 3, adopted Sept. 26, 1978. 
In lieu of former Ch. 21, § 2 of Ord. No. 2609 added new provisions relative to the municipal court as a new Ch. 21; section numbers for said provisions have been added by the editor at his discretion. 
Cross reference- General penalty for violation of this Code, § 1-6; compelling prisoners to work off fines and costs, § 1-7; board of aldermen to arrange for imprisonment of prisoners, § 1-8; department of law, §§ 2-35, 2-36; police generally, ch. 20; citations and fines for violations of motor vehicle and traffic regulations, §§ 14-190-14-205. 

Sec. 21-1. - Established. 
    There is hereby established in this city a municipal court to be known as the Grandview Municipal Court, a division of the Sixteenth Judicial Circuit Court of the State of Missouri. This court is a continuation of the police court of the city as previously established and is termed herein "the municipal court." 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(1), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-2. - Superintending authority. 
    The municipal court shall be subject to the rules of the circuit court of which it is a part, and to the rules of the state supreme court. The municipal court shall be subject to the general administrative authority of the presiding judge of the circuit court, and the municipal judge and municipal court personnel shall obey his directives. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(9), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-3. - Jurisdiction. 
    The jurisdiction of the municipal court shall extend to all cases involving alleged violations of the ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(2), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-4. - Municipal judge-Selection; qualifications. 
(a)  The judge of the municipal court shall be known as a municipal judge of the Sixteenth Judicial Circuit Court, and shall be elected to his position by the qualified voters of the city, for a term as specified in this chapter. 
(b)  A municipal judge shall possess the following qualifications before he shall take office: 
(1)  He must be a licensed attorney, admitted to practice law within the State of Missouri; 
(2)  He must be a resident of the State of Missouri and reside within the city; 
(3)  He must be between the ages of twenty-one (21) and seventy-five (75) years; and 
(4)  He may not hold any other office with the city government, but he may serve as municipal judge for another municipality. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(3), (5), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-5. - Same-Term of office; compensation; other employment. 
(a)  The municipal judge shall hold his office for a period of two (2) years. 
(b)  The rate of compensation for the municipal judge shall be established by the board of aldermen. 
(c)  The municipal judge shall be considered holding a part-time position and as such may accept (within the restrictions of the Code of Judicial Conduct, Missouri Supreme Court Rule 2) other employment. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(3)-(5), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-6. - Same-Vacation of office. 
    The municipal judge shall vacate his office under the following circumstances: 
(1)  Upon removal from office by the state commission on the retirement, removal and discipline of judges, as provided in Missouri Supreme Court Rule 12; 
(2)  Upon attaining his seventy-fifth birthday; 
(3)  If he should lose his license or be suspended from the practice of law within the State of Missouri; or 
(4)  Upon submitting his written resignation to the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(7), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-7. - Same-Filling of vacancies in office by temporary municipal judge, special election. 
    If a municipal judge be absent, sick or disqualified from acting, the mayor may designate some competent, eligible person to act as municipal judge until such absence or disqualification shall cease; provided, however, that should a vacancy occur in the office of an elected municipal judge more than six (6) months before a general municipal election, then a special election shall be held to fill such vacancy, and in case of vacancy in the office of an elected municipal judge within less than six (6) months of a general election, the office may be filled by a competent, eligible person designated by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(8), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-8. - Same-Powers and duties generally. 
    The municipal judge shall be and is hereby authorized to: 
(1)  Administer oaths and enforce due obedience to all orders, rules and judgments made by him, and may fine and imprison for contempt committed before him while holding court in the same manner and to the same extent as a circuit judge; 
(2)  Commute the term of any sentence, stay execution of any fine or sentence, suspend any fine or sentence, and make such other orders as the municipal judge deems necessary relative to any matter that may be pending in the municipal court; and 
(3)  Make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to implement and carry out the provisions of this chapter, and to make and adopt such rules of practice and procedure as are necessary to hear and decide matters pending before the municipal court and to implement and carry out the provisions of the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Court; 
and the municipal judge shall have such other powers, duties and privileges as are or may be prescribed by the laws of this state, this Code or other ordinances of this city. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(6), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-9. - Same-Docket and court records. 
    The municipal judge shall be a conservator of the peace. He shall keep a docket in which he shall enter every case commenced before him and the proceedings therein, and he shall keep such other records as may be required. Such docket and records shall be records of the Circuit Court of Jackson County. The municipal judge shall deliver the docket and records of the municipal court, and all books and papers pertaining to his office, to his successor in office or to the presiding judge of the circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(10), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-10. - Violation bureau established; funding. 
    The municipal judge shall establish a violation bureau as provided by Missouri Revised Statutes and Supreme Court Rule 37, to be under the supervision of the municipal court clerk. The city shall provide all expenses incident to the operation of the violation bureau. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(25), 12-12-78; Ord. No. 5232, § 1, 11-23-99) 
Cross reference- Traffic violations bureau, § 14-3 et seq. 
Sec. 21-11. - Office of municipal court clerk established; duties. 
(a)  There is hereby established a municipal court clerk of the Grandview Municipal Court. 
(b)  The duties of the clerk shall be as follows: 
(1)  To collect such fines for violations for such offenses as may be described, and the court costs therefor; 
(2)  To take oaths and affirmations; 
(3)  To accept signed complaints and allow the same to be signed and sworn to or affirmed before her; 
(4)  To sign and issue subpoenas requiring the attendance of witnesses and sign and issue subpoenas duces tecum; and 
(5)  To accept the appearance, waiver of trial and plea of guilty and payment of fines and costs in traffic violations bureau cases or as directed by the municipal judge and generally act as the violation clerk of the traffic violations bureau; 
and to perform all other duties as provided for by ordinance, by the rules adopted by the municipal judge and by the Missouri Rules of Practice and Procedure in Municipal and Traffic Courts and by statute; and maintain, properly certified by the city clerk, a complete copy of the Code of the City of Grandview which shall constitute prima facie evidence of such ordinances before the court. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(24), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-12. - Duty of prosecuting attorney to prosecute municipal ordinance violations. 
    It shall be the duty of the attorney designated by the city to prosecute the violations of the city's ordinances before the municipal judge or before any circuit judge or associate circuit judge hearing violations of the city's ordinances. The salary of the prosecuting attorney and his expenses incurred in such prosecution shall be paid by the city and shall not be contingent upon the result in any case. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(14), 12-12-78) 
Cross reference- Similar provisions, § 2-36(e). 
Sec. 21-13. - Issuance and execution of warrants. 
    All warrants issued by the municipal judge shall be directed to the chief of police, any other police officer of the city or any other peace officer as provided by law. The warrants shall be executed by the chief of police, or any Grandview police officer or other peace officer as provided by law any place within the limits of the county and not elsewhere unless the warrants are endorsed in the manner provided for warrants in criminal cases, and when so endorsed, shall be served in other counties, as provided for in warrants in criminal cases or by applicable state statute or rule of court. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(11), 12-12-78; Ord. No. 3652, § 2(a), 9-8-87) 
Cross reference- Administrative search warrants, § 1-10. 
Sec. 21-14. - Complaint requirement for trial following arrests without warrant. 
    The chief of police or any other police officer of the city may, without a warrant, make an arrest of any person who commits an offense in his presence, but such officer shall, before the trial, file a written complaint with the municipal court. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(12), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-15. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3652, § 2(b), adopted September 8, 1987, deleted paragraph 18 of Ord. No. 2609, adopted December 12, 1978 which was set out herein as § 12-15[21-15]. Former § 21-15 was concerned with the jailing of defendants by municipal judge. Similar provisions are set out in § 1-9 of this Code. 
Sec. 21-16. - Jury trial. 
(a)  Election by defendant authorized; reassignment of case. Any person charged with a violation of a municipal ordinance of the city shall be entitled to a trial by jury, as in prosecutions for misdemeanors before an associate circuit judge. Whenever a defendant accused of a violation of a municipal ordinance demands trial by jury, the municipal judge shall certify the case to the presiding judge of the circuit court for reassignment. 
(b)  Appeal from jury verdicts. In all cases in which a jury trial has been demanded, a record of the proceedings shall be made, and appeals may be had upon that record to the appropriate appellate court. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(13), (22), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-17. - Summoning of witnesses. 
    It shall be the duty of the municipal judge to summon all persons whose testimony may be deemed essential as witnesses at trial, and to enforce their attendance by attachment, if necessary. The fees of witnesses shall be the same as those fixed for witnesses in trials before associated circuit judges and shall be taxed as other costs in the case. When a trail[trial] shall be continued by a municipal judge, it shall not be necessary to summon any witness who may be present at the continuance; but the municipal judge shall orally notify such witnesses as either party may require to attend before him on the day set for trial to testify in the case, and enter the names of such witnesses on his docket, which oral notice shall be valid as a summons. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(15), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-18. - Disqualification of municipal judge from hearing a particular case. 
    A municipal judge may be disqualified to hear any case in which he is in any way interested or if, before the trial is commenced, the defendant or the city prosecutor files an affidavit that the defendant or the city, as the case may be, cannot have a fair and impartial trial by reason of the interest or prejudice of the judge. Neither the defendant nor the municipality shall be entitled to file more than one affidavit or disqualification in the same case. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(16), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-19. - Authority of municipal judge to transfer complaint to associate circuit judge where state law criminal offense involved. 
    If, in the progress of any trial before a municipal judge, it shall appear to the municipal judge that the accused ought to be put on trial for an offense against the criminal laws of the state and not cognizable before him as municipal judge, he shall immediately stop all further proceedings before him as municipal judge and cause the complaint to be made before some associate circuit judge within the county. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(17), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-20. - Breach of recognizance. 
    In the case of a breach of any recognizance entered into before a municipal judge or an associate circuit judge hearing a municipal ordinance violation case, the same shall be deemed forfeited and the judge shall cause the same to be prosecuted against the principal and surety, or either of them, in the name of the municipality as plaintiff. Such action shall be prosecuted before a circuit judge or associate circuit judge, and in event of cases caused to be prosecuted by a municipal judge, such shall be on the transcript of the proceedings before the municipal judge. All monies recovered in such action shall be paid over to the municipal treasury for the general revenue fund of the municipality. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(23), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-21. - Parole and probation. 
    Any judge hearing violations of municipal ordinances may, when in his judgment it may seem advisable, grant parole or probation to any person who shall plead guilty or who shall be convicted after a trial before said judge. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(19), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-22. - Installment payment of fines. 
    When a fine is assessed for violation of an ordinance, it shall be within the discretion of the judge assessing the fine to provide for the payment of a fine on an installment basis under such terms and conditions as he may deem appropriate. Failure to pay a fine or any installment may, in the discretion of the municipal judge, result in the incarceration of the violator. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(20), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-23. - Court costs-Authority to assess. 
(a)  Generally. Pursuant to RSMo § 479.260, and as authorized by RSMo § 488.012.3 (6), the municipal judge is hereby authorized and empowered to assess as fees an amount not to exceed twelve dollars ($12.00) per case for each municipal ordinance violation case filed before the municipal judge, and in the event a defendant pleads guilty or is found guilty, the judge may assess costs against the defendant except in those cases where the defendant is found by the judge to be indigent and unable to pay the costs. The fees authorized in this subsection (a) are in addition to service charges, witness fees, and jail costs that may otherwise be authorized to be assessed, but are in lieu of other court costs. The fees provided by this subsection (a) shall be collected by the municipal division clerk and shall be transmitted not less frequently than monthly to the City Treasurer for deposit in the City Treasury. 
(b)  For crime victims compensation fund. Additionally, pursuant to RSMo § 595.045 (1) and § 488.5339 (1), the municipal judge shall access as costs a surcharge of seven dollars and fifty cents ($7.50) in each municipal court proceeding involving an infraction and violation of municipal ordinance; except that no such surcharge shall be collected in any proceeding when the proceeding or the defendant has been dismissed by the court or when costs are to be paid by the City of Grandview. Such surcharge shall be collected by the municipal division clerk and transmitted not less frequently than monthly as follows: 
(1)  Ninety-five (95) per cent shall be paid to the Director of Revenue of the State of Missouri to the credit of the Crime Victims Compensation Fund; and 
(2)  Five (5) per cent shall be transmitted to the City Treasurer for deposit in the City Treasury. 
(c)  For municipal law enforcement training. Additionally, pursuant to RSMo § 488.5336.1, the municipal judge may assess as costs a surcharge of up to two dollars ($2.00) per case for each municipal ordinance violation case filed in municipal court; except that no such surcharge shall be assessed in any proceeding when the proceeding or defendant has been dismissed by the court, or when costs are to be paid by the City of Grandview. Such surcharge shall be collected by the municipal division clerk and transmitted not less frequently than monthly to the City Treasurer for use in training of law enforcement officers as provided in RSMo §§ 590.100-590.180. 
(d)  For peace officers standards and training commission fund. Additionally pursuant to RSMo § 488.5336.1, the municipal judge shall assess as costs a surcharge in the amount of one dollar ($1.00) for each municipal ordinance violation case filed in municipal court; except that no such surcharge shall be assessed in any proceeding when the proceeding or defendant has been dismissed by the court or when costs are to be paid by the City of Grandview. Such surcharge shall be collected by the municipal division clerk and transmitted not less frequently than monthly to the Treasurer of the State of Missouri to the credit of the Peace Officers Standards and Training Commission Fund, established by RSMo § 590.178, to be used state-wide for training of peace officers. 
(e)  For shelters for victims of domestic violence. Additionally pursuant to RSMo § 488.607, the municipal judge may assess as costs a surcharge of up to two dollars ($2.00) for each municipal ordinance violation case filed in municipal court; except that no such surcharge shall be collected in any proceeding when the proceeding or defendant has been dismissed by the court or when costs are to be paid by the City of Grandview. Such surcharge shall be collected by the municipal division clerk and transmitted not less frequently than monthly to the City Treasurer for the purpose of providing operating expenses for shelters for battered persons as defined in RSMo §§ 455.200-455.230. 
(f)  For reimbursement of drug or alcohol related arrest and processing costs. Every person who is convicted of or pleads guilty to a violation of municipal ordinances as contained in section 14-34 involving alcohol or drug related traffic offenses may be required to reimburse the city for costs associated with such arrest and processing. Such costs will be specified by the Grandview Police Department on a request for recoupment of funds form approved by the municipal court. The costs shall be calculated as additional costs and shall be collected by the municipal court in the same manner as other costs and fines; provided, however, that the municipal court, in its discretion, may order the costs as calculated by the police department reduced. Any costs collected shall be remitted to the City Treasurer. 
(g)  For the inmate security fund. Additionally, pursuant to RSMo. § 488.5026 the municipal judge shall assess as costs a surcharge in the amount of two dollars ($2.00) for each municipal ordinance violation case filed in municipal court; except that no such surcharge shall be assessed in any proceeding when the proceeding or defendant has been dismissed by the court or when costs are to be paid by the City of Grandview. Such surcharge shall be collected by the municipal division clerk and dispersed in accordance with RSMo. §§ 488.010 to 488.020, to the City treasurer to be deposited into the "Inmate Security Fund", for reimbursement of expenses incurred for the development and installation of biometric verification systems and after installation the funds may be used for the maintenance of biometric verification systems and expenses related to the custody and housing of prisoners to the City. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(27), 12-12-78; Ord. No. 2828, § 1, 11-11-80; Ord. No. 4579, § 1, 3-8-94; Ord. No. 4940, § 1, 12-17-96; Ord. No. 5232, § 2, 11-23-99; Ord. No. 5531, § 3, 10-8-02; Ord. No. 6091, § 1, 4-24-07) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 5531, § 2, adopted Oct. 8, 2002, repealed certain provisions of § 21-23, which derived from Ord. No. 4940, § 2, adopted Dec. 17, 1996; and Ord. No. 5232, § 3, adopted Nov. 23, 1999. 
Sec. 21-24. - Same-Assessment against prosecuting witness. 
    The costs of any action may be assessed against the prosecuting witness, and judgment be rendered against him that he pay the same and stand committed until paid, in any case where it appears to the satisfaction of the municipal judge that the prosecution was commenced without probable cause and from malicious motives. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(28), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-25. - Right of appeal. 
    In all cases tried before the municipal court, except where there has been a plea of guilty or where the case has been tried with a jury, the defendant shall have a right of trial de novo before a circuit judge or, on assignment, before an associate circuit judge. An application for a trial de novo shall be filed within ten (10) days after judgment and shall be filed in such form and perfected in such manner as provided by Missouri Supreme Court Rules. An additional fee of twenty dollars ($20.00) shall be assessed as court costs upon the filing of any application for a trial de novo. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(21), 12-12-78) 
Sec. 21-26. - Report by municipal judge to board of aldermen. 
    The municipal judge shall cause to be prepared within the first five (5) days of every month a report indicating the following: a list of all cases heard or tried before the court during a preceding month, giving in each case the name of the defendant, the fine imposed (if any), the amount of costs, the names of the defendants committed, and the cases where there was an application for trial de novo filed. The same shall be prepared under oath by the municipal court clerk or the municipal judge. This report will be filed with the city clerk who shall thereafter forward the same to the board of aldermen for examination at its first session thereafter. The municipal court shall, within the five (5) days after the first of the month, pay to the municipal treasurer the full amount of all fines collected during the preceding month, if they have not previously been paid. 
(Ord. No. 2609, § 2(26), 12-12-78) 
State Law reference- Mayor, municipal judge to make list of cases heard, RSMo § 98.660. 
Chapter 22 - PUBLIC UTILITIES 
ARTICLE I. - TELEPHONE COMPANIES 

Sec. 22-1. - License fee-Amount; when payment due, etc. 
(a)  Every person, firm, company or corporation now or hereafter engaged in the business of furnishing exchange telephone service in the city shall pay the city, as a monthly license fee, seven (7) percent of the gross receipts derived from the furnishing of such service within said city, as hereinafter set forth. 
(b)  Where used herein, the term "gross receipts" shall mean the aggregate revenue derived from charges for exchange telephone service in the city during any period described herein, less any discounts, credits, adjustments, refunds, sales taxes, and uncollectible revenue. 
(Ord. No. 1670, § 1; Ord. No. 2519, § 2, 3-28-78; Ord. No. 3162, § 2, 7-26-83) 
Sec. 22-2. - Same-In lieu of taxes, charges, etc.; exception. 
    The payments required by the provisions of this article shall be in lieu of all other excises, charges, fees, exactions, rentals, impositions or other license or occupation taxes which the city may be authorized to impose upon any person, firm, company or corporation engaged in the business described in section 22-1; but nothing herein contained shall be construed to exempt such person, firm, company or corporation from any general or special ad valorem tax imposed upon the public generally by the city. 
(Ord. No. 1670, § 5) 
Sec. 22-3. - Same-Commencement date of computation; date of first payment. 
    Every person, firm, company or corporation described in section 22-1 shall file with the finance director each month a verified statement of the gross receipts derived from the furnishing of exchange telephone service for the previous month, and at such time shall pay the fee, all as set forth herein. 
(Ord. No. 1670, § 7; Ord. No. 2519, § 3, 3-28-78; Ord. No. 3162, § 2, 7-16-83) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2519, § 3, adopted March 28, 1978, did not expressly amend the Code; at the direction of the city, provisions of said § 3 have been included herein as amendatory of the former provisions of § 22-3, which pertained to similar subject matter. 
Sec. 22-4. - Same-Furnishing of reports; inspection of accounts and records of licensee. 
    Such verified statements and payments as provided for by this article shall be made and due within thirty (30) days after the last day of each month of each calendar year and shall be for the gross receipts derived from the furnishing of exchange telephone services during such monthly period. Each payment shall be for a license to operate for the month in which the payment is made. At the time of filing each monthly statement, the person, firm, company or corporation involved shall pay the fee to the city as hereinabove provided in section 22-1, provided that any person, firm, company or corporation described herein shall have the privilege of crediting such sums as may be due hereunder with any unpaid balance due such person, firm, company or corporation for telephone service rendered or facilities furnished to said city. The city, the director of finance, the city administrator and his assistants, and any public accountant selected by the board of aldermen or by the city administrator shall have the right, at all reasonable times during business hours, to make such examinations and inspections of the books of the licensee as may be necessary to determine the correctness of such reports. The licensee shall make available such books and records as may be required by the city, or its representatives, to determine the correctness of the payments herein specified. The city shall have the right, at its own expense, to employ the same accountants who make the annual audit of the books, records, and accounts of the business of the licensee to audit, at the same time, its accounts and records, and certify as to the correctness of any payments due and payable by the licensee to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1670, § 4; Ord. No. 2519, § 3, 3-28-78; Ord. No. 3162, § 2, 7-26-83) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2519, § 3, adopted March 28, 1978, did not expressly amend the Code; at the direction of the city, provisions of said § 3 have been included herein as amendatory of former provisions of § 22-4 relating to the furnishing of quarterly reports of gross receipts. Provisions pertaining to inspection of records of the company by the city have been retained as formerly codified. 
Sec. 22-4A. - Penalty for delayed payment of license fees by telephone companies. 
    For each and every month, or part thereof, a license fee owed pursuant to article I of chapter 22 of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview, Missouri, remains unpaid, after the same becomes due and payable, there shall be added to such license fee, as a penalty for such delayed payment, ten (10) per cent of the amount of such license fee for the first month, or part thereof, the same is unpaid, and for each and every month thereafter, two (2) per cent of the amount of such license fee until the same is fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 6854, §§ 1, 2, 2-9-16) 
Sec. 22-5. - Permission granted to trim trees, foliage, etc., upon or overhanging streets. 
    Permission is hereby granted to any licensee to trim trees and foliage upon and overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the city so as to prevent the branches of such trees and foliage from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the licensee, all such trimming to be done under the direction of any city official to whom such duties have been or may be delegated. 
(Ord. No. 1670, § 2) 
Sec. 22-6. - Temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires. 
    All such person, firms, companies or corporations mentioned in section 22-1 on the request of any person shall remove, raise or lower its wires temporarily to permit the moving of houses or other bulky structures. The expense of such temporary removal, raising or lowering of wires shall be paid by the party or parties requesting such removal, raising or lowering of wires, and payment in advance may be required. Not less than forty-eight (48) hours advance notice shall be given to arrange for such temporary wire changes. 
(Ord. No. 1670, § 3) 
Sec. 22-7. - Exclusive privileges. 
    Nothing herein contained shall be construed as giving to a licensee any exclusive privileges, nor shall it affect any prior or existing rights of any licensee to maintain a telephone system within the city. 
(Ord. No. 1670, § 6) 
ARTICLE II. - GAS COMPANIES 

Sec. 22-8. - License fee-Amount; report of gross receipts to determine amount; credit for overpayment; inspection of accounts and records of licensee. 
(a)  Every gas company and every corporation, company, association, joint stock company or association, partnership and person, their lessees, trustees or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, owning, operating, managing, leasing or controlling a gas plant or system for the manufacture, distribution, sale or furnishing of gas, natural or manufactured, for light, heat, refrigeration or power, shall in addition to all other taxes, payments or requirements now or hereafter required by law or city ordinance, pay to the city as a license fee a sum equal to seven (7) per cent of the licensee's gross receipts from the sale of gas sold for domestic, commercial, and industrial consumption within the limits of the city under the licensee's applicable "General Service" rate schedule on file with and approved by the Public Service Commission of Missouri. The term "gross receipts" shall include any amounts received by licensee in the nature of a penalty for late payment arising out of such sales. 
(b)  Not later than the last day of each month the licensee shall report to the director of finance of the city the licensee's gross receipts from the last meter readings made for all customers within the city for the next preceding month, and shall pay to the city the license fee based upon the gross receipts so reported. 
(c)  The acceptance of such fees shall not prejudice the right of the city to collect any additional fee thereafter found to be due. In the event that licensee shall pay a sum greater than is due upon its gross receipts for any period by reason of its inability to determine accurately the amount properly due, licensee shall be entitled, following a determination of the overpayment, to deduct such overpayment and receive a credit therefor against the amount of license fee due for the next succeeding period or periods following the determination of the overpayment. The city, the director of finance, the city administrator and his assistants and any public accountants selected by the board of aldermen or by the city administrator shall have the right, at all reasonable times during business hours, to make such examinations and inspections of the books of such licensee as may be necessary to determine the correctness of such reports. The city shall have the right, at its own expense, to employ the same accountants who make the annual audit of the books, records and accounts of the business of the licensee, to audit, at the same time, the licensee's accounts and records and certify as to the correctness of any payments due and payable by the licensee to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1671, § 1; Ord. No. 2516, §§ 1, 2, 3-2-78; Ord. No. 3026, § 1, 4-27-82; Ord. No. 3575, § 1, 12-23-86) 
Sec. 22-9. - Same-Penalty for delayed payment. 
    For each and every month, or part thereof, any such license fee remains unpaid, after the same becomes due and payable, there shall be added to such license fee, as a penalty for such delayed payment, ten (10) percent of the amount of such license fee for the first month, or part thereof, the same is unpaid, and for each and every month thereafter, two (2) percent of the amount of such license fee until the same is fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 1671, § 2) 
Sec. 22-10. - Same-Commencement date of computation; date of first payment. 
    Each licensee subject to the provisions of this article shall commence computation of the license fee on April 1, 1971, for the remainder of the six-month period ending June 30, 1971, and payment shall be due to the city not later than August 1, 1971. 
(Ord. No. 1671, § 3) 
ARTICLE III. - ELECTRIC LIGHT AND POWER COMPANIES 

Sec. 22-11. - License fee-Amount; report of gross receipts to determine amount; inspection of accounts and records of licensee. 
    Every electric light or power company, and every corporation, company, associate, joint stock company or association, partnership and person, their lessees, trustees, or receivers appointed by any court whatsoever, owning, operating, controlling, leasing or managing any electric plant or system generating, manufacturing, selling, distributing or transmitting electricity for light, heat or power, shall, in addition to all other taxes, payments or requirements now or hereafter required by law or city ordinance, pay to the city a license fee based upon the business done within the limits of the city during the preceding period as hereinafter set forth. The amount of such license fee shall be a sum equal to seven (7) percent of the gross receipts derived from the sale of electrical energy within the present or future boundaries of the city during the same period for domestic, commercial and industrial consumption and not for resale. The sale of electrical energy to an owner or lessee of a building, who purchases such electrical energy for resale to the tenants therein, shall, for the purposes of this section, be considered as a sale for consumption and not for resale, but the resale to the tenant shall not be considered as a sale for consumption. The licensee shall and he is hereby required to make true and faithful reports under oath to the director of finance of the city, in such form as may be prescribed by the director of finance, and containing such information as may be necessary to determine the amounts to which the license fee shall apply. Each fee paid shall constitute payment for the respective periods of time hereinafter set forth; provided, however, that the acceptance of such fee shall not prejudice the right of the city to collect any additional fee thereafter found to be due. The city, the director of finance, the city administrator and his assistants and any public accountants selected by the board of aldermen or by the city administrator shall have the right, at all reasonable times during business hours, to make such examinations and inspections of the books of the licensee as may be necessary to determine the correctness of such reports. The city shall have the right, at its own expense, to employ the same accountants who make the annual audit of the books, records and accounts of the business of the licensee to audit, at the same time, its accounts and records and certify as to the correctness of any payments due and payable by the licensee to the city. 
(Ord. No. 1672, § 1; Ord. No. 2517, §§ 1, 2, 3-28-78) 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 3998, § 1, adopted January 1, 1990, enacted provisions to maintain the seven (7) percent gross receipt tax imposed upon the Kansas Power and Light Company as set out in § 22-11. 
Sec. 22-12. - Same-Manner of payment. 
    Missouri Public Service Company and Kansas City Power and Light Company, which have franchises expiring August 28, 1999, and all other power and light companies shall pay their license fees to the city on a monthly basis. The license fee shall be computed on the basis of revenue from the first day through the last day of each month. The company shall calculate the revenue due the city monthly and, within sixty (60) days after the last day of each month, file a statement notifying the city of the amount of revenue subject to payment which was received during the month and at the time of filing such statement shall pay to the city the sum due. 
(Ord. No. 1672, § 2; Ord. No. 2690, § 1, 8-28-79; Ord. No. 2691, § 1, 8-28-79; Ord. No. 3161, § 2, 7-26-83) 
Sec. 22-13. - Same-Commencement date of computation. 
    Each licensee subject to the provisions of this article shall commence computation of the license fee on April 1, 1971, and payment to the city shall be due the city as provided in section 22-12. 
(Ord. No. 1672, § 3) 
Sec. 22-14. - Same-Penalty for delayed payment. 
    For each and every month, or part thereof, any such license fee remains unpaid, after the same becomes due and payable, there shall be added to such license fee, as a penalty for such delayed payment, ten (10) per cent of the amount of such license fee for the first month, or part thereof, the same is unpaid, and for each and every month thereafter, two (2) per cent of the amount of such license fee until the same is fully paid. 
(Ord. No. 1672, § 4) 
Sec. 22-15. - Permission granted to trim trees upon or overhanging streets. 
    Permission is hereby granted to the licensee to trim trees upon and overhanging streets, alleys, sidewalks and public places of the city so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the wires and cables of the licensee, all such trimming to be done under the supervision and direction of any city official to whom such duties have been or may be delegated. 
(Ord. No. 1672, § 5) 
Sec. 22-16. - Exclusive privileges. 
    Nothing herein contained shall be construed as giving to a licensee any exclusive privileges. 
(Ord. No. 1672, § 6) 
ARTICLE IV. - VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDERS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 6213, adopted Aug. 12, 2008, amended art. IV in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former art. IV consisted of §§ 22-17-22-46, pertained to cable television and derived from Ord. No. 2506, adopted Mar. 14, 1978. 

Sec. 22-17. - Short title. 
    This article IV shall be known as the "City of Grandview Video Service Providers Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-18. - Definitions. 
    The words and phrases used in this article IV shall have the meaning as set forth in the 2007 Video Services Providers Act, sections 67.2675 through 67.2714, RSMo, inclusive ("the Act"), or, if not defined therein, shall have such meanings as established by the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview ("Code of Laws"). 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-19. - Video service provider fee. 
    Pursuant to section 67.2689, RSMo and as partial compensation for use of the city's public rights-of-way, each video service provider or other person providing cable services or video services within the City of Grandview ("city") shall, to the extent permitted by law, pay to the city a fee of five (5) per cent of the gross revenues from such video services provided in the geographic area of the city. Such payment shall be made as required by section 67.2689, RSMo. The city shall have the right to audit any video service provider as authorized by section 67.2691, RSMo. Late payments shall accrue interest due to the city compounded monthly at one and one-half (1.5) per cent or such other maximum rate as may be established by law. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-20. - Customer service requirements. 
    All video service providers providing service within the city shall adopt and comply with the minimum customer service requirements set forth in section 67.2692, RSMo. Notice or receipt of this ordinance [Ord. No. 6213] by the video service provider shall be deemed notice from the city invoking such customer service requirements. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-21. - Rights-of-way regulation; indemnification; permits and compliance with other laws. 
    Video service providers shall comply with the requirements of sections 67.2707, 67.2709, RSMo, and all applicable ordinances and regulations consistent with sections 67.1830 to 67.1846, RSMo relating to use of the city rights-of-way, including but not limited to article II, chapter 26 of the Code of Laws ("rights-of-way management"). Each video service provider shall indemnify and hold harmless the city and its officers, employees and agents from any loss or damage, including, but not limited to attorneys' fees, as provided in such ordinances or regulations, but in no event less than the obligation on video service providers set forth in section 67.2695, RSMo. The city may require documentation of such indemnification by written agreement or other instrument to the extent permitted by law. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-22. - Public, educational and governmental channels. 
    Each video service provider shall designate a number of channels for public, educational and governmental ("PEG") programming consistent with section 67.2703, RSMo; provided that any greater number of PEG channels, as may be required in the incumbent cable franchise or CATV Ordinance, shall be required pursuant to section 67.2703.2, RSMo. The city shall bear no cost relating to the transmission, availability or maintenance of PEG channels unless expressly authorized by the city in writing and approved by the board of aldermen. The incumbent cable operator and other video service providers shall provide support for PEG channels consistent with section 67.2703.8, RSMo. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-23. - Continued obligations. 
    The obligations of the incumbent cable operator and other video service providers as set forth in the incumbent's franchise agreement or the CATV Ordinance shall also continue to apply to the full extent permitted by applicable law. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-24. - Reservation of rights. 
    The city retains all rights in the Act, and may take any and all actions permitted by law to exercise such rights or to enforce such obligations on providers of video service. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-25. - Notice. 
    A copy of this video service providers ordinance shall be delivered to the incumbent cable operator and to each video service provider operating in the city after notice to the city that such provider is authorized to provide service within the city; provided that the provisions of this article shall, to the extent permitted by law, not be affected by any claimed or actual failure of a service provider to have received delivery of a copy of this article. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-26. - Severability. 
    The portions of this article shall be severable. In the event that any portion of this article is found by a court of competent jurisdiction to be invalid, the remaining portions of this article are valid, unless the court finds the valid portions of this article are so essential and inseparably connected with and dependent upon the void portion that it cannot be presumed that the board of aldermen would have enacted the valid portions without the invalid ones, or unless the court finds that the valid portions standing alone are incomplete and are incapable of being executed in accordance with the legislative intent. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-27. - Video service authorization required.
