    No video service provider or such provider's system network shall be allowed to occupy the public rights-of-way or use the streets or other public property of the city or be allowed to operate within the city without a video service authorization issued by the Missouri Public Service Commission ("PSC") and before providing all notices to the city as required by the Act. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-28. - Unlawful acts. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to establish, operate or to carry on the business of providing video service to any persons in the city unless a video service authorization therefore has first been obtained from the PSC and is in full force and effect. 
(b)  It shall be unlawful for any person to construct, install or maintain within any public street in the city, or within any other public property of the city, or within any privately owned area within the city that has not yet become a public street but is designated or delineated as a proposed public street on any tentative subdivision map approved by the city, any equipment or facilities for providing video service, unless a video service authorization therefore allowing the use of such street or property of areas has first been obtained from the PSC and is in full force and effect. 
(c)  It shall be unlawful for any person, without the consent of the owner, to willfully tamper with, remove or injure any cables, wires or equipment used to provide video services. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Sec. 22-29. - Violation. 
    Except as provided elsewhere, any person who fails to adhere to or otherwise violates the provisions of this article IV is guilty of a municipal ordinance violation punishable by imprisonment for not more than ninety (90) days or by a fine of not more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) or by both such fine and imprisonment. Each day that such person shall continue violation of the provisions of this article IV shall constitute a separate and distinct offense and shall be punishable as such. 
(Ord. No. 6213, § 2, 8-12-08) 
Chapter 22A - URBAN REDEVELOPMENT CORPORATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Ordinance No. 6467, §§ 1, 2, adopted June 14, 2011, repealed the former Ch. 22A, §§ 22A-1-22A-24, and enacted a new Ch. 22A as set out herein. The former Ch. 22A pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. No. 4821, adopted Jan. 9, 1996. 

Sec. 22A-1. - Short title. 
    This chapter shall be known and may be cited as "The Urban Redevelopment Ordinance." 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-2. - Determination of necessity for legislation. 
    It is hereby determined and declared by the board that: 
(a)  In certain portions of the city obsolete, decadent, substandard, or blighted areas exist occasioned by inadequate planning, excessive land coverage, lack of proper light, air or open space, defective design or arrangement of buildings, or the existence of buildings which, by reason of age, obsolescence, inadequate or outmoded design, or physical deterioration, have impaired the economic and social value of large areas, infecting them with blight and that such conditions are conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, or crime, or inability to pay reasonable taxes; 
(b)  Such areas are characterized by depreciated values, impaired investments, reduced or negligible income and consequent tax delinquencies; 
(c)  Such conditions exist in areas where obsolete, decadent, substandard, outworn or outmoded industrial, commercial, or residential buildings prevail; that their assembly for purposes of clearance, replanning, rehabilitation, reconstruction, and redevelopment may be difficult and costly; 
(d)  The existence of such conditions and the failure to clear, replan, rehabilitate, reconstruct, or redevelop these areas results in progressive deterioration, and occasions large outlays for creation of public facilities and services elsewhere; 
(e)  It is desirable to induce private capital investments to alleviate these conditions and redevelop these areas but that sometimes it is impossible or uneconomic for individual owners to independently undertake to remedy such conditions; 
(f)  Such conditions require the employment of capital on an investment basis, allowing however, that widest latitude in the amortization of any indebtedness created thereby; 
(g)  Such conditions further require the acquisition of adequate areas at fair prices, the clearance of such areas through demolition of existing obsolete, decadent, inadequate, or unsafe buildings and the redevelopment of such areas under proper supervision with appropriate planning as to land use and construction policies; that the clearance, replanning, rehabilitation, reconstruction, and land redevelopment of such areas on a large scale basis are necessary for the public welfare and are public uses and purposes for which private property may be acquired by purchase or eminent domain; and 
(h)  Obsolete, decadent, substandard, and blighted areas constitute a menace to the citizens of the city. 
    Therefore, the necessity for the provisions in this chapter is hereby declared as a matter of legislative determination to be in the public interest. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-3. - Acceptance of application of the Urban State Enabling Act. 
    The provisions of the Urban Redevelopment Corporations Law, found in RSMo Ch. 353, are hereby accepted and shall apply to all persons and corporations operating under this chapter insofar as the same may be applicable thereto. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-4. - Purpose statement. 
    Considering the necessity of this chapter, as established in section 22A-2, the board states its intent that this chapter be implemented, construed, and interpreted in a manner deemed most effective to carry out the following purposes: 
(a)  To remediate obsolete, decadent, substandard, and blighted areas found in exist within the city. 
(b)  To incentivize the redevelopment of such areas in accordance with the city's adopted economic development policy and other city visioning documents. 
(c)  In light of any incentives provided, to maximize benefits to the city and other affected taxing jurisdictions through payments in lieu of taxes, increased personal property tax and sales tax revenues, and revenues generated from base-level real property values. 
(d)  To ensure that applications for incentives made pursuant to this chapter fit the parameters of the city's adopted economic development incentive policy, including, but not limited to, such factors as expanding the future tax base of all affected taxing jurisdictions, satisfying minimum capital improvement requirements, and balancing incentive to investment ratios. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-5. - Definitions. 
    The following terms, whenever used or referred to in this chapter, shall, unless a different intent clearly appears from the context, be construed to have the following meanings: 
    Applicant means a person who formally seeks incentives from the city pursuant to the procedure established in this chapter. 
    Area means that portion of the city which the board has found or shall find to be blighted, so that the clearance, replanning, rehabilitation, or reconstruction thereof is necessary to effectuate the purposes of this chapter. An area may include buildings or improvements not in themselves blighted, and any real property, whether improved or unimproved, the inclusion of which is deemed necessary for the effective clearance, replanning, reconstruction, or rehabilitation of the area of which such buildings, improvements, or real property form a part. 
    Blighted area means that portion of the city which the board shall determine, that by reason of age, obsolescence, inadequate or outmoded design, or physical deterioration, have become economic and social liabilities and that the conditions in such localities are conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, crime, or inability to pay reasonable taxes. 
    Board means the Board of Aldermen of the City of Grandview. 
    Business days means all days upon which the City of Grandview City Hall is open for transacting business with the citizens of Grandview, which normally excludes any weekend days or holidays. 
    City means the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
    Displaced business means any business that moves from real property within the development area as a result of the acquisition of such property by a corporation, its assigns or transferees; as a result of written notice of such entities to vacate such property; or in connection with the demolition, alteration or repair of said property occurring after filing of the redevelopment plan by any person who subsequently transfers the property to the corporation for tax abatement purposes. 
    Displaced occupant means any occupant who moves from real property within the development area as a result of the acquisition of such property by a corporation, its assigns or transferees; as a result of written notice of such entities to vacate such property; or in connection with the demolition, alteration or repair of said property occurring after filing of the development plan by any person who subsequently transfers the property to the corporation for tax abatement purposes. 
    Developer means an applicant that has been successful in its request for incentives established in this chapter, and its authorized heirs, successors, or assigns. 
    Handicapped occupant means any occupant who is deaf, legally blind, or orthopedically disabled to the extent that acquisition of other residence presents a greater burden than other occupants would encounter or that modification to the residence would be necessary. 
    Mortgage means a mortgage, trust indenture, deed of trust, building and loan contract, or other instrument creating a lien on real property, to secure the payment of an indebtedness, and the indebtedness secured by any of them. 
    Occupant means a residential occupant of a building having lawful possession thereof, and further shall include any person in lawful possession, whether related by blood or marriage to any other occupant. 
    Person means any individual, firm, partnership, joint venture, association, corporation (except an urban redevelopment corporation organized pursuant to the provisions of the urban redevelopment corporation law and any life insurance company, organized under the laws of, or organized to do business in the state, undertaking a redevelopment project under this chapter), whether organized for profit or not, estate, trust, business trust, receiver, or trustee appointed by any state or federal court, syndicate, or any other group or combination acting as a unit, and shall include the male as well as the female gender and the plural as well as the singular number. 
    Public use means the constitutional and statutory basis for taking by eminent domain. For condemnation purposes, "public use" is one which confers some benefit or advantage to the public; it is not confined to actual use by the public. As long as the public has right of use, whether exercised by one (1) or many members of the public, a public advantage or public benefit accrues sufficient to constitute a public use. 
    Public welfare means the prosperity, well-being, or convenience of the public at large, or of the whole community, as distinguished from the advantage of an individual or a limited class. The definition of "public welfare" has been held to bring within its purview regulations for the promotion of economic welfare and public convenience. 
    Real property includes lands, buildings, improvements, land under water, waterfront property, any and all easements, franchises and hereditaments, corporeal or incorporeal, every estate, interest, privilege, easement, franchise and right therein, or appurtenant thereto, legal or equitable, including restrictions of record, created by plat, covenant, or otherwise, rights-of-way, and terms for years. 
    Redevelopment means the clearance, re-planning, reconstruction, or rehabilitation of any blighted area, and the provision for such industrial, commercial, residential, or public structures and spaces as may be appropriate, including recreational and other facilities incident or appurtenant thereto. 
    Redevelopment coordinating committee. The redevelopment coordinating committee shall consist, as a minimum, of the city administrator (or his or her designee), public works director, director of community development, director of economic development, senior planner, water district director, and others as required. 
    Redevelopment cost means the amount determined by the board to be the actual cost of redevelopment, or of that part thereof for which such determination is made. Redevelopment cost shall include, among other costs: 
(1)  The reasonable expenses of planning the redevelopment, including preliminary studies and surveys, neighborhood planning, and architectural and engineering services; 
(2)  The reasonable value of the services performed in connection with the redevelopment plan; 
(3)  Interest during construction; the actual cost of the real property or any part thereof where acquired partly or wholly in exchange for securities; the actual cost of demolition of existing structures; 
(4)  The actual cost of utilities, landscaping and roadways; the actual cost of construction, equipment and furnishings of buildings and improvements including architectural, engineering, and builder's fees; the actual cost of reconstruction, rehabilitation, redevelopment, remodeling, or initial repair of existing buildings and improvements; 
(5)  Reasonable management and operation costs until the redevelopment is ready for use; and 
(6)  The actual cost of improving those portions of the area which are to remain open spaces, together with such additions to development costs as shall equal the actual cost of additions to or changes in the redevelopment in accordance with the original redevelopment plan or after approved changes therein or amendments thereto. 
    Redevelopment plan means a plan, together with any amendments thereto, for the redevelopment of all or any part of a blighted area. 
    Redevelopment project means a specific work or improvement to effectuate all or any part of a redevelopment plan. 
    Third-party consultants means professional consultants engaged by the city to review certain important aspects of an application filed pursuant to this chapter. Third-party consultants include, but are not limited to, professionals in the following fields: Architects, engineers, environmental consultants, financial advisors, land surveyors, legal counsel, and real estate appraisers. 
    Urban redevelopment corporation means a corporation created pursuant to the requirements of the Urban Redevelopment Corporation Law, either by an applicant or by the city, to which real property must be transferred in order to trigger tax abatement in accordance with the Urban Redevelopment Corporation Law and this chapter. 
    Urban Redevelopment Corporation Law means RSMo Ch. 353 and any amendments thereto. 
    Words, not otherwise defined, shall have their common meanings. Words used in the present tense include the future; the singular number includes the plural, and the plural the singular, unless the context clearly implies otherwise. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-6. - Application for approval of redevelopment plan; preliminary conference with redevelopment coordinating committee. 
(a)  Submission of application form. Any applicant proposing to file a redevelopment plan for approval by the board pursuant to this chapter must first submit an application, using a form provided by the community development department, which shall explain, in general concepts, the proposed plan. 
(b)  Preliminary conference. Upon submission of the application form described above, the applicant shall schedule a conference with the redevelopment coordinating committee to be held within ten (10) business days after the date the application is submitted, or as soon as reasonably possible thereafter, to discuss the requirements of, the encouraged/discouraged practices related to, and a tentative timeline for, consideration of the application pursuant to the policy and procedures established in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-7. - Submittal of initial draft of redevelopment plan; preliminary funding agreement; deposit of funds. 
(a)  Initial draft. The applicant shall prepare an initial draft of the redevelopment plan in accordance with the requirements of section 22A-14 and in association with the information provided at the preliminary conference with the redevelopment coordinating committee. Upon completion of the initial draft of the redevelopment plan, the applicant shall submit ten (10) copies of the initial draft of the redevelopment plan and all supporting documentation, to the community development department, for distribution to the redevelopment coordinating committee and appropriate third-party consultants retained by the city for review of the draft redevelopment plan. 
(b)  Preliminary funding agreement. The city does not have a source of funds to finance costs incurred by it, in the form of additional legal, financial, planning, transportation and engineering and other consultants, or for direct out-of-pocket expenses and other costs resulting from services rendered to the applicant to review, evaluate, process and consider the application. Therefore, concurrent with filing the initial draft of the redevelopment plan, the applicant shall also submit an executed copy of a preliminary funding agreement between the applicant and the city and the deposit of funds required by such agreement. The redevelopment coordinating committee will not commence its review of the initial draft of the redevelopment plan, as established in section 22A-8, until the preliminary funding agreement has been considered and approved by the board of aldermen by ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-8. - Review of initial draft of redevelopment plan; pre-filing conference. 
(a)  Review of initial draft. Immediately after receipt of the initial draft of the redevelopment plan, the director of the community development shall forward the initial draft of the plan to the city clerk, the redevelopment coordinating committee, and the appropriate third-party consultants engaged by the city. Within a reasonable amount of time, not to exceed fifteen (15) business days, after the applicant has submitted the initial draft of the redevelopment plan, the redevelopment coordinating committee and any third-party consultants, shall conduct and complete its review and analysis of the initial draft and all supporting documentation; and, using the criteria established in sections 22A-4, 22A-11, 22A-13, and 22A-14, shall develop their comments and proposed edits, if any, to the initial draft of the redevelopment plan. 
(b)  Pre-filing conference. Upon completion of the redevelopment coordinating committee and third-party consultants' review and analysis of the initial draft of the redevelopment plan, the director of community development shall schedule and coordinate a pre-filing conference with the applicant to discuss the committee's comments and proposed edits, if any, to the initial draft of the redevelopment plan. Such pre-filing conference shall be held as soon as is reasonable possible after the redevelopment coordinating committee and third-party consultants complete their review and analysis of the initial draft. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-9. - Filing redevelopment plan; written statement of tax impact; notice of public hearing. 
(a)  At any point after completing the procedural steps established in sections 22A-6 through 22A-8, inclusive, the applicant may file one (1) original and nine (9) copies of its written final draft of the redevelopment plan with the community development department. 
(b)  Upon the applicant's filing of its final redevelopment plan in accordance with this section, the director of community development, in conjunction with the city clerk, shall coordinate with all appropriate parties to set a date for a public hearing before the board to consider the application. The public hearing concerning the redevelopment plan shall be held at a regularly scheduled meeting of the board, unless the board, by simple motion and voice vote, separately approves a special meeting for such purpose. 
(c)  After determining the date and time of the public hearing, the city clerk, with the assistance of the community development department, shall furnish to each political subdivision, whose boundaries for ad valorem taxation purposes include any portion of the real property to be affected by the tax abatement incentives established in this chapter, the following information: 
(1)  A written statement of the impact on ad valorem taxes the proposed tax abatement incentives will have on each affected political subdivision. The tax impact statement shall include, at a minimum, the following information: 
a.  An estimate of the amount of ad valorem tax revenues of each affected political subdivision, based on the estimated assessed valuation of the real property involved as such property would exist both before and after it is redeveloped. 
b.  An estimate of the amount of additional sales tax revenues, if any, each affected political subdivision imposing a sales tax within the redevelopment area may incur as a result of the redevelopment. 
c.  An estimate of the amount of personal property tax revenues, if any, each affected political subdivision imposing taxes upon tangible personal property within the redevelopment area may incur as a result of the redevelopment. 
d.  A statement of whether there exists or will exist, either before or after the property is redeveloped, a tax-exempt owner or user of the property. 
(2)  A written notice of the public hearing before the board regarding the proposed redevelopment plan. The notice of public hearing shall include the following information: 
a.  The reason for the notice; 
b.  The time, date, and place of said hearing; 
c.  A statement that any affected political subdivision may comment on the proposed redevelopment plan either in writing to the redevelopment coordinating committee or to the board, or through a representative in appearance at the hearing before the board; 
d.  The tax impact statement and notice of public hearing required in this section shall be provided in accordance with the requirements of section 22A-10. The city clerk, with the assistance of the community development department, shall provide for published notice of the public hearing as required in section 22A-10(b). 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-10. - Requirements for notice of public hearing. 
(a)  Mailed notification. In the event that one or more parcels of property located within the proposed redevelopment plan area is owned or controlled by a person other than the applicant, the applicant shall provide written notice to each person or entity having a property interest of record (including any interest which is merely a security interest or any leasehold of record), and each occupant and business in the project area of the public hearing regarding the redevelopment plan. Mailed notices sent in accordance with this chapter shall be deposited in the regular United States mail, postage prepaid, addressed to such person or entity having a property interest of record at the address indicated on the records of the Recorder's Office of Jackson County in which the property is located and addressed to each occupant or business at the address of said occupant or business in the project area; however, in the event the applicant has no information as to the name of any occupant, the notice shall be addressed to "Occupant" at the address, including apartment number, if any, within the project area. Mailed notices shall be postmarked not less than ten (10) days prior to the date of the public hearing. The applicant shall provide the board with an affidavit attesting its compliance with this subsection, if applicable, at the time of the public hearing. 
(b)  Published notification. Notice of the public hearing to consider the proposed redevelopment plan shall be given by publication one (1) time in a newspaper of general circulation within the city not more than twenty (20) nor less than ten (10) days before the date of the hearing. The city clerk shall provide the board with an affidavit of publication from the newspaper indicating its compliance with this subsection at the time of the public hearing. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-11. - Recommendation by redevelopment coordinating committee. 
    The redevelopment coordinating committee shall review the redevelopment plan to ensure that each of the requirements of section 22A-14 have been satisfied, and shall draft a report regarding its review and analysis of the redevelopment plan. The ultimate conclusion of such report shall be a recommendation to the board as to whether the redevelopment plan should be approved; approved with modifications; or denied, as more specifically provided in section 22A-13(b). In arriving at its recommendation, the redevelopment coordinating committee shall consider the entirety of the redevelopment plan and all supporting documentation filed by the applicant, including specifically the blight study and third-party review of the blight study; the proforma financial statements, tax impact statements and third-party review of the proforma financial statements, tax impact statements and related financial issues; and the type of development which is physically desirable for the area concerned. In addition to a determination of whether the applicant provided information sufficient for the board to make the determinations required in section 22A-13(a), the redevelopment coordinating committee shall be guided by the following factors in reaching its conclusion for recommendation to the board: 
(a)  The amount of incentives requested should not exceed twenty-five (25) per cent of the cost of the total investment in the project. 
(b)  Redevelopment plans that provide for the payments in lieu of taxes for a portion of the statutorily authorized tax abatement period are encouraged. 
(c)  Redevelopment projects that directly result in an increase in new jobs that provide pay rates equal to or above the area median income for the applicable industry are encouraged. 
(d)  Redevelopment projects that create increased sales tax revenues to the affected taxing jurisdictions are encouraged. 
(e)  Redevelopment projects that promote sustainable development standards for buildings, site design, and infrastructure in accordance with the objectives of the community development and public works departments are strongly encouraged. 
(f)  Redevelopment plans designed to produce a benefit to the affected taxing jurisdictions over the period of the abatement that is equal to or greater than the amount of the net abatement realized by the owner of the abated property are encouraged. 
(g)  Redevelopment plans which reduce the overall length of the abatement period and accelerate payments in lieu of taxes are encouraged. 
(h)  Redevelopment projects that involve a significant investment of taxable, tangible personal property are encouraged. 
(i)  Redevelopment projects designed to facilitate tax-exempt users are not preferred unless a significant benefit to the community would result. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-12. - Public hearing on proposed redevelopment plan. 
(a)  Generally. The public hearing shall be held at a time and place reasonably available to the public. All interested parties may be heard at such hearing. 
(b)  Presentation by applicant. At the hearing the applicant shall present its request for incentives authorized by this chapter, which shall include, but not be limited to a summary of the proposed redevelopment plan, and the presentation of evidence sufficient for the board to make the determinations required in section 22A-13. 
(c)  Presentation by city. Following the applicant's presentation, the city's redevelopment coordinating committee, and third-party consultants, as applicable, shall present a summary of the redevelopment coordinating committee's report on the application, including but not limited to, its recommendation to the board. 
(d)  Comments by affected political subdivisions. Any affected political subdivision may comment on the proposed redevelopment plan either in writing to the redevelopment coordinating committee or to the board or through a representative in appearance at the public hearing before the board. Following the city's presentation, the board shall invite representatives of the affected political subdivisions to present their comments. If an affected political subdivision has provided written comments in lieu of testimony at the public hearing, the board shall note such comments for the record. 
(e)  Public comments. After the affected political subdivisions have been given the opportunity to comment on the application, the board shall provide an opportunity for public comments on the matter. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-13. - Determinations required for approval of redevelopment plan; board action on redevelopment plan. 
(a)  After the board has received all of the evidence presented by the applicant, the redevelopment coordinating committee and third-party consultants, the affected political subdivisions, and through public comment, it shall review such evidence and make the following determinations in reaching its decision regarding the redevelopment plan: 
(1)  Determination as blighted area. The board shall review the evidence adduced pursuant to section 22A-15 concerning the designation of blight and that the declaration of blight is necessary and advisable to effectuate the public purposes set forth in section 22A-2. If it so finds, the board shall declare, by ordinance, that the area included within a redevelopment plan is a blighted area, and that the clearance, redevelopment, re-planning, rehabilitation or reconstruction thereof is necessary for the public convenience and necessity. 
(2)  Determination as to redevelopment plan. The board shall review the redevelopment plan and the redevelopment coordinating committee's report and recommendation and make determinations on the redevelopment plan concerning the following: 
a.  Compliance with the city's comprehensive plan; 
b.  Necessity of the power of eminent domain to carry out the project and to effectuate the purposes set forth in section 22A-2 without creating a negative effect on adjacent properties. If it so finds, the board shall declare, by ordinance, that acquisition of all or any part of the real property within a blighted area by exercise of the power of eminent domain is for the public convenience and necessity. 
c.  Sufficiency of size to allow redevelopment of the area in an efficient and economically satisfactory manner; 
d.  Practicality of redevelopment plan; 
e.  Adequacy of relocation benefits; 
f.  Availability of housing and business accommodations to displaced businesses; 
g.  Adequacy of public facilities including, but not limited to school, fire, water, sewer, police, transportation, park, playground and recreation, considering current facilities and those proposed for service concurrent with the redevelopment project; 
h.  Appropriateness of any changes to zoning ordinances or maps, vacation or closing streets and alleys, or the construction of streets and alleys; and 
i.  Compliance with the provisions of section 22A-14. 
If it so finds, the board shall declare, by ordinance, that approval of the redevelopment plan and construction of the redevelopment project are necessary for the preservation of the public peace, property, health, safety, morals and welfare. 
(3)  Determination as to financing. The board shall review the redevelopment coordinating committee's report, in addition to information provided by the city's third-party consultants regarding the statement of financing as provided in section 22A-14(g) and make a determination as to the adequacy of financing based upon the reasonable costs proposed in the redevelopment plan. 
(4)  Determination as to tax abatement. The board shall review the redevelopment coordinating committee's report, in addition to information provided by the city's third-party consultants, and make a determination regarding the necessity of tax abatement for economic feasibility of the construction of the redevelopment project and the effect of tax abatement on the political subdivisions affected by such abatement. 
(b)  After the public hearing has been held upon redevelopment plan together with the report of the committee thereon, the board shall: 
(1)  Unconditionally approve the redevelopment plan and may, if it deems desirable, authorize the city administrator or his or her designee on behalf of the city to enter into a contract with the applicant, or disapprove the plan; or 
(2)  Approve the redevelopment plan subject to such conditions, exceptions or restrictions as the board may deem to be in the public interest; or 
(3)  Refer the redevelopment plan back to the applicant with recommendations as to changes or amendments to be made therein; or 
(4)  Deny the redevelopment plan. 
(c)  In the event the board of aldermen takes action consistent with subsections (b)(2)-(4) above, the redevelopment coordinating committee shall, within five (5) business days, provide the applicant with written reasons for such action. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-14. - Contents of redevelopment plan. 
    A redevelopment plan shall contain: 
(a)  Legal description and map. A legal description of the redevelopment area by metes and bounds or other definite designation, and a map depicting the redevelopment area. 
(b)  Project description. A detailed description of the project to be undertaken pursuant to the redevelopment plan, including, but not limited to, a statement of: 
(1)  Existing buildings or improvements in the redevelopment area to be demolished, if any, and the approximate period of time during which demolition, if any, of each such building or improvement is to take place. 
(2)  The proposed improvements, if any, to each building not to be demolished, any proposed repairs or alterations to such buildings, and the approximate period of time during which such improvements, repairs or alterations are to be made. 
(3)  The type, number and character of each new residential, commercial and industrial building or other type of improvement to be erected or made. 
(4)  The portions, if any, of the blighted area which shall be determined to be amenities to the project, including but not limited to permanent residential open space for recreation, streetscape, plaza areas and other similar visual effects. 
(5)  The portions, if any, of the blighted area which are proposed to be sold, donated, exchanged or leased to the city or other public agency and an outline of the terms of such proposed sale, donation, exchange or lease. 
(6)  Proposed changes, if any, in zoning ordinances or maps, necessary or desirable for the redevelopment, and its protection against blighted influences. 
(7)  Proposed changes, if any, in streets or street levels, alleys, any proposed street closings, and any changes which would have to be made to streets or alleys adjoining or near the redevelopment project including the plan for financing these changes. 
(c)  Project phases. A statement of the various phases, if more than one is intended, by which the development is proposed to be constructed or undertaken, and the approximate time limit for the commencement and completion of each phase, together with a description of the real property to be included in each phase so as to reasonably identify the individual phases. The statement shall also set forth a time schedule clearly setting forth reasonable times for commencement and completion of: 
(1)  Acquisition of properties; 
(2)  Demolition of buildings; 
(3)  New construction and/or building renovation. 
(d)  Dwelling accommodations. If applicable, a statement of the character of the existing dwelling accommodations, if any, in the blighted area, the approximate number of occupants residing therein, together with the schedule of the rentals being paid by them, a schedule of the vacancies in such accommodations, if any, together with the rentals demanded therefor, and the names and addresses of occupants if the information is available. 
(e)  Housing and business relocation. A statement of whether or not relocation of housing or businesses will be necessary to implement the redevelopment plan, and if so, whether the housing accommodations available in other locations in the city for those occupants who will be displaced by the redevelopment project. The redevelopment plan shall set forth a feasible plan for the relocation of all occupants and businesses and any other entities displaced, including adequate reimbursements for reasonable relocation cost, in accordance with the requirements of Ordinance No. 4767 entitled "Relocation Assistance," or as amended. 
(f)  Proposed housing. A statement of the character, type and quality of construction, approximate number of units; approximate rentals and approximate date of availability of the proposed during construction and upon completion of the redevelopment. 
(g)  Financing. A statement of the proposed method of financing the costs of the redevelopment plan, including a full proforma income statement, covering the period for which tax abatement is requested and considering agreed-to reductions of abatement through payments in lieu of taxes. The financing statement shall identify the amount of loans or other financing and any equity capital which shall be required and how that equity will be raised. Also included as a part of the financing statement shall be reasonable estimates on the costs of acquisition, demolition, construction and rehabilitation, if any. Evidence shall also be submitted that sufficient funds are available, or will be available upon approval of the redevelopment plan, for the acquisition of property within the area, relocation benefits described herein, completion of all demolition, and construction and/or rehabilitation of the redevelopment project, and that the commitment of those funds shall remain available until the construction is complete. 
(h)  Management. A statement of the names of the individuals who it is proposed will be active in or associated with the management of the redevelopment project during the period of at least one (1) year from the date of the approval of the redevelopment plan and the name and address of the registered agent for the urban redevelopment corporation, if not the city's. 
(i)  Eminent domain. A statement giving the legal description of the real property, if any, proposed to be purchased or acquired by eminent domain by the city on behalf of the applicant or by any other body authorized to acquire by eminent domain and the reasons why the aid of the city or other body is sought for that purpose. Every applicant which requests the city to exercise its power of eminent domain for any part of the project area shall submit a relocation plan as part of the redevelopment plan in accordance with Ordinance No. 4767 entitled "Relocation Assistance," or as amended, and shall be responsible for and bound by all requirements of said ordinance as if they were stated herein. Every redevelopment plan seeking the city's assistance for acquisition by eminent domain shall include the certification required in section 22A-18(a). 
(j)  Assignment of plan. Appropriate controls shall be provided over the right of assignment of the development to any other entity in order that the board be assured that the intention and purpose of the redevelopment project will, in fact, be carried out. 
(k)  Certificate of incorporation. If the applicant has formed its own urban redevelopment corporation in conjunction with the application, the applicant shall include in its redevelopment plan a copy of the certificate of incorporation from the Secretary of State. 
(l)  Affirmative action plan. A program to encourage the participation of all individuals regardless of race, color, creed, sex or age in all aspects of the redevelopment project. 
(m)  Other information. The redevelopment plan, and any application for amendment thereto, shall contain such other statements or exhibits as may be deemed relevant by the redevelopment coordinating committee or board. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-15. - Supporting evidence of blight. 
(a)  Blight study. Any application for approval of a redevelopment plan shall include evidence that the area is a blighted area as defined by RSMo § 353.020 (2), and section 22A-4(c) of this chapter. The blight study shall provide evidence of the following: 
(1)  Identification of the facts which demonstrate that by reason of age, obsolescence, inadequate or outmoded design or physical deterioration, the area as a whole has become an economic and social liability and is conducive to ill health, transmission of disease, crime or inability to pay reasonable taxes. 
(2)  The existence of those conditions set out in section 22A-2 upon which the applicant relies. 
(3)  Identification of each parcel within the area and a factual description of the parcel as to the nature and age of any improvements on the parcel and the physical condition of the parcel and any improvements thereon. 
(b)  Causation of blight. No condition caused by the applicant shall be considered as evidence of blight. 
(c)  Independent study. The redevelopment coordinating committee shall conduct or commission an independent study by a third-party consultant of the existence, in the proposed area, of the criteria set out in section 22A-2 which may be supplementary to the blight study required in section 22A-15(a). 
(d)  Review by redevelopment coordinating committee. The redevelopment coordinating committee shall review the blight study required herein along with other evidence submitted to it. 
(e)  Review by board. The board shall review and consider the applicant's blight study and the third-party consultant's review of the applicant's blight study, along with other evidence, and determine if the area is a blighted area. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-16. - Redevelopment agreement. 
(a)  Prior to the applicant's formal filing of the redevelopment agreement, as provided in section 22A-9(a), the applicant and the redevelopment coordinating committee shall negotiate the terms of a proposed redevelopment agreement, which shall establish the duties and benefits of the parties and provide rules, restrictions, and guidelines for implementation of the redevelopment plan. 
(b)  The redevelopment agreement generally shall contain the provisions as embodied in the redevelopment plan; the expected approving ordinance; a provision that the applicable provisions of this chapter shall be incorporated by reference into such redevelopment agreement; a reference to the provisions of section 22A-21 requiring the expiration of development rights established in accordance with this chapter, and a provision that the terms, conditions or provisions of the redevelopment agreement can be neither modified nor eliminated except by mutual agreement between the city and the applicant. In no event shall the redevelopment agreement be construed as an enlargement of the authority conferred upon the city by the Urban Redevelopment Corporation Law. 
(c)  Payments in lieu of taxes. The city may require a provision in the redevelopment agreement for payments in lieu of taxes as authorized in RSMo § 353.110.4. Upon review of the applicant's initial draft of the redevelopment plan in accordance with section 22A-8(a), the redevelopment coordinating committee and third-party consultants shall identify whether payments in lieu of taxes may be necessary to carry out the purposes of this chapter, and if so, in what amount. The redevelopment coordinating committee is specifically authorized to negotiate a provision for payments in lieu of taxes in the redevelopment agreement, and shall provide a summary of the results of such negotiation in its report to the board and its presentation at the public hearing on the redevelopment plan. 
(d)  Eminent domain. If the redevelopment plan contemplates the city's assistance in acquiring property by eminent domain, the redevelopment agreement shall provide, in detail, the terms of the transaction necessary to complete the acquisition. 
(e)  Additional terms. The redevelopment coordinating committee is also authorized to negotiate other terms in the redevelopment agreement that it determines may be necessary to satisfy the intent of this chapter. Such terms may include, but are not limited to, "claw back" provisions tied to benefits the applicant has stated would be enjoyed by the city and other affected taxing jurisdiction as a result of implementation of the redevelopment plan (e.g., job creation, salary levels, personal property or sales tax revenue increases), community service components (e.g., job fairs, health fairs, and other events benefiting the community), and enhanced site plan or design standards encouraged by the community development department. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-17. - Consideration of approval for the city to acquire property by eminent domain. 
    If the applicant requests the city to acquire by eminent domain all or any part of the real property described in the redevelopment plan, the board may consider a provision in the ordinance approving the redevelopment plan that makes a determination that the public convenience and necessity will be served by the redevelopment plan and redevelopment project, and authorizing city staff to make preparations for the city to acquire by the exercise of eminent domain such real property in fee simple or other estate in accordance with RSMo Ch. 523; provided, however, that any real property acquired in accordance with this chapter shall be devoted to the purposes and used subject to the conditions described in the approved redevelopment plan. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-18. - Acquisition, resale of property by city. 
(a)  At the time of filing a redevelopment plan which requests the city to acquire property by eminent domain, the applicant shall certify that it has, or within thirty (30) days after approval of the redevelopment plan shall, make a good faith offer to purchase by negotiation all property within the project area for which it seeks eminent domain assistance. The applicant or developer, as appropriate, shall hold its offer open for thirty (30) days, unless an agreement is reached sooner. If a sale of the property cannot be consummated within the thirty-day offer period, the developer may request the city to commence an action for eminent domain in accordance with RSMo Ch. 523. 
(b)  Within ten (10) days after the board has approved a redevelopment plan calling for the acquisition by the city by the exercise of the power of eminent domain of all or any part of the real property described therein, developer shall deposit in escrow with the director of finance the cash amounts or securities required by section 22A-19. The payment for the acquired property by the city, in whole or in part, may be made out of the deposited funds or from other sources of funds at the sole discretion of the board. Whenever any real property, land, easement, right-of-way, use or right of any character is taken or damaged by the city for such purpose, just compensation shall be paid to the owner thereof in accordance with applicable law. 
(c)  After acquiring the title to such real property, the city shall transfer such real property and all interest therein for the purpose of redevelopment, subject to those restrictions, exceptions and conditions as provided in the redevelopment agreement approved by the board in accordance with section 22A-16. 
(d)  The developer's deposit shall be applied upon the purchase price, and the city shall give due credit therefor. When such deposit is represented by securities, the city shall immediately sell the same at the current market price thereof at private sale for cash and apply the proceeds to the selling price of such real property. 
(e)  If the developer's deposit should prove to be insufficient to equal the actual cost to the city of acquiring such real property, when such cost is determined after purchase, or by action of a condemnation jury, or otherwise, as the case may be, then the developer shall make an additional deposit with the director of finance, upon ten (10) days' written notice from the director of finance, of a sum of money in cash equal to such additional acquisition cost as so determined. If the developer fails to make such additional deposit, the city may, at its option, thereupon repeal the ordinance providing for the acquisition of such real property and dismiss the pending condemnation proceedings, if any. In such last event, the expenses of such uncompleted acquisition and condemnation proceedings, if any, other than the expense of the services of the city law and public works departments, shall be charged to and paid by the developer and the director of finance shall withhold the amount thereof from the funds or securities deposited in escrow, and applied to the payment of such expenses. If more than one (1) deposit has been made, then each person so making a deposit shall be charged equally for his share of such costs. The balance of such funds and securities so deposited in escrow shall then be returned to the owner thereof. Sale of such securities may be made only upon order of the board by resolution or ordinance. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-19. - Deposit when city acquires property for urban redevelopment corporation. 
(a)  Amount. If the developer seeks to have the city acquire property by eminent domain or otherwise, the developer shall, at the time hereinafter provided, deposit in escrow with the director of finance, subject to the provisions of this chapter, a sum of money in cash or negotiable federal or municipal securities of a cash market value equal to the cost estimated by the redevelopment coordinating committee or third-party consultants to be incurred by the city in acquiring such real property. 
(b)  Return of deposit. If the board, upon the recommendation of the redevelopment coordinating committee, and with input from the developer, determines that it is in the best interest of the city to abandon acquisition of such real property by eminent domain, then the city shall return the applicable deposit to the developer less the amount of reasonable and actual costs incurred by the city for the abandoned action and for any recovery awarded pursuant to RSMo § 523.259, or similar provision. 
(c)  "Cost" defined. The term "cost" as used in this section and section 22A-18 means all expenditures by the city, including is the price paid for such real property, appraisal, abstract, title and recording fees, court costs, witness fees, fees of the redevelopment coordinating committee, and all other expenses of acquiring such property. 
(d)  Custody of securities. All securities deposited in escrow with the director of finance shall be promptly placed in a safety deposit box under the joint control of the director of finance and city treasurer. Access to such box, however, may be had at any time by any two (2) of such persons. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-20. - Annual report. 
    After approval of a redevelopment plan by the board, the developer shall file an annual report providing the following information: 
(a)  Availability of equity financing as provided for in section 22A-14(g) hereof or some other acceptable alternative financing. 
(b)  Financial statement indicating compliance with section 22A-25 hereof, if applicable. 
(c)  Names and addresses of occupants and businesses displaced by the corporation and specific relocation benefits provided to each occupant and business as well as a sample notice provided each occupant and business within the past year. 
(d)  Legal description of property acquired and name in which property was acquired as required pursuant to section 22A-21(b). 
(e)  Addresses of all occupied residential buildings and structures owned or under the control of the corporation and the status of compliance of such buildings and structures with the provisions of chapter 6, article VIII, minimum standards for buildings, and chapter 16, nuisances. 
(f)  Status of the redevelopment project as to permits applied for, permits issued, certificates of occupancy issued and any other appropriate documentation relevant to the information as part of compliance with section 22A-14. 
(g)  Information regarding compliance with specific terms of redevelopment agreement between developer and city. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-21. - Amendment of a redevelopment plan. 
    A developer may file an application for a substantive amendment of a redevelopment plan that was previously approved by ordinance. The redevelopment coordinating committee shall review the application for amendment to a redevelopment plan, and make its recommendation accordingly to the board in the same manner in which the redevelopment plan was originally approved. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-22. - Expiration of redevelopment plan. 
(a)  Sunset provision. After approval of a redevelopment plan by the board, the developer shall proceed expeditiously to cause the appropriate urban redevelopment corporation to acquire ownership of the property within the blighted area and to commence the clearance of blight. Failure to acquire the fee interest and any lesser interest in the name of the urban redevelopment corporation, or on behalf of such corporation, by a designated person within three (3) years after the date specified in the redevelopment agreement between the city and the developer for phase 1, and each phase thereafter, shall result in an automatic loss of the development rights, including the right of tax abatement, and the redevelopment plan and redevelopment agreement shall become null and void as to the respective and all subsequent phases. 
(b)  Prior to the expiration of the time provided in section 22A-22(a), the developer shall notify the director of finance of all interests acquired by an urban redevelopment corporation or on behalf of the corporation and identify with specificity any designated person acquiring such interests on behalf of such corporation. 
(c)  For purposes of this section, the initiation of condemnation proceedings by the filing of a petition in the appropriate court and the continued pursuance thereof shall be deemed acquisition for the parcels of land under condemnation provided that the urban redevelopment corporation notifies the director of finance of the condemnation action. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-23. - Commission to check compliance, make reports, adopt rules and regulations. 
(a)  Investigation. It shall be the duty of the redevelopment coordinating committee, after a redevelopment plan has been approved by the board, to investigate and determine from time to time during construction of the redevelopment project whether the applicant undertaking such redevelopment plan is fully complying with the provisions thereof, in the manner and at the times fixed therein for the performance of the various stages thereof. 
(b)  Reports. It shall also be the duty of the redevelopment coordinating committee to make reports from time to time during the construction of the redevelopment project, and at least once a year to the board regarding each redevelopment project and the performance or compliance with each redevelopment plan, and also as to compliance with the provisions of this chapter by any developer operating thereunder. However, in the event that the redevelopment plan has been amended within the one-year time frame, no report shall be required. 
(c)  Time extension. The board may, upon the recommendation of the redevelopment coordinating committee and for good cause shown, grant to the developer operating under an approved redevelopment plan an extension of time in which to complete the redevelopment project, or any step or portion thereof. 
(d)  Recommendation of certification. When a developer operating under an approved redevelopment plan has completed the redevelopment project in accordance with the provisions of the redevelopment plan, in the manner and at the time fixed therein for the performance of the various stages thereof, the redevelopment coordinating committee, upon the written request of such corporation, shall conduct an investigation; and if the redevelopment coordinating committee determines that the project has been so completed, it shall recommend to the board that a certificate of full compliance be issued to such corporation for each stage and the board may authorize the director of community development to issue a certificate of compliance which shall be conclusive evidence of such compliance, except upon proof of fraud. The investigation and reports of the redevelopment coordinating committee required by subsections (a) and (b) of this section shall not be required or made subsequent to the date of issuance of such certificate; however, every such developer shall render annually to the director of finance, during the existence of the tax relief period provided in section 22A-27, three (3) copies of its financial report for the preceding year, which report shall disclose the earnings of the corporation and the disposition of any net earnings in excess of those provided for under section 22A-25, and the interest rate on income debentures, bonds, notes or other evidences of debt of the developer; thereupon, the director of finance shall review the financial report of such developer and thereafter the developer shall file with the city clerk and the redevelopment coordinating committee the financial report, accompanied by the developer's statement as to compliance by the developer of section 22A-25. 
(e)  Rules and regulations. The redevelopment coordinating committee shall also have power to make and adopt such rules and regulations necessary and proper to effectuate the purposes of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-24. - Schedule of fees. 
    The community development department is authorized to establish a schedule of fees for filing an application pursuant to this chapter. The fees shall be designed to offset the in-house administrative costs of the city for processing an application pursuant to this chapter. The community development department shall submit the schedule of fees and any subsequent amendments thereto to the board for approval by resolution. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-25. - Financial restrictions on urban redevelopment corporations. 
(a)  Obligations, interest thereon. No urban redevelopment corporation for which a redevelopment plan has been approved by the board shall: 
(1)  Issue income debentures, bonds, notes or other evidences of debt bearing or paying an interest rate in excess of that permitted by state law. 
(2)  Pay any interest on its income debentures or dividends on its stock, regardless of class or preference, during any dividend year unless there shall exist at the time of such payment no default under any amortization requirements with respect to its indebtedness, nor unless all accrued interest, taxes and other public charges shall have been duly paid or reserves set up for the payment thereof, and adequate reserves provided for depreciation, obsolescence and other proper reserves. 
(b)  Net earnings. The net earnings of an urban redevelopment corporation for which a redevelopment plan has been approved by the board shall be limited to an amount not to exceed eight (8) per cent per annum of the cost to such corporation of the redevelopment project including the cost of the land or the balance of such total cost of the project as reduced by amortization payments, provided that the net earnings derived from any redevelopment project shall in no event exceed a sum equal to eight (8) per cent per annum upon the entire cost thereof. Such net earnings shall be computed after deducting from gross earnings the following: 
(1)  All reasonable costs and expenses of maintenance and operation. 
(2)  Amounts paid for taxes, assessing, insurance premiums and other similar charges. 
(3)  An annual amount sufficient to amortize the cost of the entire project at the end of the period, which shall be not less than twenty (20) years nor more than sixty (60) years from date of completion of the project. 
(c)  The earnings limitation provisions of this section shall not apply to a purchaser of real property, which is subject to abatement by this chapter, in accordance with subsections 4 and 5 of RSMo § 353.150. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-26. - Disposition of surplus earnings of urban redevelopment corporations. 
    The redevelopment plan may, upon approval of the board, contain provisions that the surplus earnings provided under section 22A-25: 
(a)  May be held by the urban redevelopment corporation as a reserve for maintenance of such rate of return in the future and may be used by such corporation to offset any deficiency in such rate of return which may have occurred in prior years; or 
(b)  May be used to accelerate the amortization payments; or 
(c)  May be used for the enlargement of the project; or 
(d)  May be used for reduction in rentals therein; 
provided, that at the termination of the tax relief granted pursuant to section 22A-27, the urban redevelopment corporation shall make a strict accounting of surplus earnings and shall turn over to the city any excess of such surplus earnings not previously used as provided in subsections (a), (b), (c) or (d) of this section. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Sec. 22A-27. - Tax abatement. 
(a)  First ten years. Real property acquired by an urban redevelopment corporation pursuant a redevelopment plan approved in accordance with this chapter shall not be subject to assessment of payment of general ad valorem taxes for a period of up to ten (10) years after the date upon which such corporation became owner of such real property, except to such extent and in such amount as may be imposed upon such real property during such period measured solely by the amount of the assessed valuation of the land, exclusive of improvements, acquired pursuant to this chapter and owned by such corporation, as was determined by the Assessor of Jackson County, for taxes due and payable thereon during the calendar year preceding the calendar year during which such corporation acquired title to such real property; and the amounts of such tax assessments shall not be increased by the county during such ten-year period so long as the real property is owned by an urban redevelopment corporation, subject to the authority granted in RSMo § 353.150.4, and used in accordance with a redevelopment plan authorized by the board. 
(b)  Following fifteen years. For the next ensuing period of up to fifteen (15) years, ad valorem taxes upon such real property shall be measured by the assessed valuation thereof as determined by the county upon the basis of up to fifty (50) per cent of the true value of such real property, including any improvements thereon, nor shall such valuations be increased over fifty (50) per cent of the true value of such real property from year to year during the period of fifteen (15) years, so long as such real property is owned by an urban redevelopment corporation, subject to the authority granted in RSMo § 353.150.4, and used in accordance with an authorized redevelopment plan. 
(c)  Property already exempt. In the event, however, that any such real property was tax exempt immediately prior to ownership by any such corporation, the commission shall immediately request the county assessor to promptly assess such land, exclusive of improvements, in accordance with the provisions of RSMo § 353.110. The amount of such assessed valuation so fixed by the county assessor shall not be increased by the county assessor during the up to ten-year period next following the date upon which such corporation acquired ownership thereof, so long as such property is owned by such corporation and used in accordance with the redevelopment plan authorized and approved by the board. 
(d)  Full assessment. After such periods, totaling not more than twenty-five (25) years, such real property shall be subject to assessment by the county assessor and payment of all ad valorem taxes based on the full true value of the real property, and shall be owned and operated by the urban redevelopment corporation free from the conditions, restrictions and provisions of this chapter, the approving ordinance and any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this chapter; provided that at any time after the completion of the redevelopment project as authorized by ordinance, the urban redevelopment corporation may elect to pay the city a sum equivalent to the amount of the general ad valorem taxes, not including interest or penalties, which would have been levied on the full value of the property from the date of the completion of the project; and from that date such real property shall be owned and operated by the urban redevelopment corporation free from the conditions, restrictions and provisions of this chapter, the approving ordinance and any rule or regulation adopted pursuant to this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 6467, § 2, 6-14-11) 
Chapter 23 - REFUSE, GARBAGE AND WEEDS[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- City health officer, §§ 2-26, 2-27; nuisances generally, Ch. 16; keeping of decayed meat or vegetables, refuse, etc., on private premises, § 16-6. Prohibition against throwing substances injurious to pavement, § 26-5; refuse handling in mobile home parks, §§ 29-47-29-52; requirement that mobile home parks be free from accumulations of debris, § 29-54. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Sec. 23-1. - "Litter" defined. 
    For the purpose of this chapter, "litter" shall mean all ashes, cinders, slops, filth, excrement, boards, sawdust, wood or metal shavings, rubber, old tires, stones, rocks, sand, oil, coal oil, gasoline, paint, dirt, dust, straw, soot, sticks, lumber scraps, boxes, barrels, kegs, crates, cans, bottles, cartons, paper, trash, leavings, sweepings, rubbish, refuse, debris, slag, garbage, manure, offal, putrid fish, meat, entrails, decayed fruits or vegetables, waste water, animal or vegetable products or matter, broken ware, broken glass, rags, bones, old iron, tacks, nails, wire or other metal, grass, leaves, weeds, foliage or shrub cuttings or clippings, old wearing apparel, all dead animals or any other offensive or disagreeable substance or thing thrown, cast, dropped, blown, spilled, poured, discharged, swept, let or deposited by anyone in or upon any curb, gutter, street, alley, boulevard, highway, right-of-way, viaduct, tunnel, sidewalk, park, parkway, public square, public building, lot, vacant or occupied, vacant building or pond, stream or pool of water. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 1) 
Sec. 23-2. - Littering prohibited generally. 
    No person shall sweep, throw, cast or otherwise place or deposit litter, or direct, suffer or permit any servant, employee, agent or other person under his control to sweep, throw, cast or otherwise place or deposit litter of any kind whatsoever, in or upon any curb, gutter, street, alley, boulevard, highway, right of way, viaduct, tunnel, sidewalk, park, parkway, public square, public building, lot, vacant or occupied, vacant building or pond, stream or pool of water. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 2) 
Sec. 23-3. - Littering from vehicles prohibited. 
    No person, within any vehicle, shall throw, cast, place, drop, spill or in any manner deposit or permit to be deposited any litter, or any other offensive or disagreeable substance or thing in or upon any street, sidewalk, boulevard, highway, right of way, park or parkway or public place, or on private property without the owner's consent. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 7) 
Sec. 23-4. - Dumping trash, etc., on city property prohibited; posting of signs. 
    It shall be unlawful for anyone to willfully place, dump or deposit trash, debris, garbage or any foreign matter on city property. 
    Appropriate signs shall be posted on city property. 
(Ord. No. 763, §§ 1, 3) 
Sec. 23-5. - Property owners to keep adjacent sidewalks, gutters, etc., free from litter. 
    It shall be the duty of all persons owning or occupying any real property fronting upon any street, boulevard, or highway, to keep the sidewalk, curbing and guttering in front and alongside of such property and on the same side of the street, in good order, and to clean the same, and to remove from any such sidewalk, curbing and guttering all earth or litter that in any way obstructs or renders the same dangerous, inconvenient or annoying to any person. Such owners or occupants are prohibited from sweeping or otherwise moving litter from sidewalks into the gutters and streets. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 3) 
Sec. 23-6. - Permitting rubbish or litter to blow or wash from abutting land to streets, sidewalks, etc., prohibited. 
    No owner, occupant or agent of any land abutting upon any sidewalk, street, alley, boulevard, park or parkway of the city shall allow the earth or any rubbish or litter from such land to fall, blow or wash upon any part of the sidewalk, street, alley, boulevard, park or parkway. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 5) 
Sec. 23-7. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former § 23-7, pertaining to illegal dumping, has been deleted as being superseded by Ord. No. 2478, adopted Oct. 11, 1977, codified herein as Art. IV, § 23-28 et seq., of Ch. 23. Former § 23-7 was derived from Ord. No. 888, § 8. 
Sec. 23-8. - Vacant property to be kept clean. 
    It shall be the duty of every owner, lessee, agent or other person having control, charge, authority or management over vacant property to keep the same free and clear of any and all litter of every kind and description. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 9) 
Sec. 23-9. - Abatement procedure. 
(a)  Notice to abate nuisance; hearing. Whenever the director of community development or his representative shall determine that litter of any kind or description has been allowed to stand or accumulate upon any lot of land within the city, the director of community development shall give a hearing after five (5) days' written notice thereof, delivered either personally or by United States Mail to the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, agent or other persons having an interest in said premises, or by posting such notice on the premises. At such hearing, evidence of the litter which is deemed to constitute a nuisance shall be presented. Thereupon, the director of community development may declare such litter to be a nuisance and order abatement of same by removal to begin within ten (10) days. 
(b)  Abatement; special assessment and personal debt. In case removal of the litter is not begun within ten (10) days, the director of community development or his representative shall enter in or upon such premises and remove the litter and shall certify the notice to abate the nuisance and the actual costs of same (including amounts billed to the city by private contractors, if any) plus an administrative fee of eighty-five dollars ($85.00) to the finance director, who shall cause a bill to be prepared, filed and collected. If the bill is unpaid, the finance director shall have the option of adding said certified costs to the annual real estate tax bill or creating a special tax bill in a manner so as to be a first lien on such property from the date the tax bill is delinquent until paid. Such tax bill, if not paid within thirty (30) days of its issuance shall bear interest at the rate of eight (8) per cent per annum. The tax bill from the date of its issuance shall also be deemed a personal debt against the owner. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 10, Ord. No. 5019, § 2, 10-14-97; Ord. No. 5187, § 12, 7-13-99; Ord. No. 5348, § 2, 2-13-01; Ord. No. 5720, § 2, 12-23-03; Ord. No. 6173, § 2, 2-26-08; Ord. No. 6718, § 2, 9-9-14; Ord. No. 6913, §§ 6, 7, 8-23-16) 
Secs. 23-10, 23-11. - Reserved. 
Editor's note- Former §§ 23-10, 23-11, pertaining to the hauling of refuse and trash over streets and to placement of trash, litter or rubbish on private property, have been deleted as being superseded by Ord. No. 2478, adopted Oct. 11, 1977, codified herein as Art. IV, § 23-28 et seq. of Ch. 23. Former §§ 23-10, 23-11, were derived from Ord. No. 888, §§ 11, 12. 
Sec. 23-12. - Hauling or dumping of earth or rock. 
    The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the hauling or dumping of earth and rock material from grading or excavation activities, provided that any such material shall be conveyed in tight wagons, trucks or other receptacles so that none of the contents thereof shall spill upon the streets. 
(Ord. No. 888, § 13) 
Sec. 23-12.1. - Penalty. 
(a)  Any person or persons violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and, upon conviction and after the court, subsequent to each conviction, has examined any prior conviction record to determine if the person has previously been convicted of the same offense within a twelve (12) month period beginning with the first violation, shall be sentenced by the court according to the following schedule of fines with reference to initial or subsequent violation of the particular section within said twelve (12) month period: 
(1)  First violation ..... $200.00 including court costs 
(2)  Second violation ..... 275.00 including court costs 
(3)  Third violation ..... 350.00 including court costs 
(4)  Fourth and subsequent violations ..... 450.00 including court costs 
(b)  Each day on which litter is permitted to remain on any premises, after the duty of the owner arises hereunder to remove such litter, shall constitute a separate offense, for which the owner thereof may be arrested, tried, convicted, and punished separately, without the necessity of further notices. 
(Ord. No. 5194, § 2, 8-10-99; Ord. No. 6913, § 12, 8-23-16) 
ARTICLE II. - DAMAGED, DISABLED, ETC., VEHICLES OR JUNK 

Sec. 23-13. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Damaged or disabled vehicles. A damaged or disabled vehicle is any vehicle which has been inoperable for more than seventy-two (72) hours or is in such a state of repair as to be mechanically inoperable, except those vehicles on the premises of a duly licensed automobile repair shop, sales business, duly licensed tow lot, or duly licensed storage lot. 
    Enclosed area. Any area which is inaccessible to the public view. 
    Junk. Any metal, glass, paper, rags, wood, machinery parts, cloth or other waste or discarded material of any nature or substance whatsoever, or any scrap or salvage materials. 
    Operable vehicle. A vehicle which is mechanically capable of being operated in its customary manner. 
    Property. Any real property within the city or any city property within or without the corporate limits which is not a street or highway. 
    Street or highway. The entire width, paved and unpaved, of every publicly maintained way when any part is open to the public for vehicular travel. 
    Unlicensed vehicle. A vehicle which is not currently licensed and/or registered as required for that type of vehicle. Such licensing and/or registration may be required by federal, state or municipal statutes, ordinances or regulations in order to permit the normal operation of said vehicle. 
    Vehicles. A machine propelled by power other than human power, designed to travel along the ground by use of wheels, treads, runners or slides and transport persons or property or pull machinery and shall include, without limitations, automobile, truck trailer, motorcycle, tractor, buggy and wagon, or any part or portion thereof. 
(Ord. No. 1341, § 1; Ord. No. 2944, § 1, 10-13-81; Ord. No. 3752, § 1, 6-14-88) 
Sec. 23-14. - Declared public nuisance. 
    Any wrecked, damaged, demolished, disabled or unlicensed vehicle, or part or portion thereof or junk which is left or permitted to remain upon any property or street, including but not limited to vehicles parked or stored in violation of Code section 31-22(F), is hereby declared to be a public nuisance unless such vehicle is in a completely enclosed building, in that such vehicle, or part or portion thereof or junk may create a fire hazard or afford a nesting place, harborage place or breeding place for mosquitos, flies, rodents, rats and other vermin, and also may be an attractive nuisance to children, constitutes a serious danger and threat to such children, and may be an additional costly obstruction to the care and maintenance of such property, or streets, when weeds, grass or other vegetation must be removed by private individuals or the city. 
(Ord. No. 1341, § 2; Ord. No. 3752, § 2, 6-14-88; Ord. No. 5151, § 2, 1-26-99) 
Sec. 23-15. - Leaving within city prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person to leave or permit to remain anywhere within the city any vehicle or junk which constitutes a public nuisance as defined in section 23-14. 
(Ord. No. 1341, § 3) 
Sec. 23-16. - Abatement procedure. 
(a)  Notice to abate nuisance by removing vehicles or junk; hearing. Whenever the director of community development or his representative shall determine that any vehicle or junk is a nuisance as defined in this article, the director of community development shall give a hearing after five (5) days' notice thereof, either personally or by United States Mail, to the owner, occupant, lessee, mortgagee, agent, or other persons having an interest in the property where such vehicle or junk is located. At such hearing, some evidence of the vehicle or junk which is deemed to constitute a nuisance as defined in this article shall be presented. Thereupon, the director of community development may declare that such vehicle or junk constitutes a nuisance as defined in this article and order abatement of the nuisance by removal from the property on which such vehicle or junk is located to another location so that this or any other ordinance of the City of Grandview is not violated, such removal to begin within ten (10) days. Should the required removal be made to another premises in the City of Grandview in such a way that this or another ordinance is violated, no further notice to anyone is required before the abatement procedure set forth in Code section 23-16(b) can be commenced. 
(b)  Abatement; special assessment and personal debt.
