(a)  Oversizing of streets. 
(1)  Where a designated street, according to the city's thoroughfare plan, runs through the proposed subdivision, the subdivider shall be responsible for the construction of such a street to a collector street standard. 
(2)  If the designated street exceeds the collector standard, the subdivider shall be required to construct the designated street subject to reimbursement by the city of the construction cost of the difference between the collector street and arterial street. Should reimbursement funds by the city not be available, the subdividers responsibility for construction shall be limited to a collector standard; however, the design shall be modified to facilitate future expansion of such street. Any required improvements deleted by the director of community development in order to facilitate the future street expansion shall not relieve the responsibility of the subdivider for such improvements. The cost of such deleted improvements shall be paid to the city. Such monies received shall be deposited in a street construction fund, which may be expended by the board of aldermen for the purpose of construction of arterial and collector streets within the city. Should the subdivider make such payments, he shall be relieved of any obligation for the completion of such deleted improvements. 
(b)  Oversizing sanitary sewer system. The subdivider shall be required to provide sanitary sewer systems with adequate capacity to serve the subdivision. Sewer systems shall be extended to the boundaries of the subdivision when required to facilitate future extension of such systems. When oversizing of a sewer main in excess of the design standards of these regulations is required by the board of aldermen to facilitate community usage, the city shall reimburse the construction cost of the oversize to the subdivider upon completion and acceptance of such improvement subject to terms agreed upon by the subdivider and the board of aldermen. 
(Ord. No. 5630, § 2, 6-10-03) 
Sec. 27-72. - Resubdivision; public improvements. 
    Any lands resubdivided after passage of this chapter shall be subject to the provisions of this section. Any payment in lieu of installation previously paid on same lands will receive credit; however, in no instance will fees by the city be returned or refunded to subdividers. 
(Ord. No. 5630, § 2, 6-10-03) 
Sec. 27-73. - Easements required. 
(a)  Public utilities. Where alleys are not provided, or where otherwise required by the present or future placement of public utilities, easements of not less than ten (10) feet in width shall be granted by the owner along rear or side lot lines for public utilities. Except where prohibited by topography, such easements shall be centered on lot lines. Easements of greater width may be required along lot lines, or across lots when necessary for the placement and maintenance of utilities. No buildings or structures, except as necessary for utilities, shall be permitted on such easements. 
(b)  Public areas. Public access easements shall be required where necessary to provide access to dedicated or private open spaces provided with the platting of the subdivision. 
(Ord. No. 5630, § 2, 6-10-03) 
Sec. 27-74. - Inspections. 
(a)  Construction shall not commence on any of the improvements required by these regulations prior to granting of a public improvement permit. All plans shall have been approved by the director of public works prior to issuance of a public improvements permit. 
(b)  All public improvements required by these regulations shall be inspected and approved by the director of public works as such improvements are being installed. The subdivider shall secure inspection services of the city prior to the commencement of construction of any such improvement. 
(c)  All construction shall conform to the public improvements manual of the City of Grandview. If not specifically set forth in that manual, construction shall conform with the Kansas City Metropolitan Chapter of the American Public Works Association Specifications. 
(Ord. No. 5630, § 2, 6-10-03) 
Sec. 27-75. - Conditions of acceptance; as-built plans and guarantees. 
(a)  Prior to the acceptance of any public improvements by the city, the subdividers engineer or surveyor shall prepare and certify the "as-built" plans for the improvements. A copy shall be provided to the director of public works for review and approval by the city prior to acceptance of any improvement. 
(b)  The subdivider shall provide the city a two-year maintenance guarantee of the municipal improvements, which shall commence at the time of acceptance in writing of such improvements. The guarantee shall be in the form of a maintenance guarantee acceptable to the director of public works. In no case shall the performance bond be released until all public improvements have been accepted by the city. The two-year guarantee shall ensure any repairs or replacement of the improvements found to be necessary by the director of public works. 
(c)  Upon completion of all improvements required by these regulations, the subdivider shall make written request to the city for final inspection and acceptance of such improvements. Within thirty (30) days, the director of public works shall give notice to the subdivider of the municipal improvements acceptance or a deficiency list preventing such acceptance. Upon acceptance of such subdivision improvements, the two-year warranty period shall commence. No partial acceptance shall be considered unless a phased development plan of the subdivision has been approved by the board of aldermen as a part of the plat approval process. 
(Ord. No. 5630, § 2, 6-10-03) 
Chapter 27A - SWIMMING POOLS (MUNICIPAL)[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Swimming pool construction, § 6-40 et seq. 

Sec. 27A-1. - Operation and use generally. 
    The municipal swimming pools of the city shall be opened to the public as herein limited at all proper and seasonable times subject to such rules and regulations herein contained and as the governing body of said city may from time to time adopt or authorize and as provided by the rules and regulations of the Missouri State Board of Health. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 1) 
Sec. 27A-2. - Manager and employees-Appointment; duties generally. 
    The city administrator shall appoint a pool manager and other employees of said swimming pool who shall work under the direction of the director of parks and recreation. Said pool manager shall have general supervision over said swimming pool and over all people attending the same, and the park area in which the same is located. It shall be his duty to preserve order, to enforce all provisions of this chapter and the rules and regulations of said city and the Missouri State Board of Health; and said manager may exclude any person or persons from said pool and its grounds for the violation of this chapter, [or] such rules and regulations as may be made by the city or the Missouri State Board of Health, or when the director of parks and recreation deems such exclusion to be in the best interest of the orderly and peaceable operation and management of the pool. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 2) 
Sec. 27A-3. - Same-Duty and authority to maintain order, keep public peace. 
    It shall be the duty of the pool manager and/or the assistant pool manager of the city's swimming pools, or any police officer of this city, to maintain order and keep the public peace within the city parks and swimming pools of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 3) 
Sec. 27A-4. - Adoption, posting of rules and regulations. 
    The director of parks and recreation, by and with the consent of the parks and recreation commission, is hereby authorized to make and enforce such additional rules and regulations as may be necessary for the management and operation of the swimming pools consistent with the provisions of this chapter. Copies of all rules shall be posted in conspicuous places about the swimming pools as may be determined by the pool manager. The board of aldermen shall, by resolution, annually establish the schedule of operation, pool fees and charges, and rules and regulations. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 10; Ord. No. 2763, 3-26-80) 
Editor's note- For purposes of classification, and at his discretion, the editor has renumbered former § 27A-10, as amended by Ord. No. 2763, adopted March 26, 1980, as a new § 27A-4. Further, in order to effect this reclassification, the editor has redesignated former §§ 27A-4-27A-9 as §§ 27A-5-27A-10. 
Sec. 27A-5. - Person using to be free from contagious diseases; certificate of health may be required. 
    It shall be unlawful and a violation of this chapter for any person or persons at any time to enter the water of said swimming pool who are afflicted with any venereal, infectious or contagious disease. The manager of said pool appointed as provided herein is hereby authorized, directed and empowered within his discretion to require from any person requesting permission to enter said swimming pool a certificate of health from a licensed doctor of medicine, dated within three (3) days of the date admission is sought, stating that said person applying for admission to said pool is free from any infectious or contagious disease which might endanger the health of other occupants of the pool. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 4) 
Note- See editor's note, § 27A-4. 
Sec. 27A-6. - When admittance may be refused. 
    The pool manager appointed as provided for herein is hereby authorized, directed and empowered to refuse admission to any person applying for admission to said pool who is known to be not of good moral character, intoxicated or under the influence of drugs or opiates, or any person having a skin disease, open sores or cuts. Said pool manager may, when he deems the same to be in the best interest of orderly operation and management of said pool, refuse admission to any person or persons whatsoever. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 5) 
Note- See editor's note, § 27A-4. 
Sec. 27A-7. - Pollution and contamination prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to throw in the waters of said pool any stones, debris, refuse or discard substances; it shall further be unlawful for any person in any manner willfully to pollute the waters of said pool. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 6) 
Note- See editor's note, § 27A-4. 
Sec. 27A-8. - Animals prohibited. 
    It shall be unlawful at all times for any person or persons to place in the waters of said swimming pool, or cause or to suffer any dogs or any animals of any kind to enter to be therein. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 7) 
Note- See editor's note, § 27A-4. 
Sec. 27A-9. - Pool hours; unlawful entrance. 
    The hours during which the swimming pool shall be open for use shall be determined by the city governing body and the pool manager [as provided in section 27A-4], and it shall be unlawful for any person or persons to enter the waters of said pool except when the manager or a lifeguard is in charge of the same and on duty. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 8) 
Note- See editor's note, § 27A-4. 
Sec. 27A-10. - Charges for use. 
    The charges for public use of the swimming pool shall be fixed by the city governing body. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 9) 
Note- See editor's note, § 27A-4. 
Sec. 27A-11. - Availability to residents and nonresidents; registration for use. 
    The facilities of said swimming pool shall be available to bona fide residents of the city and to nonresidents. The method of proof of residency shall be determined by the pool regulations. The charges for admission to the pool for residents and nonresidents shall be from time to time fixed by a board of aldermen's resolution [as provided in section 27A-4]. Registration for the use of the pool and for obtaining appropriate identification cards, patches, or other devices to gain admission to the pool, shall commence and be carried out pursuant to regulations promulgated by the office of the director of parks and recreation. In all instances the burden of proof shall be on the person or persons desiring admittance to said pool. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 11) 
Sec. 27A-12. - Limitation on number of persons admitted. 
    The pool manager of the city swimming pools shall have the authority to limit admittance into the city swimming pools whenever, in his opinion, the pool is so crowded as to make it unsafe for the safety of the people to permit them. The pool manager shall, in addition, have authority to designate pool areas which may or may not be used. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 12) 
Sec. 27A-13. - Revocation of swimming privileges. 
    It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to violate the lawful orders of the swimming pool manager and/or the assistant swimming pool manager within the swimming pool area of the city park, and any person or persons who violate such order or orders shall forfeit their rights to the swimming privileges of the pool, and the manager and/or assistant manager may pick up the swimming patch or card of the person or persons and suspend the use of the same. Any person or persons whose patch or card has been suspended under the provisions of this section may make application for its return through the city clerk's office, and the director of parks and recreation of the city shall, after investigation, affirm or overrule the suspension of the person or persons' swimming privileges. Any person aggrieved of the decision of the director of parks and recreation may appeal to the parks and recreation commission. 
(Ord. No. 2065, § 13) 
Sec. 27A-14. - Penalties for violations. 
    Any person or persons violating any of the provisions of this chapter declared to be unlawful shall, upon conviction, be adjudged guilty of a misdemeanor and shall be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than one hundred dollars ($100.00); provided that the penalties herein prescribed shall not affect the provision of section 27A-13. 
(Ord. No. 2761, § 14) 
Chapter 27B - TATTOO AND BODY PIERCING STUDIO REGULATIONS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Licenses, Ch. 13. 

Sec. 27B-1. - Definitions. 
    In this chapter, unless the context requires otherwise, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them by this section: 
    Body piercing. Puncturing the skin of a person by aid of needles or other instruments designed or used to puncture the skin for the purpose of inserting jewelry or other objects in or through the human body, except puncturing the external lobe of the human ear shall not be included in this definition. 
    Body piercing facility. Any room, or any part thereof, where body piercing is practiced or where the business of body piercing is conducted. 
    Certificate of inspection. The written approval from the director or an authorized representative, that said tattoo/body piercing establishment has been inspected and meets all of the terms of this chapter relating to physical facilities, equipment and layout for operation of such business. 
    Director. The director means the community development director or an authorized representative or designee. 
    Operator. An operator means any individual, firm, company, corporation, partnership, or association that owns or operates a tattoo/body piercing parlor and any individual who performs or practices the art of tattooing or body piercing on the person of another. 
    Permanent color technician and tattoo artist. This is a person who practices tattooing or permanent color technology, or both, pursuant to this chapter. 
    Permanent color technology. The process by which the skin is marked or colored by insertion of nontoxic dyes or pigments into or under the subcutaneous portion of the skin so as to form indelible marks for cosmetic or figurative purposes. 
    Tattoo, tattooed, tattooing. Any method of placing designs, letters, scrolls, figures, symbols or any other marks upon or under the subcutaneous portion of the skin of a human being with ink or any other substance resulting in the coloration of the skin by the aid of needles or any other instruments designed to touch or puncture the skin. 
    Tattoo/Body piercing studio. Any place where persons are tattooed or body pierced for consideration other than a licensed medical practitioner or where tattooing or body piercing is regularly conducted whether or not it is in exchange for compensation. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-2. - License required. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of operating a tattoo/body piercing parlor without first obtaining an occupation license to engage in such business from the city collector in accordance with the provisions or this chapter and Chapter 13 of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview. 
(b)  No person, including a permanent color technician, tattoo artist, or body piercer shall perform tattooing or body piercing, display a sign, or in any other way advertise or purport to be a permanent color technician, tattoo artist, or body piercer unless that person holds a valid occupation license issued by the city collector. 
(c)  The license must be displayed in a prominent place in the tattoo/body piercing studio. 
(d)  An occupation license must be renewed annually in accordance with Chapter 13 of the Grandview Code of Laws entitled, "Licenses". 
(e)  In the case of a conflict between the provisions of this chapter and Chapter 13, this chapter controls. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-3. - Requirements for tattoo studio licensing. 
(a)  The operator applying for a license to operate a tattoo/body piercing studio shall include the following information in their application: 
(1)  The name, address, date of birth for the responsible individual, and the full or legal name under which they will conduct business; if a corporation, its name, date, place of incorporation, address of its principal place of business, and the names of its principal officers together with their respective addresses and date of birth, and if a partnership, association, or unincorporated company, the names of the partners, owners, and the managing officer or employee and their business and residence address and date of birth of each person identified. 
(2)  Submit a list of persons to be employed and working at the business, including their names, addresses and date of birth. 
(3)  License history of other establishments operated by any person listed in subsection (a) as required by the director. 
(4)  Certificate of inspection by the director. 
(5)  Address of location of the proposed tattoo/body piercing studio. 
(b)  To be granted a license, each owner, managing officer, and employee must have not been convicted of a violation of the provisions of any law applicable to tattoo parlor/body piercing operations, and has not had a license for such operation revoked within the three years prior to submission of the applicant's application for a license under this chapter, must not be in arrears to the city for any back taxes, license fees or permit fees, court fines, or judgments, and must not have accepted directly or indirectly any loans, equipment, money, credit or property of any kind, except ordinary commercial credit as such term is defined in the Rules and Regulations of the Supervisor of Liquor Control of the State of Missouri. 
(c)  Prelicensing inspection, upon receipt of initial license application, shall be done to determine if the building and premises meet all health, fire, zoning, and building code requirements. 
(d)  The city collector may issue a license to the operator of a tattoo/body piercing parlor after determining that the tattoo/body piercing parlor is in conformance with applicable statutes, rules, and building, health, fire, and zoning codes. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-4. - Revocation of tattoo/body piercing studio licenses. 
(a)  Any license for the operation of a tattoo/body piercing studio may be revoked at any time for violations of this chapter by the director; providing, however, that such license may not be revoked by the director until the operator has been given an opportunity for a hearing before the director. 
(b)  Upon receipt of an application for a hearing the director shall forthwith notify the applicant of the date and place of the review. The director, after taking into account all of the facts, shall thereupon take such action as he or she deems appropriate including reinstatement, revocation, or suspension of the license. Appeal of the director's decision may be made to the board of aldermen as provided in Chapter 13 of the Grandview Code. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-5. - Tattoo/Body piercing studio application fee. 
    An application for an initial tattoo/body piercing studio license shall be accompanied by a fee in the amount of five hundred dollars ($500.00). Any change of ownership shall require a new application and license, with payment of fees therefor. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-6. - Tattoo/Body piercing studio license fee. 
(a)  The tattoo/body piercing studio license fee for engaging in the business of operating a tattoo/body piercing studio within the city shall be one hundred dollars ($100.00) per annum per permanent color technician, body piercing, and/or tattoo artist plus the actual cost involved in any reinspections deemed necessary due to multiple violations of this Code. The application must be updated annually and the applicant must meet the requirements of this chapter in order to be eligible for renewal. 
(b)  No person shall: 
(1)  Sell, barter, or offer to sell or barter a license; 
(2)  Purchase or procure by barter a license with intent to use it as evidence of the person's qualification to practice tattooing or body piercing; 
(3)  Alter materially a license with fraudulent intent; 
(4)  Use or attempt to use as a valid license a license which has been purchased, fraudulently obtained, counterfeited or materially altered; or 
(5)  Willfully make a false, material statement in an application for licensure or for renewal of a license. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-7. - Health and sanitary requirements during procedure. 
    Each person who operates a tattoo /body piercing studio shall comply with the following requirements and maintain written records of such, where indicated below, for inspection by the director so as to prevent or hinder the transfer of microorganisms from one person or place to another person or place. The tattoo/body piercing studio shall be maintained in a sanitary condition at all times. 
(a)  Before administering a tattoo, the patron must be advised that the tattoo should be considered permanent; that it can be removed only with a surgical procedure; that any effective removal may leave permanent scarring and disfigurement; that there is possible risk and dangers associated with the application of each tattoo including possibility of discomfort or pain, the risk of infection, and the possibility of an allergic reaction to the pigments or other materials used. A written cautionary notice to that effect shall be furnished to and signed by the patron and retained on file at the establishment. 
(b)  Inquiry shall be made, and a conformation report shall be completed and signed in front of a witness by all patrons testifying to their freedom from jaundice, hepatitis, the HIV/AIDS virus, and/or any other blood transmitted communicable disease prior to commencing a procedure of tattooing or body piercing. Confirmation reports shall be maintained by the licensee in accordance with section 27B-14. 
(c)  Written instructions approved by the director regarding the proper care of the tattooed or pierced skin as a precaution against infections shall be provided to each patron following the tattoo procedure. These instructions shall include: 
(1)  Limit exposure to sun and swimming for at least two (2) weeks; 
(2)  Proper cleansing of tattoo area; 
(3)  Application of healing cream or ointment; 
(4)  Bandaging of tattoo or pierced area for a minimum of six (6) hours; 
(5)  Information regarding who to contact at the tattoo parlor in case of concerns or questions; 
(6)  Instructions to client to seek a health care provider in the event of infection or allergic reaction, e.g. drainage, redness, swelling, fever, etc; 
(7)  Information regarding pain control, i.e., the use of acetaminophen or ibuprofen; 
(8)  Signature of client; 
(9)  Date; 
(10)  Witness (name and/or signature). 
(d)  The room in which tattooing or body piercing is done shall have an area of not less that fifty (50) square feet and shall have adequate lighting of at least fifty (50) foot candles of illumination and shall be properly ventilated. If fluorescent light bulbs are used to illuminate a work area, said bulbs shall be within a boxed in lighting fixture. The walls, floors and ceiling shall have impervious, smooth, and washable surfaces. A toilet shall be located in the establishment and shall be accessible to the public at all times when the tattooing establishment is open for business. Adequate and conveniently located lavatory or lavatories shall be supplied with hot and cold running water, germicidal soap and single-service towels, self-dehydrating hand sanitizing products, or other approved hand drying devices and refuse containers shall be provided. Such facilities shall be kept clean and in good repair. 
All tables and other equipment shall be constructed of easily cleanable material, shall be painted or finished in a light color, with a smooth washable finish, and shall be separated from the view of waiting customers or observers by a panel at least six (6) feet high or by a door. The entire premises and equipment shall be maintained in a clean, sanitary condition and in good repair. No carpeting shall be permitted and the rooms in which tattooing or body piercing are performed shall be cleaned daily with a disinfectant. 
(e)  Barrier film should be placed over the tattoo artist work area wherever there is a possibility of cross contamination. Barrier film must be disposed of after each use. Tables shall have a disposable covering and disposed of after each use. 
(f)  Neither the patron or operator shall consume or bring food or drink into the tattooing/body piercing area and shall not smoke or consume alcoholic beverages in the tattoo/body piercing studio during the procedure, or in the room(s) where the tattooing or body piercing takes place. 
(g)  If the operator will come into contact with the patron, fore arm sleeves shall be worn to protect the patron from direct contact. 
(h)  The operator must be free from communicable disease while administering tattoos or body piercing and present no pustular lesions or open wounds of the hands or arms. The operator shall also be required to show proof of at least yearly vaccination against hepatitis B. 
(i)  Immediately before administering a tattoo or body piercing, the operator must thoroughly wash his/her hands in hot water with and anti-bacterial soap, using a short-bristled brush for a period of time of no less than three (3) minutes and then dry the hands with individual, single-use towels. 
(j)  The operator shall wear clean and easily cleanable smock or disposable apron as well as single-service examination gloves while administering the tattoo or body piercing procedure. When a tattooing or body piercing session is interrupted or immediately after gloves are torn or perforated, gloves shall be removed and discarded and hands shall be washed in the same manner as noted above and a fresh pair of gloves used. 
(k)  The operator, while administering a tattoo or body piercing, shall wear an effective hair restraint, must have clean fingernails and shall in general pay particular attention to his/her personal hygiene. A beard guard or hair restraints shall be used where appropriate. 
(l)  The skin surrounding the area where the tattoo or body piercing is to be placed shall first be washed with a germicidal skin preparation and then shaved with a disposable blade. Following the preceding, the skin must be gently scrubbed with betadine or approved antibacterial solutions or other United States Department of Agriculture approved antiseptic products using a sterile gauze pad which shall be disposed of after use. 
(m)  No tattooing or body piercing shall be done on any skin surface that has rash, pimples, boils, infections or manifests any evidence of unhealthy conditions. 
(n)  No skin area shall be penetrated, abraded or treated with chemicals for the purpose of removing, camouflaging or altering any blemish, or birthmark. 
(o)  Only disposable razors may be used and shall be promptly disposed of after each use. No other type of razor may be used. 
(p)  Only petroleum jelly in collapsible metal or plastic tubes, or its equivalent, as approve by the director, shall be used on the area to be tattooed or pierced and it shall be applied with sterile gauze. The use of styptic pencils, alum blocks, or other solid styptics to check the flow of blood are prohibited. 
(q)  Single-service or individual containers of dye or ink shall be used for each patron and the container therefor shall be discarded immediately after completing work on a patron and any dye in which the needles were dipped shall not be used on another person. Excess dye or ink shall be removed from the skin with an individual sterile sponge or a disposable paper tissue which shall be used only on one (1) person and then immediately discarded. Any acetate tattoo stencils shall be single-service and shall be properly discarded after use. After completing work on any person, the tattooed or pierced area shall be washed with a sterile gauze saturated with a betadine afterwash and an A&D ointment or equivalent, shall be applied to the tattoo/body pierced area. A sterile gauze dressing shall then be applied and fastened to the tattoo area with adhesive tape. No petroleum-based dressings shall be applied to the tattooed area. 
(r)  All infections involving communicable diseases resulting from the practice of tattooing or body piercing shall be reported to the director by the person owning or operating the establishment as soon as it becomes known or suspected. 
(s)  No tattooing or body piercing shall be performed on a person whom the operator suspects is under the influence of alcohol or drugs. 
(t)  Each tattoo artist, permanent color technician, or body piercer shall have the education, training and experience, or any combination thereof to practice aseptic technique and the proper use of sterile equipment. All procedures shall be performed using aseptic and/or sterile technique. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-8. - Equipment, care of equipment, and equipment health monitoring. 
(a)  All clean and ready-to-use needles and instruments shall be kept in a closed glass or metal case or storage cabinet while not in use. Such cabinet shall be maintained in a sanitary manner at all times. Needles and tubes shall be individually sealed. 
(b)  A steam sterilizer (autoclave) shall be provided for sterilizing all needles and similar instruments before use on any customer, person or patron. Sterilization of equipment will be accomplished by exposure to live steam for at least thirty (30) minutes after the chamber of the autoclave has been evacuated of air at a minimum pressure of fifteen (15) pounds per square inch, temperature of two hundred fifty (250) degrees Fahrenheit. All autoclaves shall be cleaned daily and unasonics shall be cleaned with Benz All and a cleaning solution. Sterilized equipment shall be stored, wrapped, or covered in a manner which will ensure that it will remain sterile until used. Each batch of sterilized equipment shall be labeled with the date of the sterilization, and the initials or the person sterilizing. 
(c)  The needles and instruments required to be sterilized shall be so used, handled, and temporarily placed during tattooing or body piercing so that they will not be contaminated. Needles and barrels shall be kept in a dry heat with sterilization for no less than one (1) hour at 240 degrees Fahrenheit prior to application. 
(d)  Records shall be kept on permanent file showing that any hazardous waste was disposed of properly according to law by a certified waste disposal company. 
(e)  Spore tests shall be run at least monthly and permanent records of such inspections by a third party approved by the director shall be kept on file. 
(f)  If needles are made on the premises, the room in which they are made shall be well ventilated in order to meet the Occupational Safety Health Act requirements for harmful vapors. Needles made on the premises shall be cleaned in a unisonic, sterilized before packaging, and then sterilized after packaging. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-9. - Materials used. 
(a)  All pigments, dyes, colors, etc. used in tattooing or body piercing shall be sterile and free from bacteria, virus particles and noxious agents and substances, and the pigments, dyes and colors used from stock solutions for each customer or patron shall be placed in a single-service receptacle and such receptacle and remaining solution shall be discarded after use on each customer or patron. To avoid the possibility of cross-contamination, in the pouring of all pigments, dyes, colors, etc. from stock solutions, no part of the container of stock solution shall come into direct contact with the single service receptacle. Material data or safety sheets shall be maintained on all inks used in accordance with the records retention requirements of section 27B-14. 
(b)  All bandages and surgical dressings used in connection with the tattooing or body piercing of a person shall be sterile. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-10. - Certification of inspection. 
    An applicant for a license to operate a tattoo/body piercing parlor shall first obtain a certificate of inspection from the director or designee, indicating the establishment has been inspected and is in compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Said certificate of inspection is valid for only one year and therefore, a current certificate must be presented each year upon application for renewal of the license. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-11. - Inspections. 
    The director or designee may conduct periodic inspections of any tattoo/body piercing studio for the purpose of determining whether or not said establishment and the persons performing the art of tattooing and/or body piercing therein are in compliance with all applicable health provisions contained within this chapter and other pertinent ordinances. It shall be unlawful for any person or operator of a tattoo/body piercing studio to willfully prevent or restrain the director or designee from entering any licensed establishment where tattooing or body piercing is being performed for the purpose of inspecting said premises, after proper identification is presented to the operator. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-12. - Minors. 
    No tattoo or body piercing may be administered to any person less than eighteen (18) years of age. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-13. - Authority to issue citations. 
    The director, or any authorized representative, is authorized to issue and serve complaints, general ordinance summons and citations on persons charged with violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-14. - Records. 
    Permanent records for each patron or customer shall be maintained by the licensee or operator of the establishment. Before the tattooing or body piercing operation begins, the patron or customer shall be required personally to enter, on a record form provided for such establishments, the date, his or her name, address, age, serial number if a member of the armed forces, and his or her signature. Such records shall be maintained in the tattoo/body piercing studio and shall be available for examination by the Director. Records shall be retained by the operator or licensee for a period of not less than three (3) years. In the event of a change of ownership or closing of the business, all such records shall be made available to the director. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Sec. 27B-15. - Penalty. 
    In addition to the revocation and suspension of any license, any person violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined not less than one hundred dollars ($100.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each offense, imprisoned for a period of up to ninety (90) days, or both, fine and imprisonment. A separate offense shall be deemed committed on each day during or on which a violation occurs or continues. 
(Ord. No. 5258, § 1(Exh. 1), 3-28-00) 
Chapter 28 - TAXICABS AND OTHER VEHICLES FOR HIRE[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Editor's note- Section 1 of Ordinance No. 4929, adopted November 26, 1996, repealed Chapter 28 in its entirety. Formerly, said chapter pertained to taxicabs and other vehicles for hire, and derived from §§ 2-18 of Ord. No. 2661, adopted May 22, 1979. Sections 2-18 of Ord. No. 4929, adopted November 26, 1996, did not specifically amend this Code; hence; inclusion of §§ 2-18 as §§ 28-1-28-17 herein was at the editor's discretion. 

Sec. 28-1. - Definitions. 
    For the purposes of this article, the following words and phrases shall have the meanings respectively ascribed to them: 
    Taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business means any business, whether sole proprietorship, partnership or corporation, which operates taxicabs, limousines or other vehicles of any kind, character or description which are being used as a taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire engaged as such in the carriage of passengers on the streets of Grandview. 
    Resident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business means a resident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business shall be any taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business with its principal place of business located within the city limits of Grandview, Missouri. 
    Nonresident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business means any taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business which does not have a principal place of business located within the city limits of Grandview, Missouri, which is licensed by or has a current taxicab permit pursuant to the ordinances or regulations of another municipal corporation. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 2, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-2. - Applicability. 
    The provisions of this ordinance shall apply to all taxicab, limousine, and vehicles for hire businesses as defined herein. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 3, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-3. - Permit required. 
    No taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire shall be operated on the streets of the city by any taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business until a permit therefor has been obtained except that any non-resident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business shall be entitled to pick up and deliver fares within the city without obtaining such a permit. Such required permit shall be in addition to any occupational license required by other ordinances of the city. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 4, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-4. - Permit application. 
    Any person desiring to operate a resident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business in the city or any person operating such a business which does not meet the definition of a nonresident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business and which intends to pick up and deliver fares in the city shall make written application for a permit, and such application shall be verified under oath and shall set forth: 
(1)  A full identification of the applicant and all persons to be directly or indirectly interested in the permit, if granted; 
(2)  The citizenship and residence and business address of the applicant, and of all partners in a partnership, and of all officers and directors of any corporation applying; 
(3)  Whether or not the business will be operated from a private residence; 
(4)  If the business will be operated from a private residence, whether the driver(s) resides at the residence; 
(5)  Names and addresses of the driver(s); 
(6)  Whether the applicant or any person with whom he has been associated or employed, or any person the applicant intends to employ, has unpaid claims or unsatisfied judgments against him for damages resulting from the negligent operation of a motor vehicle; 
(7)  The past experience, if any, the applicant has had in rendering taxicab service in other communities, and the period of time he has rendered such service; 
(8)  Whether any permit issued to him by any municipality has been revoked; 
(9)  The number of taxicabs, limousines, or vehicles for hire proposed to be operated; 
(10)  The amount of insurance covering each taxicab, limousine or vehicle for hire proposed for operation; 
(11)  The fees or rates to be charged for the hire of such taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 5, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-5. - Permit; issuance. 
    Upon satisfactory compliance with the application requirements and other provisions of this ordinance, and in such instances when it shall be deemed to be in the best interest of the citizens of Grandview, the board of aldermen shall approve such application for taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire permit and direct the city clerk to issue said permit, signed by the city administrator, as provided for herein. 
    Every taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire owner submitting an application for permit to operate such a business, following approval of the permit by the board of aldermen, shall notify the city clerk and chief of police or their designees of the name, home address, and other information as requested, of their drivers. Such notification shall be made prior to the permit being issued. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 6, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-5.1. - Investigation of applicants. 
(a)  City clerk investigation. The city clerk shall cause an immediate investigation to be made of the truthfulness of the statements contained in each new application for a permit as well as the character, background, and associates of the applicant and any indebtedness of the applicant to the city for unpaid taxes, fees or special assessments. The suitability of the location and surrounding conditions of the proposed business location shall also be investigated. 
(b)  Police investigation. Upon receipt of an application, the city clerk shall immediately request that the Grandview Police Department perform a criminal history record investigation of the applicant pursuant to Section 13-30 of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
(c)  Qualifications. No permit shall be issued or renewed if the investigation reveals the applicant has submitted a false application; is of bad moral character; has been convicted of or pled guilty to charges of driving while impaired or of any felony relating to the infliction of physical or emotional harm upon another person including, but not limited to, assault, battery, murder, robbery and sex crimes; has had a similar permit revoked by any state or local governmental entity; or is indebted to the city for any unpaid taxes, fees or special assessments. 
(d)  Annual investigations. Existing permit holders shall be subject to the same investigation contemplated by subsections (a), (b) and (c) of this section annually as a condition of renewal of said permit. 
(e)  Duty to cooperate. Failure of an applicant or permit holder to cooperate in an investigation contemplated by this section shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and shall constitute grounds for denial of an original application or nonrenewal of an existing permit. 
(Ord. No. 6334, § 1, 12-8-09; Ord. No. 6380, § 3, 6-22-10) 
Sec. 28-6. - Permits; transfers. 
(a)  No permit issued under this ordinance shall be transferred from one taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business to another. 
(b)  No permit issued under this ordinance shall be transferred from an address within the city to another address within the city without first having acquired the approval of the board of aldermen. The board shall consider such approval through a written request from the applicant, which shall be submitted to the city clerk. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 7, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-7. - Permits; revocation. 
(a)  Whenever it shall appear upon investigation and hearing by the board of aldermen that: 
(1)  A permit has been obtained by misrepresentation or fraud. 
(2)  A permit holder hereunder has knowingly violated any provision of this ordinance or any regulation properly issued by the city in the administration of this ordinance or is in violation of any state statutes, the permit shall thereupon be revoked by the board of aldermen. 
    Before a permit shall be revoked, however, the holder of the permit shall be given at least ten (10) days' notice of the place and time of a hearing before the board of aldermen, at which the holder of the permit shall have the right to appear and present evidence. 
(b)  The permit of any taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business shall be forthwith revoked by the city administrator whenever the city administrator shall have received a certificate from any court or the clerk thereof showing that such taxicab,limousine, or vehicle for hire business shall have failed to satisfy within thirty (30) days any final judgment, upon which execution has been lawfully issued against such taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business or damages on account of bodily injury, including death, or damaged property resulting from the ownership, maintenance, use or operation of a taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 8, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-8. - Permit; fees. 
(a)  No permit required by this ordinance shall be issued until there has been paid an annual permit fee in the amount of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) to the city collector. Said fee shall be due on July 1 of each year and shall not be prorated. 
(b)  No permit required by this ordinance shall be issued until there has been a driver identification fee in the amount of ten dollars ($10.00) paid to the chief of police or his designee. Said fee shall be due for each driver and shall expire July 1st of each year. Said fee shall not be prorated. 
(c)  Such permit fees shall be in addition to any occupational license fees for the operation of a resident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 9, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-9. - Insurance required. 
    It shall be unlawful to operate any taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business (except a nonresident taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business) nor shall any permit be issued hereunder until and unless the applicant for such permit, in addition to all other requirements in this ordinance, shall file and maintain with the city clerk for each taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire to be operated, either a bond or policy of liability insurance indemnifying the applicant in the sum of at least fifty thousand dollars ($50,000.00) for injury to or death of one (1) person by reason of negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire, and one hundred thousand dollars ($100,000.00) for injury to or death of more than one (1) person resulting from a single accident by reason of the negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire, and twenty-five thousand dollars ($25,000.00) for damage to property, including baggage or other property, of a passenger carried by said taxicab business, resulting from any single accident by reason of the negligence of the driver or operator of such taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire. The insurance coverage requirements provided above shall be in full force and effect beginning July 1, 1997. 
    Said policy shall further contain a clause obligating the insurance company to give twenty (20) days' written notice to the city administrator before cancellation of the policy, and the permit shall expire upon the lapse of said policy or certificate, or termination of the same by cancellation, unless within said twenty (20) days, in the case of notice of cancellation by the insurance company, the holder of the permit shall furnish another policy or bond acceptable to the city administrator. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 10, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-10. - Identification of taxicabs; display of driver's identification card and rate cards. 
(a)  Every taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire business which operates taxicabs within the city shall display a rate card stating all the elements of the schedule of fare charged by such taxicab. Such rate cards shall be visible to passengers at all times. 
(b)  Every taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire within the city shall have displayed within its interior the driver's identification, including a photograph of such driver, so as to be visible to passengers at all times. On forms provided by the city clerk, application for such identification shall be made in person before the chief of police or his designee. If in the opinion of the chief of police or his designee, the applicant is of good moral character, has not been convicted of a crime, an identification shall be issued for one (1) year. If during such one (1) year period the applicant is found guilty of a crime, a traffic citation or becomes a police character, the chief of police or his designee may revoke said identification. Following issuance of the identification or revocation thereof, copies of the application and identification or revocation thereof, shall be made available to the city clerk. The fee for said driver identification shall be ten dollars ($10.00). The fee for a duplicate/replacement identification shall be five dollars ($5.00). The fee shall not be prorated, and shall expire on June 30 each year. 
    Every taxicab. limousine, or vehicle for hire owner shall, prior to hiring a new driver during a license year, immediately inform the driver of the necessity for a driver's identification and the manner in which it is to be obtained. The owner of such a business shall notify the city clerk and chief of police or their designee of the newly hired driver by submitting the driver's name, home address, and other information as requested. Such notification shall be made within forty-eight (48) hours of the actual date of hire. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 11, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-11. - Receipt for fares. 
    The driver of every duly licensed taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire operated on the streets of this city, when requested by the passenger, shall give a numbered receipt showing the taxicab business' name, date and amount of fare charged. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 12, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-12. - Acceptance of additional passengers. 
    Whenever a taxicab, limousine or vehicle for hire, operating within the city is occupied by a passenger, the driver may not permit another person to occupy or ride in said taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire without a specific request originating from the original passenger. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 13, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-13. - Fares and charges. 
    Every vehicle providing the services of a taxicab shall be equipped with a single tariff taxi meter, which shall be in operation at all times when such vehicle is in transit carrying passengers. No taxicab, limousine or vehicle for hire shall charge more than the rates stated on the rate card required to be displayed within the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 14, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-14. - Limitation on number of passengers. 
    No driver of a taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire shall permit more passengers to be carried than the seating capacity of the vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 15, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-15. - Vehicles to be maintained in clean, serviceable condition. 
    Every taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire operated on the streets of the city shall be maintained in a clean and serviceable condition and in adequate repair. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 16, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-16. - Inspections. 
(a)  The chief of police, or his designee, shall have the power to conduct inspections of any taxicab, limousine, or vehicle for hire picking up and delivering fares within the city to determine, among other things, whether the vehicles are being maintained in a clean and serviceable condition, in adequate repair, and generally whether all other requirements and provisions of this ordinance, other ordinances of the city, and the statutes of this state have been met. 
(b)  The meters of any taxicab operated within the city are subject to inspection and test at any time by the chief of police, or his designee, and those not conforming to minimum requirements can be ordered out of service. Each taxicab business is responsible for the accuracy of meters installed in its taxicabs. The meter in each taxicab operated within the city shall be inspected and tested at regular intervals by the operator thereof to insure accuracy and a record shall be kept of each test and made available to the chief of police, or his designee, upon demand. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 17, 11-26-96) 
Sec. 28-17. - Penalties. 
    Any person who violates any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof shall be punished by a fine of not less than twenty-five dollars ($25.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00) for each such offense. 
(Ord. No. 4929, § 18, 11-26-96) 
Chapter 30 - TRANSIENT MERCHANTS AND ITINERANT VENDORS[1] 

Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Parking of peddler's or vendor's vehicle on streets regulated, § 14-92(b)-(d). 
State Law reference- Authority of city to regulate peddlers, see RSMo, § 94.270. 

Sec. 30-1. - "Peddler" defined. 
    The word "peddler," as used herein, shall include any person whether a resident of the city or not, traveling by foot, wagon, automotive vehicle, from house to house or from street to street, carrying or transporting goods, wares, products or provisions or any and all salable items, offering and exposing the same for sale or making sales and delivering articles to purchasers, or who without traveling from place to place shall sell or offer the same sale from a wagon, automotive vehicle, railroad car or other vehicle; provided, that one who solicits orders and as a separate transaction makes deliveries to purchasers as a part of a scheme or design to evade the provisions of this chapter shall be deemed a peddler subject to the provisions of this chapter. The word "peddler" shall include the words "hawker" and "huckster." 
(Ord. No. 838, § 1) 
Sec. 30-2. - Sales within one block of schools within certain time period prohibited. 
    Peddlers shall not make any sales within one block of a school on a school day from thirty minutes before school begins until thirty (30) minutes after adjournment. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 2) 
Sec. 30-3. - Children under sixteen prohibited in vending vehicles; exception. 
    No child under the age of sixteen (16) years, other than the licensed operator or his assistants, shall be allowed to be in or on a vending vehicle. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 3) 
Sec. 30-4. - Products to be dispensed from curb side of vehicle. 
    Products sold by peddlers shall be dispensed only from the curb side of the peddler's vehicle while stationary, if such vehicle is being operated on the streets of the city. 
(Ord. No. 838, § 4) 
Sec. 30-5. - Solicitation in and upon private residences prohibited without permit; regulation of solicitation. 
(a)  No person shall go in and upon private residences in the City of Grandview for the purpose of soliciting orders for the sale of goods, wares or merchandise, or for the purpose of delivering the same, without a permit from the city authorizing such solicitation. A notarized application for a permit to solicit shall be made in writing to the chief of police at least fifteen (15) days prior to the time at which the permit applied for shall become effective. The application shall contain the following information: 
(1)  The name, address and phone number of the person applying for the permit; 
(2)  If the applicant is employed by or will be representing another person, firm or corporation, partnership, or other entity when soliciting in the city, the name(s) and address(es) of each such other person or entity along with the name and telephone number of the person or of an officer or manager of each such entity who can verify that the applicant is authorized to solicit on behalf of such entity in the City of Grandview; 
(3)  A description of the products to be sold; 
(4)  A statement to the effect that if a permit is granted, it will not be used or represented in any way as an endorsement by the city or by any department, employee or officer thereof; 
(5)  The length of time for which a solicitation permit is desired; 
(6)  Two (2) photos of the applicant taken within sixty (60) days immediately prior to the date of filing of the application, such pictures to be two (2) inches by two (2) inches and showing the head and shoulders of the applicant; 
(7)  A statement as to whether or not the applicant has been convicted of any crime or misdemeanor, the nature of the offense, and the punishment assessed; and 
(8)  Such other information as may be reasonably required by the chief of police in order to determine the kind and character of the proposed solicitation and to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(b)  At the time of filing the application for a solicitation permit, the applicant shall pay a nonrefundable application fee of fifteen dollars ($15.00). 
(c)  The applicant shall be given a copy of this section of the Code of Laws of the City of Grandview upon filing the permit application and paying the application fee. The chief of police or his designee shall conduct such investigation of the applicant as it deems necessary to protect the health, safety and welfare of the public. 
(d)  After making an appropriate investigation, the chief of police shall either deny the application or approve it for a period of time consistent with both the application and the investigation. If issued, the fee for such permit will be ten dollars ($10.00) per day with a maximum of twenty-five dollars ($25.00) for up to one week; thirty dollars ($30.00) for any period from eight (8) days to one month; fifty dollars ($50.00) for any period up to six (6) months; or one hundred dollars ($100.00) for up to one year. Upon the payment of the permit fee, each person so approved by the chief of police shall receive a badge which shall be conspicuously displayed by such person at all times when soliciting in the city. The badge shall contain the name of the permit holder, his employer or principal, the permit number, the permit expiration date, a photo of the applicant, a statement that the permit does not constitute an endorsement by the city of the purpose of, or of the person conducting, the solicitation, and the words "LICENSED SOLICITOR" in letters easily discernable from a distance of ten (10) feet. 
(e)  Any permit issued under this section shall be nontransferable and shall be returned to the police department within seven (7) days of its date of expiration. 
(f)  Whenever it shall be shown, or whenever any city official has knowledge, that any person to whom a permit has been issued under this section has violated any of the provision of this section, or that any permit holder has misrepresented the purpose of the solicitation, or for other good cause shown, the police department may immediately revoke the permit and shall give the permit holder written notice of the same. It shall be unlawful for any permit holder to continue solicitation activities after receipt of such notice. No new permit shall be granted to any person found to have violated any provision of this section for a period of one year following the date of any such violation. 
(g)  The provisions of this section shall not apply to the sale, or soliciting of order for the sale of milk, dairy products, vegetables, poultry, eggs and other farm and garden products so far as the sale of the commodities named herein is now authorized by law, and shall not apply to solicitation by members of any local service, charitable or not-for-profit organizations, including schools, PTA's, churches, youth athletic organizations, and service organizations. 
(h)  No solicitation as defined above shall be permitted, with or without a permit, in and upon any private residence on which a notice is displayed by the owner or occupant of such residence bearing the words "No Solicitors" or words of similar import and also reciting the section number of this Code provision. Any violation of this provision shall be unlawful. For purposes of this section, a "No Solicitors" decal or sign issued by the police department and prominently displayed on the door shall constitute sufficient notice; however, other similar signs, as defined above, are also sufficient. 
(i)  Solicitation in and upon private residences in the City of Grandview as otherwise permitted by this section shall not be permitted prior to 9:00 a.m. or after one-half hour before sunset. Solicitation other than during permitted hours shall be unlawful. In addition, it shall be unlawful for any solicitor to engage in soliciting after having been asked by the owner or occupant to leave the premises or residence. 
(j)  No solicitor shall return to the same occupied private residence a second time after making initial contact with any person at such residence for a period of six (6) months unless previously authorized by an occupant or the owner of the residence at the time of the first call. 
(k)  It shall be unlawful for any solicitor to make any assertion, representation or statement which misrepresents the purpose of his/her call, or to use any plan, scheme or ruse which misrepresents such purpose. 
(l)  Any person who meets the provisions of this section shall not be required to obtain a separate license under Chapter 13 of this Code. 
(Ord. No. 1252, §§ 1, 3, 3-6-67; Ord. No. 4534, § 1, 10-26-93) 
Sec. 30-6. - Mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts. 
(a)  Intent of section . It is the purpose and intent of this Section 30-6 to provide regulations for the lawful operation of mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts within the City of Grandview, Missouri. 
(b)  Definitions. For the purposes of this section, the following words and phrases shall mean: 
    City: The City of Grandview, Missouri. 
    Director: The director of community development of the city or his designee. 
    Fire marshal: The director of the fire prevention bureau within the fire department. 
    Health department: The Health Department of Jackson County, Missouri. 
    Mobile food trailer: A self-contained unit that stores and prepares fresh food and drinks that attaches to and is pulled by a separate vehicle. 
    Mobile food truck: A vehicle, capable of being driven, that contains equipment to store and produce fresh food and drinks and permanently affixed to the vehicle frame. 
    Pushcart: A manually propelled mobile food trailer. 
(c)  Licensing requirements. 
a.  All operators of mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts shall apply for and obtain an occupational license from the finance department as required by chapter 13 of this Code before operating within the city. Failure to obtain an occupational license shall constitute a violation of this section and make the operator subject to the enforcement and penalties as provided for in chapter 13. 
b.  All operators of mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts shall apply for and obtain a sales tax identification number from the State of Missouri and shall remit all sales tax collected to the appropriate authorities. 
c.  All operators of mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts shall obtain all required permits and/or inspections from the fire marshal of the city. In lieu of permits and/or inspections from the city, the fire marshal will accept documentation of permits and/or inspections performed by any other fire department within the defined Kansas City metropolitan area in a reciprocal manner. 
d.  All operators of mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts shall obtain all required permits and/or inspections from the Jackson County, Missouri Health Department. In lieu of permits and/or inspections by the Jackson County, Missouri Health Department, the director will accept documentation of permits and/or inspections performed by the City of Kansas City, Missouri Health Department. 
(d)  Licensing and registration fees. 
a.  The provisions of chapter 13 of this Code notwithstanding, the occupational license fee for mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts, for both new and renewal applications, shall be twenty-five dollars ($25.00) without regard to annual gross receipts and shall be paid with the initial occupational license application or annual renewal. 
b.  Throughout the year, the city will be the sponsor and operator of certain community events. These events will include the participation of mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts and will, in most cases, take place on city-owned property. Each event will have a registration fee for participation. The registration fees for each event will be determined during the planning for each event. Mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts participating in a city-sponsored event will be exempt from the occupational license requirement. All other requirements, such as health department inspections and fire department inspections, listed in this section shall remain in full force and effect. 
(e)  Operating regulations. All mobile food trucks, mobile food trailers and pushcarts shall adhere to the following operating regulations, except when participating in a city-sponsored event or another privately sponsored event: 
a.  If the mobile food truck, mobile food trailer or pushcart is to be located on private property, the operator shall obtain written permission from the property owner prior to locating and operating. 
b.  If the mobile food truck, mobile food trailer or pushcart is to be located on public property or public right-of-way, it must be parked in such a manner that it complies with all other provisions of this Code which includes, but is not limited to, the following: 
i.  The mobile truck/trailer/pushcart is wholly contained within designated on-street and off-street parking spaces. Parking in accessible parking spaces is expressly prohibited. 
ii.  The mobile truck/trailer/pushcart must be attended at all times, whether serving food or not. 
iii.  The mobile food truck/trailer/pushcart shall not obstruct the flow or vehicular or pedestrian traffic. 
iv.  The mobile food truck/trailer/pushcart shall not block any street, alley, accessible parking space or loading zone. 
v.  The mobile food truck/trailer/pushcart shall operate only on paved surfaces. 
vi.  The mobile food truck/trailer/pushcart shall be allowed to operate between the hours of 6:30 a.m. and 9:00 p.m. 
c.  When a city-sponsored and operated event is occurring, any mobile food truck, mobile food trailer or pushcart that is not a part of said event, must locate their operation at least one thousand (1,000) feet away from the nearest participating mobile food truck, mobile food trailer or pushcart. 
(Ord. No. 7139, § 1, 3-12-19) 
Chapter 30A - WATER[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Swimming pool water supply, § 6-46 et seq.; foul liquids or substances discharged into ponds, pools, etc., prohibited, § 16-7; structures obstructing watercourses, § 16-10; plumbing, Ch. 19; regulation of discharges to public sewers, § 25-35 et seq.; water supply for mobile home park, § 29-37 et seq. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL 

Secs. 30A-1-30A-20. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE II. - WATER EMERGENCIES[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2795, §§ 1-3, adopted July 22, 1980, did not expressly amend this Code; hence, codification as Art. II of Ch. 30A, §§ 30A-21-30A-23, is at the discretion of the editor. 

Sec. 30A-21. - Declaration. 
(a)  Proclamation upon request of county district. The mayor is hereby authorized to declare and proclaim the existence of a water emergency, if he is so requested to do so by Jackson County Public Water Supply District No. 1, and if the district advises him that the water supply for residents of the city is then so critical that there is a reasonable likelihood that insufficient water, or ability to supply water, exists to maintain adequate service for fire protection and home consumption. 
(b)  Proclamation upon finding of emergency by mayor. If in the judgment of the mayor, such an emergency does exist, he may, by proclamation, declare such emergency and that the prohibitions and penalties of this article shall then be in effect. 
(c)  Contents of proclamation. Such proclamation shall state the date and time such state of emergency and the prohibitions of this article shall commence, and the time for which it shall continue, which may be until further proclamation by the mayor. 
(Ord. No. 2795, § 1, 7-22-80) 
Sec. 30A-22. - Certain uses of water prohibited. 
    During the time that the mayor has proclaimed the existence of a water emergency under the provisions of this article, no person within the city shall use water supplied by Jackson County Public Water Supply District No. 1 for any purpose which shall, by agreement between the mayor and the director of Jackson County Public Water Supply District No. 1, be determined to be detrimental to the common good. 
(Ord. No. 2795, § 2, 7-22-80) 
Sec. 30A-23. - Penalty for violations. 
    Any person who violates the provisions of this article shall, upon conviction, be fined not less than one dollar ($1.00) nor more than five hundred dollars ($500.00), and such costs as authorized by law. 
(Ord. No. 2795, § 3, 7-22-80)
